lead_paragraph: I know all you young whippersnappers don’t remember ancient history, but a long time ago, in a galaxy far, far away — well, actually, in 2011, and right here on planet Earth — oil and other commodity prices were rising, not falling. As a result, headline inflation was running fairly high. Some of us argued that core inflation was a much better guide to monetary policy, and the Fed agreed; but inflationistas were going wild, and in Europe the ECB decided, disastrously, to raise interest rates.

headline: O.S.U. Coach on Overcoming Suicide
abstract: Urban Meyer, the Ohio State football coach, said the team was extremely close and that that closeness would help the players after the death of defensive tackle Kosta Karageorge.
lead_paragraph: Urban Meyer, the Ohio State football coach, said the team was extremely close and that that closeness would help the players after the death of defensive tackle Kosta Karageorge.

headline: A Tiring Question Challenges Scientists
abstract: Scientists from around the world will compete to best answer the question “What is sleep?” in terms that a sixth grader could appreciate.
lead_paragraph: An occasional column on developments in what educators call STEM — for science, technology, engineering and math.

headline: Smooth Pivot on Immigration by the Deporter-in-Chief
abstract: In Chicago, the president acknowledged that large-scale deportations were a part of the problem.
lead_paragraph: When President Obama gave a speech last week in Chicago to promote his immigration action, I expected lots of cheers and self-congratulatory applause lines.

headline: Math That Pursues, Spins and Swarms
abstract: A new exhibit featuring dozens of glowing, motorized, interactive robots will teach people what it feels like to be Godzilla, and hopefully a little math, too.
lead_paragraph: Behind a black curtain in a downstairs corner of the National Museum of Mathematics in Manhattan (known as MoMath), a small group of mathematicians, designers and engineers was hard at work — laughing, shouting, clapping and having a blast, while being chased by robots.

headline: Oh, Go Ahead, Lick the Pages
abstract: Leading bakers down sugar-dusted paths, five books surprise and delight. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: Maida Heatter’s dessert cookbooks are so detailed in their instructions that she practically tells you when to stop sifting the flour so you can wipe off your glasses.

headline: No Need to Wrap: These Ideas Are Delivered Outside the Box
abstract: From team-embroidered skullcaps to full-body N.F.L. blankets to Premier League bras, the world of sports has you covered when it comes to holiday shopping.
lead_paragraph: From team-embroidered skullcaps to full-body N.F.L. blankets to Premier League bras, the world of sports has you covered when it comes to holiday shopping.

headline: Much-Discussed Views That Go Way Back
abstract: Avi Loeb has published more than 400 papers on the nature of early stars, galaxies, planets and black holes.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Among astrophysicists, Abraham Loeb is known for his creative and prolific attempts to understand the early universe.

headline: The Secret Life of Passwords: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Ian Urbina describes how he reported his Times Magazine story “The Secret Life of Passwords.”
lead_paragraph: Ian Urbina wrote an article about the secret life of passwords for the Nov. 23 Times Magazine. Interactive videos accompanied the piece, and The Times invited readers to share stories about their passwords. Here, Mr. Urbina provides a sense of the story behind the story.

headline: In Performance | Joy Behar
abstract: Ms. Behar recalls her Brooklyn childhood in this scene from “Me, My Mouth & I,” her solo autobiographical show that runs through Dec. 21 at the Cherry Lane Theater.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Behar recalls her Brooklyn childhood in this scene from “Me, My Mouth & I,” her solo autobiographical show that runs through Dec. 21 at the Cherry Lane Theater.

headline: Microsoft Buys Acompli, an Email Start-Up
abstract: Microsoft said it acquired Acompli, a young start-up that makes an email application for iOS and Android mobile devices, for about $200 million.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft once again is showing that it wants to meet mobile users where they are, not where the company hopes they will be one day.

headline: Barry McGee Designs a Beats Pill for NADA Miami Beach
abstract: For a special-edition version of the speaker available only at the fair, the iconic street artist created a design inspired by rolling papers.
lead_paragraph: Collaboration is built into the DNA of the personal-audio behemoth Beats by Dr. Dre, the purveyor of the ubiquitous over-ear headphones and the oblong, portable speaker known as the Beats Pill. The brand, which was sold to Apple this year for $3 billion, has worked with everyone from Nicki Minaj to Snarkitecture to Fendi and Alexander Wang. Beats has also featured designs by several iconic street artists, including Futura, Tristan Eaton and now Barry McGee. For this year’s NADA fair opening this Thursday in Miami, McGee has created a new, limited-edition Beats Pill, featuring one of McGee’s signature, melancholic cartoon characters smoking a joint.

headline: Patient Results, Risks Beyond Fertility, Tallying Up What We Eat
abstract: Letters to the editor and online comments.
lead_paragraph: Health Care

headline: Azul, Brazil Airline Started by JetBlue Founder, Files for I.P.O.
abstract: This year had been slow for Brazil’s capital markets, but the fall in petroleum prices is helping airline stocks worldwide.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil – The JetBlue founder David Neeleman is aiming to take another airline company public.

headline: First Draft Focus: A Red Ribbon on the White House
abstract: A large red ribbon was hung from the White House on Monday in honor of World AIDS Day.

headline: Report on Boeing 787 Dreamliner Battery Flaws Finds Lapses at Multiple Points
abstract: While stopping short of a firm conclusion, the regulators’ report suggested that manufacturing flaws could have introduced defects that led a battery cell to fail.
lead_paragraph: Flaws in manufacturing, insufficient testing and a poor understanding of an innovative battery all contributed to the grounding of Boeing’s 787 fleet last year after a fire in a jet at Boston’s airport and another incident in Japan, according to a report released Monday by regulators.

headline: Kathy Griffin Takes Over From Joan Rivers as ‘Fashion Police’ Host
abstract: The show will resume the day after the Golden Globes in January.
lead_paragraph: “Fashion Police,” the E! cable series that was all but built around Joan Rivers and her take-no-prisoners commentary on celebrity, design and red-carpet mishaps, is getting a new and equally outspoken host.

headline: The Modern Parent’s ABC: H Is for Harried
abstract: Frosting three dozen cupcakes for school while helping with a science project and answering your email? Welcome to the modern parent’s alphabet.
lead_paragraph: When Spencer Wilson, illustrator of “Q is for Quinoa, A Modern Parent’s ABC” joined Motherlode as our latest artist-in-residence, we asked you to nominate your favorite letters of the modern parent’s alphabet. From hundreds of possibilities, it was hard to pick a favorite, but Spencer and Q is for Quinoa author Joel Rickett chose H is for Harried:“Someone who is harried,” Spencer wrote to me, “is feeling the stress of being rushed, overworked or harassed. A harried parent might be exhausted but still have to make three dozen cupcakes for school and help with a science project whilst answering their email on their phone…”

headline: Robot Swarm
abstract: A robot exhibit at New York City’s Museum of Math shows how simple interactions lead to large-scale, organized behavior.
lead_paragraph: A robot exhibit at New York City’s Museum of Math shows how simple interactions lead to large-scale, organized behavior.

headline: Governor Cuomo Tries to Do Something About the Weather
abstract: He wants to spend $18.7 million to create a state weather service. But predicting the weather is more complicated than he seems to believe.
lead_paragraph: After the ferocious storm that unloaded more than seven feet of snow in Western New York, Gov. Andrew Cuomo at first blamed the National Weather Service for not giving his constituents enough warning. Then he talked up his $18.7 million plan to create a state weather service, which he promised would do the job a lot better than the folks around Washington.

headline: Homeland Security Chief Set to Defend Immigration Action
abstract: Jeh C. Johnson, the Homeland Security secretary, is prepared to defend the president’s decision to take executive action to overhaul the immigration system.
lead_paragraph: Jeh C. Johnson, the secretary of Homeland Security, is to tell a congressional committee on Tuesday that illegal immigrants who would be protected under President Obama’s new plan “are not priorities for removal,” according to prepared remarks released on Monday.

headline: The Secrets of our Genealogical Past
abstract: DNA analyses can reveal surprises about the emergence of our species and the political and social structures that dictate modern life.
lead_paragraph: DNA analyses can reveal surprises about the emergence of our species and the political and social structures that dictate modern life.

headline: The Virus Detectives
abstract: An old building in a shabby part of Cambridge, Mass., formerly a Budweiser distribution center, is now the world’s most powerful factory for analyzing genes from people and viruses.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — An old two-story brick building in a shabby part of town, formerly a distribution center for Budweiser beer, is now the world’s most powerful factory for analyzing genes from people and viruses.

headline: Learning Our Roots, Inside and Out
abstract: Genealogy can reveal secrets about all of us, at once: the emergence of our species, the political history of the world, and the origins of the social structures that dictate modern life.
lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, genealogy rested contentedly on the turf of hobbyists who enjoyed trolling dusty archives and filling pedigree charts. But over the past decade, because of the rise of digitized records and cheap DNA testing, the quaint pastime has turned into a lucrative commercial industry. Genealogy companies capitalize on consumers’ seemingly boundless curiosity about their personal origins. As the industry leader Ancestry.com implores on its home page: “Join us on a journey through the story of how you became, well, you.” What country did my great-great-grandparents come from? Were they rich? Adventurous? Powerful? How did they lead to me?

headline: Ask Well: Eating Fat to Boost Vitamin D and Calcium
abstract: A reader asks: Must you eat fat to absorb calcium and vitamin D?
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Republicans Try to Balance Immigration Action While Avoiding a Shutdown
abstract: House Republicans are reviewing a hybrid solution that combines elements of short-term and broader-based spending. Some refuse to rule out a shutdown.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans returning to Washington on Monday found themselves facing a treacherous 10 days as they try to balance their desire to fight President Obama’s executive action on immigration with the political imperative not to shut down the government.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Hong Kong and Elsewhere
abstract: Hong Kong and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Where a ‘Vampire’ Threat Hit Close to Home
abstract: A new study in the journal PLOS One indicates that it was locals, not immigrants, whose corpses were feared.
lead_paragraph: In 17th- and 18th-century Poland, the fear of vampires was so strong that some people were buried with sickles across their necks and rocks at their jaws to keep them from rising from the grave and attacking the living.

headline: Dec. 1, 2014 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Hong Kong, Paris, South Korea and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Hong Kong, Paris, South Korea and the United States.

headline: Cypress Semiconductor to Buy Spansion for $1.6 Billion
abstract: The deal gives the computer chip manufacturer a prominent maker of flash memory and other specialized products.
lead_paragraph: The computer chip manufacturer Cypress Semiconductor agreed on Monday to buy Spansion for about $1.6 billion in stock, giving the company a prominent maker of flash memory and other specialized products.

headline: When Everyday Noise Is Unbearable
abstract: Hyperacusis, or sound sensitivity, sometimes comes with excruciating ear pain, too. This poorly understood medical condition is just beginning to receive more serious attention.
lead_paragraph: Like many people, George Rue loved music.

headline: A Happy Holiday Week for Broadway
abstract: Sales were strong for Broadway shows during Thanksgiving week, adding up to $34.1 million for the 36 shows.
lead_paragraph: Broadway producers – especially at Disney – had much to be thankful for last week as ticket sales ballooned for many musicals and some plays through the holiday, the highest-grossing and best-attended Thanksgiving week yet for the industry. Broadway shows took in $34.1 million, an increase of $2.6 million over the record-setting Thanksgiving week in 2013, according to box office data released on Monday.

headline: A Low-Cost Alternative to Pricy Big Data on the Farm
abstract: The transformation of agriculture with information technology would seem like bad news for the little guy. The sensor-heavy machines cost more, and the data analysis requires specialized information. But there are lower-cost options.
lead_paragraph: Will big data kill the small farm or save it?

headline: 2014 Goals for Ebola Treatment May Not Be Met, U.N. Health Officials Say
abstract: A senior World Health Organization official for Ebola response said Monday that year-end goals of isolating and treating all patients and safely burying the dead would be major challenges.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The World Health Organization expressed doubt on Monday about achieving important United Nations benchmarks in battling Ebola, saying the year-end goals of isolating and treating all patients and safely burying all the dead would be major challenges.

headline: Giants Try to Ignore Speculation on Tom Coughlin
abstract: Coughlin, Eli Manning said, used part of a team meeting to urge players not to concern themselves with rumors about a coaching change or potential successors.
lead_paragraph: With the Giants having squandered a three-touchdown advantage in a 25-24 loss at Jacksonville on Sunday that stretched their losing streak to seven games and plunged their record to 3-9, their worst mark after 12 games since 1995, Coach Tom Coughlin acknowledged that his future might be in jeopardy.

headline: GlaxoSmithKline Leads In Getting Drugs to Poor
abstract: Early editions of the Access to Medicine Index focused on infectious and tropical diseases, but the list has been refined to include access to drugs to mental illnesses.
lead_paragraph: For the fourth time, GlaxoSmithKline has led all other pharmaceutical companies on an influential list ranking companies by how effectively they help the world’s poor get needed medicines.

headline: Q. and A.: James Leibold on Ethnic Policies in China
abstract: Mr. Leibold’s research focuses on the Chinese government’s policies toward ethnic minorities and their effects on people’s daily lives. He recently returned from a trip to the western region of Xinjiang,
lead_paragraph: James Leibold is a senior lecturer in politics and Asian studies at La Trobe University in Australia, and is currently based in Beijing. His research has focused on the Chinese government’s policies toward ethnic minorities and their effects on people’s daily lives. He recently returned from a trip to the western region of Xinjiang, the nominally autonomous homeland of China’s ethnic Uighurs, a mostly Sunni Muslim, Turkic-speaking people. In recent years, government restraints on cultural and religious expression have bred resentment in Xinjiang that has sometimes erupted in deadly violence.

headline: Diabetes in Midlife Tied to Memory Problems Late in Life
abstract: Researchers have found that people diagnosed with diabetes in their 50’s are significantly more likely than others to suffer mental decline by their 70’s.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have found that people diagnosed with diabetes in their 50’s are significantly more likely than others to suffer mental decline by their 70’s.

headline: Chief Justice Samples Eminem in Online Threats Case
abstract: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. quoted vivid lyrics in which the rapper appears to be threatening to drown his wife.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Supreme Court on Monday tried to puzzle out what threats may be prosecuted as crimes, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. cited an unlikely source: the rapper Eminem.

headline: Liars Bound for Heart of Dimness
abstract: Denis Johnson’s “The Laughing Monsters” reads like a mash-up of African novels by Conrad and Greene.
lead_paragraph: Denis Johnson’s characters live on the edge — of dissolution, disaster, death. They are the lost and the displaced, be it by war, addiction or spiritual despair. In his most powerful work, like “Jesus’ Son,” Mr. Johnson has extracted a harsh poetry from their unraveling lives, creating haunting, almost hallucinatory portraits of people groping for some glimpse of salvation. In his sprawling 2007 epic, “Tree of Smoke,” which won the National Book Award for fiction, he widened his canvas, forging a potent story about the American experience in Vietnam that reverberated with disquieting echoes of the American experience in Iraq.

headline: Gray Seals Are Eating Into Porpoise Population
abstract: Gray seals are a major predator of harbor porpoises, according to DNA analysis of porpoise bite wounds.
lead_paragraph: Gray seals are a major predator of harbor porpoises, according to DNA analysis of porpoise bite wounds. The seals probably wound the porpoises and then tear off large sections of blubber, researchers say. More than 1,000 autopsies of porpoises indicated that gray seals were involved 25 percent of the time.

headline: On the Heroin Beat: Dispatch from Staten Island
abstract: The reporters J. David Goodman and Michael Wilson described a suburban mother’s descent to a heroin addict whose home on Staten Island served as a drug-dealing center.
lead_paragraph: In an on Sunday article, “Heroin Takes Over a House, and Mom, on New York’s Staten Island,” David Goodman and Michael Wilson described 45-year-old Laurie Sperring’s descent from suburban mother to a heroin addict whose home on Wood Court on Staten Island served as a drug-dealing center.

headline: Part D for Drug Coverage — and Drudgery
abstract: Like doing our taxes, signing up for Medicare Part D, the insurance program for drug coverage, takes days out of our lives and leaves us sitting in a heap of papers with a splitting headache.
lead_paragraph: Death and taxes have always been twinned in cliché for their unavoidable awfulness. But death only happens to each of us once, not annually. Wouldn’t our annual encounter with the Internal Revenue Service be more aptly paired with the Medicare Part D open enrollment period, a yearly torture between mid-October and early December? Both take days out of our lives and leave us sitting in a heap of papers with a splitting headache and residual worry that we got something wrong and will wind up in jail or the poorhouse.

headline: Overcoming Injury, a Violinist Returns
abstract: The violinist Kyung Wha Chung, sidelined by injury for almost a decade, returns to the London concert stage on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Billed as “The Legend Returns,” with life-size posters on the London Underground, Kyung Wha Chung’s concert at the Southbank Center on Tuesday has been advertised as if it were a movie about a prizefighter’s comeback. “It wasn’t my idea,” she said, agreeing to put the whole thing down to record company hype.

headline: I Was My Own Trauma Unit
abstract: The victim of a cycling accident found that his body shielded him from much of the pain.
lead_paragraph: I don’t remember the moments before the accident, but I have a very keen memory of what happened just after.

headline: On the Designer Nili Lotan’s Website, a Trove of Thoughtful Gifts
abstract: Just in time for the holidays, the woman behind the label has curated a selection of vintage books, records, jewelry and other objects for sale online.
lead_paragraph: In the decade-plus since she established her eponymous fashion label, Nili Lotan has been dressing women in luxury staples, like her signature military jackets and oversized knits, that suggest a laid-back, effortlessly with-it lifestyle. Now, through a special sale beginning today on her web site, Lotan is further fleshing out this picture via a personally curated selection of one-off accouterments including vintage books and records and new and antique jewelry. “I found these pieces to be inspiring and intriguing,” says Lotan of the collection, highlights of which include a book of photographs from Tina Modotti, Bob Dylan’s “Hard Rain” album and a vintage 1940s brown alligator clutch. “This is not only an extension of my brand, but also my own holiday wish list.”

headline: Rio, Real Early
abstract: The Belmond Copacabana Palace in Rio de Janeiro is offering a sunrise picnic with sweeping views of the city.
lead_paragraph: Late risers may grumble at the pickup time for Belmond Copacabana Palace’s new sunrise picnic, but the views promise to be worth it.

headline: Democracy and Religion in Israel
abstract: Readers discuss a proposed bill declaring that Israel is a Jewish state.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Holiday Sales: The End of ‘Shop Till You Drop’?
abstract: Daniel Fink, a reader, explains why consumers are holding back.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How the Police Should Use Stop-and-Search Data
abstract: Marc Krupanski of the Open Society Justice Initiative writes that stop-and-search data “needs to be interpreted and used properly by the police.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Obama’s Immigration Plan
abstract: The biographer Meryle Secrest discusses some of the concerns underlying the immigration debate.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: New Wreaths for New York Public Library’s Lions
abstract: Patience and Fortitude will get redesigned holiday wreaths.
lead_paragraph: Who knew Christmas wreaths could be so complicated? First, in 2004, the garlands draped around the necks of the stone lions outside the New York Public Library’s Fifth Avenue flagship building were put on hiatus because it became clear that they contained metal and retained water, which could cause damage.

headline: Harvard Oil Divestment
abstract: Mark H. Alcott, a lawyer, writes that “the student-led effort to compel Harvard to sell its oil stocks is ineffectual at best, cynical at worst.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Twist on French Tradition, Bosses Take to Streets in Protest
abstract: Owners of small and midsize businesses demonstrated in Paris and Toulouse against what they said were constraints imposed by the Socialist government.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — They jammed the boulevards, blowing whistles, tossing firecrackers, wearing locks and chains around their necks, and shouting into megaphones: “Enough is enough!”

headline: Wu-Tang Clan and AC/DC Release Albums
abstract: New albums from Wu-Tang Clan and AC/DC show that these established groups are still in charge of their sounds.
lead_paragraph: WU-TANG CLAN

headline: The Dead at Franklin
abstract: In late 1864, John Bell Hood made a desperate, disastrous stab at Middle Tennessee.
lead_paragraph: In January 1865, Confederate Gen. John Bell Hood traveled to Columbia, S.C. with the diarist Mary Chesnut and the family of his recent but fading love interest, Sally “Buck” Preston. After some pleasantries, the houseguests discussed the recent, horrific battles at Franklin, Tenn. and Nashville, fought in quick succession in early December. Hood had been the Confederate leader in both battles, and both times had lost thousands in bitter defeat. “My army is destroyed,” he mourned.

headline: Verbatim: This Time Is Different
abstract: President Obama, after meeting with community leaders and law enforcement officials about the unrest in Ferguson, Mo., said he was deeply invested in making sure their relationships improve.
lead_paragraph: – President Obama, after meeting with community leaders and law enforcement officials about the unrest in Ferguson, Mo., said he was deeply invested in making sure their relationships improve.

headline: A Week Later, Protesters Remain Vocal on Ferguson, Partly With Silence
abstract: Across the country, mostly peaceful expressions of anger, including periods of silence and staged “die-ins,” continued over a Missouri grand jury’s conclusion.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — At colleges and high schools, outside police stations, courthouses, city halls and federal buildings, a series of nationwide protests on Monday maintained the momentum of those seeking justice for the unarmed black teenager who was killed by a white police officer in Ferguson, Mo., almost four months ago.

headline: American Couple in Qatar, Cleared in Child’s Death, Petition to Lift Travel Ban
abstract: The couple, Matthew and Grace Huang of Los Angeles, had hoped to leave Sunday but were thwarted by Qatari bureaucracy.
lead_paragraph: The American couple in Qatar acquitted on Sunday in the death of their adopted African daughter after a nearly two-year legal ordeal petitioned the attorney general’s office on Monday to rescind a travel ban, a bureaucratic obstacle that had prevented them from flying home immediately after they won their case.

headline: Buffalo-Area Nursing Home Changes Account of Woman’s Death After Evacuation
abstract: The home now says that a resident who died after an evacuation prompted by heavy snowfall last month had not had a seizure; a different woman had.
lead_paragraph: A Buffalo-area nursing home on Monday changed its account from last week of how one of its residents died after an evacuation prompted by heavy snowfall.

headline: Team Holiday Sweaters Are ‘So Bad, They’re Amazing’
abstract: The National Basketball Association recently released a collection of holiday-themed sweaters for all 30 teams that defy easy description.
lead_paragraph: Cole Aldrich is familiar with his teammates’ bold fashion choices: the hats and the scarves, the culottes and the high tops. The Knicks’ locker room is not a place for the meek.

headline: A Christmas Tale From a Faraway Land of Snow and Ice
abstract: “Great Russian Nutcracker” is the Moscow Ballet’s take on this classic, with choreography by Stanislav Vlasov.
lead_paragraph: It has been quite a year for Russian ballet in New York. First, in the summer, there was a visit by the Bolshoi Ballet, robust but plagued by scandal and a reactionary repertory. Then, last month, came the United States debut of the newly ascendant Mikhailovsky Ballet, with strong performances and more unadventurous programming. In January, the Mariinsky Ballet will complete the hat trick at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Casting for a Big Fish on the Big Island of Hawaii
abstract: Ulua can weigh well over a hundred pounds. So how, exactly, do you haul one in from the shore?
lead_paragraph: The ulua, also known as a giant trevally, or G.T., is a brute among fish. It’s linebacker-shaped, all blunt forehead and blocky torso, with the thin, bladelike fins of a high-speed ocean predator. Trophies can reach well over a hundred pounds of silver-clad muscle. Catching one is like towing a Volkswagen Beetle with your arms and a stick, then pulling it up a cliff.

headline: The Balanchine Specialist, Continuing in Her Own Groove
abstract: Suzanne Farrell’s company displays her approach in a program of five works at the Kennedy Center in Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During her own long career onstage, Suzanne Farrell became legendary as the ultimate Balanchine ballerina. She was the most musically amazing, the most grand, the most audacious, the most revelatory, the most unattainable, the most inspired. Her example was a beacon within the company Balanchine had created, New York City Ballet, not least during the years immediately after his death in 1983.

headline: Eminem Invoked at the Supreme Court
abstract: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. is well known for his ability to quote obscure case law, but on Monday he invoked the rapper Eminem at the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. is well known for his ability to quote obscure case law, but on Monday he invoked the rapper Eminem during an argument before the Supreme Court.

headline: Santa, Please: Ignore the Existential Questions
abstract: “Toy Story That Time Forgot” and “The Robot Chicken Lots of Holidays but Don’t Worry Christmas Is Still in There Too” are just two of the recent holiday television specials.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to “Overthinking the Animated Christmas Specials,” a new feature in which we consider the philosophical underpinnings of two radically different animated specials coming to your televisions. This year’s installment: “Toy Story That Time Forgot,” Tuesday night on ABC, versus “The Robot Chicken Lots of Holidays but Don’t Worry Christmas Is Still in There Too” special Sunday night on Adult Swim.

headline: Divvying Up Perks, Pity, Scorn and Snark
abstract: “Girlfriends’ Guide to Divorce,” the first scripted series for Bravo, taps into the separations of the rich and near-famous and all the attendant rituals.
lead_paragraph: There are businesses that bet on breakups. Patricia Cohen, an ex-wife of Steven A. Cohen, the hedge fund billionaire, recently received an infusion of cash, known as litigation financing, from a California company, Balance Point Divorce Funding, to continue her lawsuit against her former husband.

headline: His ‘Best’ Is Ahead of Him, as Podcast
abstract: Tom Scharpling’s “The Best Show,” a longtime favorite on WFMU, will find a new life on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — Last December, in one of the final installments of “The Best Show on WFMU,” the free-form radio show he had hosted for 13 years, Tom Scharpling was in his usual irascible mood.

headline: Highlights of This Week’s Design Miami Show
abstract: A guide to the installations, galleries and emerging talents not to miss at the tenth anniversary of the fair.
lead_paragraph: What a difference a decade makes. The tenth anniversary of Design Miami, the latest edition of which opens Wednesday to coincide with Art Basel Miami Beach’s opening Thursday, marks an era of gangbuster growth for not only the industry it helped spawn, but also in its host city at large.

headline: Per Se to Join Restaurants Charging in Advance
abstract: A Chicago-born prepayment system for reservations will get a big test in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Will New Yorkers pay up front for restaurant meals?

headline: A French Town Reels After Teenage Girl Vanishes, Apparently to Join Jihadists
abstract: A small but growing number of teenage girls in Europe, enticed by Internet recruiters, have shown amazing determination in their efforts to join jihadists, experts say.
lead_paragraph: BETHONCOURT, France — French intelligence officials got in touch with the parents of a shy, 15-year-old Muslim girl in this depressed town in eastern France last May to convey some shocking news: Their daughter had become a frequent visitor to websites preaching jihad.

headline: Why Our Memory Fails Us
abstract: Just because you think you recall something doesn’t mean you do.
lead_paragraph: NEIL DEGRASSE TYSON, the astrophysicist and host of the TV series “Cosmos,” regularly speaks to audiences on topics ranging from cosmology to climate change to the appalling state of science literacy in America. One of his staple stories hinges on a line from President George W. Bush’s speech to Congress after the 9/11 terrorist attacks. In a 2008 talk, for example, Dr. Tyson said that in order “to distinguish we from they” — meaning to divide Judeo-Christian Americans from fundamentalist Muslims — Mr. Bush uttered the words “Our God is the God who named the stars.”

headline: Photographing the Moments Between War and Peace
abstract: Readers have to take their time with James Hill’s new book, where he presents moments that have stayed with him, even if their meanings may be ambiguous.
lead_paragraph: Readers have to take their time with James Hill’s new book, where he presents moments that have stayed with him, even if their meanings may be ambiguous.

headline: The Secret Therapist
abstract: Sometimes, being a primary care doctor isn’t enough.
lead_paragraph: I’m a primary care physician, but with my young adult patients, I’m secretly a therapist, too.

headline: Hoping for a Good Death
abstract: What I hadn’t considered before my father’s heart attack was the precise meaning of “not wanting to live hooked up to machines.”
lead_paragraph: My 78-year-old father died recently after a sudden heart attack. I ought to have been prepared for the five days my mother, brother and I spent with him in the cardiac intensive care unit because I teach medical ethics at a university, and I am a member of a hospital ethics committee and have discussed many difficult end-of-life cases. But much of what happened – and what didn’t happen – came as a surprise to me.

headline: Therapy Prevents Repeat Suicide Attempts
abstract: Short-term psychotherapy may be an effective way to prevent repeated suicide attempts.
lead_paragraph: Short-term psychotherapy may be an effective way to prevent repeated suicide attempts.

headline: For Uber, Airbnb and Other Companies, Customer Ratings Go Both Ways
abstract: Hotel, restaurant and car service companies are now frequently using sophisticated systems that allow them to identify their best, and worst, patrons.
lead_paragraph: Travelers are often asked to review their hotel, restaurant and car service. But increasingly, it goes both ways.

headline: Boko Haram Attacks With Ease, Causing Death and Mayhem in Nigeria’s Provinces
abstract: Two attacks on Monday in Maiduguri and Damaturu, state capitals in northern Nigeria, were among a wave of assaults showing Boko Haram’s ability to strike at will, especially against civilians.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — A wave of attacks across northern Nigeria, including two on Monday — a suicide bombing at a market and an assault on security facilities — showed that the Islamist terrorist group Boko Haram remained able to strike at will in the region, especially against civilian targets.

headline: British Fashion Awards Red Carpet
abstract: Rihanna, Naomi Campbell and Cara Delevingne were among the many fashion insiders that attended.
lead_paragraph: Rihanna, Naomi Campbell and Cara Delevingne were among the many fashion insiders that attended.

headline: British Fashion Awards Red Carpet
abstract: Rihanna, Naomi Campbell and Cara Delevingne were among the many fashion insiders who attended.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 1, the British Fashion Awards were held at London Coliseum. Some of the winners included J.W. Anderson for Menswear, Erdem for Womenswear and Anya Hindmarch for Accessories. See the red carpet here.

headline: Another Killing in Ferguson Leaves a Family Grappling With the Unknown
abstract: On the night of the grand jury’s decision in the Michael Brown case, another young black man was killed in Ferguson, and the police and his family don’t know why.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Just up the road from the memorial of stuffed animals and candles that has become a place of pilgrimage and protest over the shooting death of Michael Brown, there is an empty parking lot where another young black man was killed last week on the night this city erupted in rage.

headline: Obama Calls for Body Cameras on Police
abstract: At a meeting of civil rights leaders and law enforcement officials, President Obama described plans to address what he called a “simmering distrust” between police departments and people of color.
lead_paragraph: At a meeting of civil rights leaders and law enforcement officials, President Obama described plans to address what he called a “simmering distrust” between police departments and people of color.

headline: Early Elections Looming in Israel
abstract: Amid acrimony, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s coalition appears to be on the brink of collapse.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel edged closer on Monday to early elections as a brewing government crisis brought Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s coalition to the brink of collapse.

headline: The Perils of Being Pregnant and Not Famous
abstract: Kate Hudson, founder of the e-retail site Editorialist and mother of two, shares her name with the Hollywood actress.
lead_paragraph: BUSINESS travel isn’t new to me. I work in fashion and have been flying most of my career. Now, as founder of the e-retail site Editorialist, I’m still flying a lot and, fortunately, still enjoying it. I have to admit that as the mother of two young children, I often enjoy the alone time on a plane. I miss my family terribly when I’m away for a few days, but it’s nice to have a few hours cocooned in a plane when no one can get to you.

headline: The Ethics of Fighting Ebola
abstract: How can the development and testing of Ebola drugs and vaccines help fight the outbreak while respecting ethical standards?

headline: Putin Scraps European Gas Pipeline
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia announced today that Russia is dropping plans for the South Stream pipeline and instead will expand a pipeline through Turkey.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia announced today that Russia is dropping plans for the South Stream pipeline and instead will expand a pipeline through Turkey.

headline: Most College Students Don’t Earn a Degree in 4 Years, Study Finds
abstract: A new report says that only 19 percent of students graduated in four years from most public universities and that only 50 of 580 public universities graduated a majority of their full-time students at the four-year mark.
lead_paragraph: The vast majority of students at American public colleges do not graduate on time, according to a new report from Complete College America, a nonprofit group based in Indianapolis.

headline: G.O.P. Split Over Congressional Budget Office Head
abstract: Ardent conservatives have laid out their cases against Douglas Elmendorf’s reappointment to the nonpartisan post, while other Republicans support him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Douglas W. Elmendorf is an obscure figure beyond a narrow radius around Capitol Hill. As the director of the Congressional Budget Office, his nuts-and-bolts job is to serve as the official scorekeeper on the price of legislation and the referee on the budgetary and economic impacts of policy, from the Affordable Care Act to an increase in the minimum wage.

headline: Antismoking Story That Is Tailored to Native Alaskans
abstract: Michael George Patterson tells of his impending death to Alaskan youths, who have been found to not respond to fear-inducing imagery of disease and shortened life.
lead_paragraph: JUNEAU, Alaska — Michael George Patterson, a 59-year-old Native Alaskan, stood before a group of high school students on a recent morning and told them about his impending death. Sooner or later, he said, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or another complication of lung damage from years of smoking — starting when he was 9 — will kill him.

headline: Considering the Year in Airport Security, With the T.S.A. Chief
abstract: The number of people who enrolled in programs to expedite passage through security checkpoints rose, John Pistole says, as did the number of guns found during screenings.
lead_paragraph: IF you grew accustomed to being waved into an expedited security line at the airport this year even though you didn’t belong to the Transportation Security Administration’s PreCheck program, you should probably get ready to take your shoes off again at the checkpoints next year.

headline: Three Detained in India in Harassment of Sisters Who Fought Back
abstract: The young men are accused of sexually harassing two sisters on a bus in the Indian state of Haryana in an incident caught on video.
lead_paragraph: Three young men have been detained in the Indian state of Haryana, accused of sexually harassing two sisters on a public bus, in an episode that was captured on video by a witness and posted online, local news media reported on Monday.

headline: Car Seat Maker Graco Under Investigation for Delayed Reporting of Defect
abstract: The defect under study is the buckle of the Graco children’s car seats, which were recalled this year.
lead_paragraph: Federal safety regulators on Monday began an investigation into whether Graco Children’s Products delayed reporting a safety defect that eventually led to the nation’s largest recall of children’s car seats.

headline: Sendak’s Estate: Debating Where the Things Go
abstract: Lynn Caponera, Maurice Sendak’s housekeeper and caretaker for more than 30 years, is pushing ahead to burnish his legacy, amid questions.
lead_paragraph: RIDGEFIELD, Conn. — Maurice Sendak’s red cardigan is still draped over the chair in his home art studio here, the way he left it when he died in 2012. His slippers sit side by side beneath his desk. Lynn Caponera, his housekeeper and caretaker for more than 30 years, turned on a lamp one recent afternoon to show the first pages of the last book he was working on, a Gogol-esque tale tentatively titled “No Nose”:

headline: Nae Nae, Dance That Swept the World, Has a Sequel
abstract: The whip is following in the footsteps of the Nae Nae, becoming the new go-to celebration dance among sports stars.
lead_paragraph: Where do we go after the Nae Nae?

headline: Princeton Eating Club Ousts 2 Officers Over Emails Ridiculing Women
abstract: Tiger Inn, a social club known for its rowdy, hard-drinking atmosphere, is being investigated for one of the emails, which included an explicit photo.
lead_paragraph: A coeducational Princeton University eating club has removed two officers from their posts after they sent out emails ridiculing women, in one including a sexually explicit photograph.

headline: Knicks Prepare to Host the Nets in a Battle of Futility
abstract: New York’s two N.B.A. teams, which meet Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, are turning the city into a mecca of bad basketball.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — After the Knicks finished practice Monday, Carmelo Anthony was asked during an interview session whether he was feeling pumped up to play the Nets on Tuesday night — the sort of question that players on the two teams have often had to answer since 2012, when the Nets moved from New Jersey to Brooklyn.

headline: Bitly Helps the Red Cross Get to Hope.ly
abstract: The URL shortening site will introduce Hope.ly with the American Red Cross. The new shortening tool will prompt those visiting to donate to the Red Cross.
lead_paragraph: Following the phenomenal success this summer of the Ice Bucket Challenge for the A.L.S. Association, which seeks a cure for what is commonly known as Lou Gehrig’s disease, other charities have been longing for their own viral sensations. Now the American Red Cross is introducing a fund-raising effort that, rather than creating videos or spurring supporters to upload theirs, benefits from others’ popular content.

headline: Lessons From an Ancient Time When Recyclers Walked the Earth
abstract: Archaeologists working at Qesem Cave in Israel discovered tools that indicated a prehistoric commitment to limiting waste.
lead_paragraph: ROSH HAAYIN, Israel — For years, archaeologists have been diligently digging their way through prehistoric layers of time, unearthing the secrets of Qesem Cave.

headline: Encouraging Public Service, Through Wall Street’s ‘Revolving Door’
abstract: The debate about pay for Wall Street executives who take government jobs appears to be based more on a populist shakedown than on good public policy.
lead_paragraph: The boards of Wall Street’s biggest banks recently received a letter posing a provocative question.

headline: New York Attorney General Critical of Heroin Antidote’s Cost
abstract: Eric T. Schneiderman, New York’s attorney general, wrote a letter asking the drug company that makes naloxone to explain why the cost has increased so much, so fast.
lead_paragraph: Amid a sudden and sharp increase in the price of a heroin antidote medication, Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman of New York on Monday wrote to the chief executive of a company that makes the drug, demanding an explanation for what he called an “unacceptable” rise.

headline: New Images Refine View of Infant Universe
abstract: The subject of a meeting of astrophysicists is a new baby picture — and all of its vital statistics — of the universe when it was 380,000 years old and space was as hot as the surface of the sun.
lead_paragraph: In a throwback to another era in cosmic history, astronomers on Monday discussed the birth of the universe at a meeting in a 15th-century palace, the Palazzo Costabili in Ferrara, Italy, where the amenities do not include Internet access.

headline: The N.C.A.A.’s Big Bluff
abstract: Internal N.C.A.A. emails that were recently made public shed light on the response to the sexual abuse scandal at Penn State.
lead_paragraph: Not long after the N.C.A.A. came down on Penn State three years ago, after the Jerry Sandusky child sexual abuse scandal, a small group of rabid Penn State supporters began circulating emails to each other. A few journalists were also among those receiving the emails, myself included.

headline: Class Prejudice Resurgent
abstract: Racism has fused with classism to create a new, ugly form of prejudice in America.
lead_paragraph: One of the features of all the Ferguson discussion over the past few months is how tinny the comparisons to the civil-rights era have sounded. People have tried to link Ferguson to Selma and Jim Crow, but something is off.

headline: In Egypt, a Verdict Turns Back the Clock
abstract: Former President Hosni Mubarak is likely to go free, denying justice for the hundreds who died in the 2011 uprising.
lead_paragraph: The Egyptian court that threw out the murder charges against former President Hosni Mubarak may have closed the final chapter on the Arab Spring. After the country’s brief, flawed attempt at democracy, the army and its supporters put in place an even more authoritarian system than the Mubarak regime.

headline: G.O.P. Aide Quits After Ridiculing Obama’s Daughters, Sasha and Malia
abstract: Elizabeth Lauten, a Republican aide, resigned after giving the girls an online scolding for their attitude and outfits at the White House turkey pardon, telling them to show “a little class.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A young Republican congressional aide resigned Monday after her Facebook post berating President Obama’s daughters for their attitude and outfits during the annual White House turkey pardon became a sensation on the Internet.

headline: Decoding Viruses
abstract: At the Broad Institute in Cambridge, researchers are sequencing the genomes of viruses like Lassa and Ebola to watch them mutate in real time.
lead_paragraph: At the Broad Institute in Cambridge, researchers are sequencing the genomes of viruses like Lassa and Ebola to watch them mutate in real time.

headline: An Artist Who Wrapped and Bound Her Work, and Then Broke Free
abstract: Judith Scott, who had Down syndrome and no formal training or education to speak of, built a global reputation with string and sticks.
lead_paragraph: Judith Scott was an artist based in Oakland, Calif., who made abstract works from fiber and found objects. Some of them are small and slender, like a hunter-gatherer’s quiver. Some are large enough to cradle in both arms. Some you would need a shopping cart to move. One actually is a shopping cart, piled high with seemingly random objects and cocooned in white string.

headline: Justices Urged to Intervene in Execution of Texas Man
abstract: Executing Scott Panetti, who has long shown signs of serious mental illness, would be unconstitutional, his lawyers argued before the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — On Sept. 8, 1992, Scott Panetti shaved his head, dressed in Army fatigues and killed his wife’s parents with a deer rifle as his horrified wife and daughter looked on. Mr. Panetti represented himself at his subsequent trial, wearing a cowboy costume with a purple bandanna while trying to call more than 200 witnesses, including the pope, John F. Kennedy and Jesus.

headline: What Is a True Threat on Facebook?
abstract: To protect free speech, the government should prove that a speaker intended to make a threat before it can put him behind bars.
lead_paragraph: The First Amendment protects all kinds of outrageous and upsetting speech. As the Supreme Court has stated in a long line of cases, the government cannot punish violent words — even “vehement, caustic” or “unpleasantly sharp attacks” — unless they are “true threats.”

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 1, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: N.Y.U. Faces Worker Protection Issues at Shanghai Campus
abstract: The university said that a company hired to monitor work conditions at its Shanghai campus did not comply; workers’ conditions at the Abu Dhabi campus were criticized this spring.
lead_paragraph: New York University, in the midst of a review of how laborers were treated during the construction of its Abu Dhabi campus, has acknowledged that procedures intended to protect workers at its other major foreign outpost, in Shanghai, were not followed.

headline: Louisiana Runoff: A Blue State Turns Red
abstract: Senator Mary L. Landrieu, a Democrat, faces Representative Bill Cassidy, a Republican, in a runoff election Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mary L. Landrieu, a Democrat, faces Representative Bill Cassidy, a Republican, in a runoff election Saturday.

headline: Jade’s Journey Marked by Drugs and Death
abstract: As China grows, so does its appetite for jade. But the gemstone’s journey from Myanmar’s mines to China’s consumers follows a trail of addiction, infection and exploitation.
lead_paragraph: As China grows, so does its appetite for jade. But the gemstone’s journey from Myanmar’s mines to China’s consumers follows a trail of addiction, infection and exploitation.

headline: New York City Plans Focus on Mental Health in Justice System
abstract: To reduce the number of inmates with mental health and substance abuse problems, the city plans to expand health services at almost every step of the criminal justice process.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to reduce the growing number of inmates with mental health and substance abuse problems in New York City’s jails, the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio announced plans on Monday to significantly expand public health services at almost every step of the criminal justice process.

headline: Drinking Buddy For Falstaff
abstract: In which Timothy Polin reveals his potty mouth.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — True Story: The only time I ever saw my mother visibly drunk was when my father took her out for a celebratory dinner at the legendary Trader Vic’s and she took one for the team, alcoholically speaking, in order to be a good mother.

headline: ‘Sleepy Hollow’ Recap: A Not-So-Shocking Death
abstract: In the fall season finale, a question of where the series has many places to go.
lead_paragraph: Season 2, Episode 11: “The Akeda”

headline: Seller of Art Fakes Pleads Guilty to Wire Fraud
abstract: John Re, 54, faces up to 20 years in prison for selling paintings and sketches purportedly by famous artists. He stole about $2.5 million from unwitting buyers.
lead_paragraph: An East Hampton man accused of selling dozens of fake paintings and sketches purported to be by famous artists, and using some of the money to buy a submarine, pleaded guilty in federal court on Monday to one count of wire fraud.

headline: Moving to Be Near Their Daughters, but Still Far Away
abstract: Mariya and Leonid Livshyts, both in their 70s, moved to Atlanta from Ukraine in 2008, but health issues and financial troubles drove them to New York.
lead_paragraph: When Mariya and Leonid Livshyts, both in their 70s, immigrated from Ukraine six years ago, all they wanted was to be closer to their two daughters.

headline: Searching for Burmese Jade, and Finding Misery
abstract: A New York Times documentary and article look at mine workers in Myanmar struggling with poverty and drug addiction even as the country’s jade industry is booming because of demand from China.
lead_paragraph: MYITKYINA, Myanmar — At 16, the gem trader’s son set out for the jade mines to seek his fortune in the precious stone that China craves. But a month in, the teenager, Sang Aung Bau Hkum, was feeding his own addiction: heroin, the drug of choice among the men who work the bleak terrain of gouged earthen pits, shared needles and dwindling hope here in the jungles of northern Myanmar.

headline: No Agreement Reached on Syrian No-Fly Zone
abstract: Turkey is continuing to push the Obama administration to impose a no-fly zone or safe area along the Turkish-Syrian border, administration officials said Monday, but obstacles remain.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Turkey is continuing to push the Obama administration to impose a no-fly zone or safe area along the Turkish-Syrian border, administration officials said Monday, but obstacles remain to the United States’ committing to what would be a significant increase in American military engagement in the area.

headline: Peek in Gramercy Park, Key No Longer Required
abstract: Manhattan’s famously private park is open, at least virtually, to the public after a visitor took several 360-degree panoramas and posted them on Google Maps.
lead_paragraph: With its cyborg cars and omniscient backpacks festooned with cameras, Google has mapped out and photographed much of the planet. From the comfort of their browsers, people can now visit Times Square, Tiananmen Square or the Square One mall in Mississauga, Ontario.

headline: French Far Right Gets Helping Hand With Russian Loan
abstract: The loan is seen as a helpful gesture after the party’s leadership expressed admiration for President Vladimir V. Putin and a desire to break with NATO in favor of an alliance with Russia.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France’s far-right National Front party has taken an $11.7 million loan from a Russian bank to help finance various campaigns — money, officials said, party representatives were unable to obtain from any French or European bank, though they spoke to a dozen.

headline: ‘Birdman’ Tops the Gothams
abstract: The backstage tale wins two awards; “Citizenfour” is also a winner.
lead_paragraph: “Birdman or The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance,” Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s mystical backstage tale, topped the Gotham Independent Film Awards on Monday night.

headline: Proposal Would Trim New York City’s List of Potential Landmarks
abstract: Eighty of the structures cited by the Landmarks Preservation Commission have been under consideration, but not voted on, for more than 20 years.
lead_paragraph: The chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, which is charged with protecting New York City’s historic structures, is proposing to remove more than 100 of them from her agency’s oversight, dismaying preservationists who say the move could endanger some of the properties.

headline: Dutch Envoy Shifts From Syrian Arms Post to Lebanon
abstract: Sigrid Kaag, a United Nations diplomat from the Netherlands, has been named the organization’s special coordinator in Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: Sigrid Kaag, a United Nations diplomat from the Netherlands who directed the multinational effort to destroy Syria’s chemical weapons stockpile, has been named the organization’s special coordinator in Lebanon, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon announced Monday. Ms. Kaag, left, coordinated the program with the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons. The last of Syria’s declared chemical weapons components were exported for destruction on June 23, an accomplishment largely credited to Ms. Kaag. In Lebanon, she will replace Derek Plumbly, a British diplomat. The United Nations operation in Lebanon originally focused on stabilizing southern Lebanon after the Israeli military withdrawal in 2000, and expanded its role in the aftermath of the 2006 war between Israel and Hezbollah militants based in Lebanon. The special coordinator’s role has become increasingly important because of Syria’s refugee crisis, as well as Lebanon’s tense relations with Israel and the country’s own political frailties.

headline: Lightning Again Provide a Harsh Barometer for the Rangers’ Success
abstract: The Rangers had won four of their last six games, but Tampa Bay’s Brett Connolly and Tyler Johnson each scored twice as the Lightning swept the season series.
lead_paragraph: Another reunion game at Madison Square Garden on Monday represented a chance for the Rangers to gauge whether their recent surge against teams not from Tampa Bay was genuine.

headline: Stranger Than Fiction? Try Fact
abstract: HBO plans to broadcast a six-part documentary on Robert Durst, the real estate heir notorious for leading the police on a nationwide manhunt after decapitating his neighbor.
lead_paragraph: The life of Robert A. Durst could be the stuff of legend.

headline: Susan Cianciolo Heads Up a Home-Goods Collective
abstract: The fixture of New York’s downtown avant-garde fashion scene has spearheaded a range of collaboratively designed housewares debuting at Ralph Pucci today.
lead_paragraph: Since the mid-1990s, the artist-designer-filmmaker Susan Cianciolo has been a fixture on New York’s avant-garde art and fashion scene. A bona fide cult figure, she produces not only hand-crafted clothing that is both high-concept and homespun, but also a body of drawings, videos and performance pieces exploring the social relationships behind her creations. Throughout her career, she’s been championed by everyone from Sonic Youth’s Kim Gordon to Vogue — which, during the millennial peak of New York’s downtown fashion scene (when names such as Miguel Adrover, As Four and Bruce came to the fore), enthusiastically advocated for what it called her “home-ec-y” aesthetic.

headline: Exquisite Feasts for the Eye
abstract: From ornate confections to extravagant centerpieces, the mood is decadent, and the table is set.
lead_paragraph: From ornate confections to extravagant centerpieces, the mood is decadent, and the table is set.

headline: The Eclectic World of Lisa Eisner
abstract: From her tight-knit clan to her passion for nature, the artist and designer finds inspiration in all the corners of her colorful life.
lead_paragraph: From her tight-knit clan to her passion for nature, the artist and designer finds inspiration in all the corners of her colorful life.

headline: Audit Faults New York Education Dept.'s Management of Computers
abstract: A report by the New York City comptroller’s office found what it called “grossly inaccurate” record keeping at the department, where hundreds of computers and tablets at some locations were either not in use or could not be found.
lead_paragraph: An audit by the New York City comptroller’s office found what it called “grossly inaccurate” record keeping at the Education Department, where more than 2,000 computers and tablets at a sample of department locations were either unused — still swaddled in their original wrapping — or could not be located at all.

headline: New York Philharmonic Announces Partnership With Michigan Musical Society
abstract: The partnership with the University Musical Society of the University of Michigan will include three visits by the Philharmonic.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic and the University Musical Society of the University of Michigan, in Ann Arbor, will undertake a residency partnership that will involve concerts, master classes and workshops.

abstract: This word has appeared in 245 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: wistful •\ˈwist-fəl\• adjective

headline: $1,000 Reward for Best Scientific Answer: What is Zzzz…z.z.zzz.z.. Sleep?
abstract: Alan Alda and a science-loving army of 11-year-olds want creative, accurate descriptions of sleep.
lead_paragraph: What is sleep?

headline: Jets’ All-Running Plan Works for a While, but Not When It Matters
abstract: Having Geno Smith hand off the ball instead of throwing worked for three quarters, but the Jets collapsed, squandering a 10-point lead against Miami.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — After three weeks away, the Jets returned Monday night to the hospitable environs of MetLife Stadium.

headline: Jets Replay: Week 13
abstract: The Jets allowed 10 points in the final 11 minutes, including a go-ahead field goal with 1 minute 57 seconds remaining, as they fell to the Dolphins, 16-13, and dropped to 2-10.
lead_paragraph: The Jets allowed 10 points in the final 11 minutes, including a go-ahead field goal with 1 minute 57 seconds remaining, as they fell to the Dolphins, 16-13, and dropped to 2-10.

headline: Big 12 Will Guarantee Multiyear Scholarships
abstract: The Big 12 plans to join the Big Ten and the Pacific-12 in guaranteeing scholarships for athletes’ complete eligibility periods.
lead_paragraph: The Big 12 announced Monday that, beginning in August, it would guarantee multiyear scholarships and, pending N.C.A.A. authorization, give athletes the “full cost of attendance,” an amount typically several thousand dollars higher than current scholarships. The Big 12 joins the Big Ten and the Pacific-12 in guaranteeing scholarships for athletes’ complete eligibility periods.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE DREAMERS (2004) Louis Garrel, Eva Green and Michael Pitt portray the points of a photogenic triangle in this drama from Bernardo Bertolucci (“Last Tango in Paris”) about an American who befriends French twins in Paris during the 1968 student riots. This adaptation of Gilbert Adair’s novel “The Holy Innocents” is “disarmingly sweet and completely enchanting,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “The sex in this movie is, as measured by the display of body parts and the amount of time the actors spend out of their clothes, more explicit than even the most notorious scenes in ‘Last Tango,’ ” he said. “But it is hard to imagine a voyeur more benevolent than Mr. Bertolucci, whose eager scrutiny of the eros of the young is, like Jeremy Irons’s in ‘Stealing Beauty,’ less a matter of prurience than of an honest, nostalgic appreciation of natural human vitality.”

headline: China’s Artists to Be Taught ‘Correct View’ in New Plan
abstract: In a project that echoes the Cultural Revolution, China’s top film and television industry regulator has announced a program to send artists to local communities to form a “correct view on art.”
lead_paragraph: In a project that echoes the Cultural Revolution, China’s top film and television industry regulator has announced a new program to send artists to grass-roots communities to learn from the masses and form a “correct view on art.”

headline: Corrections: December 2, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, December 2, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 2, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “Try digging all day with an iron rod and see how you feel.”

headline: Fashion's Bridge to the Art World
abstract: The art adviser has played many roles in bringing the two sectors together. Now a new generation is appearing, focusing on younger clients and emerging artists.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Fashion and art have long had a love affair, from Salvador Dali’s shoe hat created with Elsa Schiaparelli, to Jeff Koons’s balloon dog image plastered on H&M handbags. And often there has been a third party operating behind the scenes to bring the two worlds together: an art adviser.

headline: In 2015, Technology Shifts Accelerate and China Rules, IDC Predicts
abstract: The research firm IDC predicts that 2015 will see an ever-faster shift to cloud, mobile, social and big data technologies, and that China’s impact will skyrocket.
lead_paragraph: In the year-end predictions game, most technology forecasts tend to be either blue sky or boring, flights of imagination or a firm grasp of the obvious.

headline: Inspiration Meets Social Media
abstract: A designer’s ideas used to come from a journey and his feedback from buyers and clients. Now, they are more likely to be the result of a whirl through online sites.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — While vacationing in the Bahamas earlier this year, Zac Posen posted a couple of sunset snaps to his Instagram account — and each one drew more than 6,000 “likes.”

headline: South Korea Allows New Christmas Tower at Border With North
abstract: The government approved the 30-foot tower, shaped like a Christmas tree, in a move that is likely to anger North Korea.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The South Korean Defense Ministry said Tuesday that it would allow a Christian group to build a 30-foot tower shaped like a Christmas tree near the border with North Korea, a move likely to anger the isolated North, which had threatened to bomb a similar tower that once stood there.

headline: Test Yourself | Climbing Like a Gecko
abstract: Here are the first six paragraphs from a Nov. 24 article, “Climbing a Glass Building? Try a Gecko’s Sticky Pads.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are the first six paragraphs from a Nov. 24 article, “Climbing a Glass Building? Try a Gecko’s Sticky Pads.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Online Sales for Girl Scout Cookies Are Approved
abstract: Do you think selling cookies online will teach the entrepreneurial skills the cookie sales program is designed to instill? Why?
lead_paragraph: In the article “Online Sales for Girl Scout Cookies Are Approved,” Elizabeth Olson reports on a new way girl scouts can practice their entrepreneurial skills.

headline: Insurance Firms Aviva and Friends Life Agree to $8.8 Billion Merger
abstract: The deal, if approved by shareholders and regulators, would create Britain’s largest life insurer, worth roughly £20.7 billion and with more than £300 billion in assets under management.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British insurer Aviva said on Tuesday that it had finalized an agreement to acquire its rival Friends Life in an all-share deal worth about $8.8 billion that would create Britain’s largest life insurer.

headline: Are We Missing the Big Picture on Climate Change?
abstract: Stories about smaller environmental problems can distract us from the slow-motion calamity that will eventually threaten every living being.
lead_paragraph: The human hands in blue medical gloves spread out the swallow’s wings. The brown feathers jut out like spikes, their tips frizzled and scorched. These wings are no longer graceful fans capable of cupping and pushing off against the air. The left one is worse than the right, and the tail is a pitiful cluster of sticks. This is the wreckage of a bird, the ruin of it. The beauty of a rough-winged swallow is in its flight, the way its darting, swooping path carves arabesques through the skies. Not this bird.

headline: Photographing the Moments Between War and Peace
abstract: Readers have to take their time with James Hill’s new book, where he presents moments that have stayed with him, even if their meanings are sometimes ambiguous.
lead_paragraph: You can’t just flip through James Hill’s new book, “Somewhere Between War and Peace,” for a quick survey of his 20-years-and-counting career. Not only because the images are stark and demanding — but you’re also physically prevented. The pages are cut to different lengths, and the shorter pages carry Mr. Hill’s stories behind the photos. Thumb through, and you’ll land solely on those pictureless, text-only pages.

headline: 100 Notable Books of 2014
abstract: The year’s notable fiction, poetry and nonfiction, selected by the editors of The New York Times Book Review.
lead_paragraph: The year’s notable fiction, poetry and nonfiction, selected by the editors of The New York Times Book Review.

headline: Does Separating Boys and Girls Help Students Perform Better in School?
abstract: Based on your experience, do boys distract girls, and vice versa, in ways that may have a negative impact on how well they do in school?
lead_paragraph: Single-sex education used to be common in the United States, but by the end of the 19th century the approach had all but disappeared from public schools. Now, some districts are experimenting with dividing students by gender again as a way to improve academic performance. Educators disagree about whether the strategy works. What do you think?

headline: Expelled U.S. Official to Return to Bahrain
abstract: Months after meeting with an opposition leader and being told to leave the country, Tom Malinowski, the assistant secretary of state for human rights, will visit with another member of the State Department.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The State Department’s top official on human rights is planning to return to Bahrain on Wednesday, nearly five months after he was ordered to leave the country, American officials said.

headline: Leaders of Hong Kong Democracy Campaign Urge Students to Retreat
abstract: Co-founders of the Occupy Central campaign in Hong Kong on Tuesday said students should end their protests to avoid the threat of worsening violence.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Three co-founders of a pro-democracy campaign that paved the way for civil disobedience demonstrations in Hong Kong’s streets told protesting students on Tuesday that it was time to go home, saying that the students’ beleaguered protest camps faced too many dangers of worsening violence.

headline: New Freedom for Myanmar’s Artists
abstract: Since the abolition of Myanmar’s censorship board in 2012, the country’s artists are tackling once-forbidden subjects like politics.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — In past years, even if Sandar Khine’s artworks — jarringly bright acrylic nudes — made it past the military censors and into exhibitions, they were draped in black cloth and always placed in back corners.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Jeb Bush Makes an Anti-Pander Promise if He Runs in 2016
abstract: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida said Monday that he was close to making a decision about entering the 2016 presidential race.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida was blunt Monday night: If he runs for president in 2016, he will not pander to his party’s conservative base in the primaries.

headline: New York Today: City of (More) Trees
abstract: Tuesday: The story of our street trees, snow and sleet, and a look inside Gramercy Park.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this gloomy Tuesday.

headline: Video: Louisiana Runoff
abstract: Mary L. Landrieu, a three-term senator, is in the race of her career against the Republican Bill Cassidy as Louisiana voters head to the polls for a runoff vote on Dec. 6.
lead_paragraph: Mary L. Landrieu, a three-term senator, is in the race of her career against the Republican Bill Cassidy as Louisiana voters head to the polls for a runoff vote on Dec. 6.

headline: The Swiss and Needy Children
abstract: In hindsight the practice of orphans being forced into contract labor seems to have been cruel. But in the 19th century this system was deemed a type of “social welfare.”
lead_paragraph: Re “Slavery’s shadow on Switzerland” (Opinion, Nov. 11): Tony Wild’s personal experience of finding out that his grandmother had been a verdingkind in Switzerland at the turn of the century offers an interesting perspective. But there are some inaccuracies in Mr. Wild’s account which, I feel, come from his strong emotional reaction based on his family relationship, rather than from the facts.

headline: Roots of the Arab Awakening
abstract: If the purpose of Thomas L. Friedman’s article was to commend the ultramodern wonders of Dubai, then it did a great job.
lead_paragraph: Re “Did Dubai do it?” (Nov. 20): If the purpose of Thomas L. Friedman’s article was to commend the ultramodern wonders of Dubai, then it did a great job. If it was to offer an underlying motive for the Arab Spring, then it failed. To say that the Arab awakening began because young Arab people were jealous of Dubai is fallacious. It is the equivalent of saying that sexual repression inspired the European Enlightenment.

headline: Militants Divide Kenya Miners by Religion, Then Begin Killing
abstract: It was the second such massacre in northern Kenya in the past month. The Shabab militant group took responsibility.
lead_paragraph: The Kenyan miners were marched off in the predawn dark on Tuesday, some barefoot, others shirtless.

headline: 2 Educators Face Charges of Sexual Assault in Indonesia
abstract: Two staff members at a prestigious international school appeared in court on Tuesday in a case that their defense team has said is completely fabricated.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Two educators at one of Indonesia’s most prestigious international schools appeared in court on Tuesday to hear charges that they sexually assaulted several kindergarten students, in a high-profile case that their defense team and the school have said is completely fabricated.

headline: Zambia and Zimbabwe Grapple With Political Turmoil
abstract: In Zimbabwe, President Robert Mugabe is seeking to extend his 34-year tenure, while in Zambia, the governing party is split ahead of elections.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ever since colonial cartographers drew their common frontier across the Zambezi River, Zambia and Zimbabwe have shared an uneasy destiny: landlocked nations, onetime adversaries and now mirror images of political uncertainty.

headline: Taiwan’s President Resigning as Party Chief After Election Losses
abstract: The Kuomintang suffered heavy losses in voting on Saturday, leaving it in control of just six of Taiwan’s 22 counties and municipalities.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan will step down on Wednesday as chairman of the governing party, the Kuomintang, following its crushing defeat in local elections, the party announced Tuesday.

headline: Daily Report: Shortfall at Amazon Is a Calculated Sacrifice
abstract: Though the company’s third-quarter revenue fell short of forecasts, it is making moves to become a retail and entertainment one-stop shop.
lead_paragraph: Sometime last summer, a quarter-billion dollars went missing at Amazon, David Streitfeld reports.

headline: Otsuka of Japan to Buy Avanir Pharmaceuticals for $3.5 Billion
abstract: Otsuka said it would pay $17 a share in cash for Avanir, a California-based developer of treatments for Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s and other neurological diseases.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Japanese pharmaceutical giant Otsuka Holdings said on Tuesday that it had struck a deal to buy Avanir Pharmaceuticals of California, a developer of treatments for Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s and other neurological diseases, for $3.54 billion.

headline: A Fishing Lure So Effective, It Catches Criticism
abstract: Andy Poss’s Alabama Rig lure was banned by organizers of the country’s two major bass fishing competitions because some professional anglers felt it could be too effective.
lead_paragraph: The device is composed of five wires angled like spokes of an umbrella, with fishing lures attached to each end. It mimics a school of baitfish, and bass, walleye and northern pike apparently cannot stay away from it.

headline: Reporting Sexual Assault Is Difficult, but a New Technology May Help
abstract: A nonprofit seeks to encourage victims to come forward online and identify serial perpetrators who might otherwise go undetected.
lead_paragraph: One of the key factors driving the growing scandal surrounding Bill Cosby is shared awareness of the numerous rape allegations against him, which has prompted media companies and his beloved Temple University to distance themselves from him while encouraging new accusers to come forward.

headline: On Doing Real Work, Defining the Role of a Leader and Getting Paid
abstract: What would Deming say about those unfinished parts sitting around on a pallet?
lead_paragraph: First, I want to let you know that the big customer who couldn’t pay us has sent payment in full! Yes, I’m thrilled. Will this customer send more work? My prediction is it will. Time will tell.

headline: Bugs in Manhattan Compete With Rats for Food Refuse
abstract: A new study has found that millions of tiny insects are potentially consuming the equivalent of 60,000 frankfurters a year on a stretch of 150 blocks of median strips in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Every New Yorker has seen it — a rat nosing through a potato chip bag on the subway tracks, a pigeon dodging traffic while pecking at a pizza crust, a squirrel diffidently approaching the remains of a turkey sandwich abandoned on a park bench. But it turns out that these enthusiastic garbage collectors are not the only animals cleaning up the mess we make.

headline: Egyptian Court Drops Charges Against Mubarak
abstract: All legal action against the former president of Egypt, Hosni Mubarak, has ended.
lead_paragraph: All legal action against the former president of Egypt, Hosni Mubarak, has ended.

headline: The Divorce Surge Is Over, but the Myth Lives On
abstract: The high divorce rate of the late 1970s and early 1980s is starting to look like a historical anomaly, not a trend.
lead_paragraph: When Gwyneth Paltrow and Chris Martin “consciously uncoupled” this year, ABC News said it was the latest example of the out-of-control divorce rate, “50 percent and climbing.”

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Nov. 25-Dec. 1, 2014
abstract: Have you been following the news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more, and look for a new edition each week on Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: Have you been following the news?

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: President Obama’s immigration action faces the Congressional spotlight.
lead_paragraph: G.O.P. Makes Its Agenda Clear at 2 House Immigration Hearings

headline: Morning Agenda: Using Pay to Encourage Public Service
abstract: Encouraging public service, through the revolving door. | Web thieves are taking aim at the pharmaceutical industry. | Law schools battle for top students. | Lending club sets price range for I.P.O.
lead_paragraph: USING PAY TO ENCOURAGE PUBLIC SERVICE | A recent letter sent to the boards of Wall Street’s biggest banks has created quite a stir within the halls of banks and parts of corporate America, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook Column.
