lead_paragraph: If the term “international community” is to have any meaning, it should denote the shared responsibility of all nations to assist people forced to flee their countries and lose their livelihood through no fault of their own.

headline: Bobby Keys, Hard-Living Saxophonist for Rolling Stones, Dies at 70
abstract: Mr. Keys was a self-taught musician who never learned to read music but recorded with a Who’s Who of rock. One of his most memorable moments was a howling solo on “Brown Sugar.”
lead_paragraph: Bobby Keys, a Texas-born sideman whose urgent, wailing saxophone solos wove a prominent thread through more than 40 years of rock ’n’ roll, notably with the Rolling Stones, died on Tuesday at his home in Franklin, Tenn. He was 70.

headline: Lessons From a Stairwell Shooting
abstract: To prevent another tragedy like the shooting death of an unarmed man by a police officer in a Brooklyn public housing building, revise the New York Police Department’s weapons policy.
lead_paragraph: The death of Akai Gurley, who was shot by a police officer patrolling a Brooklyn public housing building, shows why the Police Department needs to revise its weapons policy.

headline: On Immigration, a Huge Job Ahead
abstract: Getting the resources required to handle the millions of families navigating the immigration bureaucracy and justice system is the next crisis coming.
lead_paragraph: There is an immigration crisis looming, but it’s not at the border. It will be hitting in offices and courtrooms, and be measured in mountains of paper and strained bank accounts, in long lines and delays. It will be caused by the critical shortage of lawyers and other legal assistance for families navigating the immigration bureaucracy and justice system.

headline: In Midst of California’s Drought, a Rainy Day Is a Welcome Sight
abstract: The drenching rainstorm that settled in California on Tuesday came as the state wheezed its way into the fourth year of the worst drought in centuries.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — This might be the only state in the nation where a rainy day — complete with blinding sheets of water, shoe-sopping flooded intersections and chalk gray skies — puts people in a good mood.

headline: Christie’s Pig-Crate Politics
abstract: The governor’s veto of a bill that would ban gestation crates probably plays less well in New Jersey than in ... oh, let’s say Iowa.
lead_paragraph: I don’t know how Chris Christie plans to become president, but then again no one could have predicted George W. Bush, or for that matter Barack Obama, so we know that stranger things have happened. In any case, I’d love to see the guy’s political prospects fall apart over pork, and not the kind you’re thinking of. Rather, I’m hoping he’ll become a primary example of how reactionary food policy will no longer play.

headline: Grand Jury in Chokehold Death of Eric Garner Could Vote This Week on Charges
abstract: The death of Mr. Garner on Staten Island in July inflamed tensions between New York’s minority communities and the police.
lead_paragraph: A police union lawyer said a Staten Island grand jury could vote as early as Wednesday on whether to bring charges in the case of Eric Garner, whose death in July from a police chokehold prompted protests and set off a citywide debate over policing tactics.

headline: Jimmy Iovine, of Beats and Apple, Is Named to Live Nation’s Board
abstract: The move extends Mr. Iovine’s wide reach in entertainment and technology.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Iovine, the record executive who joined Apple this year as part of its $3 billion purchase of Beats, has joined the board of Live Nation Entertainment, the company announced on Tuesday.

headline: Following the Victoria’s Secret and Chanel Fashion Shows
abstract: If you follow models on Instagram, your feed was probably filled with looks from the Victoria’s Secret and Chanel fashion shows. Here are some behind-the-scenes photos from Instagram.
lead_paragraph: If you follow models on Instagram, your feed was probably filled with looks from the Victoria’s Secret and Chanel fashion shows. In London, a Taylor Swift, scantily clad in lingerie, seemed to be everyone’s BFF with kissy faces to go around, while in Austria, Cara Delevingne and Kendall Jenner walked the Chanel runway holding hands. Here are some behind-the-scenes looks from today’s fashion events:

headline: Patrick Suppes, Pioneer in Computerized Learning, Dies at 92
abstract: In 1966, almost a decade before the invention of the personal computer, he predicted that children would have access to personal tutors “as well informed and as responsive as Aristotle.”
lead_paragraph: Almost a decade before the invention of the personal computer, Patrick Suppes, a Stanford philosopher, sketched a vision of the democratic future of computerized education.

headline: Gets the Team Together
abstract: Patrick Blindauer gets us over the midweek blues.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Free Puzzle Book Alert! Puzzazz has a free e-book of Hangman riddle puzzles called “Jumping to Conclusions,” written by Bruce Leban and available as a ‘thank you’ to their customers and supporters. Click here for more information about how to download it.

headline: A Gay Mayor in Poland? No Big Deal
abstract: The victory of a gay candidate amounts to a sea change in conservative Poland, where the Catholic Church wields enormous political power.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — In the end, the fact that Robert Biedron is one of Poland’s most prominent gay-rights activists seemed to play almost no role in his election as the new mayor of Slupsk, a conservative city of 97,000 near the Pomeranian coast.

headline: From Particle Physics to the Pentagon
abstract: Ashton B. Carter, a theoretical physicist and former deputy defense secretary, is President Obama’s choice to be the next defense secretary.
lead_paragraph: Ashton B. Carter, a theoretical physicist and former deputy defense secretary, is President Obama’s choice to be the next defense secretary.

headline: Magazine’s Account of Gang Rape on Virginia Campus Comes Under Scrutiny
abstract: An article in Rolling Stone magazine has come under scrutiny for its reporting methods, even as the University of Virginia and the local police investigate the events the article described.
lead_paragraph: An article in Rolling Stone magazine about an alleged gang rape on the campus of the University of Virginia has come under scrutiny for its reporting methods, even as the university and the local police investigate the events the article described.

headline: New York Plan Aims to Divert Mentally Ill People From Jail’s Revolving Door
abstract: Supporters of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plan to expand supervised release and treatment programs said one key was to identify troubled offenders early.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to walk the halls of the Criminal Courts Building in Manhattan without encountering stories of crimes committed by people with mental illnesses. On Monday, two separate murder cases were being tried against men who had presented evidence they were psychotic when they stabbed their victims to death.

headline: Kent Haruf, Acclaimed Novelist of Small-Town Life, Is Dead at 71
abstract: Mr. Haruf’s breakthrough novel was “Plainsong,” which was nominated for the National Book Award.
lead_paragraph: Kent Haruf pulled a wool cap over his eyes when he sat down at his manual typewriter each morning so he could “write blind,” fully immersing himself in the fictitious small town in eastern Colorado where he set a series of quiet, acclaimed novels, including “Plainsong,” a 1999 best seller. Mr. Haruf often wrote a chapter a day, most recently in a prefabricated shed in the backyard of his home in Salida, Colo., where he died on Sunday at 71.

headline: U.S. Holds America’s Cup but Won’t Be Host
abstract: Instead of meeting the challenge on its home waters, the United States team elected to do so in Bermuda.
lead_paragraph: The America’s Cup has generated some strange partnerships and situations in its 163 years. A yacht club from landlocked Switzerland once won the Cup in New Zealand with a crew full of New Zealanders. Another Cup match was an unfair fight between a big, single-hulled boat and a nimble, wing-masted catamaran.

headline: Obama Calls for Ebola Research Funding
abstract: On a visit to the National Institutes of Health, President Obama praised the work of researchers there and stressed the need for Congress to continue funding their research on Ebola treatments.
lead_paragraph: On a visit to the National Institutes of Health, President Obama praised the work of researchers there and stressed the need for Congress to continue funding their research on Ebola treatments.

headline: Report Says Cyberattacks Originated Inside Iran
abstract: A security firm identified Iranian hackers as the source of coordinated attacks against more than 50 targets in 16 countries, many of them corporate and government entities.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Iranian hackers were identified in a report released Tuesday as the source of coordinated attacks against more than 50 targets in 16 countries, many of them corporate and government entities that manage critical energy, transportation and medical services.

headline: Brumsic Brandon Jr., Creator of ‘Luther’ Strip, Dies at 87
abstract: “Luther” was one of the first nationally syndicated comic strips set in a black urban neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Brumsic Brandon Jr., the creator of “Luther,” one of the first nationally syndicated comic strips to feature a mainly black cast of characters, died on Nov. 28 in Cocoa Beach, Fla. He was 87.

headline: Matthew and Grace Huang, Cleared in Daughter’s Death, Are Set to Leave Qatar
abstract: Officials offered assurances that the couple would be allowed to leave the country after an appellate court exonerated them in the 2013 death of their 8-year-old girl.
lead_paragraph: Matthew and Grace Huang, the American couple in Qatar exonerated in the death of their adopted African daughter after a nearly two-year prosecution collapsed on appeal, were preparing to fly home on Wednesday. Qatari and United States officials, including Secretary of State John Kerry, offered assurances that all bureaucratic entanglements that had blocked the couple’s departure for three days had been resolved.

headline: Jets Took Ground Game on a Road to Nowhere
abstract: Coach Rex Ryan said Tuesday that the lack of a passing game in Monday’s loss to Miami was not because of a lack of confidence in quarterback Geno Smith.
lead_paragraph: Still the Jets’ coach, Rex Ryan was asked Tuesday whether he learned anything the night before about Geno Smith.

headline: Home Invasions Stoke Fears Among Indian-Americans in New Jersey
abstract: Four robberies in Middlesex County took place during or just after the Hindu festival of Diwali, when families often have gold jewelry on hand as part of their celebration.
lead_paragraph: EDISON, N.J. — Neetu Singh was headed for the trash with a diaper from her 4-year-old son. She made her way from the family room to the back porch of her home in this Middlesex County suburb.

headline: Gift From Giants Chairman to Help School Football Programs Respond to Head Injuries
abstract: A $1.2 million donation from Steve Tisch, an owner of the N.F.L. team, will pay to have trainers or emergency medical technicians at all contact practices for New York City’s public high schools.
lead_paragraph: For decades, a powerfully built football player tottering on his feet was considered just a part of the game. But increasingly, potential signals of a head injury, like that stagger, are considered dangerous warning signs that should be scouted for on every level of the sport.

headline: Big Law Firms Bring Back Hefty Bonuses for Associates
abstract: Associates at large law firms in New York are taking home bonuses this year of $15,000 to $100,000, or more, depending on their tenure.
lead_paragraph: Law firms are again paying big annual bonuses to lawyers who have put in years of working long hours on corporate deal documents, litigation papers and complex contracts.

headline: Netanyahu Calls Early Election
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel dismissed two of his cabinet ministers who had attacked government policies, and called an early parliamentary election.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel dismissed two of his cabinet ministers who had attacked government policies, and called an early parliamentary election.

headline: No Rivalry Here: Nets Prevail in Lethargic Game at the Garden
abstract: In a battle between two clubs desperate for a victory — any victory — the Nets dispatched the Knicks in front of a listless sellout crowd at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: The win will count, even if the basketball was ugly, even if the arena was generally lifeless, even if the two teams afterward remained flawed and unfinished projects.

headline: China Slips in Corruption Perceptions Report
abstract: Beijing’s campaign against graft has netted thousands of officials, but the perception of China as a deeply corrupt country is only rising, according to a watchdog group.
lead_paragraph: China’s very public campaign against graft has netted thousands of officials both big and small — “tigers” and “flies,” in Communist Party parlance — but the perception of China as a deeply corrupt country is only rising, according to a leading watchdog group.

headline: COS, Purveyor of Affordable Minimalism, Takes Manhattan
abstract: After launching online and in Los Angeles, H&M’s higher-end conceptual brand is at last coming to New York.
lead_paragraph: A step above (but conceptually beyond) the Topshops and Zaras of the world, COS — H&M’s higher-end brand of minimalist men’s and women’s clothing — will finally open its doors in New York City this Friday. For years available only overseas (which added to its cachet), COS launched a United States e-commerce site in May and debuted its first United States store in Beverly Hills at the end of October. Now, the much-hyped Spring Street location will feature 4,950 square feet of space with details like raw steel racks, concrete and glass — an industrial look that mirrors the functionality and clean lines of the clothing.

headline: The Revelry and Luxury of Art Basel Miami Beach
abstract: An estimated 75,000 guests will attend this year’s edition of the Swiss art fair’s younger, hipper, rowdier sibling. Here, more statistics from art’s biggest party.
lead_paragraph: An estimated 75,000 guests will descend upon Miami Beach for four days this week for another edition of Art Basel, which starts Thursday. Now in its 13th year, the Switzerland art fest’s younger, hipper, rowdier sibling has become a can’t-miss event on the calendars of the 600-some galleries that angle to be amongst its stalls, as well as for the countless celebrities and hangers-on that come to revel in the scene. It has also transformed Miami Beach — a place where, as the comedian Lenny Bruce once said, “neon goes to die” — into something of an art juggernaut, with countless new galleries and over 30 satellite fairs springing up in its wake, a place where high-powered buyers can throw down millions on a single purchase, and where art bros can pick up an Ai Weiwei-designed skateboard for the price of a plane ticket from LAX. Here, a brief look at the champagne and Chagalls of art’s biggest party.

headline: Fashion’s Romance With Red
abstract: As the holidays approach, indulging in the irony of the hue feels absolutely delightful.
lead_paragraph: As the holidays approach, indulging in the irony of the hue feels absolutely delightful.

headline: There's Something About Quvenzhanè
abstract: Roller skates, pizza, math class and an Oscar nomination: the life of an 11-year-old movie star.
lead_paragraph: Roller skates, pizza, math class and an Oscar nomination: the life of an 11-year-old movie star.

headline: Run to Stay Young
abstract: Running may reverse aging in certain ways, a noteworthy new study of active older people finds, while walking does not.
lead_paragraph: Running may reverse aging in certain ways while walking does not, a noteworthy new study of active older people finds. The findings raise interesting questions about whether most of us need to pick up the pace of our workouts in order to gain the greatest benefit.

headline: Word of the Day | longevity
abstract: This word has appeared in 323 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: longevity •\län-ˈje-və-te, lȯn-\• noun

headline: Middle-Class Pay Elusive for Teachers, Report Says
abstract: While higher salaries can be reached relatively early in some districts, in others it can take more than three decades to get there, the National Council on Teacher Quality says.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of their careers, teachers in certain cities earn far less than those in others and reach the top of the pay scale far later, making it hard for them to live a basic middle-class life, according to a new report being released Wednesday.

headline: 10-Year-Old Girl Dies After Two Are Struck in Brooklyn
abstract: The pregnant mother of the 10-year-old was taken to the hospital in stable condition, and later gave birth.
lead_paragraph: A 10-year-old girl died and her pregnant mother was injured after a minivan struck them in Brooklyn on Tuesday night, the police said.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (NBC) CHRISTMAS IN ROCKEFELLER CENTER In this 82nd tree-lighting ceremony, Mariah Carey, Lady Gaga, Tony Bennett, Cyndi Lauper, Billy Porter, Seth MacFarlane, Sara Bareilles, Idina Menzel, Pentatonix, LeAnn Rimes, Prince Royce, Darius Rucker and Trisha Yearwood will gather around an 85-foot-tall Norway spruce. Donated by Dan Sigafoos and Rachel Drosdick-Sigafoos of Danville, Pa., the 90-year-old tree will be covered with 45,000 LED lights and topped with a Swarovski crystal star through Jan. 7. The tree will then be milled for lumber for Habitat for Humanity. The Rockettes will put a little kick into the festivities, presided over by Matt Lauer, Savannah Guthrie, Al Roker and Natalie Morales of the “Today” show. A preview show begins at 7. “SNL Christmas,” at 9, features holiday sketches from “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: Jean Béliveau, Leader of Canadiens and a Hero to Canadians, Dies at 83
abstract: Béliveau, one of the greatest centers in N.H.L. history, was an icon in Canada, and he led Montreal to 10 Stanley Cups in his playing career.
lead_paragraph: Jean Béliveau, the powerful, elegant skater and goal scorer who was an idol in French-speaking Quebec from the time he was a teenager and, shortly thereafter, in the rest of Canada for his leadership of hockey’s greatest dynasty, the Montreal Canadiens, died on Tuesday. He was 83.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, December 3, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, December 3, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “This was like a home invasion where after taking the family jewels the hackers set the house ablaze.”

headline: An Addict on the Jade Trail to China
abstract: Kung Hpan, 27, a sometime-law student and full-time heroin addict in Myanmar, first stops by a friend’s house to get high, then he heads to the jade mines to work so he can pay for it.
lead_paragraph: In “Jade’s Journey Market by Drugs and Death,” The New York Times video journalist Jonah M. Kessel documents the human toll of jade’s journey from the mines of Myanmar to China’s consumers.

headline: Test Yourself | A New Sports Dance Craze
abstract: Here are the first eight paragraphs from a Dec. 1 article, “Nae Nae, Dance That Swept the World, Has a Sequel.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are the first eight paragraphs from a Dec. 1 article, “Nae Nae, Dance That Swept the World, Has a Sequel.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Math That Pursues, Spins and Swarms
abstract: Which robot mode sounds the most interesting to you? Why?
lead_paragraph: In the article “Math That Pursues, Spins and Swarms,” Helene Stapinski writes about a new exhibit at the National Museum of Mathematics.

headline: 3 Hong Kong Protest Leaders Turn Themselves In
abstract: The gesture was mainly symbolic because no arrest warrants have been issued for the Occupy Central leaders.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Three founders of a Hong Kong protest movement surrendered to the police on Wednesday, in a gesture meant to press the government to face up to demands for free elections and to coax demonstrators into abandoning street camps that have become increasingly exhausted and divided.

headline: Funeral of Phillip Hughes, Australian Cricket Star, Prompts Outpouring of Grief
abstract: Hughes, 25, who was killed by a speeding cricket ball last week, was buried in his hometown north of Sydney at a ceremony that drew a global following.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Thousands of Australians, including Prime Minister Tony Abbott, took part in a national outpouring of grief Wednesday during the funeral of Phillip Hughes, a 25-year-old cricket star who died last week after being hit by a speeding ball in what was depicted as a freakish accident.

headline: Cyrus Vance Jr.’s ‘Moneyball’ Approach to Crime
abstract: The district attorney of New York County believes you can get crime rates to zero — if you just look hard enough at the numbers.
lead_paragraph: A glance at New York City crime statistics might lead you to conclude that Cyrus Vance Jr., the district attorney of New York County, no longer works in what William Travers Jerome, who held the job more than a century ago, once called “the mouth of hell.” Nowhere have declining crime trends been more striking than in Manhattan, where last year burglaries, shootings and murders were the lowest since the city began keeping formal records in the early 1960s; so far this year, statistically speaking, the epidemic of civility rages on. It’s still a shock — where did Gotham go, the dangerous dark of nighttime Central Park, the East Village addicts brandishing box cutters, the cardsharps and sallow denizens of Times Square, which now seems overrun by Elmo impersonators and wide-eyed naïfs in fanny packs?

headline: My Great-Great-Aunt Discovered Francium. And It Killed Her.
abstract: 75 years ago, Marguerite Perey unearthed an element on the periodic table while working as a technician in Marie Curie’s lab. Her achievement came at a great cost.
lead_paragraph: Just after Christmas of 1938, a young woman named Marguerite Perey — then 29, with a plain, open face, her eyes intent upon her work — sat at a bench in the Radium Institute of Paris, a brick mansion near the Jardin du Luxembourg. In a glass vessel, she examined fluid containing metal salts. She carefully dosed it with lead and hydrogen sulfide, then with barium, causing the solution to separate into different substances. She was in the final stages of purifying actinium, one of the rarest and most dangerous elements yet discovered, from uranium ore. Ten tons of ore yielded just one or two milligrams of actinium; Perey, who joined the institute as a teenager to be the personal technician for Marie Curie, was an expert in its isolation.

headline: Will Wearable Technology Ever Really Catch On?
abstract: Would you want a pair of Google’s computer glasses? Would you want an Apple Watch? Is wearable technology something you’re ready to embrace? Why?
lead_paragraph: Google rolled out a test edition of its much hyped Google Glass in spring 2013, and this September Apple announced the coming of Apple Watch. But while the public waits for a general consumer release of these products, other companies, like Samsung and Sony, already have smartwatches on the market.

headline: Sharing and Liking Photos From Day 1
abstract: A major exhibit of the New York Public Library’s vast photo collection is a reminder that photography has always been a social medium.
lead_paragraph: With more than almost 5 million photos, the New York Public Library boasts a wide-ranging collection that would be the envy of any museum: from 19th century cyanotypes of algae, handcrafted scrapbooks and cartes-de-visite, to classic Farm Security Administration photos, movie location pictures and contemporary digital art.

headline: Few Clues in Chinese Editor’s Detention
abstract: The news of the detention of a mild-mannered editor on national security charges has unsettled many intellectuals and activists in Beijing. It has also added to fears that, increasingly, you don’t have to be a political firebrand to be detained.
lead_paragraph: Even amid a hardening crackdown on civil society and rights activists in China, many journalists and writers were caught off guard when Xu Xiao, a mild-mannered culture and books editor at Caixin Media magazine, was taken away last week by the Beijing police on suspicion of “endangering national security.”

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: The Year in Crime
abstract: Wednesday: A decline in crime, wet weather, and the Rockefeller Christmas tree lights up.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this wet Wednesday.

headline: Amnesty Report Condemns Police Torture in Philippines
abstract: Amnesty International says the police continue to abuse and degrade suspects despite a national effort to stem the practice.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The Philippine police continue to torture and degrade suspects despite a national effort to stem the practice, according to a new report from the human rights group Amnesty International.

headline: North Korea Has Room for Only One Jong-un
abstract: South Korean officials say North Korea, under Kim Jong-un, has formally barred anyone from having the name Jong-un, forcing those already with the name to give it up.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Plenty is off limits to North Koreans. Televisions that receive anything other than government broadcasts. Traveling outside their hometowns without official permission. And Bibles.

headline: A Start-Up That Helps Owners Build a Website for a Subscription Business
abstract: To a business owner, few things are more alluring than recurring revenue.
lead_paragraph: The Pitch: For e-commerce entrepreneurs, few things are more alluring than the recurring revenue of a subscription business model. Think BirchBox, which sends out monthly boxes of beauty and grooming products, or NatureBox, which ships boxes of nutritionist-approved snacks. But it can cost hundreds of thousands of dollars for a start-up to build a website that can handle subscription renewals and automatic payments and also help customers control their preferences. Now a start-up called Cratejoy is offering entrepreneurs — even those with no technical skills — the ability to create their own subscription platform for far less money.

headline: Notable Children’s Books of 2014
abstract: The best in picture books, middle grade and young adult fiction and nonfiction, selected by the children’s book editor of The New York Times Book Review.
lead_paragraph: The best in picture books, middle grade and young adult fiction and nonfiction, selected by the children’s book editor of The New York Times Book Review.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: Republicans are ready to put out the welcome mat for the man Mr. Obama is expected to pick as defense secretary.
lead_paragraph: Senate Prepares to Greet a Defense Dept. Nominee With Open Arms

headline: Daily Report: Hackers Steal Movies and Executive Salary Data From Sony
abstract: The breach exposed two things the movie industry loathes — the piracy of films and details about executive compensation — and sent a ripple of dread across Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: Just as Sony Pictures Entertainment appeared to be recovering from a crippling online attack last month, the studio found itself confronting new perils on Tuesday. The Federal Bureau of Investigation warned American businesses of a similar threat, and additional Sony secrets were leaked online, Brooks Barnes and Nicole Perlroth report.

headline: Q. and A. With Charles Evans of the Fed: Low Inflation Is the Primary Concern
abstract: The Fed official, who successfully pushed in 2012 for more action to reduce unemployment, warns that interest rates must not be raised prematurely.
lead_paragraph: Charles Evans, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, is nervous about inflation. His worry, however, is not the old Fed fear that prices are rising too quickly, but the new Fed fear that prices are not rising fast enough.

headline: Ukraine Reports Nuclear Plant Accident, but Official Says There’s ‘No Threat’
abstract: The announcement set off fears of a Chernobyl-like catastrophe, but there appeared to have been no radiation leak and only a temporary disruption to power.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Prime Minister Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk of Ukraine on Wednesday announced that there had been an accident at one of the country’s nuclear power plants, briefly setting off fears of a Chernobyl-like catastrophe. But there appeared to have been no radiation leak and only a temporary disruption in the power supply.

headline: Paycheck to Paycheck
abstract: The Vories family lives on a volatile income — not knowing how much each paycheck will contain month-to-month. In tough times, Alex Vories borrows his father’s car to deliver pizzas at night.
lead_paragraph: The Vories family lives on a volatile income — not knowing how much each paycheck will contain month-to-month. In tough times, Alex Vories borrows his father’s car to deliver pizzas at night.

headline: Morning Agenda: Big Law Bolsters Bonuses
abstract: Big law firms are bringing back hefty bonuses for associates. | A scramble to fix Europe’s banks. | Bank of New York Mellon gives a board seat to the Trian Fund. | How the bond king lost his empire.
lead_paragraph: BIG LAW BOLSTERS BONUSES | Big paydays for lawyers are back. Law firms are again paying hefty annual bonuses to lawyers who have put in years of working long hours on corporate deal documents, litigation papers and complex contracts, Matthew Goldstein writes in DealBook. Associates working at a large law firm in New York are taking home, on average, from $15,000 to $100,000 in bonus payments, depending on their tenure. The top bonuses being doled out by law firms are roughly $40,000 more than most big New York firms handed out to their most senior associates last year.

headline: 1939: Princess Louise Dies in London
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: 1939: Princess Louise Dies in London, Oldest Surviving Child of Queen Victoria.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Louise, oldest surviving child of Queen Victoria and oldest member of the British royal family, died at Kensington Palace at the age of ninety-one years today. At the outbreak of war last September, Princess Louise refused to leave London, declaring that she would stay there even if bombs rained on the city. At Kensington Palace, where she lived alone except for her old servants, there were no sandbags and no gummed paper on the windows. The princess merely had dark blue blinds that had seen service in the World War put up for the black-outs, while an underground tunnel near the kitchens served as an air-raid shelter. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Dec. 4, 1939

headline: Unsteady Incomes Keep Millions Behind on Bills
abstract: The Federal Reserve says that more than 30 percent of Americans report irregular incomes that sabotage efforts to budget and save. Unreliable work hours are cited most often.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Ky. — The bills arrive as regularly as a heartbeat at the Vories’s cozy bi-level brick house just across the Ohio River from Cincinnati. It’s the paychecks that are irregular.

headline: From Russia, a Front-Runner That Implicitly Criticizes Putin
abstract: Observers were surprised when Russia submitted Andrey Zvyagintsev’s “Leviathan” as its foreign-language contender.
lead_paragraph: Though the Russian director Andrey Zvyagintsev’s “Leviathan” won a prize for best screenplay at the Cannes Film Festival in May, his film’s reception back home was far less enthusiastic.

lead_paragraph: Though the Academy Awards won’t be handed out until Feb. 22, Oscar season is already upon us, and The New York Times has appointed a new Bagger — see byline — to navigate this fevered, outrageously expensive annual arms race.

lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Luxottica, the Italian eyewear behemoth, and Intel, the American technology giant, announced a partnership for the research and development of tech-infused glasses that both signals a new stage in the wearables revolution and shows the brands staking their claims as the most tech-forward fashion company and the most fashion-aware tech company.

headline: British Treasury Chief Reports Strong Growth, but Deficit Is ‘Too High’
abstract: Measures announced by George Osborne included a 25 percent profit tax on multinationals in Britain with offshore tax structures.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Still battling to clean up Britain’s public finances, George Osborne, the chancellor of the Exchequer, on Wednesday offered limited giveaways to Britons but claimed credit for delivering them rapid economic growth. It was his last big economic policy statement before the country’s national election next spring.

headline: Return of Focus Hocus Pocus
abstract: Governing is more than theater.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been getting correspondence from people saying that I need to respond to Tom Edsall channeling Chuck Schumer on how health reform was a mistake, Obama should have focused on the economy.

abstract: The three co-founders of the Occupy Central pro-democracy movement in Hong Kong turned themselves in to the police on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The three co-founders of the Occupy Central pro-democracy movement in Hong Kong turned themselves in to the police on Wednesday.

headline: Israeli Lawmakers Begin Winding Down Parliament
abstract: The motions came a day after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu fired his finance minister and his justice minister, and called for early elections.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A bill to dissolve Parliament passed its first reading on Wednesday as Israeli lawmakers began preparations for early elections now scheduled for March 17.

headline: What’s Your Pick for Best Picture?
abstract: Let us know whether you agree with choices like “Birdman” and “Boyhood,” or would go with something else altogether.
lead_paragraph: Three critics groups, three different best-picture nods: “Boyhood,” “Birdman” and “A Most Violent Year” each have nabbed top honors, and the awards season is less than a week old. It could be proof that, as some are saying, it’s a wide-open year, or just a reflection of these particular organizations and nothing more.

headline: U.S. and Iran Both Attack ISIS, but Try Not to Look Like Allies
abstract: The strikes against the Islamic State represent an unusual confluence of interests in Iraq and Syria, where Tehran and Washington find themselves fighting the same enemy in an increasingly public fashion.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iranian fighter jets struck extremist targets in Iraq recently, Iranian and American officials have confirmed, in the latest display of Tehran’s new willingness to conduct military operations openly on foreign battlefields rather than covertly and through proxies.

headline: Land Mines Are Taking Smaller Toll, Group Says
abstract: The International Campaign to Ban Landmines attributed the drop to increased compliance with the Mine Ban Treaty, which was first signed 17 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Deaths and injuries from land mines and other explosive remnants of war fell to the lowest level ever recorded last year, and production of the weapons appeared to have practically ceased, a leading disarmament group reported on Wednesday.

headline: For China, Cybersecurity Is Part of Strategy for Protecting the Communist Party
abstract: A paper released by the Center for a New American Security in Washington concludes that China’s cybersecurity strategy, like its foreign policy, is driven mainly by the domestic political imperative to “protect the longevity of the Chinese Communist Party.”
lead_paragraph: For nearly two years, cyberespionage has been a tense focal point of relations between the United States and China. On Wednesday, the Center for a New American Security, a research group in Washington, released a paper written with the aim of understanding the motivations behind China’s cybersecurity strategy. Its conclusion: that the strategy, like China’s foreign policy, is driven mainly by the domestic political imperative of needing to “protect the longevity of the Chinese Communist Party.”

headline: Viscerally Facing Up to Ferguson
abstract: In a reminder of hip-hop’s politically potent past, two performers strike a chord by sharing their emotions on a shooting in Ferguson, Mo.
lead_paragraph: There are few arguments more tiresome than the one over hip-hop’s political potential. It begins something like this: Hip-hop’s turn away from the socially conscious dates back to the early to mid-1990s, right around the time when Soundscan showed that hip-hop was truly integral to this country’s pop music. Over time, as hip-hop became flush with success, the agitating in the form of sloganeering and the implicit politics of gangster rap that were once the norm became scarcer and scarcer.

headline: Honda to Expand Airbag Recall Nationwide as Takata Resists
abstract: The Japanese supplier has dug in its heels on efforts to expand recalls, and Honda said it planned a wider recall, regardless of Takata’s stance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as Takata, the Japanese auto supplier, continued to resist demands that it expand the recall of its airbags nationwide, Honda Motor told lawmakers on Wednesday that it would take that action on its own and use replacements from other suppliers if necessary.

headline: Exonerated in Qatar, American Couple Head Home
abstract: The American ambassador attended the departure of Matthew and Grace Huang and announced that they were “wheels up” on her Twitter account.
lead_paragraph: Matthew and Grace Huang, the American couple in Qatar exonerated in the death of their adopted African daughter after a nearly two-year prosecution collapsed on appeal, headed home to Los Angeles on Wednesday.

headline: How Our Taxi Article Happened to Undercut the Efficient Market Hypothesis
abstract: An article about the falling prices of taxi medallions helped cause a drop in a company’s stock price. That’s not supposed to happen.
lead_paragraph: If the stock market is efficient, why would a single Upshot article on taxicab medallion prices help push down Medallion Financial’s stock 7 percent in a single day, when most of the information in that article was already public?

headline: Genial Force Behind Bitter Opposition to Immigration Overhaul
abstract: Roy H. Beck is the leader of NumbersUSA, a small but powerful group that has helped scuttle every effort at an immigration overhaul for nearly two decades.
lead_paragraph: He keeps grade cards for every member of Congress, deploys three million activists to blast lawmakers with anti-immigration telephone calls, faxes and emails, and runs a website where his followers have called undocumented immigrants “criminal invaders” and “wolves at the door.”

headline: Jean-Marc Vallée Narrates a Scene From ‘Wild’
abstract: Jean-Marc Vallée narrates a sequence from the film featuring Reese Witherspoon and Mo McRae.
lead_paragraph: In this video, the director Jean-Marc Vallée narrates one of the lighter moments in “Wild,” featuring Reese Witherspoon and Mo McRae. The film is based on the memoir by Cheryl Strayed, about her over 1,000 hike along the Pacific Crest National Scenic Trail. Here, she takes a detour from the trail because of snowfall and tries to hitch a ride, with comic results.

headline: ‘Hope: Entertainer of the Century,’ by Richard Zoglin
abstract: Bruce Jay Friedman reviews an exhaustively researched biography of the comedian Bob Hope.
lead_paragraph: For all his brilliance, it’s hard to imagine a Steve Martin Airport. Yet there is a Bob Hope Airport in Burbank, Calif., a postage stamp with his likeness and streets all across America named after the comedian. The Navy called one of its ships the Bob Hope. (A Gilbert Gottfried naval destroyer? Sorry, babe, I don’t think so.)

headline: What Grown-Ups Are Missing About Boys
abstract: Girls’ social aggression gets a lot of attention, but new research suggests the problem may be even bigger in boys.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to mean or destructive social behavior, Pamela Orpinas says “so much of the research has focused on girls.” “We’ve had papers and books and qualitative analyses and focus groups” about the ways girls mistreat one another socially, the professor of health promotion and behavior told Op-Talk, “but we don’t know that much about boys.”

headline: ‘Jerry Lee Lewis: His Own Story,’ by Rick Bragg
abstract: Stephen King reviews Rick Bragg’s new book about the rock ‘n’ roll pioneer Jerry Lee Lewis.
lead_paragraph: Despite the title of Jerry Lee Lewis’s 2006 album “Last Man Standing,” a few other survivors from rock’s early days still remain. Chuck Berry, an old nemesis, is still around. So are Little Richard, Fats Domino and Wanda Jackson, the let’s-have-a-party girl who briefly dated Elvis Presley and shouted her own version of the Lewis anthem “Whole Lotta Shakin’ Goin’ On.” Still, Lewis is the summation of that early period, before cleaner-cut teen idols like Frankie Avalon and Fabian came on the scene. In Tolkien parlance, he’s the one ring that binds them, and as such, he deserves a rich and textured biography.

headline: For Tim David’s Next Trick, ‘Magic Words’ That Get People to Do What You Want
abstract: In a book review of “Magic Words,” Jonathan Knee examines the work of a professional magician-mentalist turned corporate motivational speaker who provides tools to help lawyers, bankers, consultants and others close deals.
lead_paragraph: Nothing is more likely to annoy investment bankers, corporate lawyers, management consultants and other service professionals than to suggest that they are salespeople. They did not survive graduate school and toil late nights of apprenticeship honing their craft to be considered mere peddlers.

headline: Greil Marcus’s ‘History of Rock ‘n’ Roll in Ten Songs’
abstract: Touré reviews Greil Marcus’s new book about songs that have been interpreted multiple times by artists in different generations.
lead_paragraph: Every great, enduring rock song is like a cell in our cultural memory. A molecule of our shared experience containing not just an incredible performance but also a shared desire for something — love, money, sex, peace, rebellion, power, freedom — some intensely held desire. But is a great, enduring rock song powered most by the song or the performance? Are we swooning because the song is so perfectly written that we can’t help singing along? Or is it the rendition that etches it into our minds? Or is it both — and more — since every song is a Proustian madeleine that evokes all our memories of the song and of the people we celebrated it with?

headline: Was Michael Brown a ‘Teenager’?
abstract: Some Times readers took issue with calling the 18-year-old what he was.
lead_paragraph: I wasn’t surprised by the—shall we say—vibrant comment section on a blog post I wrote highlighting Officer Darren Wilson’s description of shooting Michael Brown. After all, the events surrounding and following the shooting have been contentious.

headline: H. L. Mencken’s ‘Days Trilogy: Expanded Edition’
abstract: P. J. O’Rourke reviews an expanded edition of H. L. Mencken’s memoirs, a full picture of the man and his contradictions.
lead_paragraph: If we exclude Mark Twain, whose reminiscences suffered the rapine of fiction and whose attempt at autobiography is a mess, the three best memoir writers in American literature are H. L. Mencken.

headline: ‘So, Anyway . . . ,’ a Memoir by John Cleese
abstract: Michael Ian Black reviews a memoir by John Cleese, one of comedy’s most original minds.
lead_paragraph: Full disclosure: My reverence for Monty Python is nearly boundless. After I was force-fed a diet of mediocrity and cringe-worthy catchphrases from “Saturday Night Live” during my youth, discovering Monty Python’s freewheeling, surreal style felt like a revelation. You mean, sketches could just end? You mean, things didn’t need to make sense? You mean, you didn’t have to make fun of whatever celebrities were in the news right that very second? Why hadn’t anybody told me this before? I began watching them only years after they disbanded, but their comedy still felt fresher than anything I’d been exposed to. Even the name of the show, “Monty Python’s Flying Circus,” felt wild and anarchic, a dipsy collision of unrelated words more akin to Lewis Carroll than Lorne Michaels.

headline: Songs Sung From a Prison in Malawi
abstract: The record producer Ian Brennan spent 10 days gathering music from prisoners who can spend years without a trial.
lead_paragraph: Ian Brennan, a record producer known for his work with Lucinda Williams, Ramblin’ Jack Elliott and Richard Thompson, as well as African bands like Tinariwen, from northern Mali, and the Malawi Mouse Boys, has completed an unconventional project that will put a spotlight on a largely unexplored current of music – Malawian prison songs.

headline: CME Raises Bid for GFI Group as Hostile Counteroffer Looms
abstract: Under the revised bid, GFI shareholders would receive $5.25 a share in cash and shares, bolstered by a higher cash bid by a group led by GFI’s management for the company’s wholesale brokerage business.
lead_paragraph: The CME Group said late Tuesday that it had increased its offer to acquire the GFI Group, a New York brokerage and clearing house, after BGC Partners started a competing, hostile bid for the company in October.

headline: 1914: General De Wet Is Captured
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: 1914: The Rebel Leader, General De Wet, is Captured.
lead_paragraph: Official news from Pretoria announces the taking of the rebel leader De Wet. The capture was effected by Commandant Brits on Tuesday in a farm a hundred miles east of Mafeking, where De Wet had taken refuge with fifty-two of his men.

headline: Verizon Shuts Down SugarString, Site That Had Drawn Journalistic Criticism
abstract: SugarString ran afoul of the public when The DailyDot reported in October that an editor recruiting journalists was warning them that the site would forbid reporting on “spying and net neutrality.”
lead_paragraph: As journalism and corporate promotion merge, there have been many interesting experiments. Some work and some do not. This week one of the more controversial efforts, a site called SugarString which was backed by Verizon, was shut down.

headline: A Mix of Residents and Housing
abstract: The housing stock in Hartsdale, N.Y., about 20 miles north of Manhattan, runs the gamut from one-bedroom apartments to five-bedroom houses on nearly an acre.
lead_paragraph: When Jasleen Monga, a manager for a Chase bank branch in the village of Ardsley in lower Westchester, was searching for a home for herself “in a quiet and private neighborhood,” she said she never expected to find anything affordable within easy reach of her job.

headline: 1874: Struggling to Define the Mafia
abstract: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.
lead_paragraph: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: Inviting African-American Mothers to Sell Their Breast Milk, and Profiting
abstract: A company with no ties to Detroit’s African-American community plans to promote breast-feeding and economic empowerment among mothers by encouraging them to sell their excess breast milk.
lead_paragraph: What is a for-profit company with no African-American employees, no African-American board members and no meaningful connections to African-American mothers doing starting a campaign targeting low-income African-American mothers in Detroit to sell their breast milk under the promise of economic empowerment? That’s a question that deserves an answer, particularly since the company promoting this “pull yourself up by your own nursing bra straps” approach intends to sell that milk at a profit.

headline: First Draft Focus: Regarding Rights
abstract: The Supreme Court hears arguments regarding the Pregnancy Discrimination Act.

headline: Ukrainian Officials on Nuclear Accident
abstract: The Ukrainian prime minister, Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, and the energy minister, Volodymyr Demchyshyn, discussed the accident at the Zaporizhye Nuclear Power Plant in southeast Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian prime minister, Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, and the energy minister, Volodymyr Demchyshyn, discussed the accident at the Zaporizhye Nuclear Power Plant in southeast Ukraine.

headline: What You Get for ... $900,000
abstract: This week’s properties include a modern house in California and condos in Boston and Oregon.
lead_paragraph: PALM SPRINGS, CALIF.

headline: EQT and Goldman Funds Sell $676 Million Stake in Danish Outsourcing Company
abstract: The private placement was the second time that EQT and the Goldman funds have sold shares in the company since its initial public offering in March.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Danish outsourcing company ISS said on Wednesday that two of its largest shareholders – the Swedish private equity firm EQT Partners and funds advised by Goldman Sachs –  had sold a stake in the company worth about $676 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... British Columbia
abstract: The 2008 financial crisis hit Whistler, British Columbia, hard, but its housing market is improving, with a pickup in sales and modest but steady price increases.
lead_paragraph: A MODERN FIVE-BEDROOM HOUSE ON A LAKE IN WHISTLER

headline: Police Body Cameras Could Come to New York Soon
abstract: As communities across the nation wrestle with questions about police conduct, officers in several New York precincts could be wearing the cameras as early as Friday, Mayor Bill de Blasio said.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Wednesday that the New York Police Department was accelerating its efforts to outfit nearly every patrol officer on the force with body cameras.

headline: Missing Its Own Goals, Germany Renews Effort to Cut Carbon Emissions
abstract: As the nation lags in meeting its goals and businesses complain about global competition, Chancellor Angela Merkel promised to redouble efforts to reach her goal by 2020.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany has fallen behind in its ambitious goals for reducing carbon emissions. It is burning more coal than at any point since 1990. And German companies are complaining that the nation’s energy policies are hurting their ability to compete globally.

headline: 36 Hours in Phnom Penh
abstract: Explore street view, find our points of interest and sign in to your Google account to save your map.
lead_paragraph: Explore street view, find our points of interest and sign in to your Google account to save your map.

headline: U2 Announces a World Tour
abstract: The tour, which starts on May 14 in Vancouver, British Columbia, will to some extent be a test of the band’s continued drawing power.
lead_paragraph: U2 will embark on a 19-city, 44-date world tour next year, playing indoor arenas for the first time in almost a decade, Live Nation Entertainment, the band’s promoter, announced on Wednesday.

headline: Making History
abstract: With her civil rights movie, “Selma,” Ava DuVernay has done what few female directors get the opportunity to do: go large — with politics and history, with serious muscle.
lead_paragraph: On a swampy afternoon in late June, the director Ava DuVernay stood not far from the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Ala., that haunted place where, President Lyndon B. Johnson told the country, history and fate met. She was instructing a group of white extras on all the ugly things she wanted them to yell at the several hundred black extras snaking across the bridge, part of a sizable army of cast and crew that had been gathered together for “Selma,” her new movie about the campaign for black voter rights.

headline: Wall Street Nostalgia for Geithner
abstract: The warm welcome bank chieftains gave the former Treasury secretary was recognition that the current regime doesn’t have its heart in financial regulation, Rob Cox of Reuters Breakingviews says.
lead_paragraph: A week before Thanksgiving, Wall Street’s top brass were forced to reckon with an entirely new sensation: nostalgia for their former overlord, Timothy F. Geithner.

headline: Below the Line: Shooting ‘Interstellar’
abstract: The cinematographer Hoyte van Hoytema discusses his experimentation with the Imax camera for “Interstellar.”
lead_paragraph: Christopher Nolan’s “Interstellar” portrays space travel as both a grand and intimate adventure:  there are wide vistas and deep emotions. To help with creating these two levels, Mr. Nolan worked for the first time with the the Dutch-Swedish cinematographer Hoyte van Hoytema, whose credits include the Oscar-winning “Her” and “The Fighter.”

headline: A First Edition Auction, With the Writers Nervously Looking On
abstract: The evening sale’s high price: Philip Roth’s annotated first edition of “American Pastoral” sold for $80,000.
lead_paragraph: If there’s anything more embarrassing to writers than revisiting their early works, it’s finding out just how much their neurotic second-guessing of their younger selves is worth in cold hard cash.

headline: Execution Stayed in Case of Mental Illness Claim in Texas
abstract: An appeals panel said the court needed time to consider the larger issues surrounding the death sentence of a man whose lawyers say he suffered from schizophrenia for years before killing his in-laws.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — An appeals court panel in New Orleans on Wednesday stayed the execution of a Texas man in a case that has gained national attention as a test for issues surrounding mental illness.

headline: Wheelies: The Leaf Longevity Edition
abstract: Nissan says new battery technology will double the range of the Leaf E.V.; G.M. hires the former social media boss of Ford.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: From Afar, Still Defending New York’s Landmarks, and the Stories They Hold
abstract: For Nathan Silver, an architect and the author of “Lost New York,” how a building was used, and by whom, were almost as important as what the structure looked like.
lead_paragraph: If Alan Burnham’s “New York Landmarks” was a manifesto for the nascent preservation movement of the 1960s, Nathan Silver’s “Lost New York” was its elegiac poem.

headline: Obama Hopes for Cooler Heads on Immigration
abstract: President Obama is not optimistic that a bipartisan breakthrough will bring comprehensive immigration legislation to his desk any time soon.
lead_paragraph: President Obama is not optimistic that a bipartisan breakthrough will bring comprehensive immigration legislation to his desk any time soon.

headline: Bass Pro Shops to Add a Memphis Pyramid to Its Business Empire
abstract: The former arena for sports and concerts, which did not deliver the economic lift that the city expected when it was built, has been unused since 2007.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — For years, Memphis has been haunted by its Riddle of the Pyramid: What do you do with an empty 32-story glass-and-steel monument that was supposed to be this city’s answer to the Eiffel Tower or the Gateway Arch?

headline: House Plans Next Benghazi Hearing
abstract: The special House committee on the Benghazi attacks has set a hearing for next Wednesday on efforts to secure embassy facilities, calling two State Department officials as witnesses.
lead_paragraph: The special House committee on the Benghazi attacks has set a hearing for next Wednesday on efforts to secure embassy facilities, calling two State Department officials as witnesses.

headline: Sri Lankan Catholics Urge Pope Francis to Put Off Visit
abstract: Some Catholics, alarmed by President Mahinda Rajapksa’s attempts to imply papal support for his re-election, would like Francis to delay his visit to canonize a saint.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — A number of prominent Roman Catholic priests and laypeople in Sri Lanka are appealing to Pope Francis to put off a scheduled visit, saying the government is using the occasion as propaganda to imply the pope’s support for President Mahinda Rajapaksa, who is seeking an unprecedented third term in office.

headline: Formation 8, a Start-Up Aiming to Connect Silicon Valley With Asia, Raises $500 Million
abstract: In raising that pool of capital, Formation 8’s partners have emphasized that they can connect companies in the United States with potentially important counterparts in Asia.
lead_paragraph: With billions of dollars chasing Silicon Valley’s newest darlings, venture capital firms are becoming hard pressed to declare what sets them apart.

headline: See, Before That Night I Met You, I Was ... Well, It’s Kind of Complicated
abstract: “On a Stool at the End of the Bar,” by Robert Callely, follows a couple as they adjust to some surprising truths.
lead_paragraph: The marketing for “On a Stool at the End of the Bar,” the new drama by Robert Callely at 59E59 Theaters, studiously avoids giving away the pivotal fact of the play. At Sunday’s performance, the revelation of this secret provoked a smattering of nervous laughter and, from the woman in front of me, a soft, surprised “Ohhhhh!”

headline: Congress Saves Social Security From the Nazis
abstract: The bill, hardly a profile in courage, has led to excessive gas bagging.
lead_paragraph: Let me be clear: I do not believe that Nazi war criminals should get Social Security benefits.

headline: 36 Hours in Phnom Penh
abstract: Even as high rises transform the skyline, a comfortable intimacy can still be found in Phnom Penh’s tree-lined streets, tranquil pagodas, stylish restaurants and thriving local markets.
lead_paragraph: Even as high rises transform the skyline, a comfortable intimacy can still be found in Phnom Penh’s tree-lined streets, tranquil pagodas, stylish restaurants and thriving local markets.

headline: 36 Hours in Phnom Penh
abstract: Tranquil pagodas, thriving markets and a new wave of sleek bar options await visitors to the Cambodian capital.
lead_paragraph: On Norodom Boulevard, one of Phnom Penh’s oldest arteries, a huge, new LED screen dramatically outlines the tiered eaves of the Buddhist temple Wat Langka in shadow. Around the corner, the recently erected, towering statue of the late King Norodom Sihanouk, founding father of modern-day Cambodia, looks on as teenagers dressed like K-pop stars zip by on motorbikes, and uniformed officials in SUVs navigate the thronged streets. It’s this juxtaposition of traditional and modern life, of the enduring and the mutable, that defines the capital today. As high-rises transform the skyline, stylish restaurants serving food and drink that spans the globe have arrived. Yet, the city retains a provincial intimacy found in its tree-lined streets, tranquil pagodas and thriving local markets.

headline: Indian Official’s Firing Is Sought Over Remarks
abstract: Sadhvi Niranjan Jyoti, asked an audience “whether you want a government of those born of Ram, or those born illegitimately.” Ram is a Hindu god.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Opposition lawmakers in India pressed Prime Minister Narendra Modi to dismiss his junior minister for food processing industries Wednesday after she gave a speech interpreted by some as derogatory to non-Hindus.

headline: Group Cites Grim State of India’s Mentally Ill
abstract: Many women and girls with mental disabilities face facilities with unsanitary conditions, abuse and medication without consent, Human Rights Watch said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Women and girls with intellectual disabilities or mental illness in India are subject to forced institutionalization in sometimes overcrowded and unsanitary conditions, verbal and physical abuse, and medication without consent, according to a report released by Human Rights Watch on Wednesday.

headline: First Draft Focus: A Distinguished Guest on the House Floor
abstract: Representative Earl Blumenauer brought a special guest with him to the House floor on Wednesday for a one-minute speech on the gas tax. “I’m joined this afternoon today by Ronald Reagan,” Mr. Blumenauer said, recalling a radio address by the former president explaining why he doubled the gasoline tax.

headline: Today in Small Business: Pregnancy Discrimination
abstract: Private-sector hiring fell shy of estimates in November. There is big business in ugly Christmas sweaters. And the value of the world’s largest truffle.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: ‘Fool For Love’ Will Be Revived on Broadway
abstract: The production was a hit with critics last summer at the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: The Tony Award winner Nina Arianda (“Venus in Fur”) will return to Broadway in September in an acclaimed revival of Sam Shepard’s moody, bruising drama “Fool for Love” opposite film actor Sam Rockwell (“Confessions of a Dangerous Mind”), Manhattan Theater Club announced on Wednesday.

headline: As Start-Up Strategies Evolve, So Does Role of a Business Plan
abstract: While formal business plans can still be required to get a loan, more new companies are skipping creating one, considering it a relic of the old economy.
lead_paragraph: When Joanna Elkayam was laid off from a job selling bonds at Fidelity Investments in 2011, she had been working on a business plan for months. She wanted to open a spa with her husband, Avi, who already owned a successful hair salon.

headline: Reasons to Be Pretty Cheerful
abstract: “Every Brilliant Thing” arrives in New York with lots of good reviews and a high concept that sounds a bit mawkish.
lead_paragraph: If a theater produces enough quirky, surprising and successful work, it establishes a certain trust with an audience. You won’t necessarily like every show, but its track record means you’re more likely to be willing to take a risk with something new. Barrow Street Theater, the former home of “Buyer and Cellar,” “Tribes” and the long-form improv shows of TJ and Dave, has become one of those places.

headline: Anti-Semitic Attack Reported Near Paris
abstract: The French authorities said three masked men had robbed a young couple they believed to be Jewish and raped the woman.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Three men wearing masks forced their way into a home in a southeastern suburb of Paris this week, robbed a young couple they believed was Jewish and raped the woman, the French authorities said Wednesday.

headline: Iraq’s Leader Requests More Aid in Fight Against ISIS
abstract: Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi, in Brussels for a meeting of nearly 60 nations at NATO headquarters, said he needed aid for military training and reconstruction.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi of Iraq appealed for help on Wednesday in training his military and reconstructing towns and cities that Iraq hopes to wrest from the Islamic State’s control.

headline: Pop-Up and Interactive Children’s Books
abstract: “Is There a Dog in This Book?” by Viviane Schwarz, and more.
lead_paragraph: “Is There a Dog in This Book?” by Viviane Schwarz, and more.

headline: Seeing Visions of Stardom
abstract: Nneka Okafor, starring in Katori Hall’s “Our Lady of Kibeho,” talks about her star turn, religious experiences and Texas cuisine.
lead_paragraph: Nneka Okafor kneels onstage at the Signature Theater, arms outstretched, mouth agape, entranced by a vision of the Virgin Mary. In Katori Hall’s “Our Lady of Kibeho,” Ms. Okafor’s professional stage debut, she plays Alphonsine Mumureke, one of three Rwandan schoolgirls who report Marian apparitions and dark prophecies a decade before the Rwandan genocide.

headline: How Important Is a Business Plan?
abstract: An increasing number of entrepreneurs have concluded that business plans take too long to write and become outdated too quickly.
lead_paragraph: When Joanna Elkayam was laid off from a job selling bonds at Fidelity Investments in 2011, she had been working on a business plan for months. She wanted to open a spa with her husband, Avi, who already owned a successful hair salon.

headline: A New Exhibition Offers a Virtual Link to Tehran
abstract: Amar Bakshi’s “Portals” project creates an intercontinental passage inside a custom-designed shipping container, allowing New Yorkers to talk to full-body projections of participants in Iran.
lead_paragraph: When the Harvard- and Yale Law-educated artist and journalist Amar Bakshi, born and raised in Washington D.C., was traveling the globe seven years ago for his How the World Sees America interview series, he realized something: People often kept letters from American pen pals dating back to the 1980s, before the Internet made other modes of international correspondence possible. “I thought, ‘There’s nothing really quite like that now,'” says Bakshi, 30, noting that even platforms like Skype hadn’t necessarily encouraged strangers from foreign lands to get to know each other on an intimate, one-on-one level. “Before high tech existed,” he says, “we had that sense of sacredness and mystery” about faraway lives.

headline: Brazil’s Middle Class Finds a Lifeline at the Pawnshop
abstract: With credit cards charging more than 240 percent interest a year, middle-class Brazilians are increasingly turning to a place where collateral is king.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Interest rates in Brazil would make an American loan shark blush. Credit cards charge more than 240 percent a year. Bank loans top 100 percent.

headline: Kids and Coding Light Up the White House Christmas Trees
abstract: The trees surrounding the National Christmas Tree at the White House will be illuminated with animated patterns using code generated on Google’s Made with Code website.
lead_paragraph: I just decorated the New Hampshire holiday tree outside the White House — and your kids (or you) can be next.

headline: House on Brink of Spending Deal to Avoid Another Government Shutdown
abstract: House Speaker John A. Boehner appears to have mustered enough votes for a bipartisan spending plan without the backing of conservative Tea Party lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republican leaders appeared ready to buck their Tea Party flank on Wednesday as they closed in on a spending deal to avert a government shutdown and prepared to call a vote next week.

headline: Cybersecurity Breaches Raise Questions
abstract: Nicole Perlroth, The Times’s cybersecurity reporter, charted out the matters she will be exploring in the days ahead.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Nicole Perlroth reported on two separate sets of cybersecurity breaches. At Sony Pictures Entertainment, hackers defaced websites, leaked films and disclosed the pre-bonus salaries of senior Sony executives. They sabotaged data as well. Separately, Ms. Perloth covered a report about a series of Iranian attacks on more than 50 companies around the world.

headline: Indian Army Kills 6 Militants in Kashmir Gun Battle
abstract: The fight coincided with tense state elections in the Indian-administered state of Jammu and Kashmir.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Indian Army said it killed six militants who had crossed from Pakistan into India during a prolonged gun battle in the mountainous disputed border region in Kashmir, as voters went to the polls in tense state elections. The army said it seized six AK-47 rifles, a pistol and other weapons from the dead fighters.

headline: The Connected Baby
abstract: Welcome to the age of the digitally connected baby. New devices and wearables like the MonBaby and the Mimo allow you to track baby’s breathing, temperature and heart rate all from your phone.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the age of the digitally connected baby. New devices and wearables like the MonBaby and the Mimo allow you to track baby’s breathing, temperature and heart rate all from your phone.

headline: University of Texas Says It Can Account for Missing Brain Specimens
abstract: The university in Austin said most of the missing 100 brains, collected decades ago for research, had been disposed of as biological waste.
lead_paragraph: The case of the University of Texas at Austin’s missing brains has apparently been solved.

headline: Baby Monitors for a Smart Nursery, but Parents Are Still Better
abstract: A new generation of wearable devices for sleeping infants can gather lots of data, but parents might struggle to figure out what to do with it all.
lead_paragraph: FOR years, parents have spied on their sleeping infants with grainy video images from baby monitors. If they’re lucky, maybe that video played on a website or a smartphone.

headline: Donny and Marie, and Dana, Too
abstract: Dana Bash, the network’s hard-working Chief Congressional Correspondent, turns out to be a HUGE life-long fan of Donny and Marie Osmond.
lead_paragraph: Dana Bash is all CNN, but it turns out she is also a little bit country and a little bit rock ‘n’ roll.

headline: In Hawaii, a Pearl Harbor Remembrance
abstract: The 73rd anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor will be observed in Hawaii with a keynote speech, a concert and a gala.
lead_paragraph: A commemoration of the 73rd anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor starts Friday night at the Pearl Harbor Historic Sites in Hawaii.

headline: Reaction to Eric Garner Grand Jury Decision
abstract: Reactions to a grand jury’s decision not to indict the police officer who caused the death of a Staten Island man by putting him in a chokehold.
lead_paragraph: Protesters gathered in Midtown Manhattan on Wednesday night after a Staten Island grand jury voted not to indict a police officer in the chokehold death of Eric Garner. See related article.

headline: Wave of Protests After Grand Jury Doesn’t Indict Officer in Eric Garner Chokehold Case
abstract: The panel’s decision to end the criminal case in Mr. Garner’s death on Staten Island provoked protests, and the Justice Department said it would open a civil rights inquiry.
lead_paragraph: A Staten Island grand jury on Wednesday ended the criminal case against a white New York police officer whose chokehold on an unarmed black man led to the man’s death, a decision that drew condemnation from elected officials and touched off a wave of protests.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Can Twitter Stop Harassment?
abstract: The social network is making changes it says will help users report abuse. Will they bring users the kind of experience they’ve been calling for?
lead_paragraph: The increasing attention paid to online harassment in recent months hasn’t necessarily led to a lessening of the problem. If anything, it’s sometimes felt like the opposite, with those who speak up about harassment getting harassed themselves. As Rose Eveleth at The Atlantic writes, “things seem to be getting worse, not better.” But now, Twitter has made a move to address the issue, with changes it says will help users report abuse.

headline: The Emergence of Activist Athletes
abstract: Some N.F.L. players from Washington and St. Louis have openly protested the actions of the police in Missouri, shedding light on a sensitive issue. The two teams play on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: I’m curious to see what happens Sunday during an otherwise meaningless game between Washington and the St. Louis Rams in the nation’s capital.

headline: Another Mass Death Sentence in the ‘New’ Egypt
abstract: Without pretext of fairness, a court issued a death sentence against 188 people accused of supporting the Muslim Brotherhood.
lead_paragraph: In the new Egypt, there may be even less respect for justice, the rule of law and human rights as in the old Egypt.

headline: UPS Suit Hinges on an Ambiguous Pregnancy Law
abstract: The Supreme Court wrestled with what to make of language in the Pregnancy Discrimination Act, which governs how employers must treat pregnant workers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Supreme Court argument on Wednesday in a pregnancy discrimination case against United Parcel Service had, for the most part, the arid quality of a logic problem, with the justices wrestling with an ambiguous federal law.

headline: Booyah! Activist Investor Hurls Purple Prose at Jim Cramer
abstract: In a spellbinding letter to Jim Cramer, the activist investor J. Carlo Cannell urged him to cut his pay 70 percent, resign from CNBC and direct his energy to “helping your fellow shareholders crawl back from Hades.”
lead_paragraph: Activist investors have long used sharply worded letters as weapons in their campaigns to shake up companies. Some, like Daniel S. Loeb, have built fortunes by telling chief executives that they deserve “a well-worn boot planted in the backside.”

headline: Taylor Swift Back to No. 1
abstract: Billboard introduced a revised album chart to include streaming, but Ms. Swift’s “1989” — unavailable on most streaming outlets — still beat out the competition.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift’s new album “1989” returns to No. 1 on the chart after a one-week absence, giving the album its fourth time at the top in five weeks.

headline: Puerto Rico’s Highway Authority Treasurer Is Arrested on Bribery Charges
abstract: Federal investigations into two of Puerto Rico’s largest public corporations come as investors on the mainland U.S. have scooped up some of the agencies debt at steep discounts.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Bureau of Investigation on Wednesday arrested the treasurer of Puerto Rico’s highway authority on charges of bribery.

headline: Landrieu Ad Quotes News Anchor, to Station’s Dismay
abstract: The Fox affiliate in New Orleans is taking issue with the use of its news anchor’s words in a campaign ad for Senator Mary L. Landrieu.
lead_paragraph: The art of chopping a quotation for use in a political attack ad is nothing new — just ask President Obama — but the words tweaked are usually those of politicians, not newscasters.

headline: All About That Face (Dvorak’s, That Is)
abstract: Is a doodle on the bass part of the “New World” Symphony an 1893 sketch of Dvorak?
lead_paragraph: Is a doodle on the bass part of the “New World” Symphony an 1893 sketch of Dvorak?

headline: Michael Brown’s Stepfather Apologizes for Outburst in Ferguson
abstract: Louis Head, stepfather of the slain black teenager, said he was “full of raw emotions” the night that a grand jury’s decision was announced.
lead_paragraph: The stepfather of Michael Brown apologized on Wednesday for emotional comments he made shortly after a grand jury did not indict the police officer in Ferguson, Mo., who killed his stepson.

headline: Herman Badillo, Congressman and Fixture of New York Politics, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Badillo, whose political odyssey spanned Kennedy liberalism in the 1960s to Giuliani conservatism in the 1990s, became the first Puerto Rico-born congressman.
lead_paragraph: Herman Badillo, America’s first Puerto Rican-born congressman and a fixture in New York City politics for four decades who championed civil rights, jobs, housing and education reforms, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: British Government Proposes a ‘Google Tax’
abstract: George Osborne, the British chancellor of the Exchequer, proposed a new 25 percent tax on the local profits of some international companies, including tech giants like Google.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As some in Europe call for multinational companies to pay more taxes, Britain on Wednesday proposed a new 25 percent tax on the local profits of international companies, including tech giants like Google that use complicated structures to reduce their tax burden.

headline: Bringing God’s Wrath Down to Earth
abstract: Ridley Scott and the visual effects supervisor Peter Chiang explain how they brought the plagues to Egypt in the new epic “Exodus: Gods and Kings.”
lead_paragraph: He’s tackled aliens, gangsters, androids, gladiators, the military and Robin Hood. Now the director Ridley Scott takes on the Bible with “Exodus: Gods and Kings.” The film, opening Dec. 12, turns the story of Moses (Christian Bale) and his uprising against the Egyptian pharaoh (Joel Edgerton) into an adventure tale. The film, like the original story, may be an epic, but Mr. Scott’s approach was decidedly more practical.

headline: Play on Words: The Winners of Our 2014 Vocabulary Video Contest
abstract: Ten winners and 10 runners-up chosen from more than 600 submissions to our second annual vocabulary contest.
lead_paragraph: One of the top 10 videos sent in for our contest, this one, by Aldric G., defines somnambulist.

headline: Skadden Law Firm Hires Senior Treasury Official
abstract: Cyrus Amir-Mokri, a former assistant secretary of the Treasury who oversaw efforts to develop cybersecurity policy, has joined Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom as a partner in New York.
lead_paragraph: When Washington’s revolving door spins, it often opens on Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. On Wednesday, it did just that.

headline: 17 States Suing on Immigration
abstract: Texas will lead a coalition of 17 states challenging President Obama’s executive actions in federal court.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Texas and 16 other states filed a federal lawsuit on Wednesday challenging President Obama’s executive actions on immigration, arguing that he violated his constitutional duty to enforce the laws and illegally placed new burdens on state budgets.

headline: Taiwan, an Island of Green in Asia
abstract: In recent years, Taiwan has seen the development of a number of eco-friendly initiatives, from a protected marine habitat to a high-speed rail system.
lead_paragraph: At Taipei’s Ningxia Road Night Market on a cool evening last spring, the local food blogger known as Peray showed me his favorite stalls among hawkers selling food like milkfish, charred cuttlefish and sea snails. Like many of Asia’s markets, the Ningxia Road is a neon-lit cabinet of curiosities teeming with unimaginable marine life hauled from the surrounding sea. “Where’s the shark fin soup?” I asked, assuming nothing was off-limits. Peray told me there had been a ban on shark finning in 2012. “We love seafood in Taipei, but on an island you quickly understand the ocean’s limits.”

headline: The Death of Eric Garner, and the Events That Followed
abstract: A timeline of events after black man on Staten Island died after being placed in a chokehold by a white police officer.
lead_paragraph: A timeline of events after black man on Staten Island died after being placed in a chokehold by a white police officer.

headline: First Draft Focus: The White House, in Red and Green
abstract: The 2014 holiday decorations are on display at the White House.
