abstract: Early in their friendship, Mr. Arzoumanov believed in his heart that he and Ms. Crutchfield were destined to marry. Convincing her, however, took a few years.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Arzoumanov was the first person Abigail Crutchfield met at college. He introduced himself at an ice cream social during an orientation weekend at Harvard in April 2006. And she mostly ignored him.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: A Late Curtain and a New Hero
abstract: One Alfredo was taken ill, so another stepped into the Metropolitan Opera’s “La Traviata” on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Opera fans have their favorite singers. Just like film, opera has a star system. Still, at its core, it is an ensemble art form. Great performances cannot happen in isolation; they depend upon a cast of artists who have rehearsed together and report on time and in health for the opening of the show.

headline: Excerpt: ‘La Traviata’
abstract: Marina Rebeka as Violetta in Verdi’s “La Traviata,” at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: Marina Rebeka as Violetta in Verdi’s “La Traviata,” at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Celebrity Weddings 2014: Costly and Captivating
abstract: A look back at this year’s wedding trends and the ceremonies that captured the world’s attention.
lead_paragraph: What little restraint that remained, post-recession, over the scope and price of celebrity weddings suddenly vanished on May 24, as Kanye West and Kim Kardashian, in a Givenchy gown, took to the stage at the 16th-century Forte di Belvedere in Florence, Italy, for a wedding that by some estimates cost upward of $12 million. Then again, in show business, demonstrating a lack of restraint is hardly a sin.

headline: Why U.S. Women Are Leaving Jobs Behind
abstract: The work force participation of American women has declined, as it has for men. But their situation is often quite different.
lead_paragraph: Since Kerry Devine, 32, and her friends began having children, she has noticed a stark difference between her female friends in Auburn, Wash., where she lives, and those in England and Cyprus, where she grew up. In the United States, they almost all stopped working outside the home, at least until their children were in school. Yet, she says, she can’t think of a friend in Europe who left work after her children were born.

headline: The Sky-High Notes
abstract: Richie Vergona, 62, a musician, is well known among crane operators in New York City as the laid-back dude who rides his Harley-Davidson to work with his guitar on his back.
lead_paragraph: For Richie Vergona, 62, construction and composing go hand in hand.

headline: Taking Up a New Baton: Chairman of the Board
abstract: Oscar S. Schafer, who will take over from Gary W. Parr, will become the New York Philharmonic’s board chief at a critical juncture.
lead_paragraph: Oscar S. Schafer had been sponsoring the New York Philharmonic’s free parks concerts for several years when he tried something a little different at the start of a concert one sultry summer night in 2013: He donned a white jacket, picked up a baton and led the orchestra in the overture from Bizet’s “Carmen” — the opera, he explained, at which he had met his wife.

headline: Abundance Without Attachment
abstract: Abundance at this time of year is fine. Just don’t become in thrall to it.
lead_paragraph: “CHRISTMAS is at our throats again.”

headline: Cleese: Being a Teacher
abstract: Part 6: The author and comedian talks about meeting Graham Chapman for the first time, and explains what infuriates him about the British press.
lead_paragraph: Part 6: The author and comedian talks about meeting Graham Chapman for the first time, and explains what infuriates him about the British press.

headline: Cleese: British Education
abstract: Part 5: The author and comedian reflects on coming up in the rigid British education system and talks about how that shaped his feelings about authority.
lead_paragraph: Part 5: The author and comedian reflects on coming up in the rigid British education system and talks about how that shaped his feelings about authority.

headline: Cleese: Weirdest Question I Ever Got
abstract: Part 3: The author and comedian reflects on growing up and describes how he thinks his creativity was fostered by a turbulent childhood.
lead_paragraph: Part 3: The author and comedian reflects on growing up and describes how he thinks his creativity was fostered by a turbulent childhood.

headline: Cleese: Actors Aren’t Extroverts
abstract: Part 4: The author and comedian explains why he thinks actors are exhibitionists but not extroverts.
lead_paragraph: Part 4: The author and comedian explains why he thinks actors are exhibitionists but not extroverts.

headline: John Cleese: Intro
abstract: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks; and David E. Van Zandt, president of the New School; introduce the comedian and author John Cleese.
lead_paragraph: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks; and David E. Van Zandt, president of the New School; introduce the comedian and author John Cleese.

headline: Cleese: The 2013 Python Reunion
abstract: Part 10: The author and comedian reveals the real reason the Pythons decided to reunite for a series of shows in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Part 10: The author and comedian reveals the real reason the Pythons decided to reunite for a series of shows in 2013.

headline: Cleese: British Comedy, American Comedy
abstract: Part 15: The author and comedian reflects on the big differences between British and American comedy, and explains why he actually prefers American comedy.
lead_paragraph: Part 15: The author and comedian reflects on the big differences between British and American comedy, and explains why he actually prefers American comedy.

headline: Cleese: ‘Life of Brian’
abstract: Part 9: The author and comedian explains the real message behind ‘Monty Python’s Life of Brian’ and describes what his first visit to the United States taught him about religion.
lead_paragraph: Part 9: The author and comedian explains the real message behind ‘Monty Python’s Life of Brian’ and describes what his first visit to the United States taught him about religion.

headline: TimesTalks | John Cleese: Preview
abstract: The legendary comedian reflects on the highlights of a long career, explains his theory of comedy and recalls the influences on his acting and writing.
lead_paragraph: The legendary comedian reflects on the highlights of a long career, explains his theory of comedy and recalls the influences on his acting and writing.

headline: Cleese: In Love With Kevin Kline
abstract: Part 12: The author and comedian recalls how he first met the actor Kevin Kline, and explains why making television is easier in the United States than it is in England.
lead_paragraph: Part 12: The author and comedian recalls how he first met the actor Kevin Kline, and explains why making television is easier in the United States than it is in England.

headline: Cleese: Cambridge Footlights Revue
abstract: Part 2: The author and comedian recalls the stage show that kicked off his career, and explains how his memoir was inspired by Michael Caine.
lead_paragraph: Part 2: The author and comedian recalls the stage show that kicked off his career, and explains how his memoir was inspired by Michael Caine.

headline: Cleese: Terry Jones’s Teleprompter
abstract: Part 11: The author and comedian explains why there won’t be another Python reunion, and reveals his favorite comedians of all time.
lead_paragraph: Part 11: The author and comedian explains why there won’t be another Python reunion, and reveals his favorite comedians of all time.

headline: Cleese: ‘Fawlty Towers’
abstract: Part 8: The author and comedian describes why, despite having starred in a beloved sitcom, he still prefers writing to acting.
lead_paragraph: Part 8: The author and comedian describes why, despite having starred in a beloved sitcom, he still prefers writing to acting.

headline: Cleese: The Meaning of Life
abstract: Part 14: The author and comedian discusses the upcoming projects he has in mind, and shares a favorite quote.
lead_paragraph: Part 14: The author and comedian discusses the upcoming projects he has in mind, and shares a favorite quote.

headline: Cleese: Things Falling in My Lap
abstract: Part 13: The author and comedian explains the difference between what actors do and what comedians do.
lead_paragraph: Part 13: The author and comedian explains the difference between what actors do and what comedians do.

headline: Cleese: Working With Graham Chapman
abstract: Part 7: The author and comedian explains what each member of Monty Python was best at, and why he and Graham Chapman worked so well together.
lead_paragraph: Part 7: The author and comedian explains what each member of Monty Python was best at, and why he and Graham Chapman worked so well together.

headline: No Surprise: Wall Street Got Its Way in Spending Bill
abstract: A provision in the bill passed by the House repeals a part of the Dodd-Frank financial reform.
lead_paragraph: There’s no avoiding the impression that the fix was in from the start on a provision in the federal spending bill—passed on Thursday by the House—that repeals a part of the Dodd Frank financial reform law.

headline: What Happens to Letters to Santa Claus From New York City Children?
abstract: A reader asks about the fate of letters to Santa from children in New York. They are generally handled by Operation Santa, an annual letter-writing program in major cities.
lead_paragraph: Q. What happens to letters from children in New York City that are addressed to Santa Claus?

headline: That Norwegian Scalawag Roams Anew
abstract: The Immediate Family stages a whittled-down, sexed-up and feisty version of Ibsen’s “Peer Gynt.”
lead_paragraph: Henrik Ibsen’s 1867 “Peer Gynt” is a five-act, 40-scene onion soup of a play. This verse drama, a metric mishmash, sprawls from fantasy to satire to philosophy and across several continents. Its own author called it “reckless and formless.”

headline: International Motorcycle Show Looks Back in Time
abstract: It’s been true for a while, but where motorcycles are concerned, retro is in.
lead_paragraph: The New York stop of the International Motorcycle Show circuit is at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center this weekend, offering another glimpse at what’s new in two-wheelers (and, in some cases, three-wheelers). The show is smaller than last year’s, but of the manufacturers that attended, one thing was constant: retro motorcycles.

headline: American Museum of Natural History Evacuated Because of Smoke
abstract: A small fire outside the building created the smoke, which filled the Hall of the Northwest Coast Indians; the museum will reopen Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of visitors at the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan were evacuated on Friday afternoon after a blow torch being used outside sparked a small fire that filled an exhibition hall with smoke, officials said.

headline: Taking Up a Struggle, So Her Sons Don’t Have To
abstract: Activism and social protests became more important to Cassie Morales, 32, once she became a mother.
lead_paragraph: Activism and social protests became more important to Cassie Morales, 32, once she became a mother.

headline: Questioning a Rallying Cry
abstract: At the scene of Eric Garner’s death on Staten Island, Kevin Goldston, 51, asked leaders what they meant by the slogan “No Justice, No Peace.”
lead_paragraph: At the scene of Eric Garner’s death on Staten Island, Kevin Goldston, 51, asked leaders what they meant by the slogan “No Justice, No Peace.”

headline: A Generation Searching for Leadership
abstract: Manushka Magloire, 37, said she has sensed a disconnect between young protesters and older leaders from a different era.
lead_paragraph: Manushka Magloire, 37, said she has sensed a disconnect between young protesters and older leaders from a different era.

headline: Labor Board Accelerates Process for Unionization
abstract: Employers fear that any effort to accelerate such elections will help unions by giving businesses less time to campaign against unionization.
lead_paragraph: Several prominent business groups attacked new rules that the National Labor Relations Board issued on Friday that have the potential to speed up the unionization process.

headline: Losing the Message Amid the Noise
abstract: Levar McDonald, 21, argues for a middle ground between the armchair activism common on social media and confrontations on the street.
lead_paragraph: Levar McDonald, 21, argues for a middle ground between the armchair activism common on social media and confrontations on the street.

headline: Juniper Said to Be in Talks With Elliott to Further Change Board
abstract: In recent weeks, Elliott had proposed a list of several candidates for the company’s board in advance of the period when shareholders and others can begin nominating potential directors, according to people briefed on the matter.
lead_paragraph: Juniper Networks, the networking equipment maker, is weighing adding more corporate directors proposed by the activist hedge fund Elliott Management, people briefed on the matter said on Friday.

headline: A Photographer’s Forest Tale
abstract: Anna Beeke didn’t encounter giants or princesses imprisoned in towers as she photographed forests. Her sylvan adventure led to no holy grail, but it did produce a photo project.
lead_paragraph: Anna Beeke didn’t encounter giants or princesses imprisoned in towers as she photographed forests. Her sylvan adventure led to no holy grail, but it did produce a photo project.

headline: Voices From the Protests
abstract: Tens of thousands of people nationwide have protested in recent weeks the deaths of black men at the hands of the police. Four protesters in New York City outlined their goals and motivations.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of people nationwide have protested in recent weeks the deaths of black men at the hands of the police. Four protesters in New York City outlined their goals and motivations.

headline: Flood-Causing Deluge Amounts to Just Drops in California Drought
abstract: A Pacific storm that left Northern California a mess and caused at least two deaths was not enough to make more than a “minor dent” in a historic dry period.
lead_paragraph: The strong Pacific storm that left Northern California a sodden mess will not have much impact on the state’s historic drought, meteorologists said Friday.

headline: Revisiting Mortgages With Low Down Payments
abstract: Two couples who bought homes in 2008 and 2010 and put 5 percent or less down are doing fine, but they have been tested.
lead_paragraph: This week, the government released details of a plan to encourage more people to buy homes. Soon, it will be easier for banks to offer mortgages with down payments as low as 3 percent.

headline: Winter Camp for the White-Footed Mouse
abstract: Winter hikers with sharp eyes could spot a white-footed mouse, an appealing mammal found in all five boroughs in New York City that feeds on garden pests and insects.
lead_paragraph: Summer woodlands hide many secrets beneath their leafy boughs, but in colder months a lucky hiker may uncover a few as winter strips branches bare.

headline: Oil Prices Fall Again, and Stocks Follow Suit
abstract: The swoon in oil prices led to a steep decline in equities, as investors feared that the declining energy demand meant that the global economy was slowing.
lead_paragraph: Oil prices continued their collapse on Friday as evidence mounted that the frenzy of American oil production would continue well into 2015 even while growth in global demand was declining.

headline: Walkers in New York City’s ‘Inexhaustible Space’
abstract: Capsule reviews of books about writers’ street-level view of the city, the free black community of Weeksville that flourished in Brooklyn in the mid-19th century and how racial demographics are remaking New York and America.
lead_paragraph: Using an ideal Walt Whitman line for his epigraph — “Manhattan’s streets I saunder’d pondering” — Stephen Miller invites readers on what he calls a verbal tour in “Walking New York: Reflections of American Writers From Walt Whitman to Teju Cole” (Empire State Editions, Fordham University Press).

headline: Soccer Shows How the N.B.A. Could Make Losing Hurt
abstract: With a relegation system like those in European soccer leagues, the worst N.B.A. teams would be sent down to lower tiers, providing an incentive to avoid tanking.
lead_paragraph: There are some terrible, terrible basketball teams in the N.B.A. this year.

headline: At Big Banks, a Lesson Not Learned
abstract: A scene that looks familiar on Wall Street: tripping over themselves, and the rules, to get business.
lead_paragraph: Are the colossal regulatory fines extracted from big banks today likely to deter their officials from violating the same rules tomorrow? Or are these billion-dollar settlements viewed simply as a cost of doing business, and not a very large one at that?

headline: The Torture Report: Voices of Outrage
abstract: The American Psychological Association and others respond to news articles about torture, by the United States and Brazil.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Act on the Climate, and Brush Off the Deniers
abstract: Jeffrey Ainis, a reader, calls on President Obama to address the issue in his State of the Union Message.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Cuba: A New Start
abstract: On Dec. 18, the Obama administration announced that it would establish diplomatic ties with Cuba. Take a look back at the Editorial Board’s series calling for improved United States-Cuba relations.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 18, the Obama administration announced that it would establish diplomatic ties with Cuba. Take a look back at the Editorial Board’s series calling for improved United States-Cuba relations.

headline: A Shift in Demographics at a Church in Harlem
abstract: A substantial number of white people have joined the First Corinthian Baptist Church in Harlem, a trend that defies the racial norms of American Christianity.
lead_paragraph: On a Sunday morning in September 2011, Eloise Louis stood on a street corner in Harlem, looking for a church. She was just hours off a plane from her native France, jet-lagged and buzzy with anticipation. An aspiring jazz singer with spiritual yearnings and a self-taught knowledge of civil rights history, she had finally set foot on black America’s hallowed ground.

headline: Wall St. Wins a Round in a Dodd-Frank Fight
abstract: A repeal of a derivatives rule would show that, six years after the financial crisis, large banks have found a way to kill regulations that were part of the Dodd-Frank Act.
lead_paragraph: When Wall Street traders sense opportunity in the markets they pursue it with a sharklike intensity.

headline: Police Shooting of Tamir Rice Is Ruled a Homicide
abstract: The medical examiner has issued a homicide ruling in the death of 12-year-old Tamir Rice, who was said to be holding a toy gun when he was shot by a rookie Cleveland police officer.
lead_paragraph: The medical examiner in Cuyahoga County, Ohio, has ruled that the fatal shooting of 12-year-old Tamir Rice by a rookie Cleveland police officer last month was a homicide, and that the boy died from a gunshot wound just above his navel.

headline: Making a Pig’s Ear of Food Safety
abstract: A new inspection program results in contaminated pork.
lead_paragraph: LINCOLN, Neb. — IF, thanks to an experimental inspection program, a meatpacking firm produces as much as two tons a day of pork contaminated by fecal matter, urine, bile, hair, intestinal contents or diseased tissue, should that count as a success?

headline: Before the Music Come the Machines
abstract: The D’Addario factory in Farmingdale, N.Y., produces 700,000 fretted and bowed instrument strings a day.
lead_paragraph: The words “I’m not that interested in guitars” sound strange coming from Pat Metheny, a 20-time Grammy-winning guitarist. But he can explain.

headline: Peru Is Indignant After Greenpeace Makes Its Mark on Ancient Site
abstract: A sign urging environmental action during a United Nations summit meeting on climate change was placed near a 1,000-year-old geoglyph that is a cultural treasure in Peru. Officials are outraged over the trespassing and the disturbance of the ancient grounds.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — An expression of concern by the environmental group Greenpeace about the carbon footprint was marred this week by real footprints — in a fragile, and restricted, landscape near the Nazca lines, ancient man-made designs etched in the Peruvian desert.

headline: The Odyssey of the Greek Marbles
abstract: Leila Amineddoleh, a specialist in art law, is sharply critical of the British Museum’s loan to the Hermitage.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Justices to Decide if a Ban on Life Terms for Juveniles Applies Retroactively
abstract: The case involves a Louisiana man who has been denied a resentencing hearing for a 1984 murder when he was 17.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed to decide on Friday whether  a decision it made in 2012 barring mandatory life-without-parole sentences for juvenile killers must be applied retroactively.

headline: Celebrating a Teardown in Detroit
abstract: After years of frustration, neighbors were relieved when the demolition crew finally showed up to knock down the abandoned home on Mt. Vernon Street that had been a problem for years.
lead_paragraph: After years of frustration, neighbors were relieved when the demolition crew finally showed up to knock down the abandoned home on Mt. Vernon Street that had been a problem for years.

headline: Good Intentions of Detroit Residents Are Tested by Blight
abstract: Many Detroiters are willing to wait for promised change, but it has been slow to come. “The city has good intentions,” one resident said, “but then the actions are like a snail.”
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In and around the abandoned houses on Mount Vernon Street, brawls and shootings have erupted, a dogfighting ring has been established, stolen cars were traded and drug deals consummated. So when Michelle Van-Tardy, who has lived on the block for years, saw a disheveled woman in her 50s slip into the abandoned house at 569 Mount Vernon Street, she pounced.

headline: Keeping the Mentally Ill Out of Jail
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plan for treatment and housing, instead of repeated incarceration, is an ambitious — and laudable — effort.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s ambitious plan for cutting the number of mentally ill people in New York’s jails will require a great deal of ingenuity and a big shift in priorities by the police, the courts, and social service and housing agencies. If the effort succeeds, it will improve the lives of mentally ill people by getting them treatment and places to live instead of locking them into the “frequent flier” syndrome, in which they are repeatedly jailed for minor offenses, even when they present no threat to public safety.

headline: Sudan: Prosecutor Halts Darfur Inquiry
abstract: The prosecutor of the International Criminal Court said Friday that she was suspending investigations in Darfur because no arrests had been made in a decade and the United Nations Security Council had been unwilling to use its powers to help.
lead_paragraph: The prosecutor of the International Criminal Court said Friday that she was suspending investigations in Darfur because no arrests had been made in a decade and the United Nations Security Council had been unwilling to use its powers to help. The prosecutor, Fatou Bensouda, left, said that given her limited resources and the lack of political will, she had no other choice, even as the decade-long violence in Darfur, in western Sudan, was worsening and government-run militias had stepped up attacks against civilians, especially women. Ms. Bensouda called for a “dramatic shift” in the Council’s approach and for “concrete solutions” to get arrests. In 2005, the Security Council asked the court to open a criminal investigation of Sudan’s campaign against civilians and rebel groups in Darfur. As a result, the court indicted President Omar Hassan al-Bashir, his defense minister and two other associates on charges of genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes. But when the officials traveled abroad, other countries refused to arrest them. The court has no police force of its own, and the prosecutor’s complaints to the Council were ignored, she said. “We find ourselves in a stalemate that can only embolden perpetrators,” Ms. Bensouda said. The indictments, however, will remain in place.

headline: F.B.I. to Investigate a Hanging Death in North Carolina
abstract: After state officials said Lennon Lacy, 17, whose body was found hanging from a swing set in North Carolina, committed suicide, the local chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. asked the F.B.I. to intervene.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The Federal Bureau of Investigation said Friday that it had joined the inquiry into the August death of a black teenager in North Carolina, where family members and their supporters have questioned the finding by the state authorities that he committed suicide.

headline: Where Nonna and Abuelita Share the Kitchen
abstract: The Refuge, a rustic spot that replaced Four Food Studio on Route 110, offers fare that is part cantina and part Italian grandmother’s kitchen.
lead_paragraph: When Four Food Studio opened in Melville nearly a decade ago, it became an immediate go-to for workers along busy Route 110. But last spring its owners, Jay Grossman and Ray Sidhom, closed the restaurant to update everything from its décor to its menu.

headline: Mexico Faces Growing Gap Between Political Class and Calls for Change
abstract: A special prosecutor to investigate corruption is expected to be named soon, but falling confidence in the president and the political process itself is imperiling the mission before it begins.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — As the Nobel Peace Prize was being awarded in Oslo this week, a young man dashed on stage, unfurled a Mexican flag streaked with red paint and begged for help for his country because more than 40 college students have been missing for months after clashing with the police.

headline: M.T.A. Wants to Discipline 4 Employees in Queens Subway Derailment
abstract: The final report on the May derailment that injured 30 in Woodside said the workers did not spot a defect on the track for more than a year.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said in a report that it was seeking to punish four employees for failing to repair the track that caused an F subway train to derail in Queens in May, injuring 30 passengers and two crew members.

headline: Documents Shed New Light on Legal Wrangling Over Spying in U.S.
abstract: Newly declassified documents show disagreement among judges on the secret surveillance court, and the Bush administration pushing forward with “innovative” solutions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In January 2007, Judge Malcolm Howard issued an extraordinary order on behalf of the nation’s secret surveillance court. He interpreted the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, which requires individual warrants to wiretap on domestic soil, in a way that authorized the Bush administration’s warrantless wiretapping program, according to documents declassified on Friday.

headline: Oregon: 4 Hurt in Shooting Near Portland High School
abstract: Four people were injured in a shooting outside a Portland high school on Friday, throwing an area in the north end of the city into chaos.
lead_paragraph: Four people were wounded in a shooting outside a Portland high school on Friday, throwing an area in the north end of the city into chaos as medical responders rushed to the scene and the police searched for someone believed to be involved with a local gang. A 16-year-old girl was hospitalized in critical condition and two young men, ages 17 and 20, were in serious condition. A 19-year-old woman was treated for a graze wound. The victims were able to run into the school after the attack, a police spokesman said. Their names were not available. Rosemary Anderson High School, with about 200 students, is an alternative public school for students who have either been expelled from or dropped out of regular high school. The shootings occurred just after noon on an unseasonably warm and dry day when many students were outside, but a spokesman for the Portland Police Bureau, Sgt. Pete Simpson, said it was not clear whether the victims were specifically targeted or just happened to be in the wrong place at the wrong time.

headline: Amid Details on Torture, Data on 26 Who Were Held in Error
abstract: Of 119 prisoners in C.I.A custody, the Senate report found that 26 were either described in the agency’s own documents as mistakenly detained, or released and given money.
lead_paragraph: One quiet consequence of this week’s sensational release of the Senate Intelligence Committee’s report on the C.I.A. detention program was a telephone call that a human rights lawyer, Meg Satterthwaite, placed to a client in Yemen, Mohamed Bashmilah.

headline: Mr. Obama Considers the Nationwide Protests From Three Points of View
abstract: As the president speaks out on Eric Garner and Michael Brown, his shifting roles come through clearly.
lead_paragraph: Barack Obama understood when he sought the presidency that a black candidate who spoke candidly about racism would never attract enough white support to win. He avoided using race as a platform for grievance, kept his distance from people who did and presented his life and career as an example of racial progress.

headline: Obama’s Pleas Foreshadow Tense Relationship With a New Congress
abstract: The fact that President Obama had to lobby his own party so intensely to avoid a government shutdown speaks to the challenge he faces in dealing with a hostile Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hours before the deadline for another government shutdown on Thursday night, President Obama ducked out of the photo line at a White House holiday party to plead by phone with the No. 3 House Democrat, Representative James E. Clyburn of South Carolina, to help him head off a crisis.

headline: Evening Hours | Pets, Books and Art
abstract: Celebrating life’s pleasures as the chill sets in.
lead_paragraph: Celebrating life’s pleasures as the chill sets in.

headline: Another Baseless Attack on Health Law
abstract: The latest case seeks to block federal payments that keep cost-sharing low for the poor. The harm could be significant.
lead_paragraph: The opponents of the Affordable Care Act have filed another long-shot lawsuit that could undermine health care reform and force many consumers to pay more for health insurance if the suit succeeds.

headline: Ex-Chief Leads Vocal Defense of C.I.A.
abstract: The counteroffensive, which includes a new website, began even before the Senate committee issued its report on the agency’s harsh treatment of detainees.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The last time George Tenet was asked about torture on television, he sounded defiant and jabbed his finger in the air. The year was 2007, and Mr. Tenet, the former director of the Central Intelligence Agency, was promoting his memoir when a question about waterboarding came up while he was being interviewed on CBS’ “60 Minutes.”

headline: Illinois: Holder Speaks on Police Tactics
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. spoke with the police and community members in Chicago on Friday about law enforcement practices, his latest stop in a nationwide tour.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. spoke with the police and community members in Chicago on Friday about law enforcement practices, his latest stop in a nationwide tour that coincides with heightened national discussion about how officers use force. Mr. Holder, who talked for about five minutes before the roundtable discussion was closed to reporters, said it was important for the police and residents to build mutual trust. “We have to ask ourselves some fundamental questions about the lack of trust” between the police and certain communities, Mr. Holder told the group, which included Mayor Rahm Emanuel, police officials and several young men. The visit followed similar forums in Cleveland, Atlanta and Memphis. Mr. Emanuel complimented the Chicagoans who have taken to the streets in recent weeks to protest police practices and grand jury decisions in Ferguson, Mo., and New York.

headline: Prosecuting Insider Trading
abstract: Recent overturned convictions have changed the rules.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1991, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit overturned the conviction, for stock manipulation, of a man named John Mulheren.

headline: Front Row? Too Far Away
abstract: Fans of universities can connect directly with players and teams by winning online auctions for packages billed as “experiences,” some of which sell for thousands of dollars.
lead_paragraph: When the Auburn football team emerged through a wall of smoke before its game against South Carolina in October, John Joyave was right beside the Tigers. When the Rutgers basketball team ate its pregame meal before a February game at Louisville, Jason Newcomb dug in with the players.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Holiday Magic
abstract: The hope and love of the season were on full display as the city exploded with holiday celebrations.
lead_paragraph: The hope and love of the season were on full display as the city exploded with holiday celebrations.

headline: Mary Burke Nicholas Washington Dies at 88; Led New York Police Review Board
abstract: As Mary Burke Nicholas, the name by which she was known before 1994, Mrs. Washington held prominent government posts in New York throughout the 1970s and ’80s.
lead_paragraph: Mary Burke Nicholas Washington, an economist who pioneered myriad roles for women and African-Americans in public life, notably heading a civilian panel in 1989 that assailed the New York City police over their clash with demonstrators in Tompkins Square Park, died on Nov. 30 in Arlington, Va. She was 88.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Holiday Magic
abstract: The hope and love of the season were on full display as the city exploded with holiday celebrations.
lead_paragraph: The hope and love of the season were on full display as the city exploded with holiday celebrations: The scaffolding came off Saint Patrick’s Cathedral; at the Greenmarket, red berries were as popular as evergreens; the lions at the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue were in holiday décor; and 30 guide dogs were at the tree at Rockefeller Center. A Fifth Avenue stroller wore an orange fox coat. The sounds of carols on the church steps were a sharp contrast to the Salvation Army volunteers and their electronic dance music.

headline: Working in Postwar Italy, He Was the da Vinci of the V6
abstract: An innovative design by Francesco De Virgilio, introduced more than 60 years ago, is the basis for many modern 6-cylinder engines.
lead_paragraph: The question of which engine type is best for powering the cars of the masses may never have a single, unchanging answer.

headline: Uncovering Hudson Valley Artists
abstract: Through its programs, Arts Mid-Hudson in Poughkeepsie raises the visibility of the region’s cultural diversity.
lead_paragraph: Linda Marston-Reid didn’t know a lot about Hudson Valley culture when she moved to Poughkeepsie from Brooklyn in 2011. But as executive director at Arts Mid-Hudson, a 50-year-old nonprofit aimed at exploring and enhancing the local arts scene, she made figuring it out fast a priority.

headline: Dinner Party Political Primer
abstract: Whatever you do, don’t confuse the cromnibus with the cronut, the pastry that’s half-croissant and half-doughnut at your holiday party.
lead_paragraph: The burdens of being an Informed Citizen are many. This weekend, you’ll probably be going out to some holiday party or dinner where your friends will expect you to have an opinion about the monster spending bill that’s been staggering through Congress.

headline: Caesar’s Predecessor
abstract: A Saturday romp with James Mulhern and Ashton Anderson.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — What is there to say about a puzzle that opens with the entry BUTTOCKS, which is then clued as “Cheeky couple?” I realize that you’re bound to want to crack some jokes about that but, in the end, we are a sophisticated group. So let’s do ourselves a favor and leave that all behind us.

headline: Uruguay’s Guantánamo Gesture
abstract: A leader who was a political prisoner took a moral stand in accepting six detainees. If others also stepped forward, it could hasten the closing of the prison.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, Uruguay made good on its offer to take six Guantánamo Bay detainees, a gesture that other countries in Latin America could be persuaded to emulate. The transfer of the prisoners, who had long been cleared for release, marked the largest reduction in the number of inmates at Guantánamo Bay since 2009.

headline: No Longer Fearful, a Trainer Presides Over an Empire
abstract: Ron Burke inherited his father’s training business and became the first harness racing trainer to earn $100 million in purses won.
lead_paragraph: When Ron Burke was young, he was afraid of horses. Now harness racing’s leading trainer, Burke has transformed himself into an intimidating force.

headline: Defense Nominee Ashton Carter Has Back Surgery
abstract: Ashton B. Carter, President Obama’s nominee to become defense secretary, underwent what an administration official called “a long-planned surgical procedure on his back” on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Ashton B. Carter, President Obama’s nominee to become defense secretary, underwent what an administration official called “a long-planned surgical procedure on his back” on Friday. Mr. Carter, 60, was resting comfortably with his family, according to Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary. Mr. Earnest and other White House officials did not elaborate on what was wrong with Mr. Carter’s back or why the procedure was necessary. “Mr. Carter decided to go ahead with the previously scheduled procedure so that he could complete it before beginning his confirmation process,” Mr. Earnest said. Mr. Obama nominated Mr. Carter on Dec. 5 to become the top civilian in charge of the Pentagon after Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel resigned under pressure. Mr. Carter is slated to begin his confirmation process next year, when Republicans take control of the Senate.

headline: Working With Varying Degrees of Heat
abstract: Fantasy Cuisine in Hartsdale includes many specialties of China’s Sichuan region.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, Japanese and Asian fusion restaurants have largely supplanted the neighborhood Chinese restaurant as the informal go-to place for an inexpensive bite with family and friends. Bucking that trend is Fantasy Cuisine, a Chinese restaurant on Hartsdale’s Central Avenue that opened in the summer.

headline: Rose Cochran, a Figure in a Campaign Attack Video, Dies at 73
abstract: Mrs. Cochran, a former teacher, was in a nursing home when she became part of an unsuccessful attack ad against her husband, Senator Thad Cochran.
lead_paragraph: Rose Cochran, who was unwittingly thrust into the middle of a bitter primary campaign being waged by her husband, Senator Thad Cochran, in Mississippi this year, died on Friday at a hospice in Ridgeland, Miss. She was 73.

headline: When a Genius Meets a Genius at a Bar
abstract: In “Picasso at the Lapin Agile,” his play now at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, Steve Martin finds a balance of silliness and seriousness.
lead_paragraph: No one seems impressed by the guy with messy hair, sitting alone at a bar in Montmartre on this night in 1904. After all, as we learn early on in “Picasso at the Lapin Agile,” now at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, he may claim to be a scientist, but none of his work has ever been published, and he actually spends his days in a menial job at the patent office. It’s like a waiter calling himself an actor although he has never been cast in anything.

headline: On Planned Mob Films, Multimillion-Dollar Fraud Is Alleged Before Cameras Ever Roll
abstract: A New York construction executive who invested in a movie to be written by Chazz Palminteri and another to star John Travolta fell victim to a con artist, a federal complaint charges.
lead_paragraph: If Hollywood likes a good cautionary tale about the dangers of seeking movie financing, the experiences of Fay Devlin would seem to be fodder for a surefire hit.

headline: Maker Agrees to Modify a Lacrosse Helmet That Was Decertified
abstract: The popular helmets — made by Cascade Lacrosse — will receive enhanced padding at no cost to their owners.
lead_paragraph: A leading manufacturer of lacrosse helmets, Cascade Lacrosse, announced Friday that it had reached an agreement with a safety organization on the modification of a popular helmet that was recently decertified.

headline: Barnard Considers Policy for Transgender Students
abstract: The women’s college is considering adopting a formal admissions policy as it and other single-sex schools grapple with shifting notions of gender.
lead_paragraph: At an elite college for women, the question arises: What does it mean to be a woman?

headline: Concerns Raised Over Shrill Device New York Police Used During Garner Protests
abstract: Three lawyers sent a letter asking that the beeping from long-range acoustic devices, called a deterrent function, not be used until the police had fully tested it.
lead_paragraph: Amid police warnings for protesters to stay off the streets or risk arrest last week, a distinctly different and piercing sound could be heard.

headline: Amid Underwhelming Start, Two Young Rangers Begin to Thrive
abstract: Injuries and illness have provided opportunities for Kevin Hayes, 22, and J. T. Miller, 21, to gain valuable experience playing alongside the Rangers’ veterans this year.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers have been in flux for most of this season, dealing with injuries, illness and inconsistent play.

headline: Haitian President May Drop His Premier
abstract: To end an impasse and allow for elections, President Michel Martelly said that he would accept the recommendations of a commission that has called for the prime minister to resign.
lead_paragraph: President Michel Martelly of Haiti said Friday that he would accept the recommendations of a commission that, among other things, called for the resignation of the prime minister to ease an intensifying political crisis that threatens the country as it continues to recover from the January 2010 earthquake.

headline: Silver, New York Assembly Speaker, Declines to Reveal Source of Some Outside Income
abstract: An aide confirmed that Speaker Sheldon Silver earns money from legal fees in addition to the pay he has long acknowledged receiving from a personal-injury law firm, but did not offer more details.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Sheldon Silver, the Manhattan Democrat who is speaker of the State Assembly, is earning money from legal fees in addition to the pay he has long acknowledged receiving from a major personal-injury law firm, a spokesman confirmed on Friday.

headline: With Carmelo Anthony in Center of Storm, a Cloud Lifts, Finally, for the Knicks
abstract: As speculation about his future continued, Anthony scored 22 points to help the Knicks earn their second road win of the season and end a 10-game losing streak.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Carmelo Anthony was not officially a go until the words came out of the mouth of his coach, Derek Fisher, 90 minutes before tipoff Friday night. Yes, Anthony would start for the Knicks against the Celtics.

headline: Justice and Fairness in Campus Rape Cases
abstract: How can women who say they have been raped be treated supportively and sensitively while their accounts are investigated and the accused get fair treatment?

headline: Fence at Gracie Mansion Now Taller Than de Blasio
abstract: A fence has been erected behind the short brick barricade surrounding Mayor Bill de Blasio’s residence at the behest of the Police Department, his administration said.
lead_paragraph: The home, tenantless for more than a decade, was bound to have problems.

headline: Playing Down to 76ers’ Level, a Short Drop, the Nets Shuffle to Victory
abstract: The Nets and the 76ers combined for 41 turnovers and 32 missed 3-point attempts in the game, the closest one the Nets had played in nine days.
lead_paragraph: When the Philadelphia 76ers and the Nets traded air balls early in Friday’s game at Barclays Center, fans were still settling in for a night of relatively bad basketball. It turned out worse.

headline: Preparing for Immigration Reform, and Warning of Potential Fraud
abstract: Immigrant service providers and government officials are moving to forestall an expected rise in immigration fraud ahead of President Obama’s executive action.
lead_paragraph: In the fight against the schemers and unethical lawyers trying to defraud unsuspecting immigrants, one of the many front lines is in a room above the nave of the Bronx Spanish Evangelical Church.

headline: A Focus on Farms and Freshness
abstract: At Baldanza Market and Cafe, a small place in downtown New Canaan, freshness is a key ingredient.
lead_paragraph: The first things we learned after sitting down to dinner at Baldanza Market and Cafe in New Canaan was that Brian Williams had dined there the week before and that the table at the entrance had once belonged to Faye Dunaway.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 12, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Helping a Queens Woman With Professional Development
abstract: Cumanda Kollaris, who works at a hair salon, received Neediest Cases money to enroll in a colorist course to develop further as a stylist.
lead_paragraph: Cumanda Kollaris has lost three homes in her 59 years. She does not want to lose a fourth.

headline: Masks, Murals and Cuisine of an Italian Island
abstract: Luca’s Ristorante in Somerset, decorated with murals of famous Neapolitans and commedia dell’arte masks, features cuisine from the island of Ischia.
lead_paragraph: Andréa Di Meglio believes that the ambience of his restaurant should be as enticing as its food. Which is why, no matter where I sat at Luca’s Ristorante in Somerset, I got an eyeful.

headline: An Elf on a Quest
abstract: A bright musical based upon a popular Will Ferrell movie, “Elf,” now in Milburn, is a well-tooled production that previously won success on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Anybody who doesn’t get a nice holiday kick out of Paper Mill Playhouse’s current production of “Elf” might be a candidate for Santa’s naughty list.

headline: Rev. Dr. William Barber II on Today’s Protest Movements
abstract: The president of the North Carolina chapter of the NAACP shares his thoughts on the intersectionality of today’s protest movements.
lead_paragraph: Rev. Dr. William Barber II is president of the North Carolina chapter of the NAACP and one of the leaders of the Moral Mondays movement. He shared his thoughts on today’s protesters with me by email.

headline: Saturday’s College Football Game to Watch: Navy (6-5) vs. Army (4-7)
abstract: Navy started this season 2-4, but the Midshipmen have won four of their last five and are set to play San Diego State in the Poinsettia Bowl. Saturday’s game will be the season finale for 4-7 Army.
lead_paragraph: ARMY vs. NAVY

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 13, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “I failed to raise her properly.”

headline: Corrections: December 13, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, December 13, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS: MY FAIR LADY (1964) Robert Osborne and Drew Barrymore explain why George Cukor’s adaptation of the Lerner and Loewe musical — about an uppity phonetics professor (Rex Harrison) who accepts a bet that he can transform a ragged Cockney flower girl (Audrey Hepburn) into an English rose — is required viewing. Not least, the fact that Jack Warner, the Warner Bros. studio head, personally produced the film, whose rights, controlled by CBS, were bought for $5.5 million — a record at the time — with the stipulation that Cecil Beaton be hired as the art director. Mr. Cukor “has packed such emotion into this film — such an essence of feeling and compassion for a girl in an all too human bind — that he has made this rendition of ‘My Fair Lady’ the most eloquent and moving that has yet been done,” Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times. “Though it runs for three hours — or close to it — this ‘My Fair Lady’ seems to fly past like a breeze. Like Eliza’s disposition to dancing, it could go on, for all I’d care, all night.”

headline: Taliban Ramp Up Fatal Attacks in Afghanistan
abstract: Suicide attackers and gunmen unleashed a wave of violence in the capital and beyond on Saturday, weeks before a planned withdrawal from Afghanistan by international forces.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban gunmen and a suicide bomber unleashed a wave of violence in the capital and beyond on Saturday, killing six Afghan soldiers aboard a Kabul bus, assassinating a Supreme Court official and shooting to death 12 men working to clear land mines in Helmand Province.

headline: Egypt Denies Entry to American Scholar Critical of Its Government
abstract: Michele Dunne, a former diplomat now with the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said Saturday that she was turned away at the Cairo airport.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A prominent American scholar and ex-diplomat critical of the government of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi has been barred from entering Egypt, in what appears to mark a new escalation of the government’s clampdown on dissent.

headline: Last Hong Kong Protest Camp to Be Cleared Monday, Police Say
abstract: The protest site in Causeway Bay, a crowded shopping area, has outlasted the much bigger camps, but not for much longer, a police spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Hong Kong police said on Saturday that they were preparing to dismantle the last of the three pro-democracy protest camps that blocked major streets in the city for 11 weeks. The clearance of the camp, which was by far the smallest of the three, will take place on Monday, a spokesman for the police force said.

headline: Rescuers Search for Victims of Fatal Landslide in Indonesia
abstract: At least 17 people were killed and more than 30 homes were buried or swept away by the landslide, which was caused by seasonal rains Friday in the province’s Banjarnegara District, an official said.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA — Rescue teams in Indonesia were searching on Saturday for dozens of victims of a landslide in Central Java Province that has killed at least 17 people, the authorities said.

headline: At Jingle Ball, Women in Charge
abstract: Onstage at the iHeartRadio concert Friday night at Madison Square Garden, performers including Taylor Swift, Iggy Azalea, Ariana Grande and Sam Smith worked to impress the audience.
lead_paragraph: The guys flirted, flattered, implored, made promises and pined over lost love. The gals topping the bill praised themselves and, more often than not, gave guys the brushoff or a kiss-off. The guys capered all over the stage, working hard to impress the primarily female audience with their manly vitality. The women were choreographed, flaunting both their preparation and their bump-and-grind skills.

headline: The Daily Gift: An Elegant Fitness Tracker for the Design-Minded
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: G.O.P. Angst Over 2016 Led to Provision on Funding
abstract: A provision in the spending bill to increase limits on individual donations to each party’s national committees began with Republicans weighing funding for their 2016 convention.
lead_paragraph: The secret negotiations that led to one of the most significant expansions of campaign contributions in recent years began with what Republican leaders regarded as an urgent problem: How would they pay for their presidential nominating convention in Cleveland in two years?

headline: Supreme Court Revisits Life Sentences for Juveniles
abstract: Should a 2012 ruling have applied retroactively?
lead_paragraph: The life-without-parole sentences of thousands of juveniles convicted of murder nationwide may be up for reconsideration after the Supreme Court announced Friday that it would, at last, resolve a major uncertainty lingering in a landmark 2012 ruling.

headline: Is Our Economic Commentators Learning?
abstract: Gut feelings, still reported as facts.
lead_paragraph: We are now in our seventh year at the zero lower bound. Over that period we’ve seen massive deficits rise and fall, aggressive monetary expansion and ill-advised monetary tightening, extreme fiscal austerity, and more. At this point we should therefore have a pretty good idea of how things work in this environment. And as I’ve often pointed out, everything has been more or less exactly what you would have expected from IS-LM (with the central bank controlling the monetary base, but not the endogenous money supply).

headline: Movie Review: ‘Top Five’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Top Five.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Top Five.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Exodus: Gods and Kings’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Exodus: Gods and Kings.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Exodus: Gods and Kings.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Inherent Vice’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Inherent Vice.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Inherent Vice.”

headline: Where’s the Hot Water?
abstract: This week’s questions address building codes governing water temperature; downgrading of co-op insurance; and how tenants might buy their rent-stabilized building.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: I.R.S. Asset Seizure Case Is Dropped by Prosecutors
abstract: Laws that allow officials to seize assets without criminal charges are too often wielded without care to avoid ensnaring people like Carole Hinders, critics say. A new bill aims to curb the laws’ excesses.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors have agreed to dismiss a case against Carole Hinders, an Iowa restaurant owner whose bank account was seized by the I.R.S. based solely on a pattern of cash deposits, Ms. Hinders’ lawyer said Friday.

headline: With Hotel Holiday Events, Hope and Charity
abstract: This year, hotel holiday packages come with a dash of charity.
lead_paragraph: This year, hotel holiday packages come with a dash of charity.

headline: Small Bank in Kansas Is a Financial Testing Ground
abstract: The owners of CBW in Weir, Kan., want to find solutions to problems — like obstacles to quick money transfers — that vex consumers nationwide.
lead_paragraph: The redbrick bank in Weir, Kan., in a building cater-corner from the mortuary on Main Street, does not look much like a candidate for the bank of the future.

headline: Nations Plod Forward on Climate Change Accord
abstract: The draft deal would, for the first time in history, commit every nation to cutting its greenhouse gas emissions, but it would still fall far short of what scientists say is needed.
lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru — Negotiators from around the globe were haggling into Saturday night over the final elements of a climate change agreement that would, for the first time, commit every nation to cutting its greenhouse gas emissions — yet would still fall far short of what is needed to stave off the dangerous and costly early impacts of global warming.

headline: Variety: A Messy Acrostic
abstract: A very messy acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Although this one gave me a bit of a struggle, it was well worth it. I loved this quote. How much more evocative can you get by describing someone who keeps his pile of “unanswered correspondence” tidy by stabbing them with a knife into the center of a mantelpiece?

headline: Sally Smith of Buffalo Wild Wings, on Patience in Hiring
abstract: “We use the phrase ‘wait for great’ in hiring,” a C.E.O. says. “When you have an open position, don’t settle for someone who doesn’t quite have the cultural match or skill set you want.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Sally Smith, chief executive of Buffalo Wild Wings, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Home Buyers Are Optimistic but Not Wild-Eyed
abstract: While recent expectations for home-price appreciation are optimistic, they are still nowhere near those of the bubble a decade ago.
lead_paragraph: Most of us don’t add up the short-run investment pros and cons when we consider whether to buy a house; instead, we think about the long-term lifestyle we want.

headline: Online Trail Leads to Arrest of Indian as Man Behind Posts Backing the Islamic State
abstract: As the police closed in on him, Mehdi Masroor Biswas gave a panicky interview to an Indian newspaper saying that his comments in interviews with Channel 4 had been misconstrued and that his email had been hacked.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Police in Bangalore, India, arrested on Saturday the man accused of being behind @ShamiWitness, the Twitter handle of a fervent and widely followed English-language supporter of the Islamic State extremist group.

headline: Trying to Swim in a Sea of Social Media Invective
abstract: Social media companies are often reluctant to become arbiters of appropriate and inappropriate speech online.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few months, I’ve watched friends and colleagues endure endless harassment on Twitter. Strangers have hurled offensive, racist names and gendered insults, relentlessly and with little fear of consequence. I’ve come across blog posts that capture similarly awful experiences.

headline: On Torture Report, Colorado’s Udall Leaves Subtlety at Door on the Way Out
abstract: The Democratic senator continues to deliver scathing criticism of the C.I.A. and the Obama administration for their responses to the Intelligence Committee’s findings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To Senator Mark Udall, the Central Intelligence Agency’s effort to mislead the public about its brutal interrogation program is not a thing of the past.

headline: Is It Bad Enough Yet?
abstract: Flourishing billionaires, racial divides. Finally, people seem fed up.
lead_paragraph: THE police killing unarmed civilians. Horrifying income inequality. Rotting infrastructure and an unsafe “safety net.” An inability to respond to climate, public health and environmental threats. A food system that causes disease. An occasionally dysfunctional and even cruel government. A sizable segment of the population excluded from work and subject to near-random incarceration.

headline: Some of the Rich Collect Art. Others Collect Passports.
abstract: The global wealthy are spending an estimated $2 billion a year to secure documents giving them entree into desired countries.
lead_paragraph: Along with stock and real estate portfolios, the global rich are now buying a new form of economic security: passport portfolios.

headline: After Barren Years in Somalia, Signs of Growth by the Bunch
abstract: During the civil war of the 1990s, irrigation systems were damaged, plantations were abandoned, farmers were displaced and storage facilities and ports destroyed. Now, the banana is making a tentative comeback in Somalia.
lead_paragraph: AFGOOYE, Somalia — Armed with machetes, the men push their way through the densely packed rows of trees, emerging every few minutes with large bundles of green bananas over their shoulders.

headline: Wall St. Had Invested Heavily in Dodd-Frank Changes
abstract: An analysis shows that House Democrats who voted in favor of a bill that will roll back a key provision of the Dodd-Frank law on average received nearly four times as much money from large financial institutions as others who voted “no.”
lead_paragraph: For Wall Street it must seem like money well spent.

headline: Montana Dress Code Has Female Legislators Sporting New Look: Clenched Jaws
abstract: New guidelines, including a maxim that women “should be sensitive to skirt lengths and necklines,” have produced a rolling of eyes and anger among Democratic representatives.
lead_paragraph: Montana has never been known as a black-tie place. Governors wear cowboy boots and bolo ties, and people joke that a tuxedo is a pair of black jeans and a sport coat. But this winter, when lawmakers arrive at the State Capitol, they will have to abide by a new dress code: No more jeans. No casual Fridays. And female lawmakers “should be sensitive to skirt lengths and necklines.”

headline: The Evolution of ISIS
abstract: How has ISIS, a 21st-century terrorist organization with a retrograde religious philosophy, spread from Iraq to Syria, Libya and beyond?
lead_paragraph: How has ISIS, a 21st-century terrorist organization with a retrograde religious philosophy, spread from Iraq to Syria, Libya and beyond?

headline: Former Champions, Both Men and Women, Fill the Coaching Ranks
abstract: WTA Tour players looking to break through are following the lead of Andy Murray and enlisting former top players as their guides.
lead_paragraph: Andy Murray may have cemented himself as the most influential professional tennis player in this decade, not for his dominance or his popularity, but for his hiring practices.

headline: A Global Gauge Finds Progress Against Poverty
abstract: The number of people worldwide who are living in extreme poverty has been declining sharply, partly attributable to rising incomes in India and China.
lead_paragraph: While many Americans typically focus on the ups and downs of the national economy, something remarkable has been occurring among the world’s poorest nations. In just over two decades, the number of people living in extreme poverty has been almost halved.

headline: Islamic State Imposes Strict New Order in Mosul, and Deprivation Is a Result
abstract: Six months after the Islamic State seized Iraq’s second-largest city, it has exerted tight control over schools and other aspects of society while doing little to provide services.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — As the school year began in Mosul, the largest city controlled by the Islamic State, the extremists sent a message to teachers: Report for work or lose your jobs.

headline: For Jihadists, Denmark Tries Rehabilitation
abstract: A pioneering program treats former fighters not as criminals or potential terrorists, but as wayward youths who deserve a second chance.
lead_paragraph: AARHUS, Denmark — In many parts of Europe, he would now be in jail. But here in Denmark’s second biggest city, the young man, a 21-year-old of Turkish descent who spent 13 months in Syria fighting in the name of Islam, passes his days playing soccer, working out at the gym and waiting anxiously to see if he has secured a place to study engineering at a well-regarded local university.

headline: An All-Star Candidate Wins a Nation’s Support
abstract: Latvians are flooding the All-Star voting in favor of their countryman Zemgus Girgensons, a second-year center for the Buffalo Sabres who has received more than twice as many votes as his nearest competitor.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — They rank last in goals scored, and despite a recent winning streak, the Buffalo Sabres have sat near the bottom of the N.H.L. standings since the first weeks of the season.

headline: When to Pop the Pay Question
abstract: An employer wants a job candidate to complete a long homework assignment before it offers a face-to-face interview. Is the candidate justified in first asking about salary?
lead_paragraph: I’m applying for a position I find very intriguing. I’ve had one phone interview that went well, and now I’ve been asked to complete a “challenge” that will take up to seven days to finish. Once this has been submitted, I am told, the company will call me in for a face-to-face interview.

headline: Going to the Head of the Line
abstract: A manufacturing supervisor, born in Nigeria, describes how he helped his employer establish an assembly line for its products.
lead_paragraph: Olamide Sanuth, 28, is a manufacturing supervisor and lab technician at Invisible Sentinel, a food test kit maker in Philadelphia.

headline: Thousands March in Washington to Protest Police Violence
abstract: Wearing T-shirts that read “Black Lives Matter” and chanting “I can’t breathe,” demonstrators evoked memories of civil rights marches of the past.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They came to the nation’s capital on buses and planes and minivans and trains, from Florida, Detroit and Staten Island, led as much by the families, friends and supporters of African-American men and boys killed at the hands of the police as by civil rights leaders.

headline: China’s E-Cigarette Boom
abstract: Ninety percent of the world’s e-cigarettes are made in China. Experts warn, however, that poorly manufactured devices can vaporize heavy metals and carcinogens alongside the nicotine.
lead_paragraph: Ninety percent of the world’s e-cigarettes are made in China. Experts warn, however, that poorly manufactured devices can vaporize heavy metals and carcinogens alongside the nicotine.

headline: Trying to Reinvent Italy
abstract: The prime minister struggles to get the country to change its ways.
lead_paragraph: ROME — ITALY has long suffered from inertia, its individual vitality smothered by the bureaucracy and opacity of the state. Italians are rich, prudent savers. Their state is poor, profligate and inefficient. For 30 years now, since I was a correspondent in Italy, I have watched the country deploy its ingenuity to evade modernization, culminating in the orgy of baroque escapism known as the Berlusconi years.

headline: China’s E-Cigarette Boom Lacks Oversight for Safety
abstract: Almost all of the world’s e-cigarettes are made without oversight, and experts say flawed or sloppy manufacturing could account for some of the hazards seen in the devices.
lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China — In a grimy workshop, among boiling vats of chemicals, factory workers are busy turning stainless steel rods into slender tube casings, a crucial component of electronic cigarettes. Not long ago, Skorite Electronics was a tiny firm struggling to produce pen parts. Today, it is part of an enormous — and virtually unregulated — supply chain centered here that produces about 90 percent of the world’s e-cigarettes.

headline: In Myanmar, Racing to Save a Colonial Past in Decay
abstract: Preservationists are working to salvage badly deteriorating buildings in Yangon’s historic downtown.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — The once-grand colonial building of marble floors and iron fretwork, an elegant outpost of Britain’s trading empire, is now a wreck. Moss encrusts the walls, rainwater drips down rusted steel beams, flimsy lights glow yellow in dark interiors. A century-old birdcage elevator lies idle, stuck on the first floor. It hasn’t moved in more than 60 years.

headline: Education With a Dose of Zorro
abstract: Tim Morehouse is on a mission to introduce fencing, a historically aristocratic sport, to financially disadvantaged youths in the United States.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The cold rain had been pouring for several hours by the time the Olympian Tim Morehouse exited a cab in front of North Star Academy’s Vailsburg elementary school location. Over his shoulder, he carried a large black duffel bag filled with plastic foils and fencing masks. Despite the gray skies, he seemed giddy.

headline: After the Ring, a Life on the Screen
abstract: After taking his lumps and experiencing some success in boxing, what he termed “a tough business,” the Irishman John Duddy found a new calling.
lead_paragraph: John Duddy, a former middleweight boxer, leaned against a moving truck parked in front of a residential high-rise along Central Park West.

headline: Kobe Bryant Is Nearly an Equal of Michael Jordan, Except in Fan Adoration
abstract: Entering Sunday’s game against Minnesota, Bryant has 32,284 points, 8 behind Jordan for third place on the N.B.A. career scoring list.
lead_paragraph: Kobe Bryant is one of the most talented players to grace an N.B.A. court, but he has often undercut his greatness with distractions. In another era, he would have been allowed to focus on basketball and would have been praised for his otherworldly game. But with today’s 24-hour news cycle, he has spent much of his career answering for his personality and his off-court actions.

headline: As N.C.A.A. Issues Pile Up, a Call for a Commission
abstract: A group of legislators and proponents of reform held a closed-door meeting with Secretary of Education Arne Duncan last Tuesday in Washington to push the idea of a panel.
lead_paragraph: After hearings on Capitol Hill this year to examine the N.C.A.A. and college sports, some lawmakers believe they have found the next step for the federal government’s role: a presidential commission. A group of legislators and proponents of reform pushed the idea Tuesday in a closed-door meeting with Secretary of Education Arne Duncan in Washington.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: The Many Faces of Jeb
abstract: We like to pigeonhole politicians. The ones who might run for president in 2016 don’t make that easy.
lead_paragraph: AS brothers who governed large states at the same time, each Bush was bound to be defined in terms of the other. George was the impulsive one who’d stumbled and then swaggered toward success. Jeb was the cogitator, the toiler. George was the extrovert: He worked the room. Jeb was the introvert: He read the books.

headline: A Partisan Divide in the Face of Our National Shame
abstract: The Senate report on torture should be the start of national soul searching, not partisan sniping.
lead_paragraph: There is no way that the Senate Intelligence Committee’s report on the C.I.A. could have been anything less than devastating, but at least it could have been a demonstration of how a great democracy confronts terrible acts it committed at a time of high stress and confusion, how it acknowledges the wrong and seeks ways to prevent it from ever happening again. Yet even before the report was released, it had been relegated to fodder in the tedious and agonizingly petty partisan squabbling that has become the norm in Washington. Senator Dianne Feinstein, chairwoman of the committee, deserves great credit for her perseverance in having at least the executive summary of the report released despite the resistance of Republicans and the timidity of the White House.

headline: Catherine Bailey
abstract: The craft activist and entrepreneur on fog, cabins, and riding Amtrak trains for days at a time.
lead_paragraph: Catherine Bailey is an industrial designer turned craft advocate and entrepreneur. She is co-owner of Heath Ceramics in Sausalito, Calif., a company founded in 1948 and known for its enduring and finely crafted midcentury designs.

headline: Can Seafood Be Kosher and Sustainable?
abstract: Observant Jews who want to eat eco-friendly fish face a dilemma.
lead_paragraph: A FEW months ago I was seated at a sustainable-seafood dinner in which neither the hip cooking school director to my left nor the locavore food activist on my right ate the meal. On the menu was Montauk-caught monkfish, a once overexploited creature whose stocks have been rebuilt as a result of markedly improved fisheries management. Still, my tablemates eschewed the monkfish and ate a vegetable plate instead.

headline: Why 2014 Is a Big Deal
abstract: This could have been the year that tipped the scales toward action on climate change. Then the price of oil started falling.
lead_paragraph: I WAS just about to go with a column that started like this: When they write the history of the global response to climate change, 2014 could well be seen as the moment when the balance between action and denial tipped decisively toward action. That’s thanks to the convergence of four giant forces: São Paulo, Brazil, went dry; China and the United States together went green; solar panels went cheap; and Google and Apple went home.

headline: A Home of One’s Own
abstract: Curbing financial recklessness, predation and discrimination is the way to create conditions for sound homeownership.
lead_paragraph: When Melvin Watt, the federal mortgage regulator, recently unveiled new government plans to encourage low-down-payment mortgages for cash-strapped buyers, the move was correctly understood as an effort to revive the still-ailing housing industry. But it is more than that. It is a challenge to the enduring misperception that most of the people who lost their homes in the housing bust should never have been homeowners in the first place.

headline: Fragile Gains Against Malaria
abstract: Funding for the global campaign against malaria needs to be doubled.
lead_paragraph: The global battle against malaria, a mosquito-borne infectious disease, continues to yield impressive gains, but it is encountering new obstacles that threaten future progress. It is imperative that funding from all sources be doubled to solidify the achievements and move toward the elimination of malaria from as many countries as possible.

headline: Creating a Stronger U.N.
abstract: Readers discuss reforms to make the organization more effective.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss reforms to make the organization more effective.

headline: A Shooter, His Victim and Race
abstract: A black man did a terrible thing as a teenager and has been locked up his whole adult life. The white woman he shot in the face now wants him released. Let’s learn from them.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — IAN MANUEL is a black man who has spent most of his life in prison. Yet he still has a most unusual advocate calling for his release: a white woman whom he met when he shot her in the face.

headline: The Imitation of Marriage
abstract: Can progressive ideas really save the working-class family?
lead_paragraph: IN the last two weeks, my colleagues at The Times’s data-driven project, The Upshot, have offered two ways of looking at the most important cleavage in America — the divide, cultural and economic, between the college educated and the struggling working class.

headline: Still Failing Syria’s Refugees
abstract: The need to resettle Syrians outside the overburdened Middle East is growing.
lead_paragraph: The international community is expected to offer shelter and support to more than 100,000 additional Syrian refugees, who have been forced from their homes by their country’s bloody civil war. That is progress — but it is not nearly enough when measured against the enormous need and the fact that some of the world’s wealthiest countries are still turning their backs on this humanitarian disaster.

headline: How Your City Influences Your Spending
abstract: In many ways, geography is consumer destiny. Government data show distinct spending priorities, some rather mysterious, in the 18 metro areas that it tracks — regional personalities of conspicuous (and everyday) consumption.
lead_paragraph: In many ways, geography is consumer destiny. Government data show distinct spending priorities, some rather mysterious, in the 18 metro areas that it tracks — regional personalities of conspicuous (and everyday) consumption.

headline: What People Buy Where
abstract: Who knew that nonalcoholic beer was so big in San Diego?
lead_paragraph: CONSPICUOUS consumption is everywhere, but it’s not the same everywhere. People living in certain cities spend far more than the national average on particular goods and services that they believe will enhance their social standing.

headline: Where Tech Giants Protect Privacy
abstract: Regulations on personal data are tougher abroad.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — FROM their glass-fronted office parks and start-up lofts in Silicon Valley, American tech companies oversee ever-expanding global empires.

headline: In Some Fantasy Football Leagues, Jets and Giants Excel
abstract: In reverse fantasy football, teams score points depending on how poorly a player performs, the exact opposite of how most fantasy sports leagues work.
lead_paragraph: A world exists where players on the Jets and Giants have been performing well this season. Of course, this world is a fantasy. Or more precisely, a very upside-down fantasy.

headline: The Talk: After Ferguson, a Shaded Conversation About Race
abstract: My African-American son’s appearance affords him the option to check “other” on the race card.
lead_paragraph: LIKE so many African-American parents, I had rehearsed “the talk,” that nausea-inducing discussion I needed to have with my son about how to conduct himself in the presence of the police. I was prepared for his questions, except for one.

headline: Coveting Sharpshooter, Knicks Just Missed
abstract: A desire to draft point guard Stephen Curry in 2009 set in motion events that ultimately spelled very different outcomes for the Knicks and the Golden State Warriors.
lead_paragraph: On a Wednesday evening in mid-November at Bankers Life Fieldhouse in Indianapolis, with the hometown Pacers about 90 minutes from hosting the Charlotte Hornets, Larry Riley strolled onto the court and spotted Donnie Walsh in his familiar station, a sideline seat, watching players go through warm-up rituals.

headline: Reporter May Still Face Questions About Source
abstract: The Justice Department has indicated that it will not force the reporter James Risen to divulge his confidential source, potentially eliminating a significant element of a lengthy battle over press freedoms.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has indicated that it will not force a New York Times reporter to divulge his confidential source, potentially eliminating a significant element of a lengthy battle over press freedoms. But important questions remained as the deadline of a Tuesday court hearing approached.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in the Sports section.
lead_paragraph: Finding Remedies When Calls Are Wrong

headline: In Season Gone Wrong, Giants Once Did Everything Right
abstract: As the Giants prepared for a rematch with Washington, they reflected on their best game of the season, a 45-14 rout that seemed like a distant memory.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It was the game when everything went right for the 2014 Giants. Yes, there was such a game.

headline: A Back Returns to a Place He Never Wanted to Leave
abstract: Now with the Jets, running back Chris Johnson said that the decision to leave Tennessee was not his, but that he did not expect Titans fans to give him a break.
