lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Jets running back Chris Johnson is not sure how he will be received when he returns to LP Field on Sunday to face the Tennessee Titans, a team he meant so much to before an abrupt departure last April that he has described as “nasty.” He fears the worst.

headline: Sunday’s Matchup: Washington Redskins (3-10) at Giants (4-9)
abstract: Dormant for most of the season, the Giants’ pass rush has recorded 15 sacks in the last two games.
lead_paragraph: 1 p.m., Fox

headline: Sunday’s Matchup: Jets (2-11) at Tennessee Titans (2-11)
abstract: Receiving sporadic playing time across his 13 games with the Jets, Chris Johnson has rushed for 558 yards, averaging a healthy 4.5 yards per carry.
lead_paragraph: 4:05 p.m., CBS

headline: Originally Omitted Witness Transcripts
abstract: Included in the latest release from the St. Louis County prosecutor were transcripts of interviews with people who witnessed the shooting of Michael Brown in August.
lead_paragraph: Included in the latest release from the St. Louis County prosecutor were transcripts of interviews with people who witnessed the shooting of Michael Brown in August.

headline: More Files Are Released in Shooting in Ferguson
abstract: Robert P. McCulloch, the St. Louis County prosecuting attorney, apologized for failing to immediately make public all documents tied to the grand jury’s decision in the Michael Brown case.
lead_paragraph: St. Louis County’s prosecutor on Saturday apologized for failing to immediately make public all documents tied to a grand jury’s decision last month not to indict a white police officer in the death of an unarmed black teenager in Ferguson, Mo., and released a new set of records — the third such release — since the grand jury’s return.

headline: Well, Golly!
abstract: Golly, it’s Jim Peredo.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — People often ask me how constructors get ideas for themes, and the truth is that it’s simply a matter of being observant. Add a letter, syllable or phrase to a word or phrase that exists and see if it makes another real word or phrase. If you can do the same thing a few more times, you’ve got yourself a theme set. Now all you have to do is set it in a grid, fill it with lively and familiar entries without getting yourself stuck anywhere and then write a mass of brilliant clues that have no possibility of being wrong or offending anyone. Easy peasy.

headline: A Pastor’s Turn Fighting for Ukraine
abstract: Sergei I. Reuta, a Pentecostal minister, picked up a Kalashnikov rifle to volunteer with the Ukrainian Army, where he routinely held court at his post and cooked for his unit.
lead_paragraph: PISKY, Ukraine — Sergei I. Reuta was in many ways typical of the 15,000 to 18,000 volunteers who, loosely organized in about 30 battalions, have emerged as the backbone of the Ukrainian military in the war in southeastern Ukraine.

headline: Even Before Long Winter Begins, Energy Bills Send Shivers in New England
abstract: Customers are facing drastically increased heating bills in New England, which already has the highest rates in the 48 contiguous states.
lead_paragraph: SALEM, N.H. — John York, who owns a small printing business here, nearly fell out of his chair the other day when he opened his electric bill.

headline: G.O.P. Hopefuls Honing Attacks Against Hillary Clinton
abstract: To win the party’s nomination in a contest over which Mrs. Clinton looms so large, likely Republican candidates are now jockeying to appeal to key groups.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie offered a cutting assessment of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s electoral weaknesses recently, telling a group of energy executives that she lacked her husband’s political talents and personal appeal. To punctuate the point, the New Jersey governor mischievously quoted President Obama from a 2008 campaign debate. “You’re likable enough, Hillary,” Mr. Christie said, according to two participants.

headline: The Wrong Dog
abstract: We let ourselves believe that beneath our rescued puppy’s strange, erratic behavior was a good, loving pet.
lead_paragraph: The woman walked up and down Main Street carrying a beautiful 5-month-old black Labrador mix in her arms. The dog was resting on the woman’s shoulder like a baby, gazing helplessly at the pedestrians, cars and shop windows. I was sitting at an outdoor table at the local coffee house with my husband, Alex, and we watched the comical, but endearing, scenario with curiosity.

headline: Downbeat Legacy for James Brown, Godfather of Soul: A Will in Dispute
abstract: Nearly eight years after James Brown died, his disputed will remains mired in lawsuits, and a trust set up for needy children has yet to aid its intended recipients.
lead_paragraph: AIKEN, S.C. — James Brown’s will was meant to be everything his life was not.

headline: Senate Passes $1.1 Trillion Spending Bill, Joining House
abstract: A rare Saturday session bridged some disagreements, as the chamber approved the measure to fund core domestic government operations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After moments of high drama, dry process and acrimony, the Senate passed a sweeping $1.1 trillion spending package Saturday night, abruptly ending several days of chaotic legislative maneuvers and clearing the bill for President Obama to sign.

headline: Battle Over Spending Bill Exposes Democratic Rift
abstract: Senator Elizabeth Warren’s fight over a provision in the spending bill has elevated her status as leader of the Democratic Party’s liberal base.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Elizabeth Warren once famously said that she was willing to see “plenty of blood and teeth left on the floor” in her fight against Wall Street excess.

headline: Grisly Execution in Oklahoma Detailed in Court Brief
abstract: The doctor involved in the lethal injection in Oklahoma was sprayed with blood when, in an attempt to insert an intravenous line, he struck an artery, according to documents filed in a federal lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: The Oklahoma doctor involved in the bungled execution of Clayton D. Lockett in April made one last frantic attempt to insert an intravenous line in the prisoner’s groin but struck an artery by accident and was sprayed with blood, according to a document filed in Federal District Court.

headline: Injuries to Iman Shumpert and J.R. Smith Add to Knicks’ Woes
abstract: The team announced that Shumpert would miss at least three weeks with a dislocated shoulder and that Smith had a partly torn plantar fascia.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks’ season plunged into deeper misery Saturday when the results of two magnetic resonance imaging tests were revealed.

headline: 25,000 March in New York to Protest Police Violence
abstract: The demonstration was the largest since a grand jury decided this month not to indict a white officer involved in the death of a black Staten Island man.
lead_paragraph: More than 25,000 people marched through Manhattan on Saturday, police officials said, in the largest protest in New York City since a grand jury declined this month to indict an officer in the death of an unarmed black man on Staten Island.

headline: In Texas, Architect for Bushes Also Builds With Words
abstract: David Heymann, who designed the Western White House for President George W. and Laura Bush, has turned to a different medium, writing his first book.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — The architect David Heymann, 55, is known for designing the Western White House, former President George W. and Laura Bush’s glass and limestone dwelling at Prairie Chapel Ranch near Crawford. And just as the 43rd president made a late-in-life change, from politics to painting, so has Mr. Heymann, to a point.

headline: Brenham Synagogue to Find New Life in Texas
abstract: Across the country, as Jews have left small towns for bigger cities, synagogues have deteriorated or been converted to churches, theaters and even a hardware store.
lead_paragraph: BRENHAM, Tex. — In Leon Toubin’s dreams, Jewish life would again be vibrant in this city where he and his wife, Mimi, care for B’nai Abraham, the synagogue where generations of his family worshiped.

headline: Texas Law May Short-Circuit an Advance in Storing Electricity
abstract: A Texas power line company says it has found a way to make Texas’ electrical grid more reliable without costing customers more. But other companies are objecting.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Texas’ largest power line company says it has found a way to quickly revolutionize the state’s electrical grid, making it more reliable and friendlier to renewable energy without driving up consumer costs.

headline: Rick Perry: A Governor in Texas Who’s Drawn to the Flame
abstract: Unlike so many politicians who run from adversity, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has shown an instinct for not shying away from it.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Politicians have the same reaction most of us do to adversity: Run.

headline: Robert B. Oakley, Envoy Deft at Tackling Crises, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Oakley was best known for negotiating the release of an American pilot held by Somali militiamen in 1993 in what was known as the “Black Hawk Down” crisis.
lead_paragraph: Robert B. Oakley, a blunt-spoken career diplomat who was known for successfully handling some of the world’s prickliest situations, including the capture of an American pilot by Somali militiamen in 1993 in what became known as the “Black Hawk Down” crisis, died on Wednesday at a nursing home in McLean, Va. He was 83.

headline: Tens of Thousands Protest in Poland Over Results of Local Elections
abstract: The leader of Poland’s largest opposition party claimed that the results of last month’s municipal elections had been falsified.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Tens of thousands of people gathered in Warsaw on Saturday as the leader of Poland’s largest opposition party claimed that the results of last month’s municipal elections had been falsified.

headline: What We’re Watching: Sunday Shows
abstract: The Senate Intelligence Committee’s blistering report on the C.I.A. interrogation program will dominate the conversation on the Sunday shows.
lead_paragraph: The Senate Intelligence Committee released a scathing report this week of the Central Intelligence Agency’s detention and interrogation program of suspected terrorists. Retired Gen. Michael Hayden, former C.I.A. director who led the agency during a period when the controversial program was in place, will talk about the report on ABC’s “This Week.”

headline: Liberian Court Rejects Petition to Delay Elections Over Ebola
abstract: Liberia’s Supreme Court on Saturday said it would not halt Senate elections scheduled for Tuesday, but the ultimate day of the vote remains unclear.
lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — Liberia’s Supreme Court on Saturday said it would not halt Senate elections scheduled for Tuesday, rejecting a petition calling for the vote to be delayed because of the Ebola crisis.

headline: Marcus Mariota of Oregon Wins Heisman Trophy, and Hawaii Rejoices
abstract: Mariota, a quarterback, became the first Hawaii native and the first Ducks player to win the award, given to college football’s most outstanding player.
lead_paragraph: Marcus Mariota took a deep breath, shook his lowered head and pursed his lips. His eyes welled up. He had just won the Heisman Trophy, becoming the first Hawaii native and the first Oregon Duck to do so, and he was getting choked up as he delivered his acceptance speech at a theater in Midtown. He took a moment to address the children of Hawaii who are much the way he was.

headline: Navy Regroups to Beat Army for 13th Straight Game
abstract: The Black Knights did a lot of things right but fell to the Midshipmen in the 115th meeting between the teams.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Army came out strong against Navy on Saturday, but the game ended with a familiar result as the Black Knights fell to the Midshipmen for a 13th straight meeting, this time a 17-10 defeat at M&T Bank Stadium.

headline: Kept From Homelessness by the Kindness and Caring of Friends
abstract: For most of her adult life, Ms. Williams, 52, has moved from one friend’s apartment to another so that she would not have to go to a shelter.
lead_paragraph: It has been a long time since Lita Williams had a home of her own.

headline: Obama’s Immigration Move Benefits Democrats Where It Counts
abstract: A big bounce in the polls among Hispanics suggests Democrats can rebound in 2016 by winning back persuadable voters.
lead_paragraph: A month after President Obama’s decision to defer deportation and offer work authorization to millions of undocumented immigrants, his action not only looks like a winner, but it also seems to be a fairly promising sign for Democrats after the disastrous midterm elections last month.

headline: How to Help Sweetie Sweetie
abstract: The home where Sweetie Sweetie is staying is sponsored by ChildFund International, a private aid agency.
lead_paragraph: Sweetie Sweetie is in a temporary group home for children who have lost parents to Ebola. The home, in Port Loko, Sierra Leone, is sponsored by ChildFund International, a private aid agency. For donors, contact ChildFund by email at communications@childfund.org or by telephone at 1-800-776-6767. Unicef is also supporting Ebola orphans. For more on its program, see www.unicefusa.org.

headline: An Ebola Orphan’s Plea in Africa: ‘Do You Want Me?’
abstract: After her mother died of Ebola, a young girl in Sierra Leone was left an orphan when nobody in her village, even relatives, wanted to take her, though she showed no symptoms of the virus.
lead_paragraph: PORT LOKO, Sierra Leone — Sweetie Sweetie had no choice.

headline: Protests Continue Over Eric Garner Case
abstract: The police said 25,000 marched in a demonstration that was the largest since a grand jury decided this month not to indict a police officer involved in the death of a black Staten Island man.
lead_paragraph: The police said 25,000 marched in a demonstration that was the largest since a grand jury decided this month not to indict a police officer involved in the death of a black Staten Island man.

lead_paragraph: Katie Ann Osterloh, a daughter of Cheryl M. Osterloh and Samuel L. Osterloh of Orlando, Fla., is to be married Sunday to Brian Christopher Phelps, the son of Debbie Abdo Phelps of Charlotte, N.C., and E. Dewey Phelps of New Bern, N.C.

abstract: She studied contemporary art, he is studying to be a doctor.

Friedman and Richard A. Friedman of New York. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein officiated, with Cantor Azi Schwartz taking part, at the Pierre in New York.

abstract: The couple, both medical residents, were married at the Highline Hotel in New York.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Krystin August Engelhardt and Dr. David Saul Levine were married Saturday evening at the Highline Hotel in New York. Rabbi Joshua Goldstein officiated.

abstract: A violinist and chief executive of a web start-up, are to marry in Puerto Rico.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Jo Racusin and Daniel David Almog are to be married Sunday at the Ritz-Carlton in San Juan, P.R. Cantor Diego A. Mendelbaum is to lead the ceremony.

King III of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. John J. Unni, a Roman Catholic priest and the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony at St. Cecilia Church in Boston.

abstract: The bride is an associate in a New York law firm; the groom is a partner at Davis Polk & Wardwell.
lead_paragraph: Blair Alexandra Parsont, the daughter of Ilene Parsont and Dr. Lawrence M. Parsont of Great Neck, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Brian Scott Lichter, the son of Tina Lichter and Dr. Stephen M. Lichter of New York. Rabbi Daniel A. Kraus officiated at the Plaza in New York.

lead_paragraph: Emily Lam and Artie Kwok were married Saturday at the 3 West Club in Manhattan. Lisa Traina, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

lead_paragraph: Anthony Marcel Sarkees and Ryan Edward LaFollette were married Friday at the Lambda Legal Regional Office in Chicago. Jim Bennett, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

abstract: The couple were married at the Century Association in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Valerie Hope Tocci and Francis James Longobardi III were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Michael Ehrlich at the Century Association in Manhattan.

headline: Michelle Ressler, Ronald Zelnick
abstract: A lawyer for the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency, and a general surgeon marry in Miami.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Margaret Ressler and Dr. Ronald Stuart Zelnick are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Robert Davis at the Four Seasons Hotel in Miami, with Cantor Steven Haas participating.

headline: Marie Charlevois, Alex Hetherington
abstract: The bride and groom each graduated from Yale but did not meet there.
lead_paragraph: Marie Eva Charlevois and R. Alexander Hetherington were married Saturday evening at the Inn at Round Barn Farm in Waitsfield, Vt. Seton Marshall, a cousin of the groom, received permission from Vermont to officiate.

headline: Zila Acosta and Brian Grimes Jr.
abstract: The couple — a lawyer and a financial planner — met at Columbia.
lead_paragraph: Zila Reyes Acosta, the daughter of Vasthi Reyes Acosta and Rolando T. Acosta of New York, was married Saturday to Brian Keith Grimes Jr., a son of Sherri Trader of Cherry Hill, N.J., and Mr. Grimes Sr. of Langhorne, Pa. The Rev. Carlos R. Reyes, an Assemblies of God minister and a grandfather of the bride, performed the ceremony in St. Paul’s Chapel on the campus of Columbia University.

headline: Jonathan Calabretta, Daniel Powell
abstract: Jonathan Calabretta and Daniel Powell marry in California.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan McClean Calabretta and Daniel Joe Powell were married Saturday at Beatnik Studios, an events space in Sacramento. The event was led by Amy Travis, who was temporarily designated as a deputy marriage commissioner by Sacramento County so that she could officiate.

headline: Auntie Roseanne Brought Them Together
abstract: The bride, a hospital executive, and the groom, a finance manager for a software company, met as children in Half Moon Bay, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Alison Burke Flynn and Scott Douglas Gaffney were married Saturday at the Water Club, the restaurant in New York. Christopher J. O’Connor, who became a Universal Life Minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: A Made-for-TV Encounter
abstract: Upon further review, and much to their surprise, the couple’s first meeting had been two years earlier than they thought.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Rebecca Hanley and Evan Daniel Susser were married Saturday evening at the Baltimore Museum of Industry. Rabbi William D. Rudolph officiated.

headline: Peru Plans to Charge Greenpeace Activists for Damage to Nazca Lines
abstract: About a dozen people entered a fragile protected area around the archaeological feature, leaving marks on the rocks.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — President Ollanta Humala of Peru criticized the environmental group Greenpeace on Saturday for not respecting his country’s archaeological heritage as authorities said they intended to seek criminal charges against several activists who damaged the fragile desert around the Nazca Lines.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 12:30 P.M. (13) CURTAIN UP: THE SCHOOL OF AMERICAN BALLET WORKSHOP PERFORMANCES In its debut collaboration with the School of American Ballet, “Live From Lincoln Center” presents this 50th-annual workshop, which honors George Balanchine, the school’s co-founder, and Alexandra Danilova, a former faculty member, who together devised the year-end student showcase in 1965. Taped in May at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater at Lincoln Center, the all-Balanchine lineup features “Serenade,” the first work he choreographed in the United States, as well as excerpts from “Coppélia,” “Swan Lake” and “Western Symphony.” Peter Martins, ballet master in chief of the New York City Ballet and the school’s artistic director, and his wife, the retired City Ballet principal Darci Kistler, a teacher, talk about the school’s history and the dancers. Above, Addie Tapp and Preston Chamblee.

headline: Children With No Place to Go
abstract: The United Nations estimates that 10,000 children have been orphaned in countries affected by Ebola. Many are stigmatized and shunned by their own communities.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations estimates that 10,000 children have been orphaned in countries affected by Ebola. Many are stigmatized and shunned by their own communities.

headline: A Climate Accord Based on Global Peer Pressure
abstract: The agreement reached in Lima, Peru, would be a breakthrough in 20 years of efforts to create a global warming accord, but it falls short of what scientists say is needed.
lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru — Shortly before 2 a.m. on Sunday, after more than 36 straight hours of negotiations, top officials from nearly 200 nations agreed to the first deal committing every country in the world to reducing the fossil fuel emissions that cause global warming.

headline: Corrections: December 14, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, December 14, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Child’s Play at War in South Sudan
abstract: A filmmaker chronicled how refugee children made their own dolls and houses, which they used to show what the endured in that country’s conflict.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker Andrew Berends traveled to Sudan last year to document the lingering effects of Sudan’s civil war. Although South Sudan was declared an independent country in 2011, the fighting continues.

headline: Jeff Bezos’ Lemonade Stand
abstract: The expansion of Amazon Prime benefits, as well as the company’s many other projects, appears to be fueled in part by fattened margins on physical books.
lead_paragraph: Philip K. Dick’s “The Man in the High Castle” is about what the title character calls the “terribly, terribly disruptive” nature of reality, so it is awesome that the terribly, terribly disruptive Amazon has now filmed this classic science fiction tale. The pilot will appear early next year from Amazon Studios. Any member of the Amazon Prime perks club can watch it free.

headline: There’s So Much to Say About Her Aunt’s Suicide, I Can’t Even Begin.
abstract: It’s been more than four months since my sister took her own life, and I still haven’t spoken with my 12-year-old daughter about it.
lead_paragraph: It’s been more than four months since my sister took her own life, and I still haven’t spoken with my 12-year-old daughter about it.

headline: Petrothoughts
abstract: Delusions of OPEC power.
lead_paragraph: Just leaving a conference in Dubai, and thinking about oil prices. (A lot of the conference was actually about geopolitics, and I don’t want to think about the quite grim stuff from that end.) So, some not especially organized notes.

headline: In Japan, a Landslide Victory for Shinzo Abe’s Party, Despite Scant Enthusiasm
abstract: Exit polls showed the governing party of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe on course to win as many as 306 seats, enough to keep its majority.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Despite low voter turnout, the governing party of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe won a landslide victory in parliamentary elections held Sunday that position Mr. Abe to remain Japan’s leader for several more years.

headline: The Daily Gift: Hot Air Balloons, for Flights of Fancy
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: In Push Against Muslim Cleric, Turkey Detains Police Officers and Journalists
abstract: The authorities took at least 24 officers and media workers into custody on Sunday, days after President Recep Tayyip Erdogan signaled a new campaign against supporters of a U.S.-based Muslim cleric.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Turkish police detained at least 24 police officers, journalists and media workers in raids on Sunday morning, days after President Recep Tayyip Erdogan signaled a new campaign against supporters of an influential Muslim cleric whom he has accused of attempting to overthrow his government.

headline: 1889: Influenza Grips Germany
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A flu epidemic shuts down public services in Berlin in 1889.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Influenza claims Berlin for its own. The schools are gradually becoming deserted. In some, such as that founded by Queen Louisa, many teachers and half the scholars are down with it, so that it has been suggested to let the Christmas holidays begin now. The course of justice has been interrupted by the plague. Absent witnesses, ‘‘Schoeffen’’ (Associate Judges), or lawyers, plead influenza as an excuse.

headline: The U.S. and Torture
abstract: Identifying human rights abusers.
lead_paragraph: America gets picked out of a global lineup.

headline: Israel’s Gas Offers Lifeline for Peace
abstract: A new bonanza of resources could improve the nation’s ties with Egypt, Jordan and even the Palestinian Authority. The linchpin of this diplomatic push: an oil company in Texas.
lead_paragraph: THE TAMAR PLATFORM, Israel — Alarms rang out across the Tamar natural gas platform off the coast of Israel.

headline: Ridley Scott’s ‘Exodus’ Underwhelms at the Box Office
abstract: In its opening weekend, the expensive ‘Exodus: Gods and Kings” brought in only $24.5 million, and will face stronger competition next week.
lead_paragraph: Negative reviews, a difficult release date and skepticism from religious audiences resulted in a mediocre $24.5 million opening weekend for Ridley Scott’s expensive “Exodus: Gods and Kings.”

headline: An American Who Entered North Korea Assails the U.S.
abstract: The man, who identified himself as Arturo Pierre Martinez and said that he had entered North Korea illegally, offered a lengthy criticism of the United States during a news conference.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — An American citizen who said he had illegally entered North Korea held a news conference in the capital, Pyongyang, on Sunday during which he offered a lengthy criticism of the policies of the United States and human rights conditions there, and said that he would seek asylum in Venezuela.

headline: Backing C.I.A., Cheney Revisits Torture Debate From Bush Era
abstract: Former Vice President Dick Cheney mounted a spirited rebuttal to the Senate committee’s torture report, saying there was no comparison between the C.I.A.’s tactics and terrorists’ actions.
lead_paragraph: As vice president, Dick Cheney was the most enthusiastic sponsor for the brutal C.I.A. interrogation program used on Al Qaeda suspects, protesting when President George W. Bush scaled it back in his second term. Now that a Senate Intelligence Committee report has declared that the C.I.A.’s methods, later prohibited, violated American values and produced little or no useful intelligence, Mr. Cheney is fiercely defending not just the agency’s record, but his own as well.

headline: Arson Ruled Out in Fire at West Bank Mosque, Israeli Police Say
abstract: The fire at a mosque near Ramallah last month was most likely caused by an electrical fault, the police said.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A fire at a West Bank mosque last month was most likely caused by an electrical fault and not the result of arson, Israel’s police said on Sunday.

headline: Elections in Kashmir Draw Long Lines of Voters
abstract: Voters in Srinagar said they wanted to blunt the influence of the party led by India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Kashmir’s state elections continued on Sunday as voting took place in the state’s summer capital, Srinagar, with unusually long lines at polling places.

headline: Kerry Piles On Miles, Pressing for a Middle East Compromise
abstract: Secretary of State John F. Kerry traveled to Rome on Sunday to meet Israeli and Palestinian leaders, the new European foreign policy chief and the foreign ministers of Russia, France, Britain and Germany.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With Israel in the middle of an election campaign and the Europeans pressing for a United Nations Security Council resolution on a Middle East negotiating deadline that Israel opposes, Secretary of State John Kerry traveled to Rome on Sunday to try to square the circle.

headline: Amid Assaults on Officers, New York Police Rethink Their Response to Protests
abstract: At least five officers have been assaulted by protesters — including two lieutenants on Saturday during a nighttime melee on the Brooklyn Bridge.
lead_paragraph: In the days after a grand jury declined to bring charges against a New York police officer in the death of Eric Garner on Staten Island, Commissioner William J. Bratton said he expected the large-scale protests that followed to eventually “peter out.”

headline: Sy Berger, Who Turned Baseball Heroes Into Brilliant Rectangles, Dies at 91
abstract: During the 1950s with the Brooklyn-based Topps company, Mr. Berger was credited with creating the modern baseball card, adding color, statistics and facsimiles of stars’ signatures.
lead_paragraph: Sy Berger, who transformed a boys’ hobby into a high-stakes pop culture niche as the father of the modern-day baseball trading card, died on Sunday at his home in Rockville Centre, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 91.

headline: 1939: German Battleship Is Badly Damaged by British Cruisers
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A Nazi battleship, the Admiral Graf Spee, was attacked near Montevideo, Uruguay, in 1939.
lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO — Trapped and battered in an all-day battle with three British cruisers off the coast of Uruguay, the Admiral Graf Spee, German 10,000-ton pocket battleship, lay in the inner harbor of Montevideo today [Dec. 14] while two of its attackers, the Achilles and Ajax, were patrolling the outer harbor, ready to resume the combat as soon as it attempts to put to sea. The third British cruiser, the 8,300-ton Exeter, was damaged and forced to drop out of the fighting four hours after contact was made. There was reported to be several dead and wounded aboard the Exeter, which is putting in to Montevideo tonight with a slight list.

headline: Some Fresh Faces Add New Energy to Bach
abstract: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center’s annual holiday “Brandenburg” concert benefited from new participants this year.
lead_paragraph: With its open-enrollment roster these days and its sponsorship of young performers in its CMS Two program, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has made itself an admirably renewable resource.

headline: Sony Pictures Demands That News Agencies Delete ‘Stolen’ Data
abstract: A letter sent to news media outlets warned against using the information revealed by hackers who attacked the studio’s computer systems.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Sony Pictures Entertainment warned media outlets on Sunday against using the mountains of corporate data revealed by hackers who raided the studio’s computer systems in an attack that became public last month.

headline: PetSmart Accepts $8.7 Billion Buyout
abstract: PetSmart announced on Sunday that it would sell itself to an investor group led by the private equity firm BC Partners, in the biggest leveraged buyout of a company this year.
lead_paragraph: The biggest private equity deal of 2014 — in a year of huge takeovers of cable providers and drug manufacturers — is a bet on the lucrativeness of dog food and catnip.

headline: At Climate Talks in Lima, Not ‘Same as it Ever Was’?
abstract: An environmental journalist says the Lima summit mainly shows how climate diplomacy is racing to catch up with energy progress on the ground.
lead_paragraph: Longtime readers will recall how I’ve cited the Talking Heads lyric “same as it ever was” quite often over the years in assessing negotiations aimed at forging a new global agreement on slowing global warming and limiting its impacts. Some observers at the latest round of negotiations, which ran overtime and ended this morning in Lima, Peru, insist things are no longer the way they were, and that a new theme song may be in order. I was not at the talks this year, so I’m drawing on input from a variety of contacts who were.

headline: Generosity of Everyday Surrealism
abstract: Admirers of Jane Freilicher, who died last Tuesday, attended “Presenting Jane,” a celebration of her life and career.
lead_paragraph: Jane Freilicher, a painter of gauzy Long Island marshes and floral still lifes perched, like observing angels, in windows high above Manhattan, was a leading figure among the New York School artists of the 1950s who reinserted the real world into abstraction. She was also a muse to poets whose careers, like hers, were taking off at the time. And she was a terrific person; smart, funny, generous. In short, she spread good karma all around.

headline: Imagining a Saintly Life, Some of It Not So Holy
abstract: Julia Kristeva, through an alter ego in “Teresa, My Love,” imagines the life of Teresa of Ávila.
lead_paragraph: It is hard, even knowing just a few facts about Teresa of Ávila, not to fall in love with her. This 16th-century Spanish mystic, saint and doctor of the church could sigh over her own limitations with the precision, earthiness and wit of a born writer. “I could be bribed by a sardine,” she once wrote. Nor did she muffle her sighs over the sisters in her care. “Believe me,” she wrote, “I fear an unhappy nun more than many devils.”

headline: What’s the Deal? Gifts for the Bridge Player
abstract: Let’s have a look at some books that might be worthwhile gifts for your bridge-playing friends or yourself.
lead_paragraph: Let’s have a look at some books that might be worthwhile gifts for your bridge-playing friends or yourself.

headline: Odell Beckham Jr. Puts On a Show, Leaving Defenders and Fans Stupefied
abstract: Bekham scored three touchdowns, and the Giants avoided falling too far behind as Robert Griffin III’s dive for an apparent score was eventually ruled a fumble out the side of the end zone.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The glow emanating from the blossoming career of Odell Beckham Jr. has come to this: Many fans in the stands at MetLife Stadium focus their attention on him, and only him, when the Giants’ offense is on the field.

headline: Revamping the Louvre to Lose That Lost Feeling
abstract: Jean-Luc Martinez, the president of the Louvre, is overseeing a nearly $67 million makeover to help newcomers crack the code of the labyrinthine museum.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The storybook rise of Jean-Luc Martinez begins where he grew up, in a Paris suburb dominated by blocky public housing. It ends deep within the opulent palace of the Louvre museum, where he is plotting what he calls a “petite révolution.”

headline: A Steady Hand at the Helm as Heat Turns Into Sparks
abstract: Christoph von Dohnanyi conducted the New York Philharmonic in works by Dvorak at Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Call it “Demi-Dohnanyi/Dvorak.” After missing the first week of the New York Philharmonic mini-festival named for him, the eminent conductor Christoph von Dohnanyi, evidently recovered from the flu, made it to Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday for the series’s second and final program.

headline: Choreographer Unearths Surprises in Tchaikovsky’s Score
abstract: American Ballet Theater’s “The Nutcracker,” by Alexei Ratmansky, has its last season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music before shifting to California next year.
lead_paragraph: The holiday season is supposed to be a time to count your blessings and be generous to others. For holiday fare, New Yorkers have “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker,” imperishable and unsurpassable at 60, danced every year by New York City Ballet. With such a reliable supply of true winter magic, it would be greedy to want more, greedy to be upset that the “Nutcracker” that American Ballet Theater has been presenting at the Brooklyn Academy of Music each December since 2010 will be moving next year to Costa Mesa, Calif.

headline: Unfold, Open, Reveal: Hearst Reimagines Magazine Covers
abstract: Hearst Magazines is reimagining its covers with zippers, doors, flaps, fold-outs and more to encourage Madison Avenue to spend more on its print products.
lead_paragraph: IF Irving Berlin were around to update his song “The Girl on the Magazine Cover,” the new lyrics — minus the old-fashioned term “girl,” in all likelihood — might describe the cover of a magazine featuring a diagonal strip resembling a zipper, which when pulled down reveals an actress dressed in denim and flanked on both sides by jeans ads.

headline: In Space, No One Can Hear You Scheme
abstract: In “Ascension,” it’s 2014 on Earth, but aboard a spacecraft, it’s as if “Mad Men” had been sealed in a giant tin can and shot aloft.
lead_paragraph: The Syfy channel has given us some of 2014’s silliest programming (that “Sharknado” sequel comes to mind), but it has saved one of its slickest offerings for late in the year. “Ascension,” a mini-series running Monday through Wednesday, has an intriguing premise, lots of plot twists and high production values. If you’re sick of sitcoms’ holiday episodes, this alternative is worth a look.

headline: The Rebels With Faces Less Known
abstract: “The American Revolution” is a collection of mini-stories about people not named George Washington or Paul Revere who played parts in the American Revolution.
lead_paragraph: “The American Revolution” isn’t great history programming, but it does teach us one thing: There are a lot of ways to help along an independence movement.

headline: Nobel Gives French Novelist U.S. Boost
abstract: Houghton Mifflin Harcourt has acquired Patrick Modiano’s latest novel, “So You Don’t Get Lost in the Neighborhood,” to be published in late 2015.
lead_paragraph: When the French novelist Patrick Modiano won the Nobel Prize in literature this fall, his work was virtually unknown here. Just a handful of his roughly 30 books were available in the United States, and they had collectively sold just a few thousand copies.

headline: A Shoemaker, Just Passing Through
abstract: The German baritone Michael Volle steps into the role of Sachs for two performances of “Die Meistersinger” at the Met.
lead_paragraph: When the baritone Johan Reuter, who was scheduled to sing the demanding role of Hans Sachs in the Metropolitan Opera’s revival of Wagner’s “Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg” this fall, withdrew in September, Peter Gelb, the company’s general manager, tried to line up the German baritone Michael Volle to take over. At 54, Mr. Volle is in his prime and in demand. He sang Sachs to acclaim in a new production at the Salzburg Festival in 2013 (a production that will be coming to the Met in five years).

headline: Freeze!
abstract: In which I totally confuse myself. On a Monday puzzle, yet.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Did you have a tough time sussing out this theme? All you need to do, apparently, is to STOP and think carefully.

headline: Gibney Dance Selects Artists for Residency Program
abstract: Winners include Wally Cardona, Jeanine Durning and Marjani Fortè.
lead_paragraph: The first 10 recipients of Gibney Dance’s recently expanded Dance in Process residency program for midcareer artists have been selected, organizers of the company announced on Sunday. The recipients are Wally Cardona, Jeanine Durning, Marjani Fortè, Patricia Hoffbauer, robbinschilds (the duo Sonya Robbins and Layla Childs), Anna Sperber, David Thomson, Kota Yamazaki, Keely Garfield and Silas Riener.

headline: A Personal Message From Pope Francis Resonates With Sing Sing Inmates
abstract: The pope, in response to a drawing by an inmate, sent a rosary, letters and a promise to keep those at the prison in his prayers.
lead_paragraph: OSSINING, N.Y. — Inside a cool, rugged chapel of tan brick and brown benches, the Rev. Tom Ahearn read a passage about repentance from the Gospel of St. Mark. “A voice of one that cries in the desert,” Father Ahearn said. “Prepare a way for the Lord, make his paths straight.”

headline: College Data Tools
abstract: Melinda Mechur Karp of Teachers College, Columbia University, responds to an Op-Ed article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Renouncing Citizenship
abstract: Responding to an Op-Ed writer who is giving up his United States passport, two readers say citizenship is more than a financial decision.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Japan’s Wartime Record
abstract: Sumio Kusaka, consul general of Japan, responds to an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Colorful Nets Fan Is Gravely Injured in Fall From Building
abstract: Jeffrey Vanchiro, 38, who has gained widespread attention as a colorful and outspoken fan of the Nets, was not expected to survive after falling from a second-story window in Flushing, Queens.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Vanchiro, who has gained widespread attention as a colorful and outspoken fan of the Nets, was on a ventilator late Sunday afternoon and was not expected to survive after falling from a second-story window in Flushing, Queens, on Saturday night.

headline: An Alliance to Loosen Energy Rules
abstract: Readers discuss how corporate interests are donating large sums to Republican attorneys general.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Human Rights Group’s Office Destroyed in Arson Attack
abstract: The office of the Committee Against Torture, which has been investigating the practice of punitive house burning in Chechnya, was itself destroyed.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The office of a human rights group that is investigating the practice of so-called punitive house burning in the restive Russian region of Chechnya was itself destroyed in what appeared to be an arson attack over the weekend.

headline: Uber Taxis, Not Accessible
abstract: Edith Prentiss of the Taxis for All Campaign writes that all taxis, including Uber, should be accessible.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Week Magazine’s Subscriber Base Grows
abstract: Total circulation for The Week, a publication that includes a roundup of news, has been lifted by gift subscriptions.
lead_paragraph: While many people treat the holidays as the perfect time to give the latest iPhone or video game, some gift givers are opting for a more traditional present this year: a subscription to the print magazine The Week.

headline: The Sony Hack and the Yellow Press
abstract: Every news outlet that did the bidding of Sony’s hackers is morally treasonous and spectacularly dishonorable.
lead_paragraph: “Jolie a ‘Spoiled Brat’ From ‘Crazyland,’ ” says The New York Post.

headline: Did Salaita Cross the Line of ‘Civility’?
abstract: A controversial tweet about Israel’s bombing of Gaza this summer wasn’t true. But it ought to be.
lead_paragraph: The case of Steven Salaita has been hotly debated both in and out of academic circles in the past few months. Salaita is the Palestinian-American professor and scholar whose offer of a tenured teaching position in the American Indian Studies Program at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign was rescinded by the school’s chancellor because of some very strongly worded tweets he published regarding Israel’s attack on Gaza this summer. That attack followed a series of events that had heightened tension between the Israeli government and Hamas, the de facto ruling party in Gaza, culminating in Hamas’s launching rockets into Israel and then Israel’s mounting a huge aerial assault and ground invasion against Gaza. On September 11 of this year, the university’s board of trustees voted to uphold the chancellor’s decision.

headline: Black Flag Is Hoisted as an Armed Person Takes Hostages in a Sydney Cafe
abstract: Police officers surrounded the cafe in the central business district where hostages held a flag with writing that appeared to be the shahada, the Muslim declaration of faith.
lead_paragraph: Read here for updates to the Sydney hostage siege.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Thunder at Warriors
abstract: Oklahoma City, in a precarious situation because of injuries to its stars, is going to have to steal some wins from the Western Conference’s best, a tier that includes Golden State.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Stockholm’s Housing Shortage Threatens to Stifle Fast-Growing Start-Ups
abstract: The Swedish capital serves as a cautionary tale about the troubles that arise when a booming technology sector runs into city planning rules unchanged for decades.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — Tyler Faux thought finding a place to live in New York City was tough.

headline: Free Ballet at Columbus Circle
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A young ballerina and her partner suddenly appeared in Columbus Circle and danced for 20 minutes, not for money or even applause, but for an unseen audience.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Brownback’s Tax Cuts Not Set in Stone as Kansas Faces Budget Shortfall
abstract: Within days of winning re-election, Gov. Sam Brownback was confronted with forecasts that the state would bring in a billion dollars less than initially projected over the next two years.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — As Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas campaigned for a second term this year, he was forced to fend off repeated criticism that his deep income tax cuts — the hallmark of his tenure — had put the state in a fiscal nose-dive.

headline: Capturing Carbon as a Byproduct of Running a Fuel Cell
abstract: An experimental fuel cell uses a process in which one stage emits carbon dioxide and another stage absorbs it.
lead_paragraph: DANBURY, Conn. — The more that engineers look, the more they find unexpected ways to capture carbon dioxide, a gas that scientists say threatens global climate stability.

headline: Senate Affirms Ambassador for Freedom of Religion
abstract: The Senate has confirmed the nomination of David N. Saperstein, a prominent Reform rabbi, to be ambassador at large for international religious freedom, in charge of countering religious persecution around the world.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate has confirmed the nomination of David N. Saperstein, a prominent Reform rabbi, to be ambassador at large for international religious freedom, in charge of countering religious persecution around the world.

headline: Elegy for the ‘Suits’
abstract: At least music executives imposed some quality control.
lead_paragraph: I WAS the worst kind of music retailer. I got high on my own supply. What a rush it was to anticipate the new release from a favorite artist. If my store was out of stock on an item, there was a good chance it was because my partner and I took the last copies home.

headline: As Archie Nears 75, Riverdale Gets a Youthful Infusion
abstract: A new creative team at Archie Comics plans to reinvigorate the teenage redhead with a more contemporary attitude, a Fox TV series and a Marc Ecko clothing line.
lead_paragraph: After nearly 75 years of chasing girls through the halls of Riverdale High and hanging out at Pop Tate’s soda shop, the teenage Everyman Archie Andrews is headed for a makeover.

headline: A Town, if Not a Painting, Is Restored
abstract: Grief at a botched retouching of a church fresco has turned to gratitude for divine intervention — the blessing of free publicity — that has made Borja, Spain, a magnet for thousands of curious tourists.
lead_paragraph: BORJA, Spain — After an 83-year-old widow and amateur painter tried her hand at restoring a nearly century-old fresco of Jesus crowned with thorns in her local church here, she faced nothing but scorn and ridicule.

headline: In Big Data, Shepherding Comes First
abstract: Aspiring big data software companies find themselves training, advising and building pilot projects for their customers — acting far more as services companies than they hope to be eventually.
lead_paragraph: Big data is increasingly moving into the mainstream, as companies in every industry begin to combine an abundance of digital data with smart software to analyze it. It is a potential gold mine for software makers, with analysts predicting torrid growth for the market overall.

headline: For José Gutiérrez, the Only Growth Is the Line at the Food Pantry
abstract: Statistics showing a rising economy mean little to low-wage earners like Mr. Gutiérrez, who hasn’t had a raise in five years and whose food stamps were cut last year.
lead_paragraph: Statistics showing a rising economy mean little to low-wage earners like Mr. Gutiérrez, who hasn’t had a raise in five years and whose food stamps were cut last year.

headline: St. John’s, Mindful of Its City Standing, Wins at Garden
abstract: No. 24 St. John’s, which beat Syracuse earlier this month, continued to make its case to be known as New York’s team with a 74-53 win over Fordham.
lead_paragraph: On the streets near Madison Square Garden on Sunday afternoon, taxis occasionally pulled up with ads atop their roofs proclaiming Syracuse “New York’s College Team.”

headline: Three Months of Protests End Quietly in Hong Kong
abstract: Pro-democracy protests that swept onto the streets of Hong Kong 11 weeks ago faced a muted ending on Monday, when the police prepared to dismantle the last remaining road occupation.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Pro-democracy protests that swept onto the streets of Hong Kong 11 weeks ago faced a muted ending on Monday, when the police dismantled the last remaining road occupation, and a prominent student activist, Joshua Wong, appeared in court with about 30 other arrested protesters.

headline: A Growing Economic Recovery Bypasses Low-Wage Workers and Their Tables
abstract: About one in six New Yorkers go hungry, and food pantries and soup kitchens are reporting increased demand from people whose food stamp benefits were reduced last year.
lead_paragraph: It is the season of twinkling lights and glittering evergreens, festive parties and holiday bonuses. But not for José Gutiérrez.

headline: Sowing Mayhem, One Click at a Time
abstract: Charles C. Johnson, a blogger based in California, may be the ultimate expression of a certain kind of citizen journalism — one far more toxic than we’re accustomed to seeing.
lead_paragraph: The Internet has given us many glorious things: streaming movies, multiplayer games, real-time information and videos of cats playing the piano. It has also offered up some less edifying creations: web-borne viruses, cybercrime and Charles C. Johnson.

headline: With Late Collapse, Rutgers Fails Test Against Highly Ranked Rival
abstract: The No. 17 Scarlet Knights, playing at home, were outscored by 16-2 down the stretch by the No. 11 Lady Vols of Tennessee in falling to 8-2.
lead_paragraph: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — Rutgers has rejoined the discussion when it comes to evaluating the finest women’s basketball programs in the nation. How prominently the Scarlet Knights should be viewed remains uncertain.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Dec. 15
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Waters Warm, and Cod Catch Ebbs in Maine
abstract: The Gulf of Maine’s waters are warming — faster than almost any ocean waters on earth, scientists say — and fish are voting with their fins for cooler places to live.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Me. — In the vast gulf that arcs from Massachusetts’s shores to Canada’s Bay of Fundy, cod was once king. It paid for fishermen’s boats, fed their families and put their children through college. In one halcyon year in the mid-1980s, the codfish catch reached 25,000 tons.

headline: Sony’s International Incident: Making Kim Jong-un’s Head Explode
abstract: Sony’s executives now say they knew that basing a film on the assassination of Kim Jong-un of North Korea had inherent risks.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — When Sony Pictures began casting last year for a new comedy to be called “The Interview,” early scripts included the assassination of a fictionalized North Korean ruler. It was not until auditions began that actors learned that the movie would portray something much more brazen: the violent killing of the actual leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-un.

headline: With No Stadium on Horizon, Chances Dim for a Move to Los Angeles in 2015
abstract: In a game of cat and mouse, no one appears willing to build a stadium in Los Angeles until a team has committed to moving there.
lead_paragraph: The chances of an N.F.L. team’s moving to Los Angeles next season may be dimming.

headline: The Rise of a New Smartphone Giant: China’s Xiaomi
abstract: Founded in 2010 to sell cheap phones online, the company has become the No. 3 producer worldwide behind Apple and Samsung and is looking toward Brazil and India.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In China, the smartphone battle used to be Samsung versus Apple. But not anymore.

headline: Are Midwives Safer Than Doctors?
abstract: For many women, midwives offer good, cost-effective maternity care. There is no reason that their role should not be expanded.
lead_paragraph: In a clinical assessment that could have implications for the United States, Britain’s National Institute for Health and Care Excellence has concluded that it is safer for healthy women with uncomplicated pregnancies to give birth under the supervision of midwives than in a hospital maternity ward run by doctors. The reason: Doctors are much more likely than midwives to use interventions like forceps deliveries, spinal anesthesia and cesarean sections — procedures that carry risks of infection and surgical accidents.

headline: As Johnny Manziel Takes a Hit, So Does Cleveland
abstract: The buzz created by Browns Coach Mike Pettine’s decision to put the rookie quarterback Manziel under center was drowned out by the Bengals’ stout defense.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — This city began Sunday shrouded in fog and brimming with expectation. Ever since Browns Coach Mike Pettine had announced a change at quarterback, the wait had been excruciating, the five days passing like a kidney stone.

headline: Undocumented Immigrants Line Up for Door Opened by Obama
abstract: Thousands gathered for an information session organized by advocacy groups offering unauthorized immigrants assessments of whether they meet the requirements to apply to stay in the United States.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — They pushed strollers, tugged toddlers and streamed into the convention center in the heart of this city on Sunday, thousands of immigrants here illegally and anxious to find out if they could gain protection from deportation under executive actions by President Obama.

headline: A Speck on the Map Gushes Talent
abstract: The small country of Curaçao, part of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, has been the source of a surge of talent to Major League Baseball.
lead_paragraph: TERA KORA, Curaçao — Much of the ground in Curaçao is hard and sandy, full of pebbles and small rocks that are strewn everywhere, including the coarse-dirt infields of this small island nation’s many baseball fields.

headline: New Yorker Film Critic Shifts to Staff Writer
abstract: David Denby, a film critic for The New Yorker since 1998, will write “longer critic-at-large pieces” on films, books and other topics, according to the magazine.
lead_paragraph: David Denby, a film critic for The New Yorker since 1998, will step down from that role in early 2015, though he will remain a staff writer, the magazine said over the weekend.

headline: Investigation of Rikers Island Transportation Strike
abstract: A city official investigated whether a transportation shutdown was carried out to coincide with the criminal trial of corrections officers Kevin Gilkes and Louis Pinto for use of excessive force against an inmate.
lead_paragraph: A city official investigated whether a transportation shutdown was carried out to coincide with the criminal trial of corrections officers Kevin Gilkes and Louis Pinto for use of excessive force against an inmate.

headline: A Victory and No Interceptions, but Still Lots of Questions About Geno Smith
abstract: Smith had 16 completions for 179 yards and a touchdown as the Jets won in Tennessee, but he continued to display the inconsistency that has frustrated many Jets fans.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — The flash of brilliant play revealed itself midway through the third quarter of a game that may ultimately determine Geno Smith’s fate with the Jets. Smith, the much-criticized quarterback who is slogging through his second professional season, guided a touchdown drive with a series of throws to lend a bit of credibility to his Pro Bowl comments that caused nationwide chortles last week.

headline: Virtual Reality ‘Wild’ Trek, With Reese Witherspoon
abstract: Fox Searchlight and its partners will introduce “Wild — The Experience,” a three-minute, 360-degree, virtual reality encounter with Ms. Witherspoon, the star of the film “Wild,” in character as Cheryl Strayed.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — They read the book. They saw the movie.

headline: In Final Spending Bill, Salty Food and Belching Cows Are Winners
abstract: The $1.1 trillion package that cleared the Senate over the weekend was, like many of its predecessors, filled with provisions to satisfy special interests.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Health insurance companies preserved their tax breaks. Farmers and ranchers were spared having to report on pollution from manure. Tourist destinations like Las Vegas benefited from a travel promotion program.

headline: At Rikers Island, Union Chief’s Clout Is a Roadblock to Reform
abstract: Norman Seabrook’s long reign as president of the correction officers’ union has paid dividends for his members, but has also fed a culture of corruption and violence at the Rikers jail complex.
lead_paragraph: With brutality by guards at the Rikers Island jail complex rising at an alarming rate, the chief investigator for the New York City Correction Department stood before a roomful of senior officers and union leaders in the summer of 2012 and outlined her plans to crack down on abuse and send more cases to prosecutors.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: The Screen Actors Guild nominations were announced on Wednesday, Dec. 10, and the Golden Globes followed on Dec. 11. Online chatter for the top Golden Globe films shows substantial activity and a large 24-hour jump.
lead_paragraph: The Screen Actors Guild nominations were announced on Wednesday, Dec. 10, and the Golden Globes followed on Dec. 11. Online chatter for the top Golden Globe films shows substantial activity and a large 24-hour jump.

headline: Brennan Draws on Bond With Obama in Backing C.I.A.
abstract: The close relationship that John O. Brennan, the C.I.A. director, has with President Obama helped shape his assertive response to a scathing Senate report on agency torture.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just hours before he publicly responded last week to the Senate Intelligence Committee report accusing the Central Intelligence Agency of torture and deceit, John O. Brennan, the C.I.A.’s director, stopped by the White House to meet with President Obama.

headline: History Continues to Repeat for a Struggling Franchise
abstract: At a time when the N.F.L. finds itself reacting to one moral crisis after another, Dan Snyder, the Redskins owner, is a symbol and a product of the erosion of an industry whose highest value is profit and preservation of the institution.
lead_paragraph: New York and Washington met Sunday in their 164th regular-season pairing, with the Giants emerging victorious in a game with no postseason implications for either team.

headline: New York Archdiocese Appears Likely to Shutter More Churches
abstract: Documents show that Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan has proposed that an additional 38 parishes merge, in addition to the 112 that were announced in November.
lead_paragraph: The sweeping reorganization of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, set to take effect next year, is likely to involve the merger or the closing of significantly more parishes than was originally announced last month, archdiocese documents show.

headline: Cuba’s Economy at a Crossroads
abstract: A change in Washington’s attitude could help tip Havana toward liberalization.
lead_paragraph: In July 2007, while serving as acting president as his brother underwent medical treatment, Raúl Castro delivered a startling indictment of the Cuban economy when he railed about the inefficiencies of the dairy industry. His description of the onerous and expensive mechanism to get milk from cows to dinner tables was old news to Cubans, who have been subjected for decades to a centrally planned economy that is among the world’s most dysfunctional and anomalous. It soon became clear that Mr. Castro’s unexpected candor that day signaled the start of a transformational era for the island’s economy.

headline: La economía de Cuba en una encrucijada
abstract: Un cambio de actitud por parte de Washington podría ayudar a acelerar las reformas.
lead_paragraph: En julio de 2007, cuando Raúl Castro estaba al mando del país mientras su hermano recibía atención médica, el presidente interino emitió una crítica asombrosa de la economía cubana al describir las ineficiencias de la industria láctea. Su descripción del oneroso y costoso mecanismo para llevar la leche de las vacas hasta la mesa familiar era una historia ya conocida para los cubanos, quienes han sido sometidos por décadas a una economía centralizada, que se encuentra entre las más disfuncionales y anómalas del mundo. Pronto se hizo evidente que la inesperada franqueza de Castro ese día representaba el inicio de una era de transformación para la economía de la isla.

headline: Sidney Crosby Out After Tests Reveal Case of Mumps
abstract: Crosby tested positive for the mumps on Sunday and will miss at least one more game for Pittsburgh, which is believed to be the sixth N.H.L. team to be affected by the outbreak of the viral disease.
lead_paragraph: The N.H.L.’s mumps outbreak claimed its most famous victim Sunday as the Pittsburgh Penguins announced that Sidney Crosby was out with the viral disease.

headline: Raindrops on Roses, for the Potentially Suicidal
abstract: Duncan Macmillan and Jonny Donahoe’s “Every Brilliant Thing” offers a long list of reasons not to commit suicide.
lead_paragraph: Even the most dry-eyed among us get weepy in December. There’s something about short, dark days piling up toward another year’s end, while carolers trill about comfort and joy, that brings out the Niobe in men and women of stone. Put one of them in front of a television with James Stewart on the brink in “It’s a Wonderful Life,” and you’ll need mops to wipe up the tears.

headline: The Final Story for a Paean to Journalism
abstract: Aaron Sorkin’s HBO series “The Newsroom” ended after three seasons, and despite strong writing and a charming cast, the show was eclipsed by more knowing and acerbic dramas about journalism and society.
lead_paragraph: “The Newsroom” came to a close Sunday on HBO, and even after three seasons, this Aaron Sorkin series is still puzzling. It was a paean to journalism that many journalists hated, an inside look at the immediacy of a 24-hour cable news division that was set two years in the past. Oddest of all, it was a 1940s-style screwball comedy about reporters filled with sanctimony, not cynicism: a “His Girl Friday” by Allen Drury.

headline: Hostage Standoff in Sydney, Australia
abstract: The man who took hostages in the city’s business district was described by the prime minister as “an armed person claiming political motivation.”
lead_paragraph: The man who took hostages in the city’s business district was described by the prime minister as “an armed person claiming political motivation.”

headline: Neil Reshen, 75, Dies; Manager Won ‘Outlaw’ Singers’ Freedom
abstract: Mr. Reshen, who started out doing music executives’ taxes, made deals for Willie Nelson, Waylon Jennings and others.
lead_paragraph: Neil Reshen, a New Yorker whose fierce negotiating with record labels helped a couple of twangy Texans named Waylon and Willie become the iconoclastic voices of “outlaw” country music, died on Dec. 6 in the Bronx. He was 75.

headline: Euro Minister’s Trip to Athens, the Fed’s Policy Statement, and a $392 Billion Plan
abstract: Europe’s economic affairs commissioner is to visit Athens, the Federal Reserve will hold its final meeting of the year, and European leaders will gather in Brussels for a summit.
lead_paragraph: EURO MINISTER HEADS TO ATHENS IN SUPPORT OF GREEK PRESIDENT

headline: An Unlikely Source of Big Talent
abstract: The small country of Curaçao, part of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, has been the source of a surge of players to Major League Baseball.
lead_paragraph: The small country of Curaçao, part of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, has been the source of a surge of players to Major League Baseball.

headline: State Aid Formula Said to Hurt in a District Where Most Go to Yeshivas
abstract: While a state monitor recently accused the East Ramapo school board of mismanagement that favored its yeshivas, New York’s formula gives the public schools below-average state aid.
lead_paragraph: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y. — A monitor chosen by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo recently accused the East Ramapo school board in Rockland County, which is dominated by Orthodox Jews who send their children to private yeshivas, of systematically starving the public schools in favor of the yeshivas.

headline: Long Island Could Lead in New York’s Gambling Plans With New Sites
abstract: Nassau and Suffolk Counties are planning to open electronic slot machine parlors years before proposed casino resorts could open north and west of New York City.
lead_paragraph: The first new gambling halls in New York are most likely to be “slots in a box,” not the lavish casino resorts with hotels, restaurants and entertainment centers promoted by state officials.

headline: Climbing Out of a Deep Depression by Learning to Lean on Others
abstract: After complications from knee surgery, Iris Nieves sank into a depression so severe she said she realized the only way out was to seek assistance.
lead_paragraph: From a very young age, Iris Nieves served as a caretaker and provider, roles that made it difficult for her to ask for help.

headline: America, Who Are We?
abstract: We can shout and protest, but we must vote, too.
lead_paragraph: Last week I spoke at a seminary and graduate school in New York about the protests following the grand jury decisions in the Michael Brown and Eric Garner cases.

headline: Wall Street’s Revenge
abstract: How the Masters of the Universe got politicians to bring back moral hazard.
lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, 2010 was the year of “Obama rage,” in which financial tycoons went ballistic over the president’s suggestion that some bankers helped cause the financial crisis. They were also, of course, angry about the Dodd-Frank financial reform, which placed some limits on their wheeling and dealing.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 14, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Tim Hardaway Jr. and Knicks Step Up, but Fall in Overtime
abstract: Without J. R. Smith, the Knicks were able to put up a strong fight against the Raptors but lost after missing their first seven shots in the extra period.
lead_paragraph: Every limp is met with a sigh these days at Madison Square Garden, every wince greeted by another somber roll of the eyes. First the losses piled up for the Knicks; now the injuries have arrived like a cruel prank after the team’s first victory since Thanksgiving.

headline: Corrections: December 15, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Monday, December 15, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: D’Angelo Releases First Album in 15 Years
abstract: “Black Messiah” is the third studio album for the enigmatic soul singer.
lead_paragraph: In a Beyoncé-style surprise release, “Black Messiah,” the third studio album and the first in nearly 15 years from the enigmatic soul singer D’Angelo, is available now on iTunes.

headline: Word of the Day | carnivorous
abstract: This word has appeared in 29 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: carnivorous •\kär-ˈni-v(ə-)rəs\• adjective

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7 P.M. (HBO) SAVING MY TOMORROW “I used to think that no one would listen to you unless you were a grown-up, but then I realized, well, I really don’t have time to grow up,” says Ta’Kaiya Blaney, a member of the Sliammon First Nation in British Columbia and an environmental activist since the age of 8. “And so I decided I’m going to try and fight for my future just as I am and just as the age that I am.” Ms. Blaney is one in a chorus of children, like those above, speaking and singing out for Mother Earth in this kaleidoscopic family special, created with the American Museum of Natural History, which smushes together science and animation, readings by Tina Fey, Liam Neeson and Neil deGrasse Tyson, and music by Pharrell Williams, Ziggy Marley and They Might Be Giants to address the perils of pollution, drilling and climate change. “We’re the ancestors of the many generations to come, and you know, we have a chance to do something and to change the world for the better,” says Ms. Blaney, now 13. “It can make a huge difference on the future.”

headline: Sydney Hostage Siege Ends With Gunman and 2 Captives Dead as Police Storm Cafe
abstract: The police burst into a downtown cafe where customers and employees had been captive for 16 hours, after officers reported hearing gunshots.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Heavily armed police officers ended a hostage siege in Sydney early Tuesday, storming a downtown cafe where an armed man had held employees and customers for more than 16 hours.

abstract: Led by Odell Beckham Jr., who had three touchdown catches, the Giants defeated Washington for their fifth win of the season.
lead_paragraph: Led by Odell Beckham Jr., who had three touchdown catches, the Giants defeated Washington for their fifth win of the season.

lead_paragraph: For the ride service Uber, it is getting hard to go a week without facing a new problem outside the United States.

headline: Inner Mongolian Court Exonerates Teenager Executed for Murder

headline: Technip of France Drops Pursuit of Oil Services Firm CGG

lead_paragraph: LONDON – Technip of France has abandoned its pursuit of CGG, a French oil services company, and has said that it will not make an offer directly to investors.

headline: A Photographer’s Forest Tale
abstract: Anna Beeke didn’t encounter giants or princesses imprisoned in towers as she photographed forests. Her sylvan adventure led to no holy grail, but it did produce a photo project.
lead_paragraph: Forests appear throughout literature, from fairy tales and adventure stories to Arthurian romances.

headline: What Do You Look Forward to Most–and Least–During the Holiday Season?
abstract: Do you think the holiday season has too much emphasis on buying things?
lead_paragraph: Soon, the holidays will be upon us, bringing days off from school and work, visits with loved ones, religious ceremonies and in many cases, gifts.

abstract: As Paris taxis staged a go-slow protest on Monday, an Interior Ministry spokesman said the ride-booking service would be prohibited as of Jan. 1.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The problems facing Uber, the popular ride-booking service, are going from bad to worse.

lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Irish building materials group CRH said on Monday that Bain Capital’s European arm was buying its brick and concrete businesses in Britain and its brick maker in the United States in a deal that valued the units at 414 million pounds, or about $650 million.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

lead_paragraph: LONDON – Terra Firma, the European private equity fund founded by the British financier Guy Hands, is considering an exit from one of its big bets on renewable energy.
