abstract: Monday: The police re-evaluate strategy, sunny skies, and a latke festival.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this sunny Monday.

headline: Murder Charge Is Recommended for U.S. Marine in Death of Transgender Filipino
abstract: Prosecutors opted not to file for the lesser offense of homicide because of aggravating circumstances, including the violent nature of the woman’s death.
lead_paragraph: OLONGAPO CITY, Philippines — Philippine prosecutors on Monday recommended that a United States Marine be charged with murder in connection with the grisly death of a Filipino transgender woman.

headline: Disorderly Chinese Tourists on Thai Flight Draw Official Rebuke
abstract: The China National Tourism Administration has criticized four passengers for their “uncivilized behavior” and said it would record their bad behavior.
lead_paragraph: A group of Chinese tourists returning from Thailand became so agitated over seating arrangements that they have been shamed by China’s tourism authorities for damaging “the overall image of the Chinese people.”

headline: Hostages Are Held Inside Cafe in Sydney, Australia
abstract: Police officers surrounded a cafe in Sydney as the hostage-taking prompted evacuations of major landmarks.
lead_paragraph: Police officers surrounded a cafe in Sydney as the hostage-taking prompted evacuations of major landmarks.

headline: One Business Owner’s Journey to a Health Insurance Plan
abstract: Last year, Paul Downs found that by shopping around instead of renewing an existing policy, he was able to save almost $30,000 on the company’s share of health premiums. Could he repeat that performance this year?
lead_paragraph: With my scalding experience with my bronze policy fresh in my mind, I spent 10 days trying to choose health plans for my employees. This is a double decision: First, choose which insurance company to patronize and then which plans to offer. I’m going to walk you through my experience, so that you can compare what happened to me with your own situation — and maybe make use of some of my tactics.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Dec. 15, 2014
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. A live discussion is offered from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Dec. 16, 2014

headline: Big Data Companies Turn Focus to Support, and Away From Proprietary Software
abstract: Aspiring big data software companies find themselves training, advising and building pilot projects for their customers — acting far more as services companies than they hope to be eventually.
lead_paragraph: Big data is increasingly moving into the mainstream, as companies in every industry begin to combine an abundance of digital data with smart software to analyze it. It is a potential gold mine for software makers, with analysts predicting torrid growth for the market overall.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: The lame-duck Senate gets back to business on Monday and is set to begin approving the executive and judicial branch nominations.
lead_paragraph: In Last Week of Power, Democrats Seek to Fill Vacancies

headline: Fund Manager in London Who Dodged Train Fares Is Barred From Financial Jobs
abstract: The British Financial Conduct Authority said Jonathan Paul Burrows, who had been a managing director at BlackRock, could no longer work in any regulated activities.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Regulators have been accused of not cracking down hard enough on bankers who manipulate the system. That can hardly be said in the case of Jonathan Paul Burrows.

headline: Why Even a Good Midterm Turnout for Democrats in North Carolina Fell Short
abstract: To win re-election, Senator Kay Hagan would have probably needed the young and the nonwhite to turn out as if it were a presidential year.
lead_paragraph: There aren’t many places where low turnout among young and nonwhite voters hurts Democrats more than in North Carolina, a state newly competitive in presidential elections because of rapid generational and demographic changes over the last decade.

headline: Forbidden Topic in Health Policy Debate: Cost Effectiveness
abstract: Understanding how much bang for the buck a given treatment provides is essential, yet many fear it’s a slippery slope to rationing and death panels.
lead_paragraph: If I had a pill that would extend your life by one day, but it cost a billion dollars, it’s unlikely that many people would argue that health insurance should pay for it. We all understand that while the benefit might be real and quantifiable, it’s not worth the expense. But what if the pill cost a million dollars? And what if it extended your life by 10 years?

headline: Morning Agenda: PetSmart’s Big Buyout Deal
abstract: PetSmart agrees to sell itself to a group led by BC Partners. | Wall Street wins a round in the Dodd-Frank fight. | Fines fail to alter banks’ bad behavior. | A tiny Kansas town is in banking’s fast lane.
lead_paragraph: PetSmart agreed on Sunday to sell itself to a group led by the European-American investment firm BC Partners for about $8.7 billion, months after the retailer came under pressure from two hedge funds, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. The agreement is the biggest leveraged buyout of a United States company in a year that has been defined by huge mergers, most of which have been by corporate buyers rather than private equity firms. PetSmart has long been seen as a good target for private equity firms, given its relatively strong cash flow and low debt.

headline: A Corruption Case Laden With Jade
abstract: Ni Fake, a former vice governor of Anhui Province in eastern China, enjoyed being a government official. But what he apparently loved most was jade.
lead_paragraph: Ni Fake, a former vice governor of Anhui Province in eastern China, enjoyed being a government official. But what he apparently loved most was jade.

headline: Emerson Electric Sells Power Business to Regal Beloit
abstract: The deal, for $1.4 billion in cash, is expected to begin adding to Regal Beloit’s earnings per share in 2015.
lead_paragraph: The Emerson Electric Company announced on Monday that it would sell its power transmission business to the Regal Beloit Corporation for $1.4 billion in cash.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Egypt Says It Rejected American Over Visa
abstract: Michele Dunne, a former American diplomat, was turned away at the Cairo airport in a move that had been seen as possible evidence of the military’s crackdown on dissent.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Egyptian Foreign Ministry said in a statement on Sunday night that the American scholar Michele Dunne had been turned away at Cairo’s airport for trying to enter Egypt without a proper visa, contradicting her account of her expulsion and the reports of several Egyptian news outlets.

headline: Asian Art Treasures for One and All
abstract: The Smithsonian’s Freer and Sackler Galleries will put their entire collection — more than 44,000 Asian artworks — online starting Jan. 1.
lead_paragraph: Following several years of photographing, documenting and digitizing, the Smithsonian’s Freer and Sackler Galleries in Washington will put their entire collections — more than 44,000 Asian artworks, many of which have never been publicly displayed — will be available online starting in the new year.

headline: BGC Partners to Buy British Assets of Broker RP Martin
abstract: BGC Partners said it also expected to acquire other assets and businesses of RP Martin, which was fined in the investigation into the manipulation of Libor.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – BGC Partners said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire the British assets of the brokerage firm RP Martin Group for an undisclosed amount. RP Martin was fined in the Libor investigation.

headline: The Daily Gift: A Cheeky Little Monkey
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: Riverbed Technology Agrees to $3.6 Billion Sale

lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after a big activist hedge fund called for a sale of the networking equipment maker Riverbed Technology, the company has finally picked a buyer.

headline: Europe’s Impatience With Israel on Peace Talks Tests U.S. Diplomacy
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry tried to find a way forward as Palestinians pressed for a United Nations Security Council resolution and Europe drafted its own.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The United States finds itself caught between growing European pressure to do more to advance Middle East peace and Washington’s traditional support for Israel, which is in a heated election campaign and reluctant to make unilateral concessions.

headline: The Contenders, by the Box Office Numbers
abstract: Animated films are still the big grossers among the awards-buzz movies, but “The Theory of Everything,” “Wild” and “The Imitation Game” didn’t do too badly over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Here we are in the heart of awards season, and the weekend’s box office results – “Exodus: Gods and Kings” and “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1” led the way — are providing more unneeded proof that the relationship between top-grossing movies and awards-bait films is very often an inverse one.

headline: France Arrests 10 People in Suspected Jihadist Network
abstract: The detentions came amid a series of raids aimed at dismantling a recruitment and transportation network for would-be fighters wanting to reach Syria.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French authorities arrested 10 people on Monday in a series of raids aimed at dismantling a recruitment and transportation network for would-be jihadists wanting to reach Syria, government officials said.

headline: Australian Officials on Cafe Siege
abstract: The police commissioner and the premier of New South Wales discussed the situation at a cafe in Sydney, Australia, where an assailant was holding an unknown number of hostages Monday.
lead_paragraph: The police commissioner and the premier of New South Wales discussed the situation at a cafe in Sydney, Australia, where an assailant was holding an unknown number of hostages Monday.

headline: Should You Have Things?
abstract: Conventional wisdom favors experiences over things, but possessions may have power, too.
lead_paragraph: “To care about possessions can seem like a moral failing,” writes Julie Beck at The Atlantic. “The holiday season especially can make people ornery about ‘stuff’ and the companies that encourage us to buy it.”

headline: Once Ignored, Kosovo Exits Sports Limbo
abstract: Athletes won the right to compete under Kosovo’s flag after the I.O.C. voted to admit the province as a full member.
lead_paragraph: PEJA, Kosovo — Up a steep hill on a narrow, unlit road in this town near the Montenegrin border, the Toni Kuka Judo School was filled with the smell of sweat, smoke and winter.

headline: The Green House Effect: Homes for the Elderly to Thrive
abstract: The common belief is that nursing homes are depressing places where old people go to die. But the Green House project offers cheerful, homelike facilities that are respectful of the needs and wants of elderly Americans.
lead_paragraph: In centuries past, when people got old, they were cared for in the homes of younger relatives until they died. This common custom began to change with the Industrial Revolution when women, who were the primary caregivers for the elderly, started to work outside the home.

headline: The Fight to End the Lord’s Resistance Army Violence
abstract: As the CEO of Invisible Children, I’ve always looked forward to the day when our organization would no longer be needed. That day is close.
lead_paragraph: The paradox of running a nonprofit is that the closer you get to achieving your mission, the closer you get to putting yourself out of a job. As the CEO of Invisible Children, a nonprofit working to end Africa’s longest running armed conflict, I’ve always looked forward to the day when our organization would no longer be needed. That day is close.

headline: Supreme Court Lets Decision on Arizona Abortion Law Stand
abstract: A lower court had found that the law, which limits the availability of medicinal, nonsurgical abortions, had imposed an undue burden on women.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday let stand a decision temporarily blocking an Arizona law that limits the availability of medicinal, nonsurgical abortions. As is its custom when it denies review, the court gave no reasons for its action.

headline: Riedel Creates a New Champagne Glass
abstract: A California olive oil bar in Brooklyn, holiday capons and more food news.
lead_paragraph: To Toast: Thinking Outside the Flute

headline: Xiaomi Releases Financial Data Showing Its Growing Strength
abstract: It will take a while for the Chinese phone maker to catch up to Apple and Samsung.
lead_paragraph: For as long as the Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi  has offered high-performance phones at cheap prices, customers have wondered just how good a deal they’re getting.

headline: Hardships Grow in Ukraine, U.N. Says
abstract: As fighting continues in the rebel-controlled areas of eastern Ukraine, a United Nations report said an average of 13 people were dying every day.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Fighting between Ukrainian government forces and pro-Russian armed groups is claiming an average of 13 lives a day, and after nine months of conflict, the approach of winter has created life-threatening conditions for many civilians in eastern Ukraine, the United Nations reported on Monday.

headline: NBC Extends Contract of Brian Williams for ‘Nightly News’
abstract: Mr. Williams continues to win the ratings battle virtually every week among total viewers, averaging over nine million viewers a night, the program’s best total in almost a decade.
lead_paragraph: Brian Williams, who has been a consistent ratings winner at the anchor desk of the “NBC Nightly News,” has extended his contract with the network, NBC announced Monday.

headline: What is Rikers Island?
abstract: The New York Times has been examining problems at Rikers Island, as well as the New York City Correction Department, which oversees it. Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio has declared that within the next decade, the jail complex at Rikers Island would be shut down. The mayor’s announcement was an acknowledgment that despite the hundreds of millions of dollars devoted to fixing the problems in recent years, the jail cannot be saved. An explainer to help get you up to speed:

headline: Transcript: Warren, in the Present Tense, on 2016
abstract: Senator Elizabeth Warren on her 2016 plans during an interview with NPR this morning.
lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren on her 2016 plans during an interview with NPR this morning.

headline: N.F.L. Sued by Players Union Over Adrian Peterson Ruling
abstract: The complaint, filed on Monday, argues that the league-appointed arbitrator who upheld Peterson’s season-long suspension last week was biased and disregarded collectively bargained rules.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. Players Association sued the N.F.L. on Monday on behalf of Minnesota Vikings running back Adrian Peterson, arguing that the suspension for the remainder of the season that he received for beating his 4-year-old child was unfair and that the arbitrator who upheld the suspension was biased.

headline: A Wonderful Life but Needing a Censor
abstract: Now that my father is an octogenarian, we are noticing how few filters seem to strain his words, particularly when it comes to being politically correct.
lead_paragraph: The holiday season makes me nervous. This is the time of year, after all, that our multigenerational family socializes together the most in our shared home.

headline: ‘Into the Woods': Emily Blunt on Singing for Stephen Sondheim
abstract: The actress talks about naming her nameless character and singing in front of Mr. Sondheim.
lead_paragraph: In the big-budget adaptation of the musical “Into the Woods,” directed by Rob Marshall and set for a Dec. 25 release, Emily Blunt teams up again with Meryl Streep, her on-screen foil in “The Devil Wears Prada” and her off-screen friend. In the new film Ms. Blunt plays the Baker’s Wife, whose yearning for a child sets the intertwining fairy-tale plot in motion. Ms. Streep plays the Witch, who promises to have “the curse reversed” — as Stephen Sondheim’s lyrics go — so the Baker’s Wife will no longer be barren, as long as a few key demands are met. In New York for the film’s premiere this month, before she learned of her Golden Globe nomination for best actress in a musical or comedy, Ms. Blunt had a quick sit-down with the Bagger over English tea to talk about a role she assumed she’d never get; the names she and James Corden, who plays her husband, chose for their characters; and shots from the chest up.

headline: 1889: Natives Attack Mail Boat
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A British mail steamer was attacked at the African port of Lindi in 1889.
lead_paragraph: ZANZIBAR — While a boat from the British mail steamer was delivering the mails at the German port of Lindi, she was attacked by the natives. The boat eventually got off safely, but the natives kept up a fire upon the crew as they returned to the steamer. Mr. Mackenzie arrived here today [Dec. 15] and met with a cordial reception from the Sultan and the natives. He reports having visited all the British East African Company’s posts, and says that he found everywhere signs of greater tranquility and prosperity. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Dec. 16, 1889

headline: Hacked Sony Documents Are Not Pentagon Papers: Editor’s View
abstract: The Times’s executive editor, Dean Baquet, reflects on Sony Pictures Entertainment’s request to avoid publication of material stolen from the studio’s computer system.
lead_paragraph: Sony Pictures Entertainment warned media outlets on Sunday against using material obtained by hackers who raided the studio’s computer systems. In a sharply worded letter sent to news organizations, including The New York Times, David Boies, a lawyer hired by Sony, demanded that news outlets avoid or destroy hacked material. (In a Sunday Op-Ed column, the screenwriter and playwright Aaron Sorkin wrote that journalists shouldn’t help hackers.)

headline: ScienceTake | New View of Flame
abstract: Imaging technique captures the turbulence of hot gases when a match is lit.
lead_paragraph: Imaging technique captures the turbulence of hot gases when a match is lit.

headline: In Video of Burning Match, the Eye Meets More
abstract: Three Stanford researchers, using so-called schlieren imaging, demonstrate the complexities of what seems like an ordinary thing.
lead_paragraph: In the 19th century the great inventor and experimenter Michael Faraday gave a series of public lectures on the chemistry and physics of a candle flame.

headline: E-Cigarettes May Serve as Gateway to Smoking for Teens, Study Suggests
abstract: A study published online Monday in the journal Pediatrics seems to add to the evidence that e-cigarettes are doing more to promote nicotine use than to help people quit.
lead_paragraph: When I was in middle school, I asked my mom if she would be mad if I tried smoking. I’ve never forgotten her answer: “Go ahead and try it,” she said. “You’ll hate it, and you’ll never want to do it again.” So about a year later, when the opportunity presented itself, I took a puff off an older kid’s cigarette in a public bathroom. I could barely inhale, and I’ve never had the desire to try one since.

headline: Police Patrols in New York Public Housing Draw Scrutiny
abstract: Officers walking a beat in the city’s housing projects are watching not only for offenses but also for behavior that is not illegal at all. Citations can lead to evictions.
lead_paragraph: In New York housing projects, police officers can demand identification from people who are hanging out in a public space, like a building lobby. Even if they prove that they live in the building, officers may cite them for “lingering.”

headline: A Modern, Modular Menorah
abstract: T’s pick for Hanukkah this year: Studio Armadillo’s handmade tangram design.
lead_paragraph: By the time Hanukkah begins tomorrow, many large, beautiful Christmas trees will already be up and decorated, so the more modestly scaled menorah needs to get it together and really show everyone what it’s capable of. This ingenious tangram contraption, handmade in Israel by Studio Armadillo, does just that: Its nine modular puzzle pieces — one square and slightly elevated, to serve as the shamash — can be reconfigured in multiple variations, from handsome abstract shapes to a ducky or a dreidel, to the guaranteed delight of grownups and youngsters alike.

headline: 1914: Hotel Seizes Princess’s Art
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A self-styled Hungarian princess left the Plaza Hotel without paying in 1914.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — The self-styled Princess Lwoff-Parlaghy, a Hungarian portrait painter who has made likenesses of crowned heads and many other notable persons, has left her apartment in the Plaza Hotel, owing a bill of $12,000. The management has retained the objects of art in the apartment. It has had them appraised, and is told they are worth more than $100,000. They include portraits of the Kaiser, Mr. August Belmont, Mr. Seth Low, the late Mr. Whitelaw Reid and the late General Daniel E. Sickles. King Edward VII visited her exhibition in Marienbad in 1904 and promised to give her some sittings for a portrait. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Dec. 16, 1914

headline: Wright Architecture School Sets Fund-raising Goal for Independence
abstract: To achieve its independence from the the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation, an architecture school says it needs to raise $2 million by the end of 2015.
lead_paragraph: The architecture school run by the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation will try to raise $2 million before the end of 2015 to ensure its future as an independent organization, the foundation announced on Monday, having approved a possible path toward the school’s incorporation.

headline: ‘The Newsroom’ Recap: A Too-Sweet Finale
abstract: Now that it’s over, we’re taking names for the last, unseen (and unnamed) character.
lead_paragraph: Season 3, Episode 25, “What Kind of Day Has It Been”

headline: The Consistency of Inconsistency, and How to Adapt Your Financial Goals
abstract: Getting comfortable with uncertainty can help us deal with change when it inevitably happens, a financial planner writes.
lead_paragraph: When my children took their first steps, they were tentative. They were quick to grab the nearest object to keep their balance. However, it didn’t take long before they started acting like they were invincible. Seemingly overnight, my children went from hanging on my legs to running across the room.

headline: Skiing Through Art
abstract: Projectors enable the skier Sage Cattabriga-Alosa to use snow as his own canvas.
lead_paragraph: Projectors enable the skier Sage Cattabriga-Alosa to use snow as his own canvas.

headline: Yankees End Competition at Third Base Before It Begins
abstract: The Yankees signed Chase Headley, to a four-year, $52 million contract, but Alex Rodriguez was never returning to third base, anyway.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees insist that they have no real expectations for Alex Rodriguez next season, no way to tell how much, if anything, he has left. They signed another third baseman, Chase Headley, to a four-year, $52 million contract on Monday, but Rodriguez was never returning to third, anyway.

headline: Was Sherlock Holmes Correct?
abstract: Detective Holmes is well on his way to solving another mystery. But is his logic sound?
lead_paragraph: You’re out after a fresh snow and see bike tracks. Can you tell by the tracks which way the bicycle was going?

headline: China Submits an Unexpected Contender and Surprises Even the Director
abstract: The French director Philippe Muyl didn’t think the country would nominate a film by a foreigner, but he said the Chinese may want to send a message about being open to co-productions.
lead_paragraph: The process by which China chooses its submission for the Oscar for best foreign-language film is opaque, as might be expected in a one-party dictatorship, and its choices are often baffling. This year is no exception: Though Zhang Yimou’s “Coming Home,” a gritty drama about the Cultural Revolution, was initially seen as the front-runner, China instead has offered Philippe Muyl’s “The Nightingale.”

headline: Gucci Beats Burberry in Digital Sweepstakes
abstract: L2, a digital think tank, says Gucci is tied with Coach as the most web-savvy luxury brand.
lead_paragraph: Amid all the distracting speculation last week about what has been going on at Gucci that prompted the Kering chief executive Francois-Henri Pinault to decide it was time for both Patrizio di Marco, chief executive, and Frida Giannini, creative director, to leave, there has been one bright spot: On Friday, L2, the digital think tank, announced Gucci had tied with Coach as the most digitally competent brand in luxury.

headline: Court Rules for a Mistaken Police Officer
abstract: The Supreme Court, 8 to 1, ruled that a police officer can stop a car based on a mistaken understanding of the law without violating the Fourth Amendment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A police officer can stop a car based on a mistaken understanding of the law without violating the Fourth Amendment, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday in an 8-1 decision.

headline: Harry Reid Just Wants to Go Home
abstract: As the Senate opened Monday morning, Majority Leader Harry Reid offered Republicans a holiday special: throw in the towel on the Senate’s remaining business and everyone can head home, including Mr. Reid, who is evidently pining for Nevada.
lead_paragraph: As the Senate opened Monday morning, Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, offered Republicans a holiday special: throw in the towel on the Senate’s remaining business, and everyone can head home, including Mr. Reid, who is evidently pining for Nevada.

headline: Prenatal Testing: When a Result Is Not a Diagnosis
abstract: An investigative report found that doctors and patients are misinterpreting new prenatal tests and failing to understand how often a positive screen can be a false alarm.
lead_paragraph: When fetal DNA testing for chromosomal disorders was first introduced in 2011, many experts feared that the improved results would be oversold, leading women to take irreversible steps based on a test that, while an improvement over earlier testing, remains far from conclusive.

headline: Elliott and Jana, Activist Investors, Are Behind 2 Big Buyouts
abstract: The $3.6 billion sale of Riverbed Technology and the $8.7 billion sale of PetSmart are just the latest sales of companies under pressure from the hedge funds Elliott or Jana. A list of some of the others.
lead_paragraph: Behind a fresh pair of buyout deals are two hedge funds that have successfully pressed a number of companies into sales this year.

headline: Australian TV Shows Police Entering Cafe
abstract: Pictures broadcast live on Australian TV show the police entering a Sydney cafe where a man said to be Man Haron Monis, a self-proclaimed sheikh, had been holding an unknown number of people hostage.
lead_paragraph: Pictures broadcast live on Australian TV show the police entering a Sydney cafe where a man said to be Man Haron Monis, a self-proclaimed sheikh, had been holding an unknown number of people hostage.

headline: 3.6 Degrees of Uncertainty
abstract: Science and observation have raised questions of whether the limit of a 2 degrees Celsius temperature increase, a basis of climate negotiations, is stringent enough.
lead_paragraph: After two weeks of grinding meetings in Lima, Peru, the world’s climate negotiators emerged this weekend with a deal. They settled on preliminary language, to be finalized a year from now in Paris, meant to help keep the long-term warming of the planet below 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit.

headline: Carnegie Hall Tribute to David Byrne and Talking Heads
abstract: Performers will include the Roots, Billy Gibbons of ZZ Top, Rufus Wainwright and Steve Earle.
lead_paragraph: David Byrne and Talking Heads will be the next musicians to be celebrated at Carnegie Hall in Michael Dorf’s annual series of tribute concerts that benefit music education. Mr. Byrne and the pioneering art-rock band will be honored on March 23.

headline: British Telecom Company BT Is in Exclusive Talks to Buy EE
abstract: The exclusive talks come as BT is looking to re-enter the mobile phone business as it competes with other carriers who are branching out into broadband and television services.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – BT, the former telecommunications monopoly in Britain, is trying to get back into the mobile business. ​

headline: Barcelona at Field Level: A Pro’s-Eye View
abstract: Even for a professional soccer player, my trip to the Camp Nou to see Barcelona play Paris St.-Germain was an eye opener.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — When you can smell the freshly cut and watered grass, you know you are close. When I sat down with my father in the first row at the Camp Nou last week before Barcelona played Paris St.-Germain in the Champions League, the sprinklers were still on, making the glorious green field slick and fast to suit the style of the home team.

headline: Video: Skiing Through Art
abstract: Projectors enabled the skier Sage Cattabriga-Alosa to use snow as his own canvas.
lead_paragraph: For the veteran skier Sage Cattabriga-Alosa, combining his passions for skiing and art had been a lifelong dream.

headline: Updating I.P.O.s for the Candy Crush Era
abstract: An app produced by Goldman Sachs enables executives of companies going public to track results of roadshow book-building in real time, Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews notes.
lead_paragraph: Bosses of companies heading for the public markets are hooked on an app produced by Goldman Sachs that allows them to track book-building in real time. With Apple and IBM coding mobile software for big companies, the smartphone economy is swiftly moving from the living room to the boardroom.

headline: Key Differences in Being Out of Work for Men and Women
abstract: Men are more eager to work, but tend to watch a lot of TV or surf the web when they’re jobless. Women without jobs are more likely to volunteer and do housework.
lead_paragraph: Women and men who have stopped working, and who live with children, overwhelmingly say they are spending more time with those children, according to the poll of nonworking Americans we released last week, conducted in partnership with CBS News and the Kaiser Family Foundation.

headline: Closer Look at an Underdog
abstract: One prognosticator argues that “Inherent Vice” could benefit from the Academy’s preferential ballot.
lead_paragraph: The SAG and Golden Globe nominations last week brought some clarity to what has been considered a wide-open race. But even with “Boyhood,” “Birdman,” “The Imitation Game” and “The Theory of Everything” scooping up nominations, some longshots remain. Variety argues that “Inherent Vice,” Paul Thomas Anderson’s adaptation of the Thomas Pynchon novel, is among a handful of films that could benefit from the Academy’s preferential ballot, which gives more weight to films that voters have ranked No. 1. Here Mr. Anderson explains the thinking that went into one extended scene in this shaggy detective story.

headline: Instead of Tenants, It’s Cats, Trash and Little Progress for Brooklyn Project
abstract: A construction site on the border between the Williamsburg and Greenpoint sections of Brooklyn has been stalled for about 10 years.
lead_paragraph: The steel beams rise only six stories, not much for New York, but still they overshadow the neighboring rowhouses and warehouses, as the property-to-be in Brooklyn lunges toward the sky with the silent promise of higher rents.

headline: Best Selling Science Books
abstract: Titles, fundamentally based on the sciences, as selected by the science editors from all adult nonfiction books reported to The New York Times for the month.
lead_paragraph: 1 BEING MORTAL  by Atul Gawande. Metropolitan/Holt. The surgeon and New Yorker writer considers how doctors fail patients at the end of life, and how they can do better. (1)

headline: Today in Small Business: A Retail Success for Instagram
abstract: The federal government spending bill quietly includes legislation affecting thousands of small businesses. Ten questions to ask before allowing employees to telecommute. And why retailers keep sending out catalogs.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: The Vanishing Male Worker: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: The Times economics reporter Binyamin Appelbaum explained how he delivered a trend story that resonated.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the Times economics reporter Binyamin Appelbaum wrote a front-page article called “The Vanishing Male Worker: How America Fell Behind.”

headline: Replicating the Sensitive Sides of Spiders’ Legs
abstract: Researchers from South Korea have developed a highly acute sensor based on an organ found in the legs of many spiders.
lead_paragraph: One of the most sensitive vibration sensors in the natural world is the lyriform organ, located in the legs of many spiders. The organ has a series of parallel slits of different lengths, much like the strings on the harplike instrument called the lyre, and helps spiders detect prey.

headline: To Spur Adoptions, an Oakland Cafe Puts Cats Among the Patrons
abstract: Visitors may view a cat cafe as a sort of indoor playspace for cat-loving adults, but the intent at Cat Town Cafe in California is serious.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — On a sun-drenched Saturday, Eddie Metairie wandered around the Cat Town Cafe & Adoption Center, past the miniature-golf-size buildings, cat perches and a bed shaped like a tuna can as he followed Lucia, an independent-minded brown tabby.

headline: Live Chat: Prenatal Screening: When a Result Is Not a Diagnosis
abstract: Join me and New England Center for Investigative Reporting’s Elizabeth Daley, along with experts Dr. Kecia Gaither and Athena Cherry this afternoon, Dec. 15, 2014, from 2 p.m. to 3 p.m. Eastern time, for a live chat about the reliability of prenatal screenings.
lead_paragraph: Join me and New England Center for Investigative Reporting’s Elizabeth Daley, along with the experts Dr. Kecia Gaither, director of perinatal outreach at Montefiore Medical Center and Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York, and Athena Cherry, a professor of pathology and of pediatrics at the Stanford University Medical Center and the Lucile Salter Packard Children’s Hospital, this afternoon, Dec. 15, from 2 p.m. to 3 p.m. Eastern time, for a live chat about prenatal screenings.

headline: A Desert War on ISIS, Fought From a Floating City
abstract: Aboard the U.S.S. Carl Vinson in the Persian Gulf, Navy fighter jets engage in a ballet of coordinated movements in their mission against the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: ABOARD THE U.S.S. CARL VINSON, in the Persian Gulf — More than a dozen Navy F/A-18 warplanes roar off this aircraft carrier every day to attack Islamic State targets in support of Iraqi troops battling to regain ground lost to the militants in June.

headline: German Leader Denounces Anti-Immigrant Surge
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel has denounced the demonstrations in Dresden, where attendance has swelled to 15,000 people, and said there was no place for xenophobia.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — With visible and vocal far-right protests against foreigners swelling in Germany in recent weeks, Chancellor Angela Merkel forcefully denounced the demonstrations on Monday, affirming that the country has both a special obligation and a desire to welcome anyone in need of sanctuary.

headline: Walkabout: Strike in Belgium Disrupts Air and Rail Traffic
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Halted A general strike in Belgium against the government’s austerity measures brought air and rail traffic to a near standstill on Monday. About 600 flights at Brussels Airport were canceled, affecting 50,000 passengers. (Mashable)

headline: What Our Skies Would Look Like Without City Lights
abstract: In a series of transporting images, a photographer recovers the Milky Way — and a longing for infinite spaces — for city dwellers.
lead_paragraph: “We treat light like a drug whose price is spiraling toward zero,” the science reporter Dirk Hanson wrote in Nautilus. And when faced with the availability of cheaper and more efficient lighting technology, he noted, we “simply use more of it,” rather than bank the savings.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Buemi Wins Formula E Race
abstract: Sébastien Buemi won the third Formula E race, in Punta del Este, Uruguay, on Sunday; David Coulthard won the Race of Champions in Barbados.
lead_paragraph: Sébastien Buemi took his first victory in the Formula E racing series for electric cars, holding off the spirited challenge of Jean-Éric Vergne on Sunday in Punta del Este, Uruguay. Nelson Piquet Jr. claimed second place, however, as Vergne’s suspension failed on the penultimate lap, relegating him to a 14th-place finish. Third place went to the series points leader, Lucas di Grassi.

headline: Dick Cheney Makes a Great Case for Prosecuting Torturers
abstract: He said he would do it all again “in a minute.”
lead_paragraph: In an interview on “Meet the Press” on Sunday, former Vice President Dick Cheney basically taunted ambitious lawyers at the Hague to come after him.

headline: Fallout for the S.E.C. and the Justice Dept. From the Insider Trading Ruling
abstract: Defendants who have been convicted or have settled suits involving insider trading will probably invoke an array of legal avenues to overturn their cases after an appeals court ruling, Peter J. Henning writes in White Collar Watch.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department and Securities and Exchange Commission may find that an appeals court decision overturning the insider trading convictions of two hedge fund managers has stirred up a host of challenges to previous cases.

headline: A Sensual Music Video from a Dynamic New Duo
abstract: “Jungle Lady” is the first single off the New York-based act Lion Babe’s self-titled debut EP.
lead_paragraph: In March 2013, at the invitation of the Outsiders Music label head Amanda Ghost, Lion Babe flew to London to set up shop in a local recording studio. Before they could even settle in, the New York-based duo had laid down a monumental track. “We made that song within the first hour of landing,” the multi-instrumentalist Lucas Goodman recalls of “Jungle Lady,” a smooth, island-flavored cut inspired by the studio’s royal-blue interior. “We’d have a beat going, and then I’d just go into the booth and ad-lib and come up with some melodies in, like, 10 to 15 minutes,” adds the singer Jillian Hervey. “I said, ‘You need a jungle lady,’ as a joke. Once that moment happened organically, we built the whole track around that.”

headline: Suspect in 6 Killings Is at Large Near Philadelphia
abstract: The victims were all related to the suspect, Bradley W. Stone of Pennsburg, Pa., officials said.
lead_paragraph: PENNSBURG, Pa. — Law enforcement officials in Montgomery County were searching Monday night for a man suspected of fatally shooting six people and seriously wounding another person at three homes in towns outside Philadelphia earlier in the day.

headline: Phil Stern, 95, Dies; Photographed War, Movie Stars and a President
abstract: Mr. Stern was a combat cameraman in World War II, and also captured intimate photographs of Sinatra, Bogart, Brando and Monroe, as well as the new President Kennedy.
lead_paragraph: Phil Stern, a celebrated photographer whose images caught the horrors of war, the bittersweet joys of a doomed president’s inaugural ball and the intimate moments of jazz greats and Hollywood stars just being themselves, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 95.

headline: Putin on the Fritz
abstract: The ruble, down more than oil.
lead_paragraph: It’s impressive just how quickly and convincingly the wheels have been coming off the Russian economy. Obviously the plunge in oil prices is the big driver, but the ruble has actually fallen more than Brent — oil is down 40 percent since the start of the year, but the ruble is down by half.

headline: Lights Out at the State Department
abstract: Diplomacy is never easy, especially in the dark.
lead_paragraph: Diplomacy is never easy, especially in the dark.

headline: First Draft Focus: Christie Greets Obama in New Jersey (But No Hugs)
abstract: In a pool report, The Times’s Peter Baker writes: “Greeting Gov. Christie, POTUS gave him his typical hearty handshake and a pat on the governor’s right arm. They chatted amiably for a few moments, then POTUS gave him a pat on the left arm.”
lead_paragraph: In a pool report, The Times’s Peter Baker writes: “Greeting Gov. Christie, POTUS gave him his typical hearty handshake and a pat on the governor’s right arm. They chatted amiably for a few moments, then POTUS gave him a pat on the left arm.”

headline: Stoking a Creative Spark
abstract: In this program, lesser-known choreographers are selected by more experienced peers.
lead_paragraph: It’s been proven repeatedly: Artists have a finger on the pulse of a city’s creative landscape. As part of DoublePlus, a series in which lesser-known choreographers are selected by their more experienced peers, Gibney Dance continued that nurturing spirit on Thursday at the Agnes Varis Performing Arts Center with a split bill programmed by Jon Kinzel and featuring Stuart Shugg and Anna Azrieli.

headline: Sutton Foster and Jonathan Groff Will Join ‘Encores’ Off Broadway Series
abstract: The summer series celebrating Off Broadway productions will feature “A New Brain” and “The Wild Party.”
lead_paragraph: “A New Brain,” “Little Shop of Horrors” and “The Wild Party” will be the shows featured in the third annual “Encores! Off-Center” series at City Center.

headline: Detention Center Presented as Deterrent to Border Crossings
abstract: The secretary of Homeland Security told a crowd in South Texas that a new facility, especially designed for women and children, should help deter illegal border crossings.
lead_paragraph: DILLEY, Tex. — Jeh C. Johnson, the secretary of Homeland Security, came to this South Texas outpost on Monday to open the country’s largest immigration detention facility and draw attention to border security measures that are part of President Obama’s fiercely debated executive actions on immigration.

headline: Tech and Media Companies Back Microsoft in Privacy Case
abstract: A broad array of organizations in technology, media and other fields — including Apple, Amazon, National Public Radio and Fox News — rallied behind Microsoft’s effort to block American authorities from seizing a customer’s emails stored in Ireland.
lead_paragraph: A broad array of organizations in technology, media and other fields rallied on Monday behind Microsoft’s effort to block American authorities from seizing a customer’s emails stored in Ireland.

headline: Ironclad Results
abstract: The amount of iron that might leach into food from cookware is highly variable, and may be beneficial.
lead_paragraph: Q. DOES IRON FROM CAST-IRON SKILLETS AND OTHER COOKING VESSELS LEACH

headline: Dream of a Common Language
abstract: Could a language native to no one help bring world peace? Or maybe just make movies more interesting?
lead_paragraph: It looks hard to sing, but “Feliĉan naskiĝtagon” is just “Happy birthday” in the made-up language of Esperanto. And L.L. Zamenhof, the Eastern European doctor who invented it, was born on this day in in 1859.

headline: David Garth, 84, Dies; Consultant Was an Innovator of Political TV Ads
abstract: Mr. Garth helped elect governors, senators and four mayors of New York.
lead_paragraph: David Garth, a pugnacious and indefatigable pioneer of the political commercial, who helped elect governors, senators and four New York City mayors, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: As Robots Grow Smarter, American Workers Struggle to Keep Up
abstract: Concern about technology — the printing press, the steam engine or the computer — supplanting humans is not new. But this time may be different.
lead_paragraph: A machine that administers sedatives recently began treating patients at a Seattle hospital. At a Silicon Valley hotel, a bellhop robot delivers items to people’s rooms. Last spring, a software algorithm wrote a breaking news article about an earthquake that The Los Angeles Times published.

headline: A Horned Reminder of Montana’s Past
abstract: Researchers have discovered the oldest known horned dinosaur species from the early Cretaceous in North America.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have discovered the oldest known horned dinosaur species from the early Cretaceous in North America. It dates back 113 million to 105 million years ago. The tiny dinosaur, with a skull measuring under four inches in length, was named Aquilops americanus and found in Montana. This is an artist’s reconstruction of Aquilops in its environment in ancient Montana.

headline: Lives in the Balance in a Mumbai Slum
abstract: “Behind the Beautiful Forevers,” David Hare’s stage adaptation of the best-selling book by Katherine Boo, made its premiere at the National Theater in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Sir, I work in plastics,” the man before the judge says, his voice hesitant with humility.

headline: Sydney Police Confirm Gunman Is Dead
abstract: Police in Sydney, Australia, confirmed that two civilians and a lone gunman were killed during a hostage siege that lasted more than 16 hours at a downtown cafe.
lead_paragraph: Police in Sydney, Australia, confirmed that two civilians and a lone gunman were killed during a hostage siege that lasted more than 16 hours at a downtown cafe.

headline: Mimicking a Caterpillar to Avoid Detection
abstract: A baby bird in the Amazon rain forest has downy feathers with long, orange barbs and white tips that make it look like a poisonous hairy caterpillar, researchers are reporting.
lead_paragraph: A baby bird in the Amazon rain forest has downy feathers with long, orange barbs and white tips that make it look like a poisonous hairy caterpillar, researchers are reporting.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Australia and Elsewhere
abstract: Australia and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Australia and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Vice Poaches a Lawyer from Paul, Weiss as Co-President
abstract: A denizen of the world of corporate law, James Schwab, chairman of the media and entertainment group at Paul, Weiss will help oversee a $500 million war chest at the brash media outlet.
lead_paragraph: Vice Media has built its empire — and its roughly $2.5 billion valuation — on its in-the-field commando-style reports. But the company now counts a veteran denizen of the world of corporate law as one of its newest executives.

headline: In Performance: Sting and Rachel Tucker
abstract: Ms. Tucker sings “August Winds” from the Broadway musical “The Last Ship,” accompanied by the show’s composer, Sting, on guitar. Sting performs in the show, at the Neil Simon Theater, through Jan. 24.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Tucker sings “August Winds” from the Broadway musical “The Last Ship,” accompanied by the show’s composer, Sting, on guitar. Sting performs in the show, at the Neil Simon Theater, through Jan. 24.

headline: Court to Rule on Freeing Don Siegelman, Ex-Governor of Alabama
abstract: The judge said he expected to decide by the end of the week whether to release Mr. Siegelman, who is appealing corruption convictions that sent him to prison.
lead_paragraph: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — A federal judge said Monday that he expected to decide by the end of the week whether to order the release of Don E. Siegelman, the former governor of Alabama, as he again appeals corruption convictions that sent him to prison and became a flash point in this state’s political scene.

headline: Why We Don’t Offer Black Friday Discounts
abstract: Instead of putting stuff on sale, we came up with an exclusive, limited-edition collection of products — at their regular prices.
lead_paragraph: On the Monday before Black Friday, one of our longtime retail employees came into my office seeking advice. She was thinking about creating a Facebook post aimed at our local customers and offering some secret in-store-only specials on Black Friday. She knew we shied away from discounts at Jimmy Beans Wool, but she wanted to double-check.

headline: Pictures of the Day — Dec. 15, 2014
abstract: Photos from Australia, Hong Kong, Turkey and Germany.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Australia, Hong Kong, Turkey and Germany.

headline: Obama Defends Progress Against Extremists
abstract: The president said that it had been made clear to ISIS that the United States would not back down and in the end, “we will get you.”
lead_paragraph: JOINT BASE McGUIRE-DIX-LAKEHURST, N.J. — President Obama on Monday said that after several months of fighting, the United States and its partners had undercut the momentum of Islamic extremists in Iraq and Syria, making clear to them that Americans will not back down and in the end, “we will get you.”

headline: A Richard Hunt Homecoming, Photos from India and the Balkans and More from the Art Calendar
abstract: Plus, crystal-embroidered linen works, highlights from Alexander Gerson and Matteo Zevi’s “Land Art Road Trip” residency and more happenings to see in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: T’s list of happenings worth visiting in the week ahead.

headline: A Christmas Standard, Still Different Every Time
abstract: Stella Abrera and Misty Copeland make their debuts as Clara in American Ballet Theater’s “The Nutcracker.”
lead_paragraph: Since 2010, when American Ballet Theater debuted its current production of “The Nutcracker” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, I have seen it a half-dozen times. Every time, I’ve noticed new felicities and connections. This is choreography, by Alexei Ratmansky, that rewards repeated viewings — though since the company will be taking it to Southern California next year, there aren’t many chances left for New Yorkers to see it again, or to catch it for the first time.

headline: ‘The Last Ship’ Rises With Sting in the Cast
abstract: Ticket sales rise for the musical “The Last Ship” now that Sting has joined the cast.
lead_paragraph: After two and a half months of stagnant ticket sales the Broadway musical “The Last Ship” started taking off at the box office last week when its star composer, Sting, joined the cast in a last-ditch effort to attract more theatergoers.

headline: A Meditation on the Art of Not Trying
abstract: When you’re nervous, how can you be yourself? How you can force yourself to relax? How can you try not to try? It makes no sense, but the paradox may be essential to civilization.
lead_paragraph: Just be yourself.

headline: Obama Thanks Returning Troops
abstract: President Obama thanked troops at Joint Base McGuire-Dix-Lakehurst in New Jersey on Monday, and welcomed home those who had recently returned from Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: President Obama thanked troops at Joint Base McGuire-Dix-Lakehurst in New Jersey on Monday, and welcomed home those who had recently returned from Afghanistan.

headline: Army Deserter Is Jailed for Chasing the Conflicts That Steadied His Mind
abstract: Lieutenant Lawrence J. Franks Jr. was sentenced to four years in prison and dismissed from the Army after he was accused of enlisting in the French Foreign Legion.
lead_paragraph: FORT DRUM, N.Y. — After graduating from the United States Military Academy at West Point near the top of his class in 2008, Second Lt. Lawrence J. Franks Jr. went on to a stellar career with three deployments, commendations for exceptional service and a letter of appreciation from the military’s top general.

headline: Study to Examine Effects of Artificial Intelligence
abstract: A study hosted by Stanford University will examine impacts on society, including on the economy, war and crime.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have begun what they say will be a century-long study of the effects of artificial intelligence on society, including on the economy, war and crime, officials at Stanford University announced Monday.

headline: At Miami Beach Hotel, a Gallery on 12 Wheels
abstract: The Ritz-Carlton, South Beach in South Florida enlisted local artists to design bicycles for a charity auction–and for guests to ride.
lead_paragraph: Hotels with bikes for their guests isn’t a new trend, but the Ritz-Carlton, South Beach in Miami Beach has a creative twist on the concept with a collaboration with three local artists who each designed two bicycles.

headline: Preserving Manhattan Project Sites
abstract: The Senate joined the House on Friday in passing legislation to establish a national park memorializing the secretive World War II effort that involved some of the world’s top scientists.
lead_paragraph: National parks have been set up for mountains, rivers, caves, rock formations, glaciers, forests, canyons, fossils, deserts, hot springs and volcanoes. Now, lawmakers have decided that the nation needs one for the atom bomb.

headline: Infusionarium Aims to Take Trauma Out of Chemotherapy for Young
abstract: Cancer treatments can be particularly hard on children. But in the Infusionarium their minds are transported to mountain slopes where, depending on their tastes, they are surrounded by extreme skiers or Disney princesses.
lead_paragraph: Orange, Calif. — Nick Meza, 18, recently had another five-day round of chemotherapy at the outpatient clinic here at Children’s Hospital of Orange County. Usually those days drag for Nick, an Eagle Scout with a flashing grin, a hunger for conversation, and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

headline: Gun Proliferation Fuels Homicide Rates in the Americas
abstract: An analysis of a new United Nations report on violence found that far more homicides are committed with firearms in the Americas than in any other part of the world.
lead_paragraph: Poor and middle-income nations of Latin America and the Caribbean are the most homicide-prone countries in the world, according to an analysis of a new United Nations report on violence. And because of lax gun laws, it found, far more homicides are committed with firearms in the Americas than in any other part of the world.

headline: Booker Gets Comfortable on Air Force One
abstract: Senator Cory Booker spoke to reporters on the back of Air Force One.
lead_paragraph: According to pool reports, Senator Cory Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, was chatting with reporters about his new vegan diet, his time as mayor of Newark, his interest in reforming criminal justice, his working relationship with Gov. Chris Christie and his first 13 months in the Senate.

headline: Potatoes Are the New Pork
abstract: Defying nutritionists, lawmakers added white potatoes to the list of foods that can be purchased using WIC vouchers.
lead_paragraph: In the omnibus spending bill for 2015, Congress set new rules for federal food programs, which can be summed up as follows:

headline: Darwin in Space, Dying Well, Eating the Cure
abstract: Letters to the editor and online comments.
lead_paragraph: The Red Planet

headline: Turning #IllRideWithYou Into Real-World Action in Australia
abstract: After a gunman’s siege in Sydney set off fears of repercussions, an effort to show solidarity with Muslims was amplified on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Amid the panic at the hostage siege in Sydney that left two captives and the hostage-taker dead early Tuesday, a call for compassion quickly took hold on Twitter.

headline: Innovators of Intelligence Look to Past
abstract: On the heels of his Allen Institute for Brain Science, the Microsoft co-founder launched the Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence in an effort to advance the field while reaching back to its past.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Inside the Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence, known as AI2, everything is a gleaming architectural white. The walls are white, the furniture is white, the counters are white. It might as well have been a set for the space station in “2001: A Space Odyssey.”

headline: A Shortage of Juggling Doctors
abstract: My mother, ever the comic, used to drag out an annoying little routine at dinner parties to the effect that she and my father sent me to medical school specifically to supervise their old ages. Not the best choice, Mom.
lead_paragraph: A controversial statistic suggests that in the near future our country will be in desperate need of more doctors. The Association of American Medical Colleges has estimated that by 2025 we will be about 130,000 short, thanks primarily to an exploding older population. Ten thousand Americans now turn 65 every day, entering their golden years of disproportionate consumption of medical care.

headline: Review: Nicki Minaj’s ‘The Pinkprint’
abstract: “The Pinkprint” is Ms. Minaj’s third studio album, and like the first two it’s full of compromises and half-successes.
lead_paragraph: Part of the magic of the modern record business is that the worth of the album has been diminished. Almost anything can be a great album now — a mixtape, a cluster of songs on Soundcloud, a dump of digital files. That to some the album still has a sort of aesthetic integrity, that it should mean something different from the rest of their creative output, is an increasingly old-fashioned idea.

headline: Move Over, Schroeder. Make Room for Tiny Dancers.
abstract: Phyllis Chen’s one-woman show at the Baryshnikov Arts Center featured four works with music boxes and toy pianos, among other instruments.
lead_paragraph: Toy pianos and music boxes are typically found in the nursery. Occasionally, a music box may accompany its owner into adulthood as a place to keep jewelry, guarded, most often, by a tiny spinning ballerina.

headline: Review: D’Angelo’s ‘Black Messiah’
abstract: D’Angelo’s first album in 14 years is a knotty, inward-looking, musicianly album made to reveal itself slowly. It doesn’t leap out of speakers; it oozes and bubbles.
lead_paragraph: D’Angelo’s 14-year vanishing act ended decisively on midnight as Monday began when he released “Black Messiah,” his first new album since 2000. It’s not the kind of larger-than-life pop event and sharply etched public statement that “Beyoncé” delivered as last year’s December surprise. “Black Messiah” is a knotty, inward-looking, musicianly album made to reveal itself slowly. It doesn’t leap out of speakers; it oozes and bubbles, waiting for a listener to be drawn in. As it does, the pleasures and rewards keep growing.

headline: U.S. Seeks to Use Letters Found in Bin Laden Raid in Terrorism Trial
abstract: Federal prosecutors say the correspondence reveals “powerful direct proof” of Nazih Abdul-Hamed al-Ruqai’s “knowing and intentional participation” in Al Qaeda’s conspiracies to bomb and kill Americans.
lead_paragraph: In the year before Osama bin Laden was killed by United States forces, letters from a Libyan man described as a loyal follower made their way to the Qaeda leader’s hiding place in Abbottabad, Pakistan.

headline: Shaping a Shepherd of Catholics, From Argentine Slums to the Vatican
abstract: “The Great Reformer” examines the roots of Pope Francis’s commitment to the poor, even in the face of government opposition during Argentina’s military dictatorship.
lead_paragraph: The most controversial incident in Jorge Mario Bergoglio’s tenure as Jesuit provincial (that is, regional superior) of Argentina came in 1976. Father Bergoglio, now Pope Francis, was a prayerful man, a charismatic leader and a priest deeply committed to the poor. As Jesuit provincial, he was also charged with the care of Jesuit priests and brothers throughout Argentina. A few years after taking office at the alarmingly young age of 36, he was faced with the thorny problem of how best to support two priests, Orlando Yorio and Franz Jalics, who had moved into a slum in Buenos Aires and were advocates for the poor in the face of brutal government opposition during Argentina’s so-called Dirty War.

headline: Band Ties the Loose Ends of Its Metal Lineage
abstract: Black Breath, a metal band from Seattle, twists together the loose ends of a musical line tracing to the early ’80s.
lead_paragraph: There’s the cultivated aura of metal and extreme music: loner-ish, angry, frenzied or weary, full of long-game intransigence. Then there’s the reality of Black Breath, from Seattle, whose gregarious, vigorous, line-drive of a set at Saint Vitus in Brooklyn on Sunday night transmitted more or less the opposite of all that.

headline: Review: Charli XCX’s ‘Sucker’
abstract: “Sucker” is far more direct than Charli XCX’s first album; it’s smart, loud, cheeky, gimmick-loving pop, intent on making every song go bang.
lead_paragraph: “Sucker” (Atlantic)

headline: Obama Says Coalition is ‘Hammering’ ISIS
abstract: President Obama spoke to troops at a military base in New Jersey on Monday, praising them for their part in blunting the Islamic State’s momentum.
lead_paragraph: President Obama spoke to troops at a military base in New Jersey on Monday, praising them for their part in blunting the Islamic State’s momentum.

headline: Reviving an Ancient Pulse
abstract: Using modern digital processing, researchers have given sound to some of the earliest written recordings of pulses and heartbeats.
lead_paragraph: Using modern digital processing, researchers have given sound to some of the earliest written recordings of pulses and heartbeats.

headline: Monitoring Earth’s Temperature
abstract: Scientists arrived at a limit of 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit for Earth’s temperature to increase, arguing anything above that will cause significant damage.
lead_paragraph: Scientists arrived at a limit of 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit for Earth’s temperature to increase, arguing anything above that will cause significant damage.

headline: Infusing Fun Into Cancer Treatment
abstract: In California, young patients can lose themselves in a digital dreamworld during their grueling treatments.
lead_paragraph: In California, young patients can lose themselves in a digital dreamworld during their grueling treatments.

headline: A 1908 Fetal Heartbeat
abstract: A fetal heartbeat recorded more than 100 years ago by German physiologist Otto Weiss using his invention, the “phonoscope,” which detected tiny vibrations of a fetal heartbeat using a soap bubble.
lead_paragraph: A fetal heartbeat recorded more than 100 years ago by German physiologist Otto Weiss using his invention, the “phonoscope,” which detected tiny vibrations of a fetal heartbeat using a soap bubble.

headline: Brain Waves and Heartbeats From The Golden Record
abstract: Audio from Ann Druyan’s EEG and EKG from the Golden Record, which was sent into space on board the Voyager missions.
lead_paragraph: Audio from Ann Druyan’s EEG and EKG from the Golden Record, which was sent into space on board the Voyager missions.

headline: The Echoes of Hearts Long Silenced
abstract: An artist and a historian used digital processing techniques to hear again to the pulses of people who have been dead for more than a century.
lead_paragraph: Efforts to record the pattern of human heartbeats — the wavy lines so familiar on hospital monitors — go back at least to 1854, when a German scientist pressed a weighted plate against an artery, connected it to a stylus made of a strand of hair, and traced the pulsations on a moving strip of paper blackened by the soot of an oil lamp.

headline: Donna Karan
abstract: Her prefall collection, mostly monochromatic, included belted dresses and coats.
lead_paragraph: Her prefall collection, mostly monochromatic, included belted dresses and coats.

headline: France Confronts an Ignoble Chapter
abstract: In Paris, an exhibition at the National Archives looks at French people who were genuine supporters of the Nazis during World War II.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The 1942 telegram signed by one of the highest officials of the collaborationist Vichy regime urged local prefects in unoccupied France “personally” to supervise the transfer of thousands of Jews to deportation camps.

headline: Dior
abstract: Raf Simons’s prefall collection featured long dresses and coats with architectural shapes.
lead_paragraph: Raf Simons’s prefall collection featured long dresses and coats with architectural shapes.

headline: S.E.C. Seeks to Dismiss Insider Trading Lawsuit Involving Herbalife Shares
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission said it would not be able to proceed with the lawsuit because the two main witnesses it intended to call to testify are in Poland and had no plans to return to the United States.
lead_paragraph: Federal securities regulators are seeking to dismiss an insider trading lawsuit against a man who they say profited from betting against shares of Herbalife because potential witnesses had left the country.

headline: Chanel
abstract: Karl Lagerfeld, who showed his prefall collection in Austria, showed heavily embroidered designs included capelets and high-collar dresses.
lead_paragraph: Karl Lagerfeld, who showed his prefall collection in Austria, showed heavily embroidered designs included capelets and high-collar dresses.

headline: Lawyers in iPod Trial Await Jury Decision
abstract: A class-action suit nearly a decade in the making has finally headed to the jury room in a federal court in Oakland, Calif.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — After 10 years, a class-action antitrust lawsuit involving iPods is finally in the hands of a jury.

headline: A Buried Past Springing Into the Light
abstract: Alexei Ratmansky’s restaging of Marius Petipa’s “Paquita” for the Bayerisches Staatsballett in Munich is a labor of love and a homage to the master.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Alexei Ratmansky’s restaging of Marius Petipa’s “Paquita” for the Bayerisches Staatsballett is a labor of love and a homage to the master. “We do not make dances like this now, perhaps,” George Balanchine said of “Paquita” in his “Complete Stories of the Great Ballets,” “but we could make nothing if we had not had dances like these by Petipa to teach us.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Looking for Truth in Ukraine
abstract: Maria Turchenkova has tried to cover both sides in Ukraine, going from being an amateur fumbling with her camera to making compelling pictures in the contested region.
lead_paragraph: Maria Turchenkova has tried to cover both sides in Ukraine, going from being an amateur fumbling with her camera to making compelling pictures in the contested region.

headline: Stepping Back Into a Role’s Shoes
abstract: At 67, the bass-baritone James Morris reprises the demanding role of Hans Sachs and wins praise.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, Hollywood films like “RED” and “The Expendables” have formed a sort of mini-genre in which big action stars, no longer in their first bloom of youth, use their time-honed skills to save the day one more time and to show younger generations a thing or two.

headline: The Oceans’ Depths, Saturated With Life and Color
abstract: “Spineless” oozes and creeps with salty invertebrates and its intense photographs of underwater life pulse with spellbinding strangeness.
lead_paragraph: As we stand on the thin crust of this watery planet, our gaze tends to roam from horizon to heavens. We often neglect the riot of life that seethes and thrives below us, especially in the still mysterious depths of our oceans.

headline: Senate, Ending Long Battle, Confirms Nominee for Surgeon General
abstract: The confirmation of Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, questioned for his gun-control views, was one of the last acts of business for the Democratic-controlled Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Monday confirmed President Obama’s nominee for surgeon general, ending a long fight over gun control and politics that had left the country without a permanent top doctor for a year and a half.

headline: Old Pieces With a Past
abstract: In “Secrets of the Arsenal,” a six-episode series, Geoff Edgers looks for artifacts that shaped United States history.
lead_paragraph: Television’s unusual-artifacts genre of history programming has a fair number of entries now, so a host can’t get by with merely finding and describing the memorabilia anymore. Showing genuine enthusiasm for it is important, too, and this Geoff Edgers does in “Secrets of the Arsenal,” a six-episode series that begins on Tuesday on the American Heroes Channel.

headline: The Myth of Comfort Food
abstract: The emotional healing powers of comfort food may be overrated.
lead_paragraph: Feeling sad or stressed? Put down that Oreo or bowl of mac ’n’ cheese and brace yourself for another bummer: The emotional healing powers of comfort food may be overrated.

headline: Iran’s President Pledges to Face Down Forces Opposing a Nuclear Deal
abstract: Hassan Rouhani said he was determined to reach an agreement with the West in order to have sanctions lifted.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Risking his political standing, Iran’s president stressed on Monday that he was determined to cinch a nuclear deal and prepared to take on the conservative forces who would prefer not to see an agreement with the West, even if that means continued economic sanctions on Iran.

headline: In Climate Talks, Soft is the New Hard – and That’s a Good Thing
abstract: Why the soft approach in the Lima climate talks is the only approach.
lead_paragraph: This piece takes the long view in gauging efforts to stem global warming and its impacts using the tools of diplomacy. It is not about the details of the outcome of climate treaty talks that concluded yesterday in Lima, Peru. (Here’s what parties sought; here’s the final sketchy result.)

headline: How to Rebuild Architecture
abstract: The profession is out of touch with the public it serves.
lead_paragraph: IN architecture, everyone’s a critic. One of us, Steven, was recently driving down Elliott Avenue in Charlottesville, Va., his hometown, with his 88-year-old mother. They passed a house designed and built by architecture students at the University of Virginia. To Steven, an architect, this model for affordable housing — a tough pair of stacked boxes, sheathed in corrugated metal — was a bold design statement. But to his mother’s eye, the house was a blight on the landscape, an insult to its historic neighbors.

headline: Interest Rate Raised to 17% in Russia
abstract: Western sanctions and the collapse in the price of oil have weighed on the economy and hurt the ruble.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia has a new enemy: the currency markets.

headline: Stop Wasting Doctors’ Time
abstract: Our current system of recertification is expensive busy work.
lead_paragraph: IT’S hard to believe that another 10 years have passed, but the proof is the 11-volume stack of medical review books at my bedside. It’s time for the decennial rite of cramming a thousand pages of facts for an eight-hour-long multiple choice test.

headline: On Torture: Cheney, McCain et Al.
abstract: Readers respond to remarks by former Vice President Dick Cheney and Senator John McCain.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ask Well: Noisy Knees
abstract: A reader asks: Why do my knees make a cracking sound?
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: The Ways Police Officers Think and Act
abstract: Readers react to a column by David Brooks.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Turkey’s Actions on Syria
abstract: Aydan Karamanoglu, spokesman for the Turkish Embassy, takes issue with an online letter, “Turkey’s Demand on Syria.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Vladimir Putin vs. the Currency Markets: What to Know About the Ruble’s Collapse
abstract: Raising interest rates by 6.5 percentage points in the middle of the night is a sure sign of an emerging-markets currency crisis.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin’s biggest enemy right now may well be the currency markets.

headline: Questions for My Grandfather’s Psychiatrist
abstract: There was no suicide note. Maybe the doctor could explain.
lead_paragraph: My maternal grandfather killed himself inside his bedroom closet on the morning of March 22, 1966. I have a copy of his death certificate here beside me, stamped with the seal of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. His basic biographical data is all there — name: Francis Michael Wiener; birthplace: Prague; age at time of death: 55 years and 19 days — and the cause of death still makes me flinch a little every time I see it: “Suicide — Shotgun wound, left side of face below ear.” He was an acoustic engineer, trained in the intricacies of sound design, so I imagine he chose his closet as the place to pull the trigger for its sound-dampening qualities. It worked; no one heard the gunshot that morning.

headline: Security Council to Discuss North Korea
abstract: The United Nations Security Council agreed late Monday to consider the human rights situation in North Korea next week, paving the way for discussions on whether to refer the country to the International Criminal Court.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council agreed late Monday to consider the human rights situation in North Korea next week, paving the way for discussions on whether to refer the country to the International Criminal Court. The move places China, North Korea’s principal ally on the Council, under a spotlight. Rebuffing Chinese concerns, the Council on Monday said that it would seek a briefing from senior United Nations officials next week. The Council is not expected to take any immediate action. The move follows a landmark decision by the human rights committee of the General Assembly to ask the Council to consider referring North Korea to the court.

headline: Phil Stern, Photographer, Dies at 95
abstract: Mr. Stern always attributed his success to being in the right place at the right time.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Stern always attributed his success to being in the right place at the right time.

headline: Wife of Bill Cosby Places Fault With News Media
abstract: Camille O. Cosby faulted the news media for what she said was a failure to scrutinize the women who have made sexual assault accusations against her husband.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of silence as sexual assault allegations against Bill Cosby have mounted, his wife, Camille O. Cosby, came to his defense Monday and faulted the news media for what she said was a failure to scrutinize the women who have made the accusations.

headline: What General Holtzclaw Saw
abstract: Why a Confederate general praised a failed assault by black troops on a rebel fortification at the Battle of Nashville.
lead_paragraph: Viewed as a matter of tactics, the assault by the 13th United States Colored Troops against Confederates holding Overton Hill late on Dec. 16, 1864, contributed nothing to the Union victory at the Battle of Nashville. The Southerners easily repulsed the charge in a handful of minutes, leaving the regiment shot to pieces, its dead and wounded scattered across the muddy ground. In one sense, it was just another bloody and fruitless assay against strong defensive works, something that happened thousands of times in the Civil War.

headline: Aspirin Risks Outweigh Benefits for Younger Women
abstract: For many women the risk of taking a small dose of aspirin a day may outweigh the benefits.
lead_paragraph: For many women the risk of taking a small dose of aspirin a day may outweigh the benefits.

headline: Classic Hip-Hop Is Spreading on the Radio Dial
abstract: The format is sweeping the radio market in some cities, yielding one of the medium’s most enduring signs of success: a format turf war.
lead_paragraph: Oldies radio used to mean Johnny Mathis and the Four Seasons. Now it’s Tupac Shakur and LL Cool J.

headline: Defining a Movement
abstract: Like the Occupy demonstrations, the "Black Lives Matter" protests have their own motivation and message. What makes them more or less effective than others?

headline: Poor Sleep Tied to Brain Changes of Dementia
abstract: Sleep apnea and other problems that cause low oxygen saturation of blood during sleep may increase the risk of brain changes associated with dementia, a new study reports.
lead_paragraph: Poor sleep in older adults may be linked to brain changes associated with dementia, a new study has found.

headline: An Army for Afghanistan
abstract: In this short documentary, a front-line company of Afghan soldiers in Helmand, the country’s most dangerous province, faces new difficulties as their foreign allies prepare to withdraw.
lead_paragraph: In this short documentary, a front-line company of Afghan soldiers in Helmand, the country’s most dangerous province, faces new difficulties as their foreign allies prepare to withdraw.

headline: ‘An Army for Afghanistan’
abstract: In this short documentary, Afghan soldiers struggle to fight an ongoing insurgency, as United States and NATO troops withdraw.
lead_paragraph: The Afghan Army is now charged with leading an unfinished war against an ongoing insurgency. But how much do we know about the Afghan soldiers themselves?

headline: A Plan to Limit Cars in Paris Collides With French Politics
abstract: The mayor of Paris, Anne Hidalgo, has proposed banning high-emission vehicles, particularly those that run on diesel, in the city’s center by 2020.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When the mayor here detailed plans to ban diesel and other vehicles from the center of Paris by 2020, she framed the measures as a public health imperative in a country that has grown increasingly worried about the quality of its air.

headline: Carlyle’s Holiday Video, With ‘Rap Star’ David Rubenstein
abstract: It ain’t “Straight Outta Compton,” but the co-chief of Carlyle can bust a rhyme in his own way.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Dre has been an inspiration to many aspiring rappers over the years.

headline: Iraq’s Premier Narrows Divide, but Challenges Loom
abstract: The early performance of Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi has encouraged Iraqi and Western officials, but his efforts are being tested by militants who control one-third of Iraq.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — When an Iraqi court sentenced a prominent Sunni politician to death recently, it seemed like an unmitigated disaster for the country’s new prime minister, Haider al-Abadi.

headline: U.A.W. Pledges to Pursue Higher Wages Next Year
