For many watching the gruesome scene, it would be the first time they had heard of the radical group on a violent campaign to create a new religious state. But the Islamic State — also known as ISIS or ISIL — had been organizing for years before sweeping through northern Iraq in 2014.

headline: Pennsylvania Man Sought in Slaying of Family Is Found Dead
abstract: The district attorney of Montgomery County, Pa., said at a news conference that the man, Bradley W. Stone, died of “self-inflicted cutting wounds.”
lead_paragraph: EAGLEVILLE, Pa. — A man sought in the killing of six family members was found dead with self-inflicted stab wounds on Tuesday, ending a two-day manhunt, officials said.

headline: E.U. Confirms Wide Fraud in Afghan Presidential Runoff Election
abstract: The report from European Union election observers offered the fullest picture yet of the allegations of fraud that plagued the election.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A new report by European Union election observers on Tuesday supports some of the most stark estimates of systematic electoral fraud in the Afghan presidential runoff election in June, and says an earlier audit of the voting invalidated only a small fraction of suspect votes.

headline: Smithsonian Sheet Music for Sale
abstract: More than 400 titles of digitized sheet music from the Smithsonian’s collection are being offered for sale online, with profits to help support archival work.
lead_paragraph: The Smithsonian Institution has teamed up with Sheet Music Plus, an online retailer of music manuscripts, to sell digitized sheet music from the Smithsonian’s collection. More than 400 titles went online this week, including music by Franz Liszt, Irving Berlin and the Broadway composer Harry Tierney.

headline: Ava DuVernay Will Serve as a Keynote Speaker at SXSW
abstract: The filmmaker will speak at the annual film conference and festival in Austin.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker and recent Golden Globe nominee Ava DuVernay will be a keynote speaker at the 2015 South by Southwest film conference and festival in Austin, organizers announced Tuesday. The news comes as Ms. DuVernay is making a transition into studio filmmaking (and building Oscar momentum) with her Martin Luther King Jr. biopic “Selma,” but her indie roots, as well as her previous work in marketing and publicity, are likely to be discussed.

headline: A Foreskin in the Right Place at the Right Time
abstract: Proposed CDC guidelines would have doctors promote the benefits of circumcision in newborns, teenagers and adults, but parents will still make their own decisions—sometimes for unexpected reasons.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention just released the first proposed federal guidelines on circumcision. Highlighting research suggesting that circumcision helps protect heterosexual men from urinary tract infections, penile cancer, H.I.V. and other sexually transmitted diseases, the C.D.C.plans to recommend that health care providers offer all uncircumcised men and the parents of newborn or uncircumcised boys “comprehensive counseling on the risks and benefits of circumcision.” Having your son circumcised is not just a cultural or religious choice anymore — it’s a public health issue. (Care to comment on that proposal? Click here.)

headline: U.S. Tries to Calm Latest Israeli and Palestinian Strife
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said the United States had made “no determinations” about efforts toward Security Council resolutions on the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Calling the status quo “unsustainable for both parties and for the region,” Secretary of State John Kerry said here on Tuesday that the United States was working “to lower the temperature” between Israelis and Palestinians, amid Palestinian and European efforts for United Nations Security Council resolutions that would pressure Israel on the timing and shape of peace talks.

headline: An Unassuming Miracle Worker for Dry Skin
abstract: Skinfix’s hand-repair cream, based on a formula from 1850, is an affordable indulgence to combat winter dehydration.
lead_paragraph: In 1850, a compound chemist in Yorkshire, England named Thomas Dixon created a “miracle balm” that 162 years later landed in the hands of the beauty-industry veteran Amy Regan. She acquired the formula in 2012 when she bought the brand Skinfix from Dixon’s great-great-great-granddaughter. Since then, Regan, who has had stints at L’Oréal, Coty and Estée Lauder, has used the rich and reparative recipe, which is anhydrous (containing no water, unlike most moisturizers on the market, which have a high percentage), to create products like this new hand-repair cream. It’s already garnering a cult following — and its price tag (just $20!) doesn’t hurt.

headline: ‘A Great Moment’: Rover Finds Methane, a Clue That Mars May Harbor Life
abstract: The presence of the gas could be the result of a geological process or the product of microbes.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Life on Mars? Today? The notion may not be so far-fetched after all.

headline: Layoffs Begin at The Times After Buyouts Come Up Short
abstract: The newspaper and its primary union said 21 union-represented employees would be let go by the end of the week.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times and its primary union said on Tuesday that the paper was laying off at least 21 employees because it had not received enough voluntary buyouts to cover newsroom budget cuts.

headline: Parity? A.F.C. Is Made Up of Haves and Have-Nots
abstract: Despite the perception that parity exists to a greater degree in the N.F.L. than in other major professional sports, that has not been the case over the last several years in the A.F.C.
lead_paragraph: The New England Patriots and the Denver Broncos have the two best records in the A.F.C. The Indianapolis Colts are the class of the A.F.C. South, but no other team in the division has a winning record.

headline: Throwing Money at Start-Ups in Frenzy to Find the Next Uber
abstract: Thanks to overzealous venture capital firms, companies are going from zero to billion-dollar valuations faster then ever before, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: The $41 billion valuation for the ride-sharing service Uber may or may not be a bubblicious number, but it certainly shows that the venture capital industry is in a bad place.

headline: Jeb and Dynasties
abstract: How many years of Bushes and Clintons are enough?
lead_paragraph: So it seems that Jeb Bush is a lot more likely to run for president in 2016 that some people (myself included) thought. There will be time to game out some of the implications (apart from making my preferred primary scenario much less likely); for now a quick thought on political dynasties.

headline: Yankees Add Capuano to Rotation, but It’s Still Incomplete
abstract: With their fragile starting rotation a work in progress, the Yankees re-signed the left-handed starting pitcher Chris Capuano to a one-year, $5 million deal.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees on Tuesday re-signed the left-handed pitcher Chris Capuano to a one-year, $5 million deal, a small step to help solidify their fragile and incomplete starting pitching rotation.

headline: Questioning the Idea of Good Carbs, Bad Carbs
abstract: For people who already follow a healthful diet, the glycemic index may not be very important.
lead_paragraph: The idea that all carbohydrates are not created equal has become the foundation of many popular diets. Some argue that foods like white bread and potatoes, which have a high so-called glycemic index because they spike blood sugar and insulin, should be avoided in favor of more healthful carbs like whole grains and non-starchy vegetables.

headline: Does Jeb Bush Still Have a Place in the Republican Party?
abstract: Observers say that the former Florida governor will bring a lot of resources to a White House run — but is he out of step with today’s Republican Party on a couple of key issues?
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush, the former governor of Florida, announced Tuesday (on Twitter and Facebook) that he had “decided to actively explore the possibility of running for president of the United States.”

headline: ‘Something Rotten!’ to Skip Seattle Premiere and Debut on Broadway in March
abstract: With a Broadway theater suddenly available, producers of the new musical comedy “Something Rotten!” dropped plans for a run in Seattle.
lead_paragraph: With a prime Broadway theater suddenly available, the producers of the new musical comedy “Something Rotten!” announced on Tuesday that they are dropping plans for a world premiere in Seattle and instead starting performances in New York in March.

headline: My Fantasy Football Brag: I Created the Game
abstract: By starting an early fantasy football league, the author describes a diversion that became the ultimate faux success story.
lead_paragraph: On any given Sunday during autumn and early winter, you do not need GPS or a search party to track me down. My perch is a stool at a sports bar, eyes darting between a laptop and banks of television screens beaming every N.F.L. game.

headline: Goodbye, Nation. Goodbye, Blowhard Self.
abstract: After nine years nurturing his TV persona of a conservative talk show host, Stephen Colbert will bid farewell to the other Stephen Colbert on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: For nine years, Stephen Colbert has relentlessly maintained his pompous, deeply ridiculous but consistently appealing conservative blowhard character on his late-night show, “The Colbert Report” — so much so that when he puts the character to rest for good on Thursday night, he may have to resort to comicide. The Grim Reaper is his last guest.

headline: Less Is More With the 2014 Honda CBR650F
abstract: A new sportbike from Honda demonstrates that you don’t need a load of electronic gadgets to enjoy a long-distance motorcycle ride.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks before I left for a recent vacation, I bought a new cellphone to replace a four-year-old model. The new phone was loaded with an updated version of the same Android operating system, and all of my contacts and photos were copied over.

headline: Love Christmas Lights? Thank the 22nd President
abstract: A famous inventor strung the first bulbs, but it took a president to make them popular.
lead_paragraph: Soon after Thomas Edison patented the first commercially viable light bulb, he strung a few together during the 1880 Christmas season and hung them outside his lab in Menlo Park, N.J.

headline: Wandering Jane Austen’s World
abstract: A tour through the villages in Hampshire where the author spent the most creative periods of her short life.
lead_paragraph: Standing in the Steventon churchyard on a September morning, the dew glistening on the closely mowed grass between the gravestones, I heard the wind whispering in the 900-year-old yew tree that stands at the west end of the church. I could imagine Mr. Bingley and Jane or Eliza and Mr. Darcy bursting through the doors, arrayed in Regency wedding garb, greeted by a crowd of onlookers. But Steventon was quiet, except for the breeze.

headline: Israeli Forces Kill Palestinian in Raid of West Bank Camp
abstract: The Israeli military said soldiers opened fire after explosives were thrown at them in the Qalandia refugee camp in the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli special forces fatally shot one Palestinian man and wounded another in the Qalandia refugee camp in the West Bank when clashes broke out during an overnight military operation, the Israeli military said Tuesday.

headline: James Franco and Seth Rogen Talk About ‘The Interview’
abstract: A corporate hack and threats against movie theaters were “not something that we expected at all,” said Mr. Rogen, who directed and stars the film.
lead_paragraph: In a previous film, Seth Rogen and James Franco experienced a comic vision of the end of the world, but their new movie, “The Interview,” has had serious fallout, including a devastating corporate hack and threats against theaters showing the film.

headline: Movies and Music in Mexico
abstract: Festival Sayulita, scheduled for next month in Mexico, includes films, a day of music and surfing events.
lead_paragraph: Cinephiles looking to enjoy a film with their feet in the sand can do so from Jan. 14 to 18 at the second Festival Sayulita, a five-day culture and food fest in the chilled-out coastal town of Sayulita, 45 minutes north of Puerto Vallarta.

headline: Q. and A.: John Osburg on the Angst Found Among China’s Newly Rich
abstract: A new book by John Osburg, “Anxious Wealth: Money and Morality Among China’s New Rich,” paints a rich picture of the complex ways in which men and women try to buy favors and get ahead in business ventures, often by courting government officials at night clubs and often over drinking and sex.
lead_paragraph: John Osburg, 39, an assistant professor of anthropology at the University of Rochester, is the author of “Anxious Wealth: Money and Morality Among China’s New Rich,” based on research he conducted in the southwestern Chinese city of Chengdu. The book paints a detailed picture of the complex ways in which men and women try to buy favors and get ahead in business ventures, often by courting government officials at night clubs and often over drinking and sex. It also describes a milieu beset by anxiety over whether their gains can last.

headline: Preserving 2014’s Most Beautiful Georgia Blooms for All of 2015
abstract: Two Southern entrepreneurs — one with a floral design studio, the other with a letterpress company — collaborated on a limited-edition calendar for the new year.
lead_paragraph: In this series, the photographer Rinne Allen documents harvests across the South, exploring the many uses of nature’s seasonal yield of ingredients.

headline: Game Consoles Are Using More Electricity Than Ever
abstract: The latest gaming consoles can do more than ever. So it shouldn’t be much of a surprise that their electrical consumption is going up as well.
lead_paragraph: With guns, grenades and other weapons, U.S. Special Forces will slug it out against the Federation in ever more households on Christmas, as new video game consoles fire up Call of Duty: Ghosts, a recent version of the popular game.

headline: Mark Bittman: By the Book
abstract: Op-Ed columnist Mark Bittman talks books with Pamela Paul, editor of the Book Review.
lead_paragraph: Mark Bittman is an Op-Ed columnist. He talks with Pamela Paul, editor of the Book Review.

headline: Pausing for Hanukkah While Everything Else Keeps Going
abstract: Celebrating Hanukkah and Christmas has made me aware of how much easier the outside world makes it to protect one tradition over the other.
lead_paragraph: I spent part of yesterday evening in the basement, as I can only assume anyone might, contemplating such great mysteries as why the box so clearly labeled “Hanukkah” so clearly did not include any menorahs, or dreidels, or in fact anything related to Hanukkah at all except a few boxes of the more depressing brand of candles and whether it was possible that, in mid-December, I still had a big pile of Halloween decorations down there to put away. (It is, and this is the kind of behavior that, one year, led me to use the tail end of the holiday lights still strung on the house to inflate a child’s wading pool in June.)

headline: Recalls of Cars Abroad Prompt No Urgency in U.S.
abstract: A Times examination of actions by major United States automakers found different standards for recalls of substantially similar vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Toyota discovered a braking defect, Honda a power steering flaw and Nissan a problem that could lead drivers to lose control of their cars. Ford found that wires in some cars could melt, General Motors that some airbags might fail to deploy, and Chrysler that some of its Jeeps could burst into flames.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan, Sierra Leone and Elsewhere
abstract: Australia, Pakistan and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Australia, Pakistan and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Striking Dissident Notes, With Many Reprises
abstract: For Geoffrey Baker, author of “El Sistema: Orchestrating Venezuela’s Youth,” the program that produced the conductor Gustavo Dudamel operates in a “climate of fear.”
lead_paragraph: The premise of “El Sistema: Orchestrating Venezuela’s Youth” is easy to accept. Geoffrey Baker, who teaches in the music department at Royal Holloway, University of London, is certainly right to denounce the mostly uncritical adulation that has been heaped on Venezuela’s music program for children in recent years by performers, educators and the news media alike, and to call for thorough scrutiny.

headline: Pictures of the Day — Dec. 16, 2014
abstract: Photos from Pakistan, Australia, Sierra Leone and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Pakistan, Australia, Sierra Leone and India.

headline: The Ruble’s Fall and Mr. Putin’s Reckoning
abstract: Russia’s economic calamity rests largely with the disastrous policies of President Vladimir Putin.
lead_paragraph: Russians are watching their country suffer another avoidable economic calamity. The blame for this rests largely with the disastrous policies of President Vladimir Putin, who has consistently put his ego, his territorial ambitions and the financial interests of his cronies ahead of the needs of his country.

headline: Utah Rules an Online Insurance Broker Is Unfair to Traditional Brokers
abstract: So far eight states, including Utah, have investigated Zenefits. Three have cleared it; decisions are pending in four others
lead_paragraph: When does innovation become unfair competition? That was the question Utah’s insurance commissioner, Todd E. Kiser, put before himself when he started an investigation of Zenefits, the online human-resources software platform that is also an insurance broker.

headline: The Bloom Is Off the Rose, the Cap Off the Toothpaste
abstract: Sophie Fillières’s “If You Don’t, I Will” looks at an unhappy French couple (Emmanuelle Devos and Mathieu Amalric) living in too-close quarters.
lead_paragraph: There is a turning point in many marriages, after the passion has cooled, when tiny irritants that once were tolerated threaten to turn into toxic infections. In Sophie Fillières’s “If You Don’t, I Will,” the French stars Emmanuelle Devos and Mathieu Amalric portray such a couple with a subtlety and depth that let you glimpse their rich shared history, as well as their dismal present.

headline: A Diva and a Holiday, Intertwined
abstract: Mariah Carey is performing mostly Christmas music during her six-show run at the Beacon Theater.
lead_paragraph: Mariah Carey wished, she said from the Beacon Theater stage on Monday night, that she could show everyone in the room how she does Christmas at home, in her personal life. “You need to know that I have a 10-foot tree,” she said, standing in front of a 10-foot tree. “And real reindeer,” she added. “Yes, real reindeer.”

headline: Car Bombs in Yemen Kill Dozens, Including Schoolchildren
abstract: There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the bombings in the central city of Rada, but suspicion fell on Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Two car bombs exploded in a city in central Yemen on Tuesday afternoon, killing more than two dozen people, including at least 15 children returning home from school, according to a witness and Yemeni officials.

headline: 4 Years Old and Orphaned by Ebola
abstract: Readers respond to the front-page article about a 4-year-old girl.

headline: Misuse of the Healing Professions for Torture
abstract: The psychiatrist Robert Jay Lifton responds to a front-page article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Sex Assault in the Military
abstract: Senator Claire McCaskill, a Missouri Democrat, takes issue with an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Disciplining Police Officers
abstract: A police officers’ association urges passage of a New York state bill on disciplinary procedures.

headline: D’Angelo’s ‘Black Messiah’ Was Released in Response to Protests
abstract: RCA had planned to release “Black Messiah” in early 2015, but its reclusive singer was done waiting.
lead_paragraph: For almost 15 years, the long-teased third album from the embattled soul singer D’Angelo came not at all. Then, on Sunday, the album — “Black Messiah” — came all at once, debuting at an industry listening party in the sleek rooftop lounge of a Manhattan hotel.

headline: Email Hack in Hollywood
abstract: Niobe Way, a psychologist at New York University, responds to an Op-Ed article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Girls Can Compete
abstract: Dorothy Mortman, a reader, explains why she is dismayed by the move to separate the genders in school classrooms.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Conserving Water
abstract: The director of Los Angeles Waterkeeper describes its campaign to encourage motorists not to wash their cars for 60 days.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Bilbo Baggins in the Shadow of Bloodthirsty Hordes
abstract: Peter Jackson concludes his trilogy treatment of J. R. R. Tolkien’s “The Hobbit” with a film devoted to warfare and driven by greed.
lead_paragraph: “You are only quite a little fellow in a wide world, after all,” Gandalf reminds his companion at the end of “The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies.” The avuncular line has a cozy feel that evokes the bedtime-storytelling of J. R. R. Tolkien’s 1937 children’s classic — now better known as the trilogized prequel to a 21st-century fantasy phenomenon. Gandalf’s sentiment is also all too apt for Peter Jackson’s vexing conclusion to his oddly apportioned adaptation: Bilbo Baggins is indeed quite a little fellow in Mr. Jackson’s wide world here — less a central hero on a quest than a supporting player in a film bookended by destruction and war in gray, grim lands.

headline: Cruz Apologizes to Colleagues for Spending Bill Delay
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas did not win himself many friends over the weekend when he delayed the vote on the $1.1 trillion spending, scuttling the travel plans of his colleagues.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas did not win himself many friends over the weekend when he delayed the vote on the $1.1 trillion spending, scuttling the travel plans of his colleagues.

headline: Slowdown in China Bruises Economy in Latin America
abstract: China’s insatiable hunger for Latin America’s raw materials fueled the region’s most prosperous decade at least since the 1970s. That era is over.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Few people are as intensely worried about the slowing Chinese economy as Latin Americans.

headline: Texas Congressman Sued by Aide Who Complained of Mistreatment
abstract: Representative Blake Farenthold is accused of using sexual innuendoes to create a hostile work environment.
lead_paragraph: Representative Blake Farenthold is being sued by a former staff member who said she was illegally fired after complaining about mistreatment.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Listening to Mozart and Dreaming at the Same Time
abstract: “Le Nozze di Figaro” has returned to the Met for a short run with a new cast and conductor.
lead_paragraph: Long before fantasy football, opera lovers dreamed up imaginary teams. You loved Maria Callas and Tito Gobbi in their classic 1953 “Tosca” recording, but thought Giuseppe di Stefano wasn’t quite on their level? Draft (in your mind, at least) Jussi Bjoerling, Richard Tucker or Franco Corelli.

headline: Stumbling Into Divorce
abstract: “Goodbye to All That” tracks an amiably self-centered guy (Paul Schneider) through a divorce and the perils of Internet dating.
lead_paragraph: In “Goodbye to All That,” Otto Wall (Paul Schneider), a web designer and happy-go-lucky family man in suburban North Carolina, is caught off guard when his wife, Annie (Melanie Lynskey), summons him to her therapist’s office. While Annie wipes away tears, the therapist (Celia Weston) brusquely informs him that his 11-year marriage is over.

headline: Reassembling a History Told in Paint
abstract: Jacob Lawrence’s 60 panels portraying the Great Migration of blacks from the South will be brought together in a show at MoMA next year.
lead_paragraph: From 1915 onward, six million black Southerners quit that region for points north in an epic tide of souls fleeing oppression and seeking opportunity. This spring, the Museum of Modern Art will honor the Great Migration’s centennial by reuniting Jacob Lawrence’s famous paintings of this mass movement, a suite of 60 panels to be shown at MoMA for the first time since 1995.

headline: In Sicily, a European Union on Wheels
abstract: A German woman and her French car have proven to be an ideal match for Palermo’s cobblestone streets.
lead_paragraph: A German woman and her French car have proven to be an ideal match for Palermo’s cobblestone streets.

headline: Quandary for Sony in Terror Threats Over ‘The Interview’
abstract: As Sony came under pressure to cancel or postpone the release of the film, about the assassination of North Korea’s leader, the New York premiere was called off.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Sony Pictures Entertainment, the F.B.I., theater owners and competing film studios scrambled on Tuesday to deal with a threat of terrorism against movie theaters that show Sony’s “The Interview,” a raunchy comedy about the assassination of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un.

headline: For Techno Collective, the Politics Lie Ahead
abstract: Techno looks to the future and solving problems there, members of Underground Resistance said at a panel discussion on Sunday at MoMA PS1.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday afternoon, under a dome on the grounds of MoMA PS1, DJ Dex was spinning a set of amiable, springy techno, with flickers of funk and jazz, for a small crowd of people who were either dancing awkwardly, seated on foam cushions or talking among themselves. It was not, on its face, a site of radical politics or action.

headline: Harlem Man Is Killed by Tire Swing in Tompkins Square Park
abstract: The police said Aleim Perkins, who was hit in the face by the swing, was unconscious when emergency officials arrived on the scene.
lead_paragraph: A 39-year-old man died this week after being hit in the face with a tire swing in Tompkins Square Park in the East Village, the police said on Tuesday.

headline: Never Too Young to Take On Beethoven and Bartok
abstract: At 18, Stephen Waarts takes on a daunting program of Beethoven’s Violin Sonata No. 8 at Merkin Concert Hall.
lead_paragraph: At just 18, the violinist Stephen Waarts has already taken top prizes in competitions and played more than 30 concertos with various orchestras. It’s a wonder he has time for his studies at the Curtis Institute in Philadelphia.

headline: A Perfect Car for Palermo’s Melting Pot
abstract: German-born Katja Iseler and her 1987 Citroën 2CV feel right at home in Sicily’s eclectic capital.
lead_paragraph: PALERMO, Italy — Among a group of dark-haired Sicilians bustling around the Mercato del Capo open-air market here in Sicily’s capital, one might peg Katja Iseler, 48, with her lighter hair and clipped German accent, as a tourist. And in this land of Fiat and Ferrari, her car, a bug-eyed 1987 Citroën 2CV, would appear to be an outsider as well.

headline: Lawmakers Are Roommates No More
abstract: The last of a group of Democratic lawmakers who have lived in a Washington rowhouse for years finally moved out, taking their comforters and Hendrix records with them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They had packed up their comforters, antacids and Jimi Hendrix records.

headline: Surviving Rape in the Military
abstract: The disturbing statistics on military rape — and the fleeting attention of the public — led Mary F. Calvert to document the stories of those who survived assaults.
lead_paragraph: The disturbing statistics on military rape — and the fleeting attention of the public — led Mary F. Calvert to document the stories of those who survived assaults.

headline: Methane and Holes on Mars and Earth
abstract: Some musings on very different methane-emitting holes on Mars and Earth.
lead_paragraph: I hope you’ll excuse this but I can’t resist after a tough pulse of climate news and academic work.

headline: Andrew Litton to Lead New York City Ballet Orchestra
abstract: It is unusual for a conductor of Mr. Litton’s stature to decide to lead a ballet company ensemble.
lead_paragraph: Before Andrew Litton, who has led orchestras around the world, became a conductor, his first real job was accompanying ballet dancers: As a student at Juilliard, he was hired as the onstage pianist for one of Rudolf Nureyev’s engagements on Broadway.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Lydia Polgreen, Nick Bilton and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Push to Provide Lawyers in New York City Housing Court Gains Momentum
abstract: A City Council bill is part of a national campaign by elected officials, legal scholars and tenant advocates to establish a right to counsel in civil actions that affect basic needs like housing.
lead_paragraph: At the information table at Housing Court in the Bronx, tenant after tenant approached, often anxious and often in a familiar predicament — they owed their landlords rent and needed more time to pay it. Some had received eviction papers and did not know what to do.

headline: New Owners for an Agency That Markets for a Cause
abstract: The agency, named Fenton, is getting new leadership along with its new ownership.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the first agencies devoted to handling communications efforts for causes, nonprofit organizations, charities, foundations and activists seeking social change — a specialty that is now thriving — is being sold by its founder and longtime leader, David Fenton, to investors who are forming a holding group for agencies of that kind.

headline: Ecuador Family Wins Favors After Donations to Democrats
abstract: A scion of the Isaías family who was banned from entering the United States had the ban waived after her family poured tens of thousands into Democratic coffers.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The Obama administration overturned a ban preventing a wealthy, politically connected Ecuadorean woman from entering the United States after her family gave tens of thousands of dollars to Democratic campaigns, according to finance records and government officials.

headline: Free the Philosophical Beast
abstract: The subject that changed my life, and so many others, has been pacing for too long in its cage.
lead_paragraph: When I entered college nearly a quarter-century ago, my two main concerns were playing soccer and preparing for a successful career as a certified public accountant, like my older brother had. The two “philosophers” with whom I was most familiar were Jesus and the apostle Paul. I was born and raised in a small town in Pennsylvania, and immersed in a church modeled after the Plymouth Brethren tradition, where the Bible was taken literally as the inerrant word of God. But by the time I was ready to graduate, soccer and a business career — and my religious belief — had taken a back seat to two other things that had bitten me hard: poetry and philosophy. In the 20 years since, the intersection of the two has been my overwhelming preoccupation.

headline: Wheelies: The Bandit Gone Edition
abstract: Burt Reynolds’s 1977 Pontiac Trans Am sells for $450,000; a report says Toyota officials called for a last-minute redesign of the new Prius.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Confronting an Ugly Killer
abstract: Alzheimer’s is deadly, costly and finally getting the blunt discussion it needs.
lead_paragraph: My maternal grandmother lives in my memory as two distinct images. Two distinct people, really.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,340 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,342 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: News Analysis: Pakistan School Attack
abstract: The Pakistani Taliban’s attack on a school in Peshawar in December signaled a significant change of tactics.
lead_paragraph: The Pakistani Taliban’s attack on a school in Peshawar in December signaled a significant change of tactics.

headline: End Solitary Confinement for Teenagers
abstract: Their prison stories haunt me. Their rights must be protected.
lead_paragraph: SOLITARY confinement can be psychologically damaging for any inmate, but it is especially perverse when it is used to discipline children and teenagers. At juvenile detention centers and adult prisons and jails across the country, minors are locked in isolated cells for 22 hours or more a day. Solitary confinement is used to punish misbehavior, to protect vulnerable detainees or to isolate someone who may be violent or suicidal. But this practice does more harm than good. It should end.

headline: This Israeli Election Matters
abstract: A nation struggles with its identity.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Bibi Netanyahu has set new elections in Israel for March 17. Israel has had critical elections before, but this could be its most important, because the Israeli right today is no longer dominated by security hawks and free-marketeers like Netanyahu. It is dominated by West Bank settlers and scary religious-nationalist zealots like Naftali Bennett, who, if they run the next government and effectively annex the West Bank, will lead Israel into a dark corner, increasingly alienated from Europe, America and the next generation of American Jews.

headline: Isolated No More
abstract: We Australians liked being cut off from craziness.
lead_paragraph: AUSTRALIA’S remoteness is, for those of us who live there, possibly the greatest thing about it.

headline: F.D.A. Approves System That May Make Blood Transfusions Safer
abstract: The system is being used in clinical trials in West Africa to make plasma donated by Ebola survivors safer to use as a possible treatment.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday approved the first system that could be used by blood banks to destroy viruses and bacteria in donated blood plasma, potentially making transfusions safer.

headline: Bleeping, En Español
abstract: Should the F.C.C. do more to regulate Spanish language media in the U.S.?

headline: High Hopes for the White Sox and Their Fans
abstract: Both Chicago teams start from the same point: a 73-89 record in 2014, after at least 96 losses in 2013. But only the White Sox have made themselves significantly better.
lead_paragraph: David Robertson did not know who would chase him in free agency, and he did not think much about it.

headline: Federal Judge Calls Obama’s Immigration Actions Unlawful
abstract: A federal judge in Pennsylvania issued an opinion on Tuesday declaring unconstitutional President Obama’s executive actions on immigration, but the finding had no immediate effect.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Pennsylvania issued an opinion on Tuesday declaring unconstitutional President Obama’s executive actions on immigration, which offer protection from deportation to millions of unauthorized immigrants. The finding had no immediate effect, and it was unclear how it might affect the president’s measures in the future.

headline: Norman Bridwell, Creator of ‘Clifford the Big Red Dog’ Books, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Bridwell’s “Clifford” books, about a dog as big as a house, became an international favorite for parents to read aloud to their children.
lead_paragraph: Norman Bridwell, the creator of Clifford the Big Red Dog, a figure who looms as large in toddler lit as the great white whale does in the American canon, died on Friday in Oak Bluffs, Mass., on Martha’s Vineyard. He was 86.

headline: Dick Rich, Who Helped Redefine TV Advertising, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Rich’s whimsical and sardonic commercials for clients like Alka-Seltzer helped introduce a more freewheeling approach to TV advertising in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Dick Rich, a copywriter and advertising executive who turned the disadvantages of indigestion and outsize cigarettes into classic 1960s television commercials for Alka-Seltzer and Benson & Hedges 100s, died on Nov. 11 in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: U.S. Imposes Steep Tariffs on Chinese Solar Panels
abstract: The Commerce Department approved a collection of tariffs on imports from China and Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: The Commerce Department began closing a chapter in a protracted trade conflict with China over solar equipment Tuesday, approving a collection of steep tariffs on imports from China and Taiwan.

headline: Ashanti, R&B Singer, Is Cross-Examined by Her Convicted Stalker
abstract: The singer had to answer questions from Devar Hurd, a fan who was convicted of stalking her in 2009, and is charged with doing it again.
lead_paragraph: For a stalker, a courtroom is one of the few places one can come face to face with one’s obsession.

headline: You Ain’t Seen Nothin’ Yet
abstract: The “cromnibus” spending bill attacks progressive food legislation, and it doesn’t stop there.
lead_paragraph: What’s more depressing, gutting progressive moves in school nutrition or gutting progressive moves in restaurant meal labeling?

headline: Thomas Garbutt
abstract: Mr. Garbutt is a senior managing director for TIAA-CREF, a financial services company and a provider of retirement services.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Garbutt, 56, is a senior managing director and head of global real estate for TIAA-CREF, a financial services company and a provider of retirement services in the academic, research, medical and cultural fields. Mr. Garbutt, who joined the organization in 1982, also serves as the chairman of TIAA Henderson Real Estate, a newly formed real estate asset management company.

headline: Nets Struggle to Contain Wade and Mother Nature
abstract: The Nets’ game against the Heat at Barclays Center was stopped for nearly 30 minutes after water began dripping onto the court from a leak in the roof late in the first quarter.
lead_paragraph: Things were just starting to get interesting in Tuesday’s game between the Nets and the Miami Heat when nature intervened, casting the game into the realm of the bizarre.

headline: Federal Health Exchange Sees Enrollment Flurry
abstract: In its second year, the much-maligned HealthCare.gov website showed a vastly improved performance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Tuesday that nearly 2.5 million people had selected health insurance plans through the federal marketplace in the first four weeks of open enrollment this fall.

headline: American Apparel Ends Role of Dov Charney and Hires a New Chief
abstract: Paula Schneider, a longtime retail executive, will take over on Jan. 5, replacing Dov Charney, who was ousted in June for misusing company funds.
lead_paragraph: Six months after abruptly removing its founder, Dov Charney, as chief executive, American Apparel chose the longtime retail executive Paula Schneider as its new leader.

headline: Recent Commercial Transactions
abstract: Notable properties that have been recently listed for sale, sold or leased.
lead_paragraph: RECENT SALE

headline: OnDeck, a Lender to Small Businesses, Raises $200 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: The stock sale priced OnDeck’s shares at $20 each, surpassing a forecasted range of $16 to $18, and reflected Wall Street investors’ continued embrace of the alternative lending industry.
lead_paragraph: The successful debut of Lending Club appears to have rubbed off on another alternative lender looking to trade on the public markets.

headline: Aalsmeer Flower Auction Fights the Clock
abstract: More than 20 million stems are auctioned daily near Amsterdam at the world’s largest flower market. But the Internet and globalization have decentralized the market, casting its future into doubt.
lead_paragraph: More than 20 million stems are auctioned daily near Amsterdam at the world’s largest flower market. But the Internet and globalization have decentralized the market, casting its future into doubt.

headline: Vivek Murthy, the New Surgeon General, Isn’t Afraid to Take a Stand
abstract: Dr. Murthy, who at the age of 37 has become one of the youngest surgeons general of the United States, is a self-described dreamer and grass-roots organizer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, a Boston internist who at the age of 37 has become one of the youngest surgeons general of the United States, is a self-described dreamer and grass-roots organizer.

headline: Dutch Flower Auction, Long Industry’s Heart, Is Facing Competition
abstract: An auction system that helped make flowers as synonymous with the Dutch identity as wooden shoes and windmills is being buffeted by a variety of forces.
lead_paragraph: AALSMEER, the Netherlands — Each weekday morning, the buyers descend on Aalsmeer, about a half-hour southwest of Amsterdam, arriving at an enormous warehouse covering some two million square meters.

headline: TheSkimm, an Email Newsletter, Draws Fans Like Oprah Winfrey – and Investors
abstract: After leaving NBC News, two news fans created a compelling newsletter with a fresh voice, drawing more than a million active readers.
lead_paragraph: Online news start-ups have garnered buzz, and millions of dollars, over the last few years. But few can boast of vocal fans like Oprah Winfrey, especially while focusing on the least sexy of media: email.

headline: Tortured by Psychologists and Doctors
abstract: After two health professionals tortured some C.I.A. detainees, Congress should enact legislation that explicitly prohibits medical personnel from direct involvement in interrogations.
lead_paragraph: One of the most disturbing revelations in the Senate report on the Central Intelligence Agency’s interrogation program was the deep complicity of psychologists and doctors in torturing suspected terrorists. We already knew from earlier reports that health professionals had facilitated the torture by advising the interrogators when their brutal tactics might inadvertently kill a prisoner.

headline: Market Turmoil Will Test the Post-Crisis Financial System
abstract: One change is that the banks are stronger today because they rely less on borrowed money to finance their trading and lending.
lead_paragraph: Washington has been trying to bolster the financial system for the last five years so it can deal with mayhem in the markets. The turmoil this week will test those rebuilding efforts.

headline: With the Way Eased, Two More Obama Nominees Win Approval From the Senate
abstract: Senators confirmed over Republican objections Sarah Saldaña as director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement and Antony Blinken to be deputy secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Tuesday finished its final session of the year by moving forward on more disputed nominations over Republican objections, confirming Sarah Saldaña, a federal prosecutor, as director of the United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency and Antony Blinken, a former national security adviser to President Obama, to be deputy secretary of state.

headline: Executive’s Ride Into Sunset Signals Brighter Day for U.S.A. Cycling
abstract: Steve Johnson, the president and chief executive during the rampant doping of the Lance Armstrong era, will leave after the world championships next fall.
lead_paragraph: An early holiday gift landed on the doorstep of the sport of cycling last week. It didn’t come wrapped in shiny paper, or decorated with a bow. But a note said it was from Bob Stapleton, the new chairman of U.S.A. Cycling, and now every single clean American cyclist has reason to celebrate.

headline: Bond Investors Are Skittish Over Emerging Markets
abstract: The precipitous fall in the Russian ruble has already rattled investors. Concerns are mounting that bond troubles of big energy companies in emerging markets will unleash a new wave of market contagion.
lead_paragraph: They were the darlings of global investors.

headline: The Taliban’s Massacre of Innocents in Pakistan
abstract: The Pakistani Taliban’s attack on a Peshawar school should prompt the country to reconsider its approach to the insurgency that is threatening its survival.
lead_paragraph: With the slaughter of at least 145 schoolchildren and teachers at a school in Peshawar, Pakistan, on Tuesday, the Taliban took its grisly war against the state to a more horrific place.

headline: New York City Teachers Score Highly Under New Evaluation System
abstract: The system was created to make it easier to identify which teachers performed the best so their methods could be replicated, and which performed the worst, so they could be fired.
lead_paragraph: Nine out of 10 New York City teachers received one of the top two rankings in the first year of a new evaluation system that was hailed as a better way of assessing how they perform, according to  figures released on Tuesday.

headline: Jeb Bush Takes a Step Toward a Presidential Run
abstract: Mr. Bush, the former governor of Florida, could commandeer the center-right of the Republican Party, but his views on immigration and education may not please more conservative members.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida said Tuesday that he would “actively explore” a presidential run, immediately sending reverberations through the potential Republican field, tying up donors whom other candidates are courting and forcing contenders to accelerate their own considerations for 2016.

headline: Pieces That Built 49ers Into a Power Appear to Be Falling Apart
abstract: A year ago, the 49ers had a top-tier coach, an All-Pro roster and a talented quarterback. This season, amid speculation about Coach Jim Harbaugh’s future, the team has sputtered and will miss the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — Deep inside Levi’s Stadium, built largely on the recent resurgence of a storied franchise under Coach Jim Harbaugh, some of the 49ers dressed for Tuesday’s practice in a locker room so big that a pass from one end to the other would constitute a big play on a football field.

headline: U.N. Secretary General to Visit Ebola-Plagued Nations
abstract: The trip, which is to begin later this week, seems designed to send a message of solidarity with the three affected countries: Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, plans to visit the three West African countries that have been hit the hardest by the Ebola outbreak, according to a senior United Nations official.

headline: Soccer Fans in Turkish Protests Stand Trial
abstract: The case has drawn criticism from human rights groups who accused the government of using the trial to warn other people against expressing dissent.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Thousands of people have already been indicted on charges related to last year’s nationwide anti-government protests. On Tuesday, it was the turn of soccer fans.

headline: Google’s Detractors Take Their Fight to the States
abstract: Critics of Google are turning to state attorneys general to push the company to censor illegal content and sites from search results.
lead_paragraph: They have lobbied state attorneys general. They have hired former state attorneys general. They have even helped draft a menacing letter for one state attorney general.

headline: Letter to Google From Mississippi’s Attorney General
abstract: This document shows revisions to a letter sent to Google by the attorney general of Mississippi, that had been largely drafted by a law firm representing the Motion Picture Association of America.
lead_paragraph: This document shows revisions to a letter sent to Google by the attorney general of Mississippi, that had been largely drafted by a law firm representing the Motion Picture Association of America.

headline: Panel to Set Terms to End Abusive Reign at Los Angeles County Jail System
abstract: A federal panel will implement dozens of changes in Los Angeles County’s troubled jails in an agreement reached a year after guards were charged with beating prisoners.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles County jail system, the nation’s largest, agreed Tuesday to impose sweeping changes, a year after guards were charged with regularly beating prisoners and supervisors in the Sheriff’s Department were accused of seeking to thwart a federal investigation into corruption and violence in the jails.

headline: Russian Minister on Ruble Exchange Rates
abstract: The minister of the economy, Aleksei V. Ulyukayev, talked about stabilizing the ruble after a steep overnight increase in interest rates failed to stop it from falling.
lead_paragraph: The minister of the economy, Aleksei V. Ulyukayev, talked about stabilizing the ruble after a steep overnight increase in interest rates failed to stop it from falling.

headline: As the Ruble Swoons, Russians Desperately Shop
abstract: As Russia faced a currency crisis that prompted bickering among some top presidential allies, consumers afraid of losing their savings flooded stores, rushing to dump rubles.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia faced a snowballing currency crisis on Tuesday that prompted an unusual outburst of public bickering among some top presidential allies, as President Vladimir V. Putin struggled to tame events that had the potential to wreck his reputation as the leader who brought stability and prosperity to this country.

headline: Democrats in New York Assembly Say They Support Ethics Reform
abstract: Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker, said his Democratic caucus supported measures to close campaign finance loopholes, an assertion that came after lawmakers had unsuccessfully lobbied for a raise.
lead_paragraph: Assembly Democrats on Tuesday challenged Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s assertion that New York lawmakers had shown little interest in ethics reform, saying they were prepared to back substantial changes to the way business is done in Albany.

headline: Family of Former Marine Held in Iran Issues Plea for Obama Not to Forget Him
abstract: The Marine’s request came as the United States intensified negotiations with the Iranians on their disputed nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: Relatives of a former Marine imprisoned in Iran for more than three years said Tuesday that he had begun a hunger strike, and they released an open letter he had written to President Obama urging him “not to forget me” as the United States intensifies negotiations with the Iranians on their disputed nuclear program.

headline: Obama Indefinitely Bans Drilling in Alaskan Bay
abstract: President Obama has again enforced environmental policy by executive action, extending a ban on oil and gas exploration in Bristol Bay, Alaska, home to major fisheries and marine mammals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday again used his executive authority to enact an environmental priority as he indefinitely barred oil and gas exploration of Alaska’s picturesque Bristol Bay to protect some of the nation’s most productive commercial fisheries.

headline: American Held in Iran Sends Letter to President Obama
abstract: Amir Hekmati, a former Marine who has been incarcerated in Iran for more than three years, sent this letter to President Obama as the United States intensifies negotiations with Tehran on its disputed nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: Amir Hekmati, a former Marine who has been incarcerated in Iran for more than three years, sent this letter to President Obama as the United States intensifies negotiations with Tehran on its disputed nuclear program.

headline: F.B.I. Appoints New York Leader
abstract: Diego G. Rodriguez, formerly in charge of the Dallas office, is to be the assistant director in charge of the New York field office.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has named a new leader for its New York field office, the agency said on Tuesday.

headline: Litotes for Beauty
abstract: In which I start having anxiety dreams again. Thanks a lot, Stu Ockman.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Have you ever awakened in the middle of the night, soaked in sweat and terrified that you hadn’t prepared properly for a test, even if there is no real test for which you need to prepare?

headline: Mexico: Former President’s Brother Is Cleared in a Corruption Case
abstract: Raúl Salinas de Gortari has been cleared of charges of illicit enrichment, ending his two decades of legal battles over charges ranging from money laundering to murder.
lead_paragraph: Raúl Salinas de Gortari, the brother of former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, has been cleared of charges of illicit enrichment, ending his two decades of legal battles over charges ranging from money laundering to murder. This week a federal court upheld an earlier ruling that the attorney general had failed to prove that Mr. Salinas had illegally obtained money to buy properties valued at about $15 million, while holding only government jobs. He also had tens of millions of dollars in offshore accounts under aliases. Mr. Salinas, 68, spent 10 years in prison on charges of ordering his former brother-in-law’s murder but was absolved in 2005.

headline: Jury Is Deciding if Rikers Captain Ignored a Dying Man
abstract: Terrence Pendergrass is charged with depriving the rights of an inmate who ingested a toxic soap ball and suffered chemical burns.
lead_paragraph: There was no argument about the clinical reason for Jason Echevarria’s death: The 25-year-old inmate at Rikers Island had swallowed a packet of highly toxic detergent, known as a soap ball, and died after the chemicals burned through the lining of his mouth, throat and stomach.

headline: The Rise of ‘Welfare Chauvinism’
abstract: In Europe, populist right-wing parties have become proponents of a more lavish, but also more restrictive, welfare state. Could that happen here?
lead_paragraph: The same economic and cultural forces that have fractured political parties on the left and on the right in Europe are disrupting the Democratic and Republican Parties here.

headline: Federal Judge’s Opinion on Obama’s Immigration Actions
abstract: A federal judge in Pennsylvania issued an opinion on Tuesday declaring unconstitutional President Obama’s executive actions on immigration, but the finding had no immediate impact.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Pennsylvania issued an opinion on Tuesday declaring unconstitutional President Obama’s executive actions on immigration, but the finding had no immediate impact.

headline: At New York City Council Hearing, Concerns About Housing Authority Practices
abstract: Among the officials’ concerns were the slow pace of repairs and the practice of police officers’ citing residents for violations of housing authority rules.
lead_paragraph: One month after a police officer fatally shot an unarmed black man in a darkened public housing stairwell in Brooklyn, elected officials at a City Council hearing on Tuesday honed in on some of the New York City Housing Authority practices that they said exacerbated unsafe conditions and heightened unease among residents.

headline: Terrorism Insurance Is Rejected in the Senate
abstract: A retiring senator refused to drop his opposition to an extraneous measure that had been added at the last minute by House Republicans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal terrorism insurance, the government backstop that was first passed in the wake of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, died in the Senate on Tuesday night after a retiring senator refused to drop his opposition to an extraneous measure that had been added at the last minute by House Republicans.

headline: U.S. Should Shun Torture, Clinton Says in New York
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton condemned the use of torture on Tuesday in her first remarks about the issue since the Senate Intelligence Committee released its scathing report last week.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Tuesday made an impassioned argument against the use of torture in her first remarks about the issue since the Senate Intelligence Committee released its scathing report last week about interrogation tactics used by the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: Senate Confirms Nominee to Head Auto Safety Agency
abstract: The Senate has confirmed a specialist on human fatigue to fill a longstanding vacancy at nation’s top automotive safety agency.
lead_paragraph: The Senate has confirmed a specialist on human fatigue to fill a longstanding vacancy at nation’s top automotive safety agency. On Tuesday, the nominee, Mark R. Rosekind, was approved as the new administrator at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, which has come under fire this year for its role in General Motors’ decade-delayed deadly ignition switch recall and an ever-expanding series of recalls for exploding Takata airbags. Mr. Rosekind, 59, occupies one of five seats on the National Transportation Safety Board, an independent agency. His confirmation comes almost a year after the resignation of David L. Strickland as agency’s leader.

headline: For Knicks, the Only Question Now Is How They’ll Lose
abstract: The Knicks trailed Dallas by as many as 19 points in the first half and never made things interesting in the second as their record dropped to 5-22.
lead_paragraph: Wins and losses, in the dispiriting world of the Knicks, have been replaced by losses in which they keep the game close and losses in which they do not. Their game on Tuesday against the Dallas Mavericks, from start to end, fell comfortably into the second category.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 16, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Regaining His Health to Be There for His Children
abstract: Fitz Alexander, whose son has cerebral palsy, is no longer homeless and has been getting alcohol rehabilitation and help for his bipolar disorder.
lead_paragraph: When Fitz Alexander was told he had a bipolar disorder, he could barely comprehend the concept. He was in his early 50s and prided himself on an indomitable spirit.

headline: Chief of Agency for International Development to Step Down
abstract: Rajiv Shah praised President Obama for giving the agency a stronger role in foreign policy decisions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rajiv Shah, the administrator of the United States Agency for International Development and the highest ranking Indian-American in the Obama administration, announced on Wednesday that he would step down as head of the agency early next year.

headline: How Exercise Changes Our DNA
abstract: Exercise, a new study finds, changes the shape and functioning of our genes, an important step on the way to improved health and fitness.
lead_paragraph: We all know that exercise can make us fitter and reduce our risk for illnesses such as diabetes and heart disease. But just how, from start to finish, a run or a bike ride might translate into a healthier life has remained baffling.

headline: Word of the Day | tempestuous
abstract: This word has appeared in 63 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: tempestuous •\tem-ˈpes-chə-wəs, -ˈpesh-\• adjective

headline: Iran Criticized for Executing Drug Offenders
abstract: Rights groups have called on the United Nations to halt its counternarcotics aid to the country because of its mandatory death penalty for drug crimes.
lead_paragraph: Six international human rights groups have petitioned the United Nations to freeze its counternarcotics aid to Iran until that country abolishes the death penalty for drug offenses.

headline: Rights Groups Request Penalties For Iran’s Executions
abstract: Six international groups have called on the United Nations to halt its counternarcotics aid to the country because of its mandatory death penalty for drug offenses.
lead_paragraph: Six international groups have called on the United Nations to halt its counternarcotics aid to the country because of its mandatory death penalty for drug offenses.

headline: The Best Sellers: Filed Under Sports
abstract: A look at the best-selling sports books in November, according to the New York Times best-seller list.
lead_paragraph: The best-selling sports books in November 2014, according to the New York Times best-seller list.

headline: Guardrail Maker Trinity Industries Conducts More Tests for Malfunction
abstract: Questions grew over whether some of the units being evaluated were different than those previously installed.
lead_paragraph: Trinity Industries on Tuesday conducted the second of eight crash tests of a potentially dangerous guardrail system, as questions grew over whether some of the units being evaluated were different than those previously installed.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 3:45 P.M. (HBO) EPIC (2013) M. K., the spirited 17-year-old daughter (voiced by Amanda Seyfried) of the eccentric scientist Bomba (Jason Sudeikis), trying to prove the existence of a nearly invisible kingdom, ventures into a lush forest and shrinks to two inches, the better to ride on the backs of hummingbirds. This animated film, directed by Chris Wedge, was inspired by William Joyce’s children’s book “The Leaf Men and the Brave Good Bugs.” In the forest she meets Ronin (Colin Farrell), the leader of the Leafmen army, all ecowarriors committed to saving their environment from the evil Boggans, who want to turn it into a wasteland. Beyoncé provides the voice for the Leafmen’s ruler, whose 100-year reign will end when a flower pod bursts under a full moon to reveal the new queen. Christoph Waltz is the leader of the Boggans, and Steven Tyler is the distracted yellow caterpillar in charge of recording the forest’s history. “The gorgeous 3-D adventure comedy ‘Epic’ suggests a warmer, fuzzier ‘Avatar,’ with a green heart,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, adding that the movie “is on the side of the angels.”

headline: Corrections: December 17, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, December 17, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, December 17, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “It was an ‘oh my gosh’ moment.”

headline: More Than 100 Vietnamese Brides Are Said to Have Disappeared From Hebei Villages
abstract: A Vietnamese woman who had lived in the area for more than 20 years helped introduce other Vietnamese women for local marriages, collecting thousands of dollars in matchmaking fees. By late November, more than 100 of the women had vanished.
lead_paragraph: When Yuan Xinqiang’s last negotiations for marriage with a Chinese woman fell through over monetary matters, he, like many other men in China, asked a matchmaker to help him find a Vietnamese fiancée. But his happiness, he told The Beijing News, was short-lived: His bride-to-be vanished just two months after they were introduced, along with dozens of other Vietnamese women in the area.

headline: Library of Congress Likes ‘Rosemary’s Baby’ and ‘The Big Lebowski’
abstract: “Rosemary’s Baby” and “The Big Lebowski” are two of 25 films being added to the National Film Registry.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to pray for “Rosemary’s Baby,” or fear that your reverence for “The Big Lebowski” is just, like, your opinion man: the 1968 Roman Polanski thriller and Joel and Ethan Coen’s 1998 shaggy-dog comedy noir are two of the 25 movies that have been added to the National Film Registry this year, along with Steven Spielberg’s “Saving Private Ryan,” Howard Hawks’s “Rio Bravo” and Arthur Penn’s “Little Big Man.”

headline: Pakistan’s Military Campaign Against the Taliban
abstract: Maps of the major attacks since June.
lead_paragraph: Maps of the major attacks since June.

headline: Test Yourself | Young Grandmasters Try to Make Chess Cool
abstract: Here are several paragraphs from a Dec. 12 article, “Young Grandmasters Try to Make Chess Cool.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are several paragraphs from a Dec. 12 article, “Young Grandmasters Try to Make Chess Cool.”

headline: Australian Government Faces Questions Over Sydney Gunman
abstract: On Wednesday, Prime Minister Tony Abbott asked why Man Haron Monis had been dropped from a terrorism watchlist around 2009 and had been granted permanent residency.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The Australian authorities came under pressure on Wednesday to explain why the gunman in a siege at a Sydney cafe that left two hostages dead had dropped off a security watch list and was not being monitored despite his criminal record, history of violence, and public airings of his radical views.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Pakistani Taliban Attack on Peshawar School Leaves 145 Dead
abstract: How should the Pakistani government respond to this school attack?
lead_paragraph: In “Pakistani Taliban Attack on Peshawar School Leaves 145 Dead,” Ismail Khan and Salman Masood report on a violent attack in Pakistan that killed many children.

headline: Tibetan Man Dies After Self-Immolation in Protest of Chinese Rule
abstract: The man in western China was the 134th person to self-immolate in protest of Chinese rule over Tibetan areas, Radio Free Asia reported.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A Tibetan man set himself on fire and died outside a police station in the western Chinese province of Gansu on Tuesday, becoming the 134th person to self-immolate in protest of Chinese rule over Tibetan areas, according to a report by Radio Free Asia, which is financed by the United States government.

headline: What Were the Best and Worst Things About 2014?
abstract: You can put anything you like on your lists — the movies, music, TV or books you liked best ; the news stories or viral videos or sporting events that you thought were great or terrible; the aspects of your personal, family or academic life that were most notable for being bad or good; or a mix.
lead_paragraph: As December winds down and the 2014 retrospectives begin to roll out in The Times and around the Web, we thought we’d ask you for your own lists.

headline: Surviving Rape in the Military
abstract: The disturbing statistics on military rape — and the fleeting attention of the public — led Mary F. Calvert to document the stories of those who survived assaults.
lead_paragraph: The issue of sexual assault in the military makes the news periodically, usually in articles with mouth-dropping statistics and official outrage.

headline: Pakistan Urges Afghans to Help Find Taliban Leaders Behind Massacre
abstract: Gen. Raheel Sharif went to Afghanistan to seek help in locating the Pakistani Taliban commanders who orchestrated the Peshawar school massacre.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Pakistan’s army and intelligence chiefs traveled to Afghanistan on Wednesday to seek help locating the Pakistani Taliban commanders responsible for the massacre of students at a school here in Peshawar the day before, officials said.

headline: UBS to Nominate Former Head of JPMorgan’s Investment Bank to Board
abstract: James E. Staley, a managing partner at the New York hedge fund BlueMountain Capital Management, is expected to be considered for the board during UBS’s annual meeting in May, and to join the bank’s risk committee.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Swiss bank UBS said on Wednesday that it would nominate James E. Staley, the former head of JPMorgan Chase’s investment bank, for election to its board of directors.

headline: Philips Agrees to Acquire Maker of Medical Devices for $1.2 Billion
abstract: Acquisition of Volcano, a maker of catheter-based imaging and measurement devices, would bolster Philips’s lineup of medical imaging devices and expand its opportunities to sell its existing products to Volcano customers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Philips, the Dutch electronics giant, said on Wednesday that it had agreed to acquire the American medical device maker Volcano Corporation for $1.2 billion, including the assumption of debt.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: Bravery in Transit
abstract: Wednesday: The M.T.A. honors its workers, oddly warm weather, and a vigil for Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this mild Wednesday.

headline: Stemming a Tide of Cultural Theft
abstract: Antiquities around the world, but especially in war zones, are increasingly under pressure, leading preservationists to call for more protections.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — They have always been among the spoils of war, alluring in their beauty, tantalizing in their value to dealers, museums and collectors. And after a decade of turmoil, and a longer stretch of willful destruction, the world’s antiquities are in such jeopardy that preservationists are sounding a screeching alarm.

headline: Church of England Names Libby Lane as First Female Bishop
abstract: Just weeks after the church authorities took the final step to reverse centuries of canon law, the church appointed the Rev. Libby Lane, a priest for 20 years, as bishop of Stockport.
lead_paragraph: The Church of England on Wednesday named the Rev. Libby Lane, a parish priest for 20 years in the north of England, as its first female bishop, just weeks after the church authorities took the final step to reverse centuries of canon law to begin what the archbishop of Canterbury called “a completely new phase of our existence.”

headline: Malaysia Airline Tragedy Puts Zhang Yimou Project on Back Burner
abstract: “Impression Melaka” would have been the first of the series co-directed by Zhang Yimou, the prominent filmmaker, to take place outside China.
lead_paragraph: After Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 vanished in March, many ordinary Chinese and officials became incensed at Malaysia’s handling of the disaster and vowed never to travel to the country. Most of the 227 passengers on board had been Chinese flying to Beijing from the Malaysian capital, Kuala Lumpur.

headline: European Court Reverses Designation of Hamas as a Terrorist Organization
abstract: A decision to reverse the European Union’s designation of the group came amid a swell of opinion in favor of recognizing a Palestinian state.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Strains between Israel and parts of Europe intensified on Wednesday when the European Union’s second-highest court reversed the bloc’s designation of the militant Palestinian group Hamas as a terrorist organization.

headline: Ruble Crisis Is Testing Russia’s Resources
abstract: The country’s Finance Ministry said it was prepared to sell as much as $7 billion of its foreign currency reserves to support the ruble, which an official called “extremely undervalued.”
lead_paragraph: Just a couple of months ago, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia confidently told business leaders that the country could withstand the economic storms. If foreign investors continued to withdraw money, he said, the government could simply tap its sizable reserves to help.

headline: How I Learned to Stop Stressing Over Health Insurance
abstract: Other owners often look at Fred Warmbier in disbelief when he says he’s not interested in spending a lot of time trying to figure out health coverage. It’s a look that says, “Man, you HAVE to manage this closely! What is wrong with you? You’re leaving money on the table.”
lead_paragraph: I’m not looking for analysis on health care. I know the outcome. The price is going up, and the coverage we offer will have to be compromised.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: It has begun. The 2016 presidential campaign is underway.
lead_paragraph: With Bush Announcement, the 2016 Presidential Race Gets Into Gear

headline: A Steep Slide in Law School Enrollment Accelerates
abstract: The 37,924 full- and part-time students who started classes this fall represent a 30 percent decline from just four years ago, when enrollment peaked at 52,488.
lead_paragraph: The bottom of the law school market just keeps on dropping.

headline: How a Porcupine and YouTube Helped Save the Bronx Zoo’s Budget
abstract: How a century-old conservation group chose YouTube and a porcupine to fight budget cuts in the depth of the recession.
lead_paragraph: Below you’ll find a guest post by Nikita Iyengar, a talented Pace University environmental studies major graduating later this month. The post draws on her research for her senior thesis, which is focused on the adoption of online and social media by the Wildlife Conservation Society, one of the world’s oldest environmental groups. (I was her thesis adviser.)

headline: Jeb Bush and the Base: Persona Trumps Policies
abstract: The G.O.P. establishment favorite has big advantages, but his approach and tone may not be acceptable to conservatives.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush’s announcement that he would “actively explore” a 2016 presidential run has been met with healthy skepticism, in no small part because he has staked out positions at odds with the Republican Party’s conservative base.

headline: Google Subpoena From Mississippi
abstract: The state’s attorney general asked the technology company to answer dozens of questions and provide even more documents about its operations, including its practices around illegal and sexual content, as well as advertising partnerships.
lead_paragraph: The state’s attorney general asked the technology company to answer dozens of questions and provide even more documents about its operations, including its practices around illegal and sexual content, as well as advertising partnerships.

headline: Exchanges Between Current and Former Missippippi Attorneys General
abstract: An email exchange between the current and former attorneys general of Mississippi shows a push to try to investigate Google.
lead_paragraph: An email exchange between the current and former attorneys general of Mississippi shows a push to try to investigate Google.

headline: Former Attorney General Lynch Calling for Google Investigation
abstract: Patrick Lynch, a former Attorney General from Rhode Island, has worked closely with a group called FairSearch, sending dozens of letters and emails to attorneys general around the United States, since at least 2011, repeating urging them to investigate Google.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Lynch, a former Attorney General from Rhode Island, has worked closely with a group called FairSearch, sending dozens of letters and emails to attorneys general around the United States, since at least 2011, repeating urging them to investigate Google.

headline: After ‘The Affair,’ Ruth Wilson Hits Broadway in ‘Constellations’
abstract: Ruth Wilson, an established presence in Britain, is poised to conquer America, making her Broadway debut in “Constellations” just as her first season on Showtime’s “The Affair” comes to a close.
lead_paragraph: As winter’s first snowflakes floated down over the theater district, two actors and their director were discussing the fine points of physics (theoretical) and kissing (actual). Playing a scientist and a beekeeper at the beginning of what might be a romance, Ruth Wilson and Jake Gyllenhaal experimented with different tones — brusque, tentative, flirtatious — and degrees of drunkenness. “Make sure you’re someone who could be slept with,” the director, Michael Longhurst, told Mr. Gyllenhaal.

headline: Morning Agenda: A Test for Post-Crisis Banking System
abstract: Market turmoil will test Washington’s efforts to bolster the financial system. | Bond investors skittish over emerging markets. | Venture capital’s feeding frenzy. | Email newsletter theSkimm raises $6.25 million in financing.
lead_paragraph: The market turmoil this week will test Washington’s efforts over the last five years to bolster the financial system, Peter Eavis reports in DealBook. Investors are stampeding out of risky markets, dumping junk bonds issued by American energy companies that have borrowed heavily to exploit the shale oil boom. A steep slide in the price of oil could now cause some of the companies to default, analysts say. But the most dangerous pain is occurring abroad, particularly in Russia, which is dealing with a currency crisis.

headline: Looking Back on 2014 | 15 Ways to Teach and Learn About the Year That Was
abstract: Fifteen ideas for teaching and learning about 2014, using retrospective videos, photos, articles and lists from The New York Times and around the Web.
lead_paragraph: What were the biggest events of 2014? How will the year be remembered? What will 2015 be like?

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Pharmacy Executives Face Murder Charges in Meningitis Deaths
abstract: Among the 14 people arrested were the founders of the New England Compounding Center, which made steroids blamed for an outbreak that killed 64 people.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Two senior executives of a Massachusetts compounding pharmacy were charged Wednesday with racketeering and murder in the production of tainted drugs that killed 64 people and sickened hundreds of others across the country with fungal meningitis in the fall of 2012.

headline: Everyone’s a Preservationist
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Walking near Astor Place, a burly, blue-collar type and a woman leaving a Historic Districts Council meeting shared their disapproval of an outsize condo building.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Stirring Passions in Hockey Hotbed
abstract: Michigan Tech is 13-3-0 and ranked No. 5 in the N.C.A.A.’s Division I, a development that is more than welcome in Copper Country, where professional hockey was born.
lead_paragraph: HOUGHTON, Mich. — Hockey rules this remote part of Michigan’s Upper Peninsula, where it is played by everyone from children to those in their 70s and 80s. All through the long winter it is always game on — in modern arenas, outside (into the wee hours of the night) and in two of the oldest hockey rinks in the world.

headline: What Happened When Marissa Mayer Tried to Be Steve Jobs
abstract: The inside story of how Yahoo’s C.E.O. lost her way.
lead_paragraph: Eric Jackson was sitting in his hotel room on Sea Island, Ga., watching his kids splash around in the pool, when he clicked “publish” on his latest blog post for Forbes.com. Jackson, an influential hedge-fund manager, had become fixated on Yahoo and the efforts of its chief executive, Marissa Mayer, to turn around the enormous yet floundering Internet company.
