headline: A Second Bank of America Whistle-Blower Is Set to Get $56 Million
abstract: Robert Madsen, one of four whistle-blowers in the $16.65 billion civil settlement, said keeping secret his cooperation with prosecutors for nearly four years had not been easy.
lead_paragraph: Robert Madsen, one of four whistle-blowers in the federal government’s $16.65 billion civil settlement with Bank of America, said keeping secret his cooperation with federal prosecutors for nearly four years had not been easy.

headline: In Twist, Tenant Who Was Forced Out Will Displace One Who Moved In
abstract: As a result of a precedent-setting decision, Tranquilina Alvillar will soon be able to return to the Brooklyn apartment she was made to leave three years ago.
lead_paragraph: Tranquilina Alvillar has spent three years waiting for this moment.

headline: Pictures of the Day — Dec. 18, 2014
abstract: Photos from Australia, Pakistan, Cuba and Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Australia, Pakistan, Cuba and Ukraine.

headline: Rocky Kingdom of a Man With Petty Cares
abstract: Nuri Bilge Ceylan’s “Winter Sleep” offers a portrait of a landlord, writer and husband in Turkey.
lead_paragraph: At the start of “Winter Sleep,” a speck of a man can be seen in long shot, dwarfed by the staggering natural beauty that envelops him like an embrace. He runs a hotel carved into a rock face in Cappadocia, a geological astonishment in central Turkey characterized by jutting spires and curvaceous formations that give the region an anthropomorphic sensuality. He spends much of his time in a gloomily lit home office — at times alone in near-monastic quiet, at times with bitingly effusive company — writing editorials about a world from which he has largely retreated.

headline: Zipping Around Cape Town
abstract: The company SA Forest Adventures has opened a zip line course with bird’s-eye views of Cape Town.
lead_paragraph: There’s a new adventure activity for adrenaline junkies visiting Cape Town, South Africa.

headline: Kepler Spacecraft Finds New ‘Super-Earth’ 180 Light-Years Away
abstract: The planet, about two and a half times the size of Earth, is in a category of planets called super-Earths that do not exist in our solar system.
lead_paragraph: A year and a half after a pointing failure threatened to derail its epochal search for worlds beyond our solar system, NASA’s Kepler spacecraft has bagged another planet, astronomers announced on Thursday.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: How to Deal With Holiday Issues
abstract: Holiday issues: those sexist in-laws; what music to listen to on the way and whether to confess about those nonvegan cookies.
lead_paragraph: My in-laws host their four children, spouses and grandchildren for Christmas dinner. They prepare the food, and the younger generations do the cleanup. But all the men (sons, in-laws and grandsons) retire to the television room, leaving the women to do all the cleaning. This gendered division of work makes me seethe. Can I do something about it, or should I just pull on my dish gloves in silence? Anonymous

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Dec. 19
abstract: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include scenes from the protests of police shootings, and the Santacon pub crawl.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include scenes from the protests of police shootings, and the Santacon pub crawl.

headline: Striking Oil in a Dakota Boomtown
abstract: Wanting to go beyond his usual Middle East haunts, Bryan Denton went looking for someplace exotic for his latest photo essay.
lead_paragraph: Wanting to go beyond his usual Middle East haunts, Bryan Denton went looking for someplace exotic for his latest photo essay.

headline: Psst! It’s Me, the Mannequin. This Would Look Great on You.
abstract: Retailers are experimenting with mannequins that communicate electronically with customers’ smartphones, hoping to lure them into the store.
lead_paragraph: The mannequins want to tell you something.

headline: When Regulators Are Blind to Rules
abstract: In the United States, a series of crises sent out warning signals that were not heeded.
lead_paragraph: What happens when you turn over regulatory responsibilities to people who think there is really no need for regulation?

headline: Oldest Testaments: A Close-Up View
abstract: The Crusader Bible and the Winchester Bible are vastly different handmade medieval works that will be on display this winter in museums.
lead_paragraph: They don’t make Bibles like they used to: before the Gutenberg revolution, that is, when the books were created painstakingly by hand with illustrations and ornamentation added by unidentified artists of the highest order. Two of the most celebrated examples of medieval Bibles are now on view in New York museums. At the Metropolitan Museum of Art, there’s the “Winchester Bible,” a giant tome produced in England between 1155 and 1175, and at the Morgan Library & Museum, there’s the Crusader Bible, which was made in Paris in the 1240s.

headline: Secret Service, Stretched Too Thin, Needs More Agents, Report Says
abstract: The report released by the Department of Homeland Security also said the next director should come from outside the agency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Secret Service “is stretched to and, in many cases, beyond its limits” and needs to hire 85 agents and 200 uniformed officers to sufficiently perform its mission, according to a report released on Thursday by the Department of Homeland Security.

headline: Sony’s Movie Chief Meets With Black Leaders
abstract: Amy Pascal, whose emails were disclosed by hackers, met in New York with the Rev. Al Sharpton and Marc Morial of the National Urban League.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Black leaders, angered by racially insensitive emails sent by Amy Pascal, the movie chief at Sony Pictures Entertainment, emerged from a meeting with her on Thursday saying they had reached an understanding about how to move forward.

headline: Medicaid Rolls Surge Under Affordable Care Act
abstract: The states that did not expand their programs saw increases in enrollment, and the states that did saw even more. Call it the woodwork effect.
lead_paragraph: In Idaho, the number of people who signed up for Medicaid has jumped by 13.4 percent. In Georgia, it’s up 12.9 percent. In North Carolina, the rate has climbed 12.4 percent.

headline: Mistrial Declared for Man Accused of Stalking R&B Star Ashanti
abstract: A juror’s illness, which would disrupt deliberations for more than 24 hours, forced a judge to end the trial of a fan accused of stalking the singer.
lead_paragraph: The trial of a man accused of stalking the R&B singer Ashanti ended in a mistrial on Thursday, after it became apparent that a juror’s illness would interrupt deliberations for more than 24 hours.

headline: Weekend Entertainments from the Archives of The New York Times
abstract: Say what you will about “Gone With the Wind” — and it’s all been said — it had a heck of a cast. Just one marquee name from the movie, released 75 years ago this week, survives.
lead_paragraph: 75 YEARS AGO

headline: 2014’s Noteworthy Dressers
abstract: Some key style moments this year included Lupita Nyong’o in a Prada dress at the Oscars, Amal Alamuddin in an Oscar de la Renta wedding dress and Rihanna in a see-through gown at the CFDA’s. Here are some noteworthy dressers.
lead_paragraph: Some key style moments this year included Lupita Nyong’o in a Prada dress at the Oscars, Amal Alamuddin in an Oscar de la Renta wedding dress and Rihanna in a see-through gown at the CFDA’s. Here are some noteworthy dressers.

headline: 2014’s Noteworthy Dressers
abstract: Some key style moments this year included Lupita Nyong’o in a Prada dress at the Oscars, Amal Alamuddin in an Oscar de la Renta wedding dress and Rihanna in a see-through gown at the CFDA’s. Here are some noteworthy dressers.
lead_paragraph: Some key style moments this year included Lupita Nyong’o in a Prada dress at the Oscars, Amal Alamuddin in an Oscar de la Renta wedding dress and Rihanna in a see-through gown at the CFDA’s. Here are some noteworthy dressers.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Dec. 19, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Annie,” “Winter Sleep” and “Mr. Turner.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Annie,” “Winter Sleep” and “Mr. Turner.”

headline: Xerox to Sell I.T. Outsourcing Unit to Atos for $1 Billion
abstract: The disposal is the latest move for Xerox, which has been transformed under the leadership of Ursula M. Burns into a provider of various business services.
lead_paragraph: Xerox has agreed to sell its information technology outsourcing business to Atos, the French technology company, for just over $1 billion.

headline: Degree Push for a Symbol of Injustice in Texas
abstract: The fight, this time for an honorary degree, goes on for Timothy Brian Cole, who died in prison while serving a sentence for a rape he did not commit.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Less than two months before Election Day, the Republican and Democratic candidates for governor and lieutenant governor sat together in a Lubbock park, speaking without any partisan bickering. There was only agreement that Timothy Brian Cole was worth remembering.

headline: Classical Critics Pick the Top Music Recordings of 2014
abstract: The classical music critics of The Times pick the best recordings of 2014, from orchestral explosions to intimate songs.
lead_paragraph: HERE it is: the annually anticipated choices from the classical music critics of The New York Times of the best recordings of 2014. First, though, a qualification: None of us remotely claims to have heard all the recordings of note released this past year. Still, among the ranks of music lovers, we are probably more aware than many of the range of what’s been issued. In the end, these are personal choices. The only ground rules were that we agreed not to duplicate one another’s selections, and that we would not pick more than five each.

headline: Texas Once Again to Consider a Statewide Smoking Ban
abstract: Next year, Texas lawmakers will again consider a statewide ban on smoking in public places. It will be the fifth legislative session in a row in which such a measure has been proposed.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — A decision by the Paris City Council in March to ban smoking in public places, including restaurants, angered Brent McKee. A restaurant owner, Mr. McKee was thinking about the customers who enjoyed a cigarette or two while nursing their morning coffee.

headline: Your Waitress, Your Professor
abstract: Why do we draw a line between blue-collar and white-collar work?
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — ON the first day of the fall semester, I left campus from an afternoon of teaching anxious college freshmen and headed to my second job, serving at a chain restaurant off Las Vegas Boulevard. The switch from my professional attire to a white dress shirt, black apron and tie reflected the separation I attempt to maintain between my two jobs. Naturally, sitting at the first table in my section was one of my new students, dining with her parents.

headline: Goliath Opens His Wallet
abstract: The myth of the enemy is over; the difficult reality of coexistence has begun.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — IN one of my earliest memories, I am in a schoolyard before a campfire. The kids are screaming and jumping around it while the teacher stokes the flames, where a ridiculous Uncle Sam puppet is burning. This image came to mind on Wednesday, as I listened to the speeches of Raúl Castro and Barack Obama about the re-establishment of relations between Cuba and the United States.

headline: Kraft Chief to Step Down as Company Seeks Change
abstract: The chief executive, Tony Vernon, will be succeeded by John Cahill, a former PepsiCo executive who is Kraft’s chairman.
lead_paragraph: Kraft stunned Wall Street on Thursday with the announcement that Tony Vernon, its chief executive, would step down on Dec. 27.

headline: The Texas State Tax That Consumers Are Ignoring
abstract: In 2012, the state would have had an additional $1.78 billion in revenue if it had been able to collect everything owed on online and catalog sales, including a use tax that few know about.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Don’t say this too loudly: The goods you buy online and through mail-order catalogs from out of state are not tax free. It’s just that the state has a hard time collecting the taxes that are due.

headline: The U.S. and Cuba, at a Turning Point
abstract: Readers react to President Obama’s announcement.

headline: Obama Appointment Reinforces Ties With C.I.A.
abstract: President Obama brought the deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency back to the White House to serve as one of his top national security aides.
lead_paragraph: President Obama brought the deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency back to the White House on Thursday to serve as one of his top national security aides, reinforcing the close ties between his staff and the leadership of an agency under fire for its past interrogation techniques.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around Texas this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: New York’s Ban on Fracking: Contrasting Views
abstract: Readers, including activists for and against, respond to a front-page article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Talking to Kids About Race
abstract: A reader laments that black children need to be warned about the dangers of encounters with the police.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Bocce of Kings and Queens
abstract: A Brooklyn resident writes that Queens deserves the title.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tunisia: ISIS Fighters Claim 2 Killings
abstract: Tunisian fighters with the Islamic State group have claimed responsibility in a video for the assassinations of two left-wing politicians.
lead_paragraph: Tunisian fighters with the Islamic State have claimed responsibility in a video for the assassinations of the left-wing politicians Chokri Belaid and Mohamed Brahmi last year and have threatened to carry out more assassinations before Tunisia’s presidential runoff on Sunday. Three Tunisians, dressed in black and armed with rifles, speak in the video, exhorting Tunisians to rise up and expand the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL, across North Africa from Libya to Algeria. The video was released Wednesday on social media. The Interior Ministry on Thursday confirmed that one of the men was Boubakr Hakim, the chief suspect in the two murders. Mr. Hakim says in the video, according to the SITE Monitoring Service, that Tunisians “will not live secured as long as Tunisia is not governed by Islam.”

headline: Trauma in Psychoanalysis
abstract: Dr. Stephan J. Levitan, a psychoanalyst, writes that “some patients are unable to tolerate its intensity.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Top 5 Changes on Madison Ave. Over the Last 25 Years
abstract: Much is different for advertisers, marketers and consumers, but there are similarities that a time traveler might find comforting.
lead_paragraph: FROM the early 1990s to the mid-2010s — almost a quarter-century of fundamental changes for Madison Avenue, and for those who have covered the advertising industry.

headline: The Man Who Would Be King
abstract: Capping a very busy year of performances, the British actor David Oyelowo plays what he considers the role of a lifetime: the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in “Selma.”
lead_paragraph: He gained 30 pounds. He shaved back his hairline. He traveled to corners of the South with the darkest history. But the unexpected preparation that helped David Oyelowo play the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in the film “Selma,” which opens in theaters on Christmas Day, was spending his tender years in Nigeria and Britain, far from the country that gave birth to the 1960s uprisings against the routine oppression of African-Americans.

headline: Total Immersion, One More Time
abstract: “The Bubble” (a.k.a. “Fantastic Invasion of Planet Earth”), by the 3-D pioneer Arch Oboler, comes to Blu-ray and the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: Giant wraparound screens, in-your-face 3-D, fragrant Smell-O-Vision, seat-shaking Percepto! The immersive cinema of the 1950s, intended to lure people away from the living-room TV, has made a 21st-century comeback, even (unexpectedly) in the realm of home video.

headline: Avenging the Big Lie Behind the Big Eyes
abstract: Margaret Keane and Amy Adams, who plays her in Tim Burton’s “Big Eyes,” talk about Ms. Keane’s fight for recognition as the artist behind well-known paintings of waifs.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In 1964, Margaret Keane was among the most famous living artists in the country, only no one knew it. Ms. Keane was the painter behind the big-eyed waifs that were gracing rec rooms and lounges all across America, the mother of a legion of adorable, forsaken children. Her canvases were all signed simply “Keane,” and that allowed her husband, Walter Keane, a charlatan and salesman par excellence, to take credit for the work.

headline: Where Does Moral Courage Come From?
abstract: Kailash Satyarthi, who shared the Nobel Peace Prize with Malala Yousafzai this year, turned his life’s setbacks into a mission.
lead_paragraph: Readers of Fixes know that our primary mission each week is to highlight strategies that work to effect social change and improve lives. In her column last week, Tina Rosenberg zeroed in on some of the strategies that successful efforts have in common. They are crucial, but there is also something fundamental that underlies all these efforts: the human ability to imagine that wrongs can be righted, and the belief that change can happen.

headline: Champion of the Lone Russian Everyman
abstract: “Leviathan,” from the Russian director Andrey Zvyagintsev, underscores his persistent focus on the resistance of the individual to some arbitrary exercise of authority.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, the Russian director Andrey Zvyagintsev was in Manhattan shooting a chapter of the anthology film “New York, I Love You,” when he heard the story of an auto-repair shop owner in Colorado who had demolished the town hall and a former mayor’s house with an armored bulldozer after losing a zoning dispute. From that American seed has sprung “Leviathan,” a quintessentially Russian tragedy suffused with political and religious overtones.

headline: Ford Recall of Takata Airbags to Extend Nationwide
abstract: Ford said it was expanding the recall nationwide — and globally — adding another 447,000 vehicles to the list.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Under pressure from regulators, Ford Motor is expanding nationwide the recall of vehicles with airbags manufactured by the Japanese supplier Takata, the automaker said on Thursday.

headline: Army Restores Full Benefits for Captains Being Forced Out
abstract: A change in the Army’s drawdown policy will allow 120 captains who rose from the enlisted ranks to retain their officers’ benefits in involuntary retirement.
lead_paragraph: The Army changed its drawdown policy this week, notifying captains who were being forced to retire with sergeants’ benefits that they instead would retire at their current rank.

headline: Celebrating the Legacy of a Chinese Explorer
abstract: A Malaysian town is commemorating the contributions of Zheng He, a Chinese seafarer who spread his country’s culture and architecture here in the 15th century.
lead_paragraph: MALACCA, Malaysia — When Zheng He, the seafaring eunuch explorer of the Chinese Ming dynastic court, guided boats packed with porcelain to Africa and the Arabian Peninsula, he brought giraffes back to China and founded stockades along the shipping lanes of Southeast Asia.

headline: Putin Cites Claim About U.S. Designs on Siberia Traced to Russian Mind Readers
abstract: Seeking to justify his foreign policy as essentially defensive, Russia’s president cited apocryphal remarks wrongly attributed to Madeleine Albright.
lead_paragraph: Speaking to reporters in Moscow on Thursday, Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin, claimed that economic sanctions were not primarily a response to the annexation of Crimea but part of a long-running plot by Western powers to weaken his nation and steal its natural resources.

headline: London Tenants Win Battle Against American Private Equity Firm
abstract: The private equity firm Westbrook Partners has thrown in the towel and says it will sell the New Era Estate, a London housing block whose tenants protested its plans to raise rents.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On a cold, gray morning last month, protesters, including the comedian and activist Russell Brand, gathered in front of the stylish London offices of the American private equity firm Westbrook Partners, brandishing signs that read “Westcrooks” and “Social housing not social cleansing.”

headline: Shooting Spurs Debates Over Race and Guns in a Gingerbread Town
abstract: Loose ends and questions remain months after a Muslim tourist was shot and killed in a Bavarian-themed town in Georgia.
lead_paragraph: HELEN, Ga. — The blast from Glenn Lampien’s handgun echoed through the streets of this faux Alpine town.

headline: Islamist Militants in Nigeria Kidnap 185 in a Deadly Attack on a Village
abstract: Boko Haram, the extremist group that operates widely in the volatile northeastern part of the country, is suspected of being responsible.
lead_paragraph: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — Islamist militants on Sunday killed 35 people and kidnapped about 185 others, primarily women and young girls, in a small village in northeastern Nigeria, survivors of the attack and local officials said Thursday.

headline: Hope Against Horror
abstract: What is the best way to oppose the Pakistani Taliban?

headline: Ally Financial Receives Subpoena in Subprime Auto Loan Inquiry
abstract: Ally said that it had received a Justice Department subpoena as part of an investigation “related to subprime automotive finance and related securitization activities.”
lead_paragraph: Ally Financial disclosed on Thursday that it had received a Justice Department subpoena as part of an investigation “related to subprime automotive finance and related securitization activities.”

headline: Putin’s Bubble Bursts
abstract: The global plunge in oil prices and the falling ruble have wreaked havoc on the Russian economy. It’s been quite a comedown for the strongman.
lead_paragraph: If you’re the type who finds macho posturing impressive, Vladimir Putin is your kind of guy. Sure enough, many American conservatives seem to have an embarrassing crush on the swaggering strongman. “That is what you call a leader,” enthused Rudy Giuliani, the former New York mayor, after Mr. Putin invaded Ukraine without debate or deliberation.

headline: States Execute Fewest Convicts in 20 Years, Report Finds
abstract: Executions in the United States fell to a 20-year low in 2014 as the public became more skeptical about the death penalty, according to a report released Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Executions in the United States fell to a 20-year low in 2014 as the public became more skeptical about the death penalty and several states botched the executions of condemned men, according to a report released Thursday.

headline: 2014: Rubio Criticizes Obama on Cuba
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, became a leading voice of criticism Wednesday as he denounced President Obama’s announcement of the restoration of diplomatic relations with Cuba.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, became a leading voice of criticism Wednesday as he denounced President Obama’s announcement of the restoration of diplomatic relations with Cuba.

headline: Sony Hacking Fallout Includes Unraveling of Relationships in Hollywood
abstract: The attack has disrupted the web of executive, business and talent relationships that stitches together Sony’s core moviemaking operation.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As Washington considers a response to an online attack on Sony Pictures, Hollywood is trying to repair relationships that were shattered by the assault.

headline: Millions of Fake Instagram Users Disappear in Purge
abstract: The photo and video sharing service is deleting fake and spam accounts, resulting in sharp drops in the number of followers listed for top celebrities and brands.
lead_paragraph: Social media services like Facebook and Twitter are always battling against spam or fake accounts that hijack hashtags, artificially pump up follower counts for celebrities and brands and inflate costs for advertisers that want to reach real customers, not automated bots.

headline: In a Political Gamble, Marco Rubio Sticks to His Tough Line on Cuba
abstract: Mr. Rubio, Republican of Florida and a likely presidential candidate, will find out on just which side of the polls — and history — he stands.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When a visibly angry Senator Marco Rubio of Florida emerged as the face of hard-line Republican opposition to President Obama’s new outreach to Cuba, he swept political calculations aside.

headline: Foes of Unions Try Their Luck in County Laws
abstract: An effort to get local governments to restrict unions’ authority to impose fees, long a state prerogative, is the next step in a conservative campaign to reshape American law.
lead_paragraph: BOWLING GREEN, Ky. — Conservative groups are opening a new front in their effort to reshape American law, arguing that local governments have the power to write their own rules on a key labor issue that has, up to now, been the prerogative of states.

headline: Celtics Trade Rajon Rondo to Mavericks for Three Players and Two Draft Picks
abstract: Boston dealt Rondo, a four-time All-Star and a first-round pick of the Celtics in 2006, as part of a major rebuilding project.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Already engaged in a major rebuilding project, the Boston Celtics traded their most prized asset, the four-time All-Star Rajon Rondo, to the Dallas Mavericks on Thursday for three players and two draft picks, the teams announced.

headline: For a Second Day, Fed Comments Send Stock Market Soaring
abstract: The stock market began the week burdened by geopolitical worries, but by the close of trading on Thursday it had bounced back to achieve one of its biggest upswings in recent years.
lead_paragraph: The stock market began the week burdened by geopolitical worries, but by the close of trading on Thursday it had bounced back to achieve one of its biggest upswings in recent years.

headline: Nebraska and Oklahoma Sue Colorado Over Marijuana Law
abstract: Nebraska and Oklahoma argued that marijuana has entered their states, leading to more arrests, more impounded vehicles and higher jail and court costs.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Two heartland states filed the first major court challenge to marijuana legalization on Thursday, saying that Colorado’s growing array of state-regulated recreational marijuana shops was piping marijuana into neighboring states and should be shut down.

headline: The Union Future
abstract: Do the people who have marched over the Brown and Garner cases have the stamina to force change?
lead_paragraph: Over the past decades, the case for enhancing union power has grown both stronger and weaker. On the one hand, as wages have stagnated while profits have soared, it does seem that there is something out of whack in the balance of power between labor and capital. Workers need some new way to collectively bargain for more money.

headline: Insurance Fairness for Transgender People
abstract: In a move to protect the civil rights of New Yorkers, Gov. Andrew Cuomo is making sure that gender reassignment surgery and other treatments are covered.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo advanced the cause of civil rights last week by declaring an end to a routine form of discrimination against transgender New Yorkers.

headline: Dying In, Rising Up
abstract: The protests over Eric Garner’s death have united New Yorkers. It is the head of the largest police union who divides, with his false narrative of police victimhood.
lead_paragraph: The protesters who lay down in the streets by the thousands across New York City this week, memorializing Eric Garner and calling for policing reform, showed a vivid grasp of symbolism and, despite seething anger, a commitment to peaceable dissent that lent credibility and potency to their demands.

headline: Obama Intends to Lift Several Restrictions Against Cuba on His Own
abstract: Administration officials said travel and commerce restrictions could be lifted as early as next month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will move as soon as next month to defang the 54-year-old American trade embargo against Cuba, administration officials said Thursday, using broad executive power to defy critics in Congress and lift restrictions on travel, commerce and financial activities.

headline: Sony and Mr. Kim’s Thugs
abstract: The decision to cancel the release of a movie in response to threats by North Korean hackers could embolden rogue regimes and criminals.
lead_paragraph: Sony Pictures pulled the movie “The Interview” after large theater chains said they would not show it, fearing threats of violence to their customers and employees by hackers believed to be working for the North Korean government. Though the companies are understandably cautious, this decision will establish a dangerous precedent that could further embolden rogue regimes and criminals.

headline: Focusing on Future, Cuba Leaves Fidel Castro to History
abstract: A venerable figure to generations of Cubans is fading from daily conversation as his more pragmatic brother, Raúl, reshapes the nation.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — The college students of a surprised Cuba sang karaoke on Thursday afternoon beside a dark green tank memorializing the Cuban revolution. They played dominoes in the shade of the University of Havana law school, where Fidel Castro found his footing as a leader with a pistol at his side.

headline: FIFA Investigator Michael J. Garcia’s Resignation Ended an Uneasy Marriage
abstract: Michael J. Garcia’s blistering resignation letter showed the difficulty of his task as FIFA’s independent ethics investigator.
lead_paragraph: Michael J. Garcia and FIFA were an odd match from the start, and their relationship always seemed destined for an ugly breakup.

headline: A Diplomatic Triumph in Cuba Comes With a Challenge in North Korea
abstract: Cuba and North Korea are posing opposite challenges for the Obama administration — with Havana experimenting with integration, and Pyongyang brandishing a new weapon.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than five decades, the United States has found itself in periodic confrontation with two Communist nations that have survived on a diet of anti-Americanism, and defied the overwhelming odds that they would have collapsed years ago.

headline: New Mexico and Linda Singer
abstract: Open records requests from across the United States turned up dozens, and in some cases hundreds, of pages of emails and other documents from Ms. Singer, as she pitched attorneys general on a wide array of possible cases, most of which they never pursued.
lead_paragraph: Open records requests from across the United States turned up dozens, and in some cases hundreds, of pages of emails and other documents from Ms. Singer, as she pitched attorneys general on a wide array of possible cases, most of which they never pursued.

headline: New York and Linda Singer
abstract: Much of the work Ms. Singer does relates to pitches that are not successful. Here are 71 pages’ worth of emails as Ms. Singer tries to get New York State to hire her, offering a long list of lawsuits and investigations she could handle. But at least so far, she has not secured a contract with New York State, Ms. Singer said.
lead_paragraph: Much of the work Ms. Singer does relates to pitches that are not successful. Here are 71 pages’ worth of emails as Ms. Singer tries to get New York State to hire her, offering a long list of lawsuits and investigations she could handle. But at least so far, she has not secured a contract with New York State, Ms. Singer said.

headline: Mississippi and Contingency-Fee Contracts
abstract: No state rivals Mississippi when it comes to contingency-fee contracts.
lead_paragraph: No state rivals Mississippi when it comes to contingency-fee contracts.

headline: Plaintiffs’ Lawyers Enlist Attorneys General For Help
abstract: Patrick C. Lynch, a former attorney general of Rhode Island, was hired by three plaintiffs’ firms to recruit state attorneys general to urge the United States Supreme Court not to put new limits on securities fraud litigation, which the contingency firms often handle for state attorneys general.
lead_paragraph: Patrick C. Lynch, a former attorney general of Rhode Island, was hired by three plaintiffs’ firms to recruit state attorneys general to urge the United States Supreme Court not to put new limits on securities fraud litigation, which the contingency firms often handle for state attorneys general.

headline: Louisiana and the Fight Over Outside Lawyers
abstract: Nowhere has the battle been more intense over the last year than in Louisiana, where groups aligned with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and major pharmaceutical companies and the business community teamed up to push the State Legislature to crack down on the hiring of outside lawyers by the attorney general.
lead_paragraph: Nowhere has the battle been more intense over the last year than in Louisiana, where groups aligned with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and major pharmaceutical companies and the business community teamed up to push the State Legislature to crack down on the hiring of outside lawyers by the attorney general.

headline: Former Attorneys Generals at Work
abstract: At least nine former attorneys general, in recent years, have worked with law firms seeking to serve attorneys general on a contingency basis. Some serve as lawyers at these firms, actually litigating cases, and others are simply hired to make introductions. Either way, it can be lucrative work.
lead_paragraph: At least nine former attorneys general, in recent years, have worked with law firms seeking to serve attorneys general on a contingency basis. Some serve as lawyers at these firms, actually litigating cases, and others are simply hired to make introductions. Either way, it can be lucrative work.

headline: An Alliance That Enriches All Sides: Plaintiffs’ Lawyers and Attorneys General
abstract: Documents from more than a dozen states offer an inside look at the multibillion-dollar industry that has emerged as plaintiffs’ lawyers team up with state attorneys general ​to sue corporations.
lead_paragraph: Documents from more than a dozen states offer an inside look at the multibillion-dollar industry that has emerged as plaintiffs’ lawyers team up with state attorneys general ​to sue corporations.

headline: Big Eyes, Big Lies
abstract: The artist Margaret Keane surprised the cast of “Big Eyes” — and herself — by showing up at the premiere of the new movie based on her stranger-than-fiction life.
lead_paragraph: The artist Margaret Keane surprised the cast of “Big Eyes” — and herself — by showing up at the premiere of the new movie based on her stranger-than-fiction life.

headline: Political Gifts from Plaintiffs’ Lawyers
abstract: How much plaintiffs’ law firms have contributed to benefit state attorneys general.
lead_paragraph: How much plaintiffs’ law firms have contributed to benefit state attorneys general.

headline: Lawyers Create Big Paydays by Coaxing Attorneys General to Sue
abstract: A flourishing industry pairs plaintiffs’ lawyers with attorneys general to sue companies, setting off a furious competition among trial lawyers and lobbyists to influence these officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When they met at the J. W. Marriott Hotel two blocks from the White House, Linda Singer, a former attorney general turned plaintiffs’ lawyer, approached Attorney General Gary King of New Mexico with an unusual proposition.

headline: Correction Officers’ Union Flexes Its Muscles in Albany
abstract: The union representing guards on Rikers Island got a bill passed in Albany that would put the Queens district attorney in charge of crimes committed at the jail.
lead_paragraph: Unhappy with the district attorney in the Bronx, the union representing correction officers on Rikers Island got a bill passed in Albany that would put the Queens district attorney in charge of crimes committed at the jail.

headline: Ernie Terrell, Heavyweight Champion, Dies at 75; Lost Grudge Match to Ali
abstract: In 55 bouts, Terrell had 21 knockouts and a record of 46-9. He briefly shared the heavyweight championship with Muhammad Ali.
lead_paragraph: Ernie Terrell, who briefly shared the heavyweight championship with the fighter then widely known as Cassius Clay and who later, after refusing to acknowledge that Clay had taken the Muslim name Muhammad Ali, was battered by him in a 15-round grudge match, died on Tuesday in Chicago. He was 75.

headline: Arizona: Phoenix Police Chief Fired for Insubordination
abstract: The police chief of Phoenix was fired for insubordination on Thursday after he held a forbidden news conference demanding a new two-year contract.
lead_paragraph: The police chief of Phoenix was fired for insubordination on Thursday after he held a forbidden news conference demanding a new two-year contract. Chief Daniel V. Garcia was terminated by the city manager, Ed Zuercher, for disobeying an order not to give a statement. Mr. Garcia was Phoenix’s police chief for two and a half years, after serving 33 years in Dallas. His overall performance and handling of a recent fatal police shooting of an unarmed man had been criticized by the local police union, a city councilman, and city residents. He was immediately replaced by Joseph Yahner, a veteran who will serve as acting chief.

headline: Uber Suspends Portland Operations in Deal With City Regulators
abstract: Uber agreed to a three-month hiatus while lawmakers create a regulatory framework under which the company can operate.
lead_paragraph: Uber, the popular ride-hailing service, regularly spars with regulators. But on Thursday, the company seems to have found common ground with lawmakers in at least one city.

headline: Cuomo Signals Changes for Education Next Year
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s goals include making it easier to fire low-performing teachers and increasing the number of charter schools.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signaled on Thursday that he intended to push next year for sweeping changes to the state’s education system, with goals that include making it easier to fire low-performing teachers and increasing the number of charter schools.

headline: There’s the Rub
abstract: Gird your loins. Brad Wilber and Doug Peterson are back.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — The constructing duo of Brad Wilber and Doug Peterson is back, and boy, is this a tough one.

headline: Hotelier Avoids Prison for Violating Campaign Finance Laws
abstract: In sentencing Sant Singh Chatwal, a Democratic fund-raiser, to three years’ probation against prosecutors’ wishes, Judge I. Leo Glasser described his crimes as an “aberrance.”
lead_paragraph: A Democratic fund-raiser and high-profile hotelier, Sant Singh Chatwal, who had pleaded guilty to skirting federal campaign-finance laws and witness tampering, avoided being sent to prison on Thursday, despite facing a possible sentence of more than five years.

headline: Left Homeless After a Gas Explosion in East Harlem That Killed 8
abstract: The Children’s Aid Society used Neediest Cases money to help several families displaced in March by the East Harlem blast that killed eight people,
lead_paragraph: One moment, Legah Kokouet was in bed, her newborn daughter asleep in her crib. The next moment, she was on the ground.

headline: Liberia Will Proceed With Senate Vote Delayed by Ebola
abstract: An election repeatedly delayed because of the epidemic and other challenges will be held on Saturday, but critics worry whether voting will fair and safe.
lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — Senate elections that were repeatedly delayed because of the Ebola epidemic and legal challenges, and further complicated by a presidential ban on large political gatherings in the capital, will finally be held in Liberia on Saturday. Whether they will be fair, peaceful and safe is unclear.

headline: Cuba Thaw Lets Rest of Latin America Warm to Washington
abstract: Leaders who have consistently lambasted the United States and President Obama abruptly changed course, praising the policy shift on Cuba.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — President Obama has been lambasted for spying in Brazil, accused of being a warmonger by Bolivia, dismissed as a “lost opportunity” by Argentina, and taunted in Nicaragua by calls for Latin America to draw up its own list of state sponsors of terrorism — with the United States in the No. 1 spot.

headline: Rap Artist Bobby Shmurda Is Arraigned on Violent Crime Counts
abstract: The rapper, whose given name is Ackquille Pollard, and a dozen other alleged members of the GS9 group are accused of operating a violent street gang linked to a murder and several shootings.
lead_paragraph: When Bobby Shmurda and his group GS9 took the stage for Power 105’s annual concert at the Barclays Center in late October, it was an important moment for the promising rap artist from Brooklyn. And critics said he carried it off, performing his smash hit “Hot Boy” with a hard, muscular style, as tough as asphalt.

headline: Shock in Southern Tier of New York as Hopes of Gambling and Fracking Both Die
abstract: Hopes in the Binghamton area for an economic revival led by hydraulic fracturing and a luxury casino were dashed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.
lead_paragraph: BINGHAMTON, N.Y. — To get a sense of the deep disappointment felt by many here at the twin killings of two potentially lucrative dreams, hydraulic fracturing and a new luxury casino, one needed to look no further than the front-page headline of Thursday’s edition of The Press & Sun-Bulletin.

headline: De Blasio Reluctantly Supports ‘Taxi of Tomorrow’
abstract: New York City officials said a revised agreement with Nissan included several notable changes, suggesting the contract was no longer the “exclusive” agreement its critics had long denounced.
lead_paragraph: A revamped plan for a nearly uniform fleet of New York City yellow taxis will go forward, city officials said on Thursday — casting Mayor Bill de Blasio as a reluctant cheerleader for a vehicle he has long criticized.

headline: For Knicks, Futile Start Is Factor in Deciding Whether to Play Through Pain
abstract: With a 5-22 record, and injuries to Carmelo Anthony, J.R. Smith, Iman Shumpert and others, Amar’e Stoudemire chose to pass on a planned day of rest.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — An ugly confluence of injuries and defeats has squeezed the Knicks and their players into an awkward situation.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 18, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: U.S. Government Court Filings in Rikers Case
abstract: The federal government indicated in a court filing on Thursday that it planned to sue New York City over widespread civil rights violations in the treatment of adolescent inmates at Rikers Island. Instead of filing a separate lawsuit, the government asked to join an existing class-action lawsuit over brutality at the jail complex.
lead_paragraph: The federal government indicated in a court filing on Thursday that it planned to sue New York City over widespread civil rights violations in the treatment of adolescent inmates at Rikers Island. Instead of filing a separate lawsuit, the government asked to join an existing class-action lawsuit over brutality at the jail complex.

headline: Connecticut Offers Test, but Duke Stays Unbeaten
abstract: With a victory over UConn, Duke improved its record at Izod Center to 21-1.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — For more than two decades, Izod Center played host to some of college basketball’s biggest games. The N.C.A.A. tournament regionals were held here 11 times, and the 1996 Final Four was, as well. But the tournament has not been back since 2007.

headline: Lee W. Wattenberg, Who Saw Cancer Fighters in Foods, Dies at 92
abstract: Dr. Wattenberg, a University of Minnesota researcher hailed as the “father of chemoprevention,” found weapons in chemical compounds in broccoli, cabbage, coffee and garlic.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Lee W. Wattenberg, a medical researcher who helped jump-start the field of cancer prevention, finding weapons in the food people eat — including chemical compounds in broccoli, cabbage, coffee and garlic — died on Dec. 9 in Minneapolis. He was 92.

headline: Darlene Love’s Last ‘Letterman’ Christmas
abstract: The rock, soul and gospel singer is bringing to an end a television holiday tradition that has lasted for nearly 30 years.
lead_paragraph: Darlene Love would like it known that she is available at the holiday season to perform “Christmas (Baby Please Come Home),” under certain conditions.

headline: Virna Lisi, Italian Actress Lured to Hollywood, Dies at 78
abstract: Ms. Lisi, an Italian who had her breakthrough Hollywood role in “How to Murder Your Wife” in 1965, had an award-winning revival in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Virna Lisi, who first captivated Italian moviegoers with her smoldering eyes, sulky smile and stunning beauty before sweeping into Hollywood in the 1960s to star opposite such leading men as Frank Sinatra and Tony Curtis, died on Wednesday. She was 78.

headline: With Families Refusing to Return, ‘Naked’ Officials Are Demoted
abstract: The series of demotions represents a new phase in the Communist Party’s campaign against “naked officials,” those who have sent their families to live overseas.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese government has demoted 1,000 senior officials with a spouse or child living abroad after those relatives refused to return to China. The move is the latest effort by the Communist Party to clamp down on the international dimensions of graft.

headline: Word of the Day | metaphysical
abstract: This word has appeared in 108 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: metaphysical •\ˌme-tə-ˈfi-zi-kəl\• adjective

headline: A Centennial for Asian Art at the Met
abstract: The Met’s department of Asian art, once tiny, is celebrating 100 years with 17 exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: Maxwell K. Hearn remembers when he first arrived at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1971. “There were only two spaces for Asian art: the Great Hall Balcony, which housed Chinese ceramics, and an adjacent gallery of Chinese Buddhist art,” he recalled. “Douglas Dillon, then chairman, and Thomas Hoving, the director, surveyed the museum and realized that Asian art was the weakest department. They also recognized that it was too important an area to neglect.”

headline: Bulls, Without Derrick Rose, Edge Knicks, Without Carmelo Anthony
abstract: Anthony sat out with pain in his left knee, and the Bulls, playing without an ill Rose, prevailed at home as the battered Knicks fell to 5-23.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — An ugly confluence of injuries and defeats has squeezed the Knicks into an awkward situation. On one hand, there is the long, growing list of players who could use a few days rest to heal their aching bodies. On the other, there is the dwindling amount of time left to keep the club’s ailing season from taking a turn for the worse.

headline: Raising Ambitions: The Challenge in Teaching at Community Colleges
abstract: Two-year colleges enroll nearly half of all undergraduates in the United States. How to better educate them is critical to increasing economic mobility.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Eduardo Vianna, a professor at LaGuardia Community College in Queens, had a student who passed an entire semester without speaking in class. Like many others, the student, Mike Rifino, had come to LaGuardia requiring remedial instruction.

headline: What U.S. Companies Can Expect in Cuba
abstract: Many American companies are eager to enter Cuba, but they will face big obstacles to succeeding in the market.
lead_paragraph: Many American companies are eager to enter Cuba, but they will face big obstacles to succeeding in the market.

headline: Photos: He Rarely Missed a Shot
abstract: Barton Silverman, an esteemed sports photographer, is retiring from The New York Times after a five-decade career capturing “the peak of action.”
lead_paragraph: You’ve noticed his photo credit line for years — BARTON SILVERMAN/THE NEW YORK TIMES — but he is retiring at 72 after a five-decade career of capturing what he called “the peak of action” at sports events.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8:35 A.M. (TMC) SECRETS & LIES (1996) Hortense (Marianne Jean-Baptiste), a black London optometrist who was adopted as an infant, discovers that her birth mother, Cynthia (Brenda Blethyn), is a white lower-class factory worker with a dysfunctional family in this Mike Leigh drama. Timothy Spall (currently starring in Mr. Leigh’s “Mr. Turner”), Phyllis Logan (Mrs. Hughes on “Downton Abbey”) and Claire Rushbrook play Cynthia’s brother, sister-in-law and daughter, who have secrets of their own. “In a performance that lurches thrillingly from grief to comedy to compassion, never losing its tart humor, her Cynthia rises up from the sodden mess of her life to face regret over the past and uncharacteristic hope for the future,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times about Ms. Blethyn, who along with Ms. Jean-Baptiste and Mr. Leigh received Oscar nominations. “Soap opera?” Ms. Maslin asked. “Never. Mr. Leigh’s wry and magnanimous intelligence keeps ‘Secrets & Lies’ determinedly unsentimental, helped immeasurably by Cynthia’s fine, tough resilience and idiomatic verve.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, December 19, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “You have to ask yourself, ‘To what end?'”

headline: Corrections: December 19, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, December 19, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: In Harlem, Renaissance Theater Is at the Crossroads of Demolition and Preservation
abstract: Over the objections of some preservationists, an apartment tower is planned for the site of the Renaissance Theater and Casino, once a hot spot for sports and cultural events.
lead_paragraph: The Renaissance Theater and Casino in Harlem has been vacant for more than 30 years. The doors and arched Palladian windows are covered in warped sheets of wood. The tapestry brick on the squat, blocklong two-story building is loose, and many of the mosaic tiles inspired by architecture in North Africa have fallen away. Tree branches pierce the roof.

headline: South Korea Disbands Party Sympathetic to North
abstract: The court ruling against the United Progressive Party marked a political victory for President Park Geun-hye, who had sought to have the party dissolved.
lead_paragraph: In the first verdict of its kind, the Constitutional Court of South Korea on Friday ordered the dissolution of a small leftist party accused of supporting North Korea at the cost of the South’s national security and in violation of its Constitution.

headline: China G.D.P. Is Revised 3.4% Higher For Last Year
abstract: The National Bureau of Statistics said the revision was mainly because of better measurement of the size of the service sector after a recent economic census.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — China said on Friday that the size of its economy in 2013 was about 3.4 percent larger than previously reported and that gross domestic product reached $9.6 trillion, according to the National Bureau of Statistics.

headline: 8 Children Found Dead Near Cairns, Australia
abstract: Their bodies were discovered in Manoora, a suburb of Cairns, and a woman believed to be the mother of seven of the children was arrested after being treated for stab wounds.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The police have arrested a 37-year-old woman following the deaths of eight children in a house in a suburb of Cairns, Australia, on Friday.

headline: Under Xi, China’s Wave of ‘Weird Architecture’ May Have Peaked
abstract: Ever since President Xi Jinping issued his admonishment against the rise of outlandish and exorbitant buildings across China, government officials, planners and architects have been scrambling to figure out what it means for them.
lead_paragraph: It’s the newest dreamscape in a country clotted with them. When it opens in two years on Beijing’s east side, Chaoyang Park Plaza, a ring of glass towers molded like mountains in a classic Chinese landscape painting and designed by the renowned architect Ma Yansong, will feature apartments, offices and shops.

headline: Chinese Investors Raise Their Bid for Club Med
abstract: Fosun International raised its bid for the resort operator just hours before the expiration of a Friday deadline set by the French market regulator.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Chinese conglomerate Fosun International raised its bid for the resort operator Club Méditerranée just hours before the expiration of a Friday deadline set by the French market regulator, thus ensuring that the battle for will continue into the new year.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Riches to Rags for New York Teenager Who Now Says His Story Is Hoax
abstract: What lessons should be learned from this incident?
lead_paragraph: In “Riches to Rags for New York Teenager Who Now Says His Story Is Hoax,” Kate Taylor and Ravi Somaiya report on a $72 million tale.

headline: Test Yourself | A Makeover for Archie and the Gang
abstract: Here are several paragraphs from a Dec. 14 article, “As Archie Nears 75, Riverdale Gets a Youthful Infusion.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are several paragraphs from a Dec. 14 article, “As Archie Nears 75, Riverdale Gets a Youthful Infusion.”

headline: Was Sony Right to Cancel ‘The Interview’ After Receiving a Threat Against Theaters?
abstract: Many in Hollywood expressed dismay that hackers could force a studio to cancel a movie. Does Sony’s decision threaten First Amendment freedoms?
lead_paragraph: Sony Pictures announced this week that it was canceling its Christmas Day release of the action-comedy film “The Interview,” starring Seth Rogen and James Franco, which includes a scene depicting the leader of North Korea getting assassinated. The studio took the unusual step after hackers delivered vague but menacing threats against movie theaters. North Koreans have called the movie an “act of war.”

headline: Striking Oil in a Dakota Boomtown
abstract: Wanting to go beyond his usual Middle East haunts, Bryan Denton went looking for someplace exotic for his latest photo essay.
lead_paragraph: Bryan Denton considers himself “somewhat of an immigrant” in the Middle East, where he has spent pretty much his entire photographic career. He feels comfortable covering conflict — much of his work in the region looks at how violence changes cultures and societies.

headline: Rating Plan Would Put Colleges Into One of Three Categories
abstract: A report offers the first glimpse into the Obama administration’s plan to grade colleges, placing them into three categories of performance.
lead_paragraph: In a report released Friday, the Obama administration offered its first public glimpse of a planned system for rating how well colleges perform, saying it wanted to group schools into three broad categories — good, bad and somewhere between.

headline: The Irish Rebellion Over Water
abstract: After putting up with years of austerity, people finally lost their patience.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — In the west of Ireland, they say that if you can see the mountain, it’s going to rain. And if you can’t see the mountain? It’s raining.

headline: New York Voters Oppose Raise for State Legislators, Poll Finds
abstract: Only 28 percent of voters who responded to a Siena College survey supported higher pay for state lawmakers, compared with 63 percent who opposed it.
lead_paragraph: As members of the State Legislature lobby Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to agree to raise their salaries, a poll released on Friday found that voters overwhelmingly oppose the idea.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: Your Last Minute
abstract: Friday: Send us your holiday-prep photos. Also: partly sunny skies and a precedent-setting tenant case.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this cloudy but brightening Friday.

headline: Ex-City Official and Property Tycoon Are Convicted in Hong Kong Graft Trial
abstract: The trial suggested the cozy ties between the city’s business elite and career officials who rose through the ranks of the British colonial government.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The highest-level corruption trial in Hong Kong’s history ended on Friday with the convictions of a man who was once the city’s second-highest official and a billionaire property tycoon charged with bribing him.

headline: Resolve Hardened by Massacre at School, Pakistani Forces Kill Dozens of Militants
abstract: Pakistani forces stepped up operations against insurgents near the Afghan border after 148 students and staff members died in a siege in Peshawar.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Military action against the Pakistani Taliban intensified on both sides of the border with Afghanistan on Friday, officials said, in a reflection of hardening resolve to fight the group after it carried out the school massacre in Peshawar this week.

headline: New Software Helps Connect the Money Dots in Politics
abstract: The Upshot announces the debut of Bedfellows, a project to shed light on the links between donors and recipients.
lead_paragraph: Consider this a last-minute holiday present for the campaign finance enthusiast on your list. Today The Upshot is releasing a piece of software that helps define the relationships between federal political action committee donors and their recipients.

headline: Putin Critic in Graft Trial Could Face 10-Year Sentence
abstract: Aleksei A. Navalny, a prominent opposition figure, and his brother, Oleg, were accused of stealing almost $500,000 from two firms.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Prosecutors on Friday said they would seek a 10-year prison sentence for Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s most prominent critic of President Vladimir V. Putin, on embezzlement charges that critics say are intended to crush the opposition.

headline: Week 16 N.F.L. Matchups
abstract: Allowing an average of 101 yards a game on the ground, good for seventh in the N.F.L., the Redskins smothered LeSean McCoy, Philadelphia’s star running back, limiting him to 22 yards on 19 carries in Week 3.
lead_paragraph: Eagles (9-5) at Redskins (3-11)

headline: Intel Betting on (Customized) Commodity Chips for Cloud Computing
abstract: Next year, half of the chips Intel sells to cloud businesses will be custom. The company is used to selling tens of millions of the same thing, but outfits like Google and Facebook need special features, and pay for them.
lead_paragraph: Cheap, mass-produced semiconductors have transformed our world, with smartphones, laptops, sensors and tablets, all connected to big cloud computing systems.

headline: How One Technology Company Managed to Hire a More Diverse Work Force
abstract: Step 1: Think about gender diversity early in your company’s formation. If you wait until the company is established, it’s too late.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to hiring, Silicon Valley has long been a bastion for white and Asian men. In fact, at several of the world’s most well-known tech companies, including Google, Apple, Yahoo and Facebook, women account for fewer than one in five tech jobs. Several of those companies have said they are serious about improving the gender makeup of their work forces and for good reason — research shows that companies with more diverse teams tend to perform better financially.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: President Obama will hold a news conference before leaving on Friday for a two-week vacation in Hawaii, and much of the questioning will likely center on plans to renew ties with Cuba.
lead_paragraph: Holiday Break From Policy Fights and Partisan Bickering. (We Think.)

headline: On Cuba
abstract: The United States will restore full diplomatic relations with Cuba.
lead_paragraph: The United States will restore full diplomatic relations with Cuba.

headline: European Regulator Issues New Guidelines for Online Payments
abstract: The European Banking Authority is requiring payment processors to put in place stronger authentication to verify the identities of those buying goods and services online.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A European banking regulator said on Friday that online payment processors must put in place tighter security protocols by next summer to help cut down on fraudulent payments in Europe.

headline: Scientist Who Had Claimed Stem Cell Breakthrough Resigns From Japanese Research Institute
abstract: The institute said the researcher had failed in the three months it gave her to replicate what she had portrayed as a simple way to make stem cells.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In a blow to the prestige of Japan’s scientific community, a government-backed research institute accepted the resignation of one of its highest-profile scientists on Friday after she failed to replicate research results that were once hailed as a breakthrough in stem cell research.

headline: Student Crossword | Winter Weather
abstract: Test your knowledge of winter weather by playing our crossword.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of winter weather by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: 1914: Scandinavian Alliance Formed
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Three Scandinavian countries concluded an alliance in 1914.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — The conference of the three Scandinavian Kings at Malmo, Sweden, is the all-absorbing subject of interest here, and it is reported to-night [Dec. 19] that, as a result of the Royal meeting, Sweden, Norway, and Denmark will perfect a minor triplice and that united action will be taken on all questions that affect the national welfare of any one or all of the three kingdoms.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: BlackBerry Narrows Loss, But Its Revenue Declines
abstract: The company reported a drop in third-quarter revenue to $793 million, despite the introduction of a heavily publicized phone.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — BlackBerry’s chief executive, John S. Chen, thinks people who have been waiting for the demise of his troubled company can stand down.

headline: Thai Union Frozen to Buy Bumble Bee for $1.5 Billion
abstract: The deal will add the largest canned seafood producer in North America to a portfolio of brands that already includes Chicken of the Sea.
lead_paragraph: The world’s largest canned seafood company is getting even bigger.

headline: Varmints on Ellis Island
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: An Ellis Island tour guide recounted the interest shown by four Texas women who had seen traces of the native wildlife.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Mandy Rice-Davies, Figure in Profumo Scandal, Dies at 70
abstract: Ms. Rice-Davies achieved notoriety in 1963 in one of Britain’s most spectacular sex scandals, which brought down a government minister.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Mandy Rice-Davies, a former nightclub dancer and model who achieved notoriety in 1963 in one of Britain’s  most spectacular Cold War sex scandals, died on Thursday. She was 70.

headline: Even for the Person Who Has Everything, Gifts Matter
abstract: Some research says the cost of a physical gift makes a difference, while other research shows experiences, not always extravagant, are better.
lead_paragraph: R. COURI HAY, a society figure in Manhattan, is not one to think small when it comes to holiday presents.

headline: Video: An Artist Finally Gets Her Due in ‘Big Eyes’
abstract: Margaret Keane’s waif paintings were all the rage in the 1960s and ’70s, but few knew that she and not Walter Keane was the artist behind them.
lead_paragraph: In the new movie “Big Eyes,” Amy Adams plays Margaret Keane, the real-life artist whose ex-husband, played by Cristoph Waltz, took credit for her wildly popular paintings of giant-eyed children in the 1960s and ’70s.

headline: The Daily Gift: Felt Pouches for Odds and Ends
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: A Champion at 20. A Graduate at 74.
abstract: Bobby Bell, who overcame segregation and helped the University of Minnesota and the Kansas City Chiefs win championships, is completing his degree to honor his father.
lead_paragraph: Bobby Bell won a national championship at the University of Minnesota and a Super Bowl title as a Kansas City Chief. He is a member of the College Football and Pro Football Halls of Fame, but last week he achieved something that was even more important to him.

headline: As Colbert Moves On, ‘Colbert’ Ends
abstract: The final episode of “The Colbert Report” was a reminder of what an anomaly that late-night comedy series really was.
lead_paragraph: A studio filled with an incongruous group of celebrity guests — Mayor Bill de Blasio, Big Bird, Ambassador Samantha Power, Yo-Yo Ma, Gen. Ray Odierno, Cyndi Lauper — singing “We’ll Meet Again” was a little weird, but so were the commercials that bracketed the occasion: ads for scotch, beer and dating services called Asiandate.com and Anastasiadate.com.

headline: Daily Report: U.S. Weighs Response to Sony Cyberattack, With North Korea Confrontation Possible
abstract: White House officials said the hacking episode had become a major concern at the upper levels of government, including President Obama.
lead_paragraph: A White House official said on Thursday that the administration was considering a “proportional response” against those who hacked into Sony Pictures computers, a retaliation that could thrust the United States into a direct confrontation with North Korea, Peter Baker reports.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Annie,’ ‘Winter Sleep’ and ‘Mr. Turner’
abstract: Times critics review “Annie,” “Winter Sleep” and “Mr. Turner.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Annie,” “Winter Sleep” and “Mr. Turner.”

headline: Selling the Family Home Is Liberating for Many Retirees
abstract: By putting on the market a house where they have lived for many years, retirees can free up money for travel or to finance a mortgage-free lifestyle.
lead_paragraph: WHEN is a house your safe haven and when is it standing in the way of richer life experiences?

headline: FIFA Agrees to Release Redacted Ethics Report
abstract: Sepp Blatter, the president of the world governing body of soccer, said the findings by an ethics committee would be edited to protect privacy and investigations.
lead_paragraph: FIFA said on Friday that it would release a redacted version of the 430-page report compiled by Michael J. Garcia, the former chief investigator for the governing body of soccer’s ethics committee, who spent more than a year digging into allegations of corruption in the World Cup bidding process.

headline: How School Segregation Divides Ferguson — and the United States
abstract: Education in St. Louis is separate and unequal.
lead_paragraph: ON Aug. 1, five students in satiny green-and-red robes and mortarboards waited in an elementary school classroom to hear their names called as graduates of Normandy High School. This ceremony, held months after the official graduation, was mostly for students who had been short of credits in May.

headline: T’s Top 10 Videos of 2014
abstract: These 10 videos explore the passions, homes and backstories of utterly fascinating subjects.
lead_paragraph: These 10 videos explore the passions, homes and backstories of utterly fascinating subjects. More…

headline: Oh the Humiliation! Oh the Film Glory!
abstract: In “Force Majeure,” Sweden’s Oscar entry, a scene in which a young woman tells the protagonist that he actually isn’t that attractive was taken from the director’s life.
lead_paragraph: The crumbling of the male ego after an act of cowardice is the idea underpinning “Force Majeure,” a critical hit at the Toronto International Film Festival, and a Golden Globe nominee as well as Sweden’s official entry for the foreign language Oscar.

headline: H.M.O.s Offer Lower Prices in Health Care Marketplaces
abstract: Plans that limit a patient’s choice of where to go to seek care are not without controversy, but they are making a comeback.
lead_paragraph: Health insurers are selling more than 100,000 plans at a county level through the Affordable Care Act’s marketplaces, at radically different prices and varied designs. The carriers range from established local Blue Cross plans and national for-profit behemoths to upstarts like local hospital systems and the new consumer-oriented co-ops that were created under the federal law.

headline: Australian Detective on Stabbing Deaths
abstract: Bruno Asnicar, the detective inspector of the Queensland state police, discussed the stabbing deaths of eight children in the northern Australian city of Cairns.
lead_paragraph: Bruno Asnicar, the detective inspector of the Queensland state police, discussed the stabbing deaths of eight children in the northern Australian city of Cairns.

headline: A Sausage Roll Recipe for Boxing Day
abstract: In Britain, sausage rolls make an appearance on Christmas Eve, on Christmas Day or on Dec. 26, Boxing Day.
lead_paragraph: Though the concept of savory chopped meat wrapped in dough exists in every cuisine, in one way or another — fried, baked or boiled — the British have proudly claimed sausage rolls as their own. Or so says my friend Caroline, an expat Briton who considers herself an expert in such things. (I am always asking her for the English point of view, and she is not shy.)

headline: How To Survive The Movie Apocalypse
abstract: To save your memories, sometimes it’s better just not to watch.
lead_paragraph: Consider this a supplement to yesterday’s piece on how the current fiasco surrounding “The Interview” will reinforce all of Hollywood’s worst contemporary instincts. (For once, George Clooney and I are on exactly the same page.) I’ve been reading reviews this week of “The Hobbit: The Battle of Five Armies,” the finale to a bloated trilogy that never should have been, and a number of them have done a good job discussing the differences between Peter Jackson’s choices in his “Lord of the Rings” adaptations and the choices he’s made while cashing in on and corrupting the real Tolkien trilogy’s slighter predecessor. (Sonny Bunch’s close-read of the final, blessedly CGI-free battle sequence in “The Fellowship of the Ring” is particularly good.) But I was struck by this depressing point in Chris Orr’s review of “Five Armies,” because it has relevance for a much wider range of contemporary movies:

headline: Sneak Peek at the Next Big Fashion Show (Hint: Vanessa Hudgens Is in It)
abstract: A revamped version of “Gigi,” starring Vanessa Hudgens, will have its premiere at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.
lead_paragraph: O.K., that title is a bit misleading, I admit it.

headline: Reply All: The 12.7.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: FRANCIUM KILLED MY GREAT-GREAT AUNT

headline: A Boy Named Dana
abstract: Applicant ambiguity; bidding peace; window undressing.
lead_paragraph: I have applied over email for internships with several high-tech companies in the Bay Area, and I suspect I have benefited from my potential employers’ incorrectly assuming that I am a woman. Many of these companies actively seek female applicants to balance out the field’s male dominance. Nowhere on my résumé do I state my gender, as that’s not typically done. Do I have an ethical obligation to mention my gender in the email? By refraining from doing so, am I taking advantage of a policy designed to counter social and institutional discrimination against women? Am I receiving some form of cosmic payback for having been given a woman’s name? DANA, CALIFORNIA

headline: Jane Pratt on Why Writing for Young Women Never Gets Old
abstract: The women’s-magazine editor on the Internet, feminism and reading the comments.
lead_paragraph: The editor talks with Susan Dominus about navigating the pitfalls of online publishing.

headline: Praying for Common Ground at the Christmas-Dinner Table
abstract: A born-again Christian, a practicing Muslim and a militant atheist walk into a dining room.
lead_paragraph: The prayer is what tripped us up. It was the first Christmas that my wife and I hosted in our home, and for a good 10 minutes, our two families stood around the dinner table arguing about how to thank God for the meal we were about to eat.

headline: Citigroup Says Instagram Is Worth $35 Billion
abstract: Facebook’s $1 billion acquisition of the photo-sharing app now looks like quite the bargain, according to a new analysis.
lead_paragraph: When Facebook bought Instagram for $1 billion in 2012, critics of the social network said the deal was another sign of Silicon Valley overreach.

headline: Secret Cabals of the Elite
abstract: Henry Kissinger meets Big Bird.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to mock conspiracy theorists who imagine that everything important in the world is determined by secret cabals — the Trilateral Commission, alumni of Skull and Bones, whatever (which is not to discount the influence of old-boy networks). Even non-crazy people, however, tend to imagine that people whose names they recognize form much more of a cohesive social group than they really do. I can’t vouch for what happens at Bohemian Grove or suchlike, but if your notion is that I routinely hang out with media figures, let alone influential politicians or celebrities — well, no.

headline: U.S. Declares Bank and Auto Bailouts Over, and Profitable
abstract: A final sale of stock from what was once General Motors’ finance arm closed a turbulent chapter of the financial crisis, the Obama administration said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Six years after President George W. Bush began the auto bailout, the Obama administration on Friday declared a profitable end to the sweeping federal interventions in Wall Street and Detroit, saying a final sale of stock from General Motors’ former finance arm had closed a turbulent chapter of the financial crisis.

headline: State of the Union Address Is Set for Jan. 20
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner has invited President Obama to address the country on Jan. 20 and give a State of the Union speech before a joint session of the new Republican-controlled Congress.
lead_paragraph: Speaker John A. Boehner has invited President Obama to deliver a State of the Union speech on Jan. 20, despite calls from a few Republicans to break with tradition and withhold a formal invitation.

headline: Letters: Group Portrait
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Mary Street Alinder’s “Group f.64,” Gordie Howe’s “Mr. Hockey” and more.
lead_paragraph: Group Portrait

headline: Trading to Win Now (Mavericks) and Later (Celtics)
abstract: Thursday’s trade between Dallas and Boston could be a good deal for both N.B.A. teams, who are trying different ways to win a title.
lead_paragraph: After years of rumors and near misses, it finally happened: Point guard Rajon Rondo has been traded from the Boston Celtics.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Héctor Tobar, whose “Deep Down Dark” is No. 15 on the hardcover nonfiction list, worked alongside Michael Connelly when they were both young reporters for the Los Angeles Times.
lead_paragraph: Bidding Adiós: Héctor Tobar’s new book, “Deep Down Dark” — about the 2010 mine collapse that trapped 33 workers beneath the Chilean desert for months — enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 15. If you lived in Southern California in the 1990s, as I did, and paid any attention to newspaper journalism, you quickly learned to seek out Tobar’s byline in The Los Angeles Times. Whether reporting on murder trials or lottery winners, Tobar had an eye for humanizing details: the wife in the back of the courtroom reading a book about her husband’s case, say, or the small African-­American barbershop persevering as its neighborhood became increasingly Latino. Those were glory days at the newspaper; Tobar sometimes shared a byline with a young crime reporter named Michael Connelly. But in September, Tobar — the son of Guatemalan immigrants, whose father used to deliver The Times — announced he was leaving after more than 20 years to teach at the University of Oregon. He does plan to keep writing books. (“Deep Down Dark” is his fourth, after a couple of novels and “Translation Nation,” a look at Spanish-speaking communities across America.) “For the first time in my life,” he explained on Facebook, “I gave myself permission to think of myself as an artist — not an easy thing for me or any other son of immigrants to do.”

headline: Crème Brûlée French Toast
abstract: Melissa Clark soaks challah bread in heavy cream, rum and spices to make French toast.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark soaks challah bread in heavy cream, rum and spices to make French toast.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Switzerland and the Inflation Hawks
abstract: Let’s be franc about monetary policy.
lead_paragraph: I tend to go on a lot about the persistence of inflation paranoia, but it is an amazing thing. A lot of people have been predicting soaring inflation since 2009 if not earlier, and have refused to change their views even though actual events have been nothing like what they predicted — and almost exactly what liquidity-trap theorists predicted, in advance.

headline: Girl Scout French Toast: As Good as the Cookies
abstract: The technique differs from other French toast recipes, with their quick dip into eggy milk. This one calls for patience. (Article plus video.)
