lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The cleanup of Japan’s devastated Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant crossed an important milestone on Saturday when the plant’s operator announced it had safely removed the radioactive fuel from the most vulnerable of the four heavily damaged reactor buildings.

headline: Jennifer Goodman and Michael Lilintahl
abstract: The bride works at the Kennedy Center for the Arts in Washington; the groom works for a lab-equipment exporter.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Rebecca Goodman and Michael Martin Lilintahl are to be married Sunday at the Thalatta Estate, an event space in Palmetto Bay, Fla. Rabbi Mario Rojzman is to lead the ceremony, with Cantor Cesar J. Beleniski participating.

headline: Rebecca Grossman-Cohen and Daniel Halioua
abstract: The bride works at The Times; the groom works for Change.org.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Grossman-Cohen and Daniel Halioua were married by Rabbi Dr. Linda Henry Goodman Friday at the Union Temple in Brooklyn. On Saturday Jeremy A. Haile, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, led another ceremony for friends and family at Studio 450, an event space in Manhattan.

headline: Cheryl Lau and Daniel Gonzalez
abstract: The couple met at the University of Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Cheryl Seto Lau, the daughter of Betty S. Lau and John T. Lau of Princeton, N.J., was married Saturday to Daniel Anthony Gonzalez, a son of Joanne E. Gonzalez of Del Mar, Calif., and Dr. Melvin A. Gonzalez of Rancho Mirage, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Richleigh H. Powers, a minister of the Calvary Chapel School of Ministry, officiated at L’Auberge Del Mar, a hotel in Del Mar, Calif.

headline: Julia Sinnott and Nicholas Giobbi
abstract: A special projects accountant at the Peabody Essex Museum marries an auditor at PricewaterhouseCoopers.
lead_paragraph: Julia Siobhan Sinnott and Nicholas Michael Giobbi were married Saturday at St. John’s Chapel of Groton School in Groton, Mass. The Rev. Austin Fleming, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Margot Kern and Scott Lurding
abstract: The bride advises a university on clinical trials; the groom runs his own consulting firm.
lead_paragraph: Margot Ingrid Kern, the daughter of Nathaniel R. Kern of Bethesda, Md., and the late Ingrid A. Valtin-Kern, was married Saturday evening to Donald Scott Lurding, a son of Nora S. Lurding and Donald R. Lurding of Louisville, Ky. The Rev. Oran Warder, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Paul’s Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Va.

headline: Meghan Gladden, Jeffrey Coyle
abstract: The marriage took place at a country club in Brunswick, Ga.
lead_paragraph: Meghan Hunt Gladden and Jeffrey Charles Coyle were married Friday at the Glynn County Courthouse in Brunswick, Ga. Judge Debra G. Howes, whose chambers are there, officiated.

headline: Katherine O’Connor, Benjamin Zeidler
abstract: The bride works for a division of Amazon; the groom works for a digital advertising agency.
lead_paragraph: Katherine Doris O’Connor, the daughter of Patricia J. O’Connor and Gerald B. O’Connor of New Vernon, N.J., was married Saturday to Benjamin Edward Zeidler, a son of Marilyn R. Zeidler and Edward D. Zeidler of Holland, Pa. The Rev. Patrick O’Donovan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of Christ the King in New Vernon.

headline: Patrick Allard, James Wang
abstract: Mr. Wang is a resident in dermatology, and Mr. Allard is an assistant professor in public health, both at U.C.L.A.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Allard and Dr. James Yen Wang were married Thursday on the Mayor’s Balcony at San Francisco City Hall. Valerie Walker, a deputy marriage commissioner, officiated.

headline: Jacob Jeffries and Jackson Bloom
abstract: The couple were married in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Jacob Christopher Jeffries and Jackson Nicholas Bloom were married Saturday at the Green Building, an event space in Brooklyn. The Rev. Joshua D. Walters, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Diana Beckner, Patrick Whelan
abstract: The bride, a coordinator at a New York hospital, and the groom, a third-year law student at Fordham, marry in Nashville.
lead_paragraph: Diana Thompson Beckner, a daughter of Carolyn T. Beckner and James L. Beckner of Nashville, was married Saturday to Patrick Marren Whelan, a son of Susan M. Whelan and William J. Whelan III of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Alan J. Fogarty, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Henry Catholic Church in Nashville.

headline: Dinner Dates Forever
abstract: A couple finds love through a shared enthusiasm for the same New York restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Rebekah Blair Bowling and Andrew Yau-Chang Chen were married Saturday evening at the Harold Pratt House in New York. The Rev. Jason P. Radmacher, a Methodist minister, officiated.

headline: Corrections: December 21, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, December 21, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: 1914: France Silences Enemy Guns Near Arras
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: After intense German shelling near Arras in 1914, the French fight back.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Arras is once more the centre of severe fighting, and that fine city of the north of France, so many of whose artistic or historic monuments are already in ruins, has received further punishment from the pitiless German shells. Having already destroyed the belfry of the famous church, the Germans are now probably bent on leaving not one stone of it upon another. But although the army of “Kultur” may destroy the beauties of helpless French cities, it is having no success when opposing itself to the French troops. In front of Arras the French artillery threw such a rain of shells into the enemy’s lines that no fewer than thirty-six cannon were silenced. Immediately after the infantry advanced, and after a hand-to-hand fight gained several trenches. The cavalry also took a distinguished part, the cuirassiers nailing the German artillerymen at their guns. Not satisfied with working further havoc in Arras, the Germans have also had recourse to another one of their favorite diversions, and have bombarded the hospital in Ypres. Such tactics on the part of the Germans generally indicate that they can make no headway in legitimate fighting. This view is, in fact, frankly expressed by a war correspondent of the “Berliner Tageblatt.” — The New York Herald, European Edition, Dec. 22, 1914

headline: Distracted Driving and the Risks of Ride-Hailing Services Like Uber
abstract: In an effort to move fast, phone apps like Uber, Lyft and Flywheel may be placing a premium on speed and in the process sacrificing safety.
lead_paragraph: It Can Wait. The buzz phrase, popularized by AT&T in a public service campaign, urges drivers to show restraint with their phones.

headline: This Holiday, Don’t Hide the Piercings From Grandma
abstract: Rather than a one-way transfer of my beliefs to them, my kids, now 19 and 16, are teaching me to see the world—and my in-laws—with new eyes.
lead_paragraph: Our youngest child hasn’t even left the nest yet, but my husband already dreams of a time when our adult children will boomerang home. He wants my mother to live with us, too. We both like to imagine the dynamism and mutual support of a multigenerational household. During the holidays – with our daughter home from college and grandparents on both sides visiting – we get to live our fantasy.

headline: Egypt’s President Replaces Influential Intelligence Chief
abstract: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi removed Gen. Mohamed Farid el-Tohamy, a mentor, and named Khaled Fawzy, a top deputy in the intelligence service, as his successor.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi has removed an influential mentor as chief of general intelligence, Egyptian state media reported on Sunday, citing health concerns but raising speculation about a government shake-up.

headline: The Daily Gift: a Gourmet Cheese Subscription from Bklyn Larder
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: A Quick Video of a Slow Burn
abstract: What happens when you strike a match. A lot, it turns out. A video reveals swirling streams of hot gas and flame.
lead_paragraph: Three research scientists from Stanford University have made an entrancing slow-motion video of what happens when a match is lit. In “The Hidden Complexities of the Simple Match,” Victor Miller, Matthew Tilghman and Ronald Hanson employed Schlieren imaging to capture the fleeting, normally unseen patterns in the flame.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 3:15 P.M. (Showtime 2) LEE DANIELS’ THE BUTLER (2013) Inspired by the real story of Eugene Allen, Mr. Daniels follows a White House butler, Cecil Gaines (Forest Whitaker), and his wife, Gloria (Oprah Winfrey), as history — particularly the civil rights movement — unfolds over seven presidential administrations. A. O. Scott, writing in The New York Times, called the film “a brilliantly truthful movie on a subject that is usually shrouded in wishful thinking, mythmongering and outright denial.” Robin Williams portrays Dwight D. Eisenhower; Liev Schreiber is Lyndon B. Johnson; and Alan Rickman is Ronald Reagan, with Jane Fonda as his wife, Nancy; Cuba Gooding Jr. and Lenny Kravitz are the fellow butlers who become Cecil’s close friends; and David Oyelowo is the older son whose politics Cecil eschews. “In part, their story is a chronicle of the generational misunderstanding that has occurred in upwardly mobile families of every background, especially in the baby boom era, when educated and restless young people turned against the parents who had sacrificed so much on their behalf,” Mr. Scott wrote. “ 'The Butler’ has the historical insight and the generosity of spirit to honor the father and the son equally, and to look with skepticism at each’s point of view.” He added: “We remember those who marched and who stood up for themselves in the face of injustice. It is good to remember that, to paraphrase Milton, they also stand who only wait and serve.”

headline: New York Police Add Precautions After Ambush
abstract: The killings of two officers in Brooklyn on Saturday set off a bunker mentality across the department, as sentries were posted outside station houses and officers were barred from patrolling alone.
lead_paragraph: Faced with the first targeted killings of New York City police officers in years, police leaders ratcheted up precautions for their vast patrol force on Sunday as officials described the predatory final movements of a gunman bent on killing officers.

headline: Old-Guard Politician Seen Leading Tunisia’s Interim President in Runoff Election
abstract: Exit polls indicated that Beji Caid Essebsi, who served two dictators, was ahead of President Moncef Marzouki, a former human rights activist, who did not concede defeat.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Supporters of Beji Caid Essebsi, a veteran statesman who served in the governments of both of Tunisia’s former dictators, celebrated his expected victory in Sunday’s presidential runoff as three exit polls showed him in the lead. His rival, the interim president Moncef Marzouki, did not concede defeat.

headline: Measuring Mayor de Blasio’s First Year by a Broken Toe and a $360 Check
abstract: A woman’s successful fight for sick pay offers a look at whether New York’s mayor has delivered on his promise to uplift struggling families.
lead_paragraph: The public service announcements popped up everywhere she looked, on her television screen, in the newspapers, on the rumbling subway trains that carried her to work: New York City was finally requiring the vast majority of employers to offer paid sick leave.

headline: Six New Madonna Tracks Released
abstract: Madonna released six tracks from her upcoming album, “Rebel Heart,” after music she described as unfinished work was leaked last week.
lead_paragraph: If you can’t beat ‘em, join ‘em.

headline: ‘Hobbit’ Movie Wins Box Office Skirmish
abstract: Last of Middle Earth entries, “The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies” garners $90.6 million in ticket sales to lead box office take
lead_paragraph: “The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies” collected $90.6 million in ticket sales during its first five days in North American theaters, slightly better than the five-day total for last year’s “Hobbit” installment.

headline: 1964: Tempers Flare as Italian Parliament Fails to Elect New President
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: After failed ninth and 10th rounds of voting, the presidential election became the longest in the 18-year history of the Italian Republic in 1964.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Communists and neo-Fascists nearly came to blows in the Italian parliament today as its two houses failed again — in the ninth and tenth ballots — to elect a new president of the republic. Today’s two votes made the current presidential election the longest in the 18-year-old history of the Italian Republic. The previous record was the nine ballots it took in 1962 to elect Antonio Segni president. Mr. Segni resigned earlier this month after it became clear that he would not be able to perform the functions of the office as a result of a stroke he suffered in August. The voting today was also marked by the appearance, for the first time on the ballot, of Deputy Premier Pietro Nenni’s name. Mr. Nenni, long an outsider in government affairs, is leader of the left-wing Socialists. He joined the government of Premier Aldo Moro last year in its “opening to the left.” Former Premier Giovanni Leone, the official Christian Democrat candidate, polled 299 votes tonight — six less than in the ninth ballot this morning. A total of 482 votes are needed for election. The Social Democrats and Republicans, as well as the neo-Fascist Italian Social Movement, abstained in tonight’s vote. Legislators nearly came to blows in the morning session when Communists and Fascists jeered and shouted at each other. It was the first such outbreak since balloting began Dec. 16. Parliament meets again tomorrow morning for the 11th ballot. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Dec. 22, 1964

headline: Obama to See if North Korea Should Return to Terror List
abstract: President Obama said he would “review” whether to return North Korea to the list, part of a broader government response to a damaging cyberattack on Sony’s Hollywood studio.
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — As the United States moves closer to taking Cuba off the list of state sponsors of terrorism, President Obama said he would “review” whether to return North Korea to the list, part of a broader government response to a damaging cyberattack on Sony’s Hollywood studio.

headline: A Brooklyn Ambulance Corps Is Seeking Its Own Emergency Aid
abstract: The volunteer group, which transports patients and trains medical technicians, is eligible for a $125,000 grant, but it must raise that much before it can receive the money.
lead_paragraph: The phone never stops ringing at Brooklyn’s Bedford-Stuyvesant Volunteer Ambulance Corps, and not just for urgent medical help. These days, many of the callers are looking to train as emergency medical technicians with the hope of finding steady work with decent pay.

headline: Killing of New York Police Officers Tests Promise of ‘One City’
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio, along with responsible police leaders and protesters, must bring New Yorkers together.
lead_paragraph: First, the grieving. The horrifying killings of two police officers in Brooklyn on Saturday shock the soul of the city and require us all to stop to honor the dead, Rafael Ramos and Wenjian Liu. Police Commissioner William Bratton, looking stricken at a news conference at Woodhull Hospital, reminded us that behind each blue uniform is a family. Officer Liu was newly married. Officer Ramos had a wife and 13-year-old son. Mayor Bill de Blasio called the officers’ deaths “an attack on everything we hold dear.”

headline: In Hopes of Ending Deadlock, Premier Offers Early Elections
abstract: Prime Minister Antonis Samaras of Greece offered to call elections toward the end of next year in a bid to rally lawmakers behind the government’s candidate for president.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Prime Minister Antonis Samaras of Greece, seeking to rally lawmakers behind the government’s candidate for president in a critical vote that could throw the country into new financial turmoil, offered on Sunday to set a date for early general elections toward the end of next year.

headline: Jordan Executes 11 After 8-Year Moratorium
abstract: The kingdom’s last execution took place in 2006, and the hangings of 11 convicted murderers on Sunday prompted criticism by human rights organizations.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Jordan ended an eight-year moratorium on executions on Sunday when 11 men were hanged at dawn.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Thunder at Spurs
abstract: San Antonio, which has been missing some of last season’s key contributors, has lost five of its last six. Oklahoma City is also looking to get healthy.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: A Star D.J. Moves On in the Wake of Turmoil
abstract: Mister Cee, who quit the New York hip-hop station Hot 97 after 21 years, has a new radio gig, a turning point both personal and professional.
lead_paragraph: In late November, Mister Cee, the prominent hip-hop D.J., unexpectedly announced his second resignation in little more than a year from Hot 97, the influential New York station where he worked for 21 years. He said he stepped down this time not because of the earlier disclosures that he had solicited transgender prostitutes, but because he could see the station evolving without him — incorporating more pop crossovers in its playlist, for instance — and he wanted to leave on his own terms.

headline: Third-Quarter Growth and November Consumer Data
abstract: The Commerce Department will issue its final estimate for third-quarter growth, and data for November will be released for durable goods, income, spending and new-home sales.
lead_paragraph: FINAL UPDATE ON GROWTH FOR THIRD QUARTER

headline: A Muscle Car of Rock Still Purrs and Roars
abstract: Mr. Seger, an exponent of soulful rock since the 1960s, played his hits and other songs that gently blended politics with the personal.
lead_paragraph: Bob Seger didn’t show any rock-star vanity when he headlined Madison Square Garden on Friday night. Mr. Seger is 69; his hair and beard were gray and he wore glasses, an untucked black shirt and bluejeans. Soon after he started his set, he put on a sweatband that he would, about two hours later, fling into the crowd. There was no dress code in his Silver Bullet Band, either; they weren’t onstage to pose. The show was in the songs that were played as straightforwardly as they deserved.

headline: Jets Keep Patriots at Bay, Then Revert to Type Against Their Rivals
abstract: Tom Brady was sacked three times early, and the Jets, although booed multiple times, led entering the fourth quarter. But a conversion of a third-and-7 helped the Patriots seal the victory.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It has been weeks since the Jets actually had something to play for; since fans had reason to cheer; since Coach Rex Ryan had cause to smile.

headline: The Dark Side of a Digital Future
abstract: “Black Mirror,” the British anthology drama that mines cautionary, “Twilight Zone”-style narratives from our obsessions with gadgetry, returns to American television on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Picture, if you will, a world where our digital devices seem eerily alive; where technology lets us block unwanted people not only from our social media streams but from our eyes and ears; and where the maladroit can receive stealthy, real-time pickup and dating advice from debonair coaches resembling the “Mad Men” star Jon Hamm.

headline: A Child With H.I.V., Shunned by His Entire Village
abstract: More than 200 villagers in the southwestern province of Sichuan, including the boy’s guardian, have signed a petition unanimously calling for the boy’s expulsion.
lead_paragraph: Rosy-cheeked, with a mop of black hair and big smile, Kun Kun, 8, just wants to be like the other kids in his village. But because he is H.I.V. positive, his neighbors have denied him the most basic joys of childhood.

headline: Down Mean Streets a Writer Went to Create a Hard-Boiled Character
abstract: “The World of Raymond Chandler: In His Own Words” looks at the world and the works of that detective novelist.
lead_paragraph: In Raymond Chandler’s 1940 detective novel, “Farewell, My Lovely,” he took the measure of a rogue cop named Blane in a typical flight of literary fancy: “He was a windblown blossom of some 200 pounds with freckled teeth and the mellow voice of a circus barker.” Blane, of course, is not the character Chandler’s fans remember best. That honor goes to his suave but “shop-soiled” Los Angeles gumshoe, Philip Marlowe.

headline: In Brooklyn, the Lives of 2 Officers Are Recalled as Their Deaths Are Mourned
abstract: Neighbors and business owners recalled Officers Wenjian Liu and Rafael Ramos as law enforcement colleagues visited the Brooklyn homes of the fallen officers.
lead_paragraph: The two officers lived at opposite ends of Brooklyn, one in Gravesend and one in Cypress Hills. They were stationed in another neighborhood, in Brooklyn Heights, and died in yet another.

headline: Steering Without Seizing Glory
abstract: In taking over a role originally played by Jimmy Nail, the rock star Sting takes a more subdued approach in “The Last Ship.”
lead_paragraph: As followers of Broadway news and obsessive watchers of the box office are well aware, there’s a new crew member aboard “The Last Ship.” Sting, the composer of the evocative score for this ambitious musical about a shipbuilding town in decline, has clambered aboard, taking over the role originally played by a good friend, the actor Jimmy Nail, through Jan. 24.

headline: A Prince, a Time-Bending Clock and Magic at Work
abstract: Keith Michael’s “The Nutcracker” for New York Theater Ballet is a compact entry in the company’s Once Upon a Ballet series.
lead_paragraph: The most enlightened assessment of New York Theater Ballet’s “The Nutcracker” would probably come from a child between the ages of 3 and 8. Such is the target demographic for this abridged version of the holiday standard, which returned to Gould Hall over the weekend as part of the company’s Once Upon a Ballet series.

headline: It’s ‘Pink Flamingos,’ But, You Know, for Kids
abstract: You will soon be able to see John Waters’s notorious 1972 film, as adapted for a staged reading by children.
lead_paragraph: How does a movie about the “filthiest people alive” become family-friendly? Viewers will soon find out with John Waters’s “Kiddie Flamingos,” a video art piece based on Mr. Waters’s notorious 1972 film, “Pink Flamingos.” The 74-minute video will play on a loop at his coming art exhibition, “Beverly Hills John,” at Marianne Boesky Gallery in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan.

headline: Sitting, but Showing Range
abstract: The pianist Simone Dinnerstein’s imaginative recital at the Met had distinct halves and mixed results.
lead_paragraph: Simone Dinnerstein, a pianist who has won acclaim for her Bach performances over the past decade or so, set out to show a broader range of artistry in her recital at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday evening. She partly succeeded.

headline: A Cubanized Blending of Musical Languages
abstract: The “New Jazz Frontiers” concert combined a tricky instrumentation and various musical languages, and featured Orlando Valle, a Cuban flutist rarely heard in New York.
lead_paragraph: One possible result of a normalized relationship between the United States and Cuba: greater ease in the creation of concerts like “New Jazz Frontiers,” an experiment and a success presented on Friday and Saturday nights at Jazz at Lincoln Center’s Appel Room.

headline: Energy-Storage Plans Gain Ground in California
abstract: Southern California Edison plans to retire some power plants and replace them with storage — including conventional batteries and giant ice packs — as well as other power generators.
lead_paragraph: In an unusual competition in California, proposals for energy storage systems beat out hundreds of bids to construct new power plants as a way to meet peak power needs.

headline: Flat Board Is a Big Deal at Vanderbilt Knockout Teams
abstract: The American Contract Bridge League’s Player of the Year award goes to the person who wins the most platinum master points.
lead_paragraph: The American Contract Bridge League’s Player of the Year award goes to the person who wins the most platinum master points. These can be accrued only in the major national championships.

headline: North Korea’s Coming to Town
abstract: Relations between North Korea and the Sony corporation remain chilly.
lead_paragraph: Relations between North Korea and the Sony corporation remain chilly.

headline: Two-Course Feast of Stage and Song
abstract: Two versions of “The Long Christmas Dinner” were performed on Friday at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: It would be fascinating to see a performance of Sardou’s play “La Tosca” followed by a production of Puccini’s enduring operatic adaptation. Or, imagine other such double bills of a play and opera: Maeterlinck’s and Debussy’s “Pelléas et Mélisande,” Oscar Wilde’s and Richard Strauss’s “Salome.” Of course, these fantasy pairings would be marathons.

headline: In China, a Rapid Jump to Mobile Advertising
abstract: Next year, companies are expected to spend more money on digital advertising than on TV commercials in China.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Liu Xuelong, a television and documentary producer in Beijing, hasn’t used his television in years. He gets all of his entertainment on his iPhone 6 Plus, where he also taps a plethora of apps to buy plane tickets, pay bills, talk with clients.

headline: Seen on a Street Corner, Briefly
abstract: Lynn Lempel encourages us to hang out on street corners. Also, news about the film “The Imitation Game”: print out and solve the puzzle Alan Turing created to recruit his Bletchley Park code breakers.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Usually, Lynn Lempel’s Monday puzzles are a breeze, a breath of fresh and easy-to-solve air after the weekend brain twisters. Today’s puzzle was a bit tougher, although I would still confidently put it in the “Monday puzzle” category.

headline: Edith Ramirez Is Raising the F.T.C.’s Voice
abstract: Edith Ramirez’s tenure as leader of the commission has been marked by an effort to bring the regulator into the public eye, directing particular attention on digital privacy and transactions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The New England Journal of Medicine is not a common venue for antitrust debates. But it was in that academic journal that Edith Ramirez, chairwoman of the Federal Trade Commission, warned this month that mergers of physician practice groups could stifle competition.

headline: The Architects, Together and Apart
abstract: Architects respond to an Op-Ed article about rebuilding the profession.

headline: Life and Experience Make College More Meaningful
abstract: Professors from Wright State University and Golden Gate University School of Law respond to an Op-Ed article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Have N.F.L. Pay Schools
abstract: A reader suggests how to finance college sports.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Safety and Truck Drivers
abstract: Bill Graves of the American Trucking Associations responds to a column by Gail Collins.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Racial Profiling at the Border
abstract: Cecillia D. Wang of the A.C.L.U. Immigrants’ Rights Project responds to a front-page article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Obama, the Least Lame President?
abstract: Like Bush’s, his last two years might be the best ones.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — HISTORIANS rate presidents by every conceivable quality. One survey of presidential scholars rates presidents along no fewer than 20 dimensions, from best luck (Washington) and best imagination (Theodore Roosevelt) to best intelligence (Jefferson) and best handling of Congress (Lyndon B. Johnson). And of course, there’s the ultimate prize: Best president, a distinction Lincoln and Franklin D. Roosevelt have traded back and forth since at least the first modern survey, in 1948.

headline: Knicks Sleepwalk Through Loss as Nightmare Continues
abstract: The Knicks, with injuries continuing to sap their strength, fell to 5-25 after an uninspired performance against the Raptors.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — It took the Knicks only 37 seconds to concede three offensive rebounds to the Toronto Raptors on Sunday. At the 39-second mark, James Johnson scored the Raptors’ first basket on a two-handed, put-back dunk.

headline: Despite Cheaper Gas, Public Transit Ridership Is Up, Trade Group Reports
abstract: Investment in transit around the country is leading to record-high ridership rates and more people leaving their cars at home despite low prices at the pump.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — David Needham thought he would need to buy a car when he moved to Minneapolis-St. Paul from San Francisco in February 2013, but was pleasantly surprised to find that his adopted city has an extended transit system that meets all of his business and social needs, allowing him and his family to remain car-free.

headline: Privilege, Among Rape Victims
abstract: Why do we pay so much attention to the sexual assault of college students?
lead_paragraph: DENVER — LATELY, people have been bombarded with the notion that universities and colleges are hotbeds of sexual violence. Parents fear that sending their teenagers to school is equivalent to shipping them off to be sexually victimized.

headline: How the Hacking at Sony Over ‘The Interview’ Became a Horror Movie
abstract: Things have gone so deeply wrong so quickly, it is hard to keep track of all the mistakes that led us here, David Carr writes.
lead_paragraph: Kim Jong-un, who appears to be America’s newly self-appointed minister of culture, has decided that it is not enough that “The Interview,” the Seth Rogen film about North Korea that includes Mr. Kim’s assassination, will not be released. On Thursday, a message from the Guardians of Peace, the hacker group that breached the computer systems of Sony Pictures and warned against releasing the film, said “we want everything related to the movie, including its trailers, as well as its full version down from any website hosting them immediately.”

headline: G.O.P. Hopes for Unity May Be Upset by Ben Carson
abstract: The Republican establishment is determined not to repeat the mistakes of 2012, but Ben Carson is riding a groundswell of support from outside the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — A conservative think tank recently sent Ben Carson, a potential presidential candidate and fierce critic of the federal health care overhaul, a series of messages to post on Twitter during the grilling in the House of Jonathan Gruber, the M.I.T. economist who advised the Obama administration.

headline: Jameis Winston Is Cleared in Hearing Over Student’s Rape Accusation
abstract: In a Florida State University hearing, a judge said there wasn’t enough evidence to find Winston guilty of violating the student code of conduct.
lead_paragraph: Jameis Winston has been cleared of violating Florida State’s student code of conduct after a hearing involving a 2012 rape accusation by a female student.

headline: Courtesy of the Gravedigger
abstract: After 38 years of raising horses, deciding when and how to euthanize one hasn’t gotten any easier.

headline: With Jay Cutler on the Bench and Jimmy Clausen Starting, the Bears Lose Again
abstract: The Bears lost to the Lions despite a shake-up at quarterback that left Jay Cutler, who signed a big contract extension less than a year ago, watching from the sideline.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Bears quarterback Jay Cutler jogged onto the field Sunday through a haze of pyrotechnics. He tossed a few warm-up passes and then headed toward the bench, where he donned a hat — blue and white with a pompom on top — and a long parka.

headline: YouTube Challenger Lets Music Fans Call the Shots
abstract: The technology company Interlude has attracted the attention of the music industry with a tool that creates music videos with branching plots subject to a viewer’s choices.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago Yoni Bloch, an Israeli rock star, wanted to make a music video that would let viewers choose what happened as the story unfolded. But the technology did not exist, so Mr. Bloch and his band members developed it themselves and shot the video for $2,000.

headline: ‘The Case Against Torture’
abstract: In this short documentary, a former defense lawyer for prisoners at Guantánamo Bay argues against the C.I.A.'s use of torture.
lead_paragraph: A few months before the recent release of the Senate’s report on the C.I.A.'s use of torture, I interviewed the man charged with defending one of the most notorious prisoners at Guantánamo Bay. Maj. Jason Wright was part of the military counsel for Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, accused of being the mastermind behind the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001. He also represented an Afghan villager named Obaydullah, who has been held in detention for 12 years and still has not been tried in court.

headline: Neighborhood Mourns Slain Officers
abstract: The day after two police officers were killed while on duty in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, residents came together at the scene of the crime to express their sorrow.
lead_paragraph: The day after two police officers were killed while on duty in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, residents came together at the scene of the crime to express their sorrow.

headline: The Case Against Torture
abstract: In this short documentary, a former defense lawyer for prisoners at Guantánamo Bay argues against the C.I.A.’s use of torture.
lead_paragraph: In this short documentary, a former defense lawyer for prisoners at Guantánamo Bay argues against the C.I.A.’s use of torture.

headline: Protecting a Home Where the Puffer Fish Roam in Biscayne National Park
abstract: A dispute over the possibility of a no-fishing zone in Biscayne National Park off the coast of Florida has raised contrasts with hunting bans on federal land.
lead_paragraph: BISCAYNE NATIONAL PARK, Fla. — For 15 years, officials, environmentalists, fishermen and boaters have struggled to put together a plan to protect one of South Florida’s jewels — a national park, almost entirely underwater, where a part of the largest reef tract in the United States lures throngs of divers and anglers who fish its once-abundant grouper and snapper.

headline: Christie Wants Obama to Push Cuba to Return New Jersey Trooper’s Killer
abstract: Joanne Chesimard, who goes by the name Assata Shakur, was convicted in the 1973 killing of a New Jersey state trooper and fled to Cuba.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has asked President Obama to demand that Cuba return a woman convicted of killing a New Jersey state trooper 41 years ago, the governor’s office said on Sunday.

headline: Conquest Is for Losers
abstract: There is still a powerful political faction in America that hasn’t learned this lesson.
lead_paragraph: More than a century has passed since Norman Angell, a British journalist and politician, published “The Great Illusion,” a treatise arguing that the age of conquest was or at least should be over. He didn’t predict an end to warfare, but he did argue that aggressive wars no longer made sense — that modern warfare impoverishes the victors as well as the vanquished.

headline: In Bavaria, Krampus Catches the Naughty
abstract: A centuries-old Christmas tradition called the Krampus Run returns to Bavaria where monsters roam the streets in search of bad children.
lead_paragraph: A centuries-old Christmas tradition called the Krampus Run returns to Bavaria where monsters roam the streets in search of bad children.

headline: Pursuing Justice for All
abstract: America’s anguish over judicial fairness stretches across generations and the racial gulf.
lead_paragraph: He is prisoner No. 260. He stares into the camera for his mug shot, head cocked, eyes forlorn of hope. It is the kind of picture that haunts.

headline: America’s Addiction
abstract: Opioids cause more deaths in the United States than any other drug. Here is a photographic history of the nation’s relationship with these and other narcotics.
lead_paragraph: Opioids cause more deaths in the United States than any other drug. Here is a photographic history of the nation’s relationship with these and other narcotics.

headline: Top-Secret N.S.A. Document
abstract: A redacted document contained an analysis of intelligence gathered from Zarrar Shah’s online activities.
lead_paragraph: A redacted document contained an analysis of intelligence gathered from Zarrar Shah’s online activities.

headline: Missed Signals Before the Mumbai Attacks
abstract: Intelligence agencies in three countries tracked conspirators and deployed high-tech surveillance tools in advance of the Mumbai attacks, but they did not put the pieces together.
lead_paragraph: Intelligence agencies in three countries tracked conspirators and deployed high-tech surveillance tools in advance of the Mumbai attacks, but they did not put the pieces together.

headline: Prosecute Torturers and Their Bosses
abstract: The tactics used on terror suspects after the Sept. 11 attacks were crimes, and the perpetrators knew it. Now they must be brought to justice.
lead_paragraph: Since the day President Obama took office, he has failed to bring to justice anyone responsible for the torture of terrorism suspects — an official government program conceived and carried out in the years after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: In 2008 Mumbai Attacks, Piles of Spy Data, but an Uncompleted Puzzle
abstract: An investigation reveals how American, British and Indian agencies failed to pull together intelligence streams, including a plotter’s online activity, before attacks that Indians regard as their 9/11.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2008, a 30-year-old computer expert named Zarrar Shah roamed from outposts in the northern mountains of Pakistan to safe houses near the Arabian Sea, plotting mayhem in Mumbai, India’s commercial gem.

headline: Crunch Time for FedEx and UPS as Last-Minute Holiday Shipping Ramps Up
abstract: FedEx and UPS are aiming to avoid last year’s chaos, when a late surge in shipments and bad weather left many gifts to be delivered late.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — Donner Pass, the icy stretch of road that cuts through the Sierra Nevada mountains, is 2,000 miles away from FedEx’s world hub in Memphis.

headline: Workers’ Rights at McDonald’s
abstract: The movement pushing for unions and better pay got some validation from the federal government, which issued complaints against the fast-food chain.
lead_paragraph: The Fight for $15 is ending the year on a high note. The protest movement, which began in New York City two years ago with fast-food workers demanding at least $15 an hour and the right to unionize without retaliation, has spread to more than 100 cities and many industries, including retail, home care, hospitality and airport services.

headline: After a Tumultuous Year at the Box Office, Hollywood Looks to 2015
abstract: Hackers, changing movie habits and plain old duds — 2014 has not been kind to the industry. Attendance is driven by the movies themselves, but attendance this year may turn out to be the lowest since 2000.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The delay of major movies from Pixar and Universal. The pirating of “The Expendables 3” and “Annie” before their release. Warner Bros. suffering one dud after another. Hackers forcing the cancellation of a big Sony comedy.

headline: Do We Need the C.I.A.?
abstract: Would the security needs of the United States be better served if the agency were dismantled?

headline: He Sees You When You’re Sleeping, and Gives You Nightmares
abstract: In Germany, misbehaving children had better watch out. The Krampus, a devilish goblin who tears through the streets as St. Nick’s evil counterpart, is making a comeback.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Long before parents relied on the powers of Santa Claus to monitor their children’s behavior, their counterparts in Alpine villages called on a shaggy-furred, horned creature with a fistful of bound twigs to send the message that they had better watch out.

headline: Beauty Shines Through Decay
abstract: In Cuba, from the baseball games on the fields to those played in streets with balls wrapped in duct tape, it’s a love pursued amid the ruins.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — To walk the playing fields at Ciudad Deportiva — a vast public sports complex — is to wander into glorious obsession in full flower.

headline: For Mayor de Blasio and New York Police, a Rift Is Ripped Open
abstract: The long-simmering tensions between Mayor Bill de Blasio and the Police Department he has pledged to reshape have reached an extraordinary nadir after two officers were killed.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio sat in the front pew at St. Patrick’s Cathedral on Sunday, head bowed at times, with his wife on his left and the police commissioner on his right.

headline: Rivals Shake Hands, and One Shakes Head
abstract: Rex Ryan, in perhaps his final home game as the Jets’ coach, fell short once more against Patriots Coach Bill Belichick, a longtime nemesis.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When it was over, Rex Ryan met his nemesis, Bill Belichick, at midfield. Their relationship is cordial, Ryan has said, but it is also complicated — all those New England victories and division titles over the last six seasons have something to do with that.

headline: Trying to Save Russia’s Punch Line of a Car
abstract: Russians ridicule their endangered Ladas, but also cherish them. So the Kremlin recruited a blunt Swedish-American executive with long experience in Detroit to overhaul the carmaker.
lead_paragraph: TOGLIATTI, Russia — Ladas are the family cars that Russians love to hate.

headline: With Knocks Before and After Whistle, the Giants Rattle the Rams
abstract: The Giants got help from a turnover-prone St. Louis offense in the first half and ran over a Rams defense that had not given up a touchdown in its last three games.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — The Giants — like everyone else around the N.F.L. — have seen enough to know that Odell Beckham Jr. is a special talent. They sent a message on Sunday that if they perceive that an opposing team is taking liberties on him, they are going to respond — even if it costs them a player or two.

headline: Cuba Seizures Now Present Opportunities
abstract: Lawyers are scrambling to determine whether normalized relations with Cuba will create a chance to get compensation for lost properties now estimated to be worth nearly $7 billion.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — It was a routine Saturday morning, almost two years after Fidel Castro took power in Cuba, when Lois and Roy Schechter went to check on their tobacco farm 100 miles west of their home in Havana.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: As people travel to friends and family, there are countless ways to reach them with video and print ads.
lead_paragraph: As people travel to friends and family, there are countless ways to reach them with video and print ads.

headline: Officers’ Killer Took Aim at New York City of Today
abstract: In an instant this weekend, it seemed as though it was 1971 again, a time when the city was riven and dangerous, its ordinary criminal activity outdone by political violence.
lead_paragraph: If you happen to walk the Macombs Dam Bridge, which crosses the Harlem River between the Bronx and Manhattan near 155th Street, you may notice a staircase that drops down to the street on the Manhattan side. Nearby are the Colonial Park Houses.

headline: New York Officers’ Killer, Adrift and Ill, Had a Plan
abstract: Before shooting two police officers, Ismaaiyl Brinsley had an extensive history with police, suffered from mental problems and was isolated from his family, his relatives said.
lead_paragraph: Ismaaiyl Brinsley, who had drifted between friends and family members for most of his short life, alienating most of them and failing at almost anything that he tried, decided to come home on Saturday. He boarded a bus in Baltimore, arrived in Midtown Manhattan just before 11 a.m., and then disappeared onto the N train at the Times Square subway stop.

headline: Accusers and the Accused, Crossing Paths at Columbia University
abstract: Paul Nungesser was cleared of responsibility by Columbia University after being accused of rape by a fellow student, who turned her outrage into a performance piece. He is now speaking out.
lead_paragraph: Knit cap pulled down over his ears, shoulders hunched against the biting wind, Paul Nungesser was almost indistinguishable from the dozen or so other students traversing the steps of Columbia University’s Low Memorial Library one menacing December day. But a few of those students recognized him anyway, flicking their eyes up for a discreet peek before hurrying on to the last classes of the semester.

headline: At Demonstrations, a Change in Tone After Officers Are Killed
abstract: New York protest groups are determining how to continue their push for police reform while responding to the ambush killings of two police officers in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: For weeks after a Staten Island grand jury declined to indict a white police officer in the chokehold death of a black man, civil rights rallies in New York City had gathered momentum and spurred dialogue among activists and city officials.

headline: ‘The Affair’ Recap: In the Finale, an Answer to What Happened Between Noah and Alison
abstract: But Scotty Lockhart’s death remains a mystery.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 10

headline: A Few Tips for Christmas Dinner
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: In the crush of the holiday season, an Upper West Sider found that gratuities, while thoughtful, simply couldn’t do all the work for him.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: In Cavaliers’ Evolving Puzzle, a Focused Guard Provides an Edge
abstract: At first distracted by his move to the bench, Cleveland guard Dion Waiters came on to score 21 points in a victory over formidable Memphis.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The prevailing feeling here about the city’s professional basketball team seems to fall somewhere between guarded optimism and cautious enthusiasm. The Cavaliers are months into the N.B.A.’s latest experiment in superstar collectives, and it has been, as coaches are fond of saying when things could be better, a process.

headline: Laszlo Varga, Cellist for the New York Philharmonic, Is Dead at 89
abstract: After escaping a Nazi work camp, Mr. Varga became principal cellist for the New York Philharmonic in 1951 and remained in the post for 11 years.
lead_paragraph: Laszlo Varga, a Hungarian-born musician and teacher who escaped a Nazi work camp to become principal cellist for the New York Philharmonic under the batons of Dimitri Mitropoulos and Leonard Bernstein, died on Dec. 11 at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 89.

headline: Inspired by Her Twins, a Mother Moves From a Shuffle to a Stride
abstract: Nicole Paige’s children helped her focus on her dream to make a career out of baking.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Paige, 27, loves to tell the story of the red velvet cheesecake.

headline: Restaurant in Beijing Temple Rejects State Media Censure
abstract: Temple Restaurant Beijing, which serves French-influenced cuisine, has countered that it is a properly licensed business that is open to the public and has not engaged in any illegal operations.
lead_paragraph: An investor in a company that rents and is restoring a temple near the Forbidden City in Beijing has rejected state media criticism that it is improperly operating a private club on the historic site.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 21, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: The Best of Week 16 in the N.F.L.
abstract: The top performers and key injuries this week in the league.
lead_paragraph: Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers threw for 318 yards and a touchdown in a victory over the Buccaneers. Rodgers rebounded after the only game this season in which he failed to throw a touchdown pass — last week’s 21-13 loss to the Bills — by completing 31 of 40 passes without an interception.

headline: AbbVie Deal Heralds Changed Landscape for Hepatitis Drugs
abstract: Express Scripts, the nation’s largest manager of prescriptions, has negotiated a “significant discount” for Viekira Pak, a new entrant to the expensive class of hepatitis C medications.
lead_paragraph: In a sign that price competition may take hold for hepatitis C drugs, the nation’s largest manager of prescriptions will require all patients to use AbbVie’s newly approved treatment rather than two widely used medicines from its rival Gilead Sciences.

headline: Word of the Day | ravine
abstract: This word has appeared in 41 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: ravine •\rə-ˈven\• noun

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 22, 2014.
lead_paragraph: I know that being a cop is dangerous, but I must do it. If I don’t do it and you don’t do it, then who is going to do it?

headline: In Showdown, Cardinals Can’t Stop the Seahawks
abstract: The Cardinals’ magic carpet ride of a season hit a major snag when they lost to the defending champion Seahawks, leaving the teams tied for first in the N.F.C. West.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Before Sunday’s game against the Seattle Seahawks, the Arizona Cardinals had the best record in the N.F.C., led their division and had one of the toughest defenses in the N.F.L.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TMC) HAPPY-GO-LUCKY (2008) The irrepressible optimism of a 30-year-old London schoolteacher (Sally Hawkins, above) grates on those whose days she’s intent on brightening up — among them, her driving instructor (Eddie Marsan), flamenco teacher (Karina Fernandez) and sister (Caroline Martin) — in this character study directed and written by Mike Leigh, which earned him an Oscar nomination for best original screenplay. Ms. Hawkins’s portrayal is “glorious,” a “gurgling, burbling stream of gasps, giggles and words,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, choosing the film as a critic’s pick. “Mr. Leigh has a documentarian’s eye for unadorned reality — his people and places look equally lived in — and his dialogue has the ebb and flow, the swells and eddies and logjams of ordinary conversation,” she added. “But the dramatist in Mr. Leigh is always hard at work, aligning his characters for maximum narrative effect and emotional pow. That’s true even if ‘Happy-Go-Lucky’ seems as lighthearted as the bobbing bloom at its center.”

headline: Corrections: December 22, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Monday, December 22, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

abstract: Lockhart brings lasagna, whiskey in paper cups, Frannie acts adorably. But in the end…

headline: Test Yourself | ‘Christmas Icetastrophe’ on Syfy
abstract: In this quiz you’ll find all four paragraphs of a Dec. 19 TV review, “Making Icicles of Everyone.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are all four paragraphs from a Dec. 19 TV review, “Making Icicles of Everyone.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Two New York City Police Officers Ambushed
abstract: Who were the police officers killed in an ambush in Brooklyn?
lead_paragraph: In “Two N.Y.P.D. Officers Are Killed in Brooklyn Ambush; Suspect Commits Suicide,” Benjamin Mueller and Al Baker report on the incident and its aftermath.

headline: Ready and Waiting for the Moment to Unfold
abstract: In the run-up to the Iraq invasion, Ruby Washington went to the United Nations hoping to find a different kind of image. She found it when Secretary of State Colin Powell was handed a note.
lead_paragraph: It was another busy day at the United Nations Security Council meeting on Feb. 14, 2003. Another day of photographing in a controlled and very restrictive environment. My assignment was to look for a different kind of photograph — to make something interesting.

headline: What Does Santa Claus Mean to You?
abstract: Beyond the promise of receiving presents, why might it be worth believing in Santa Claus?
lead_paragraph: Some people think of Santa Claus as the spirit of generosity. Others believe he’s real, but they tend to have their own definition of “real” when it comes to jolly old St. Nick.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: After the Shootings
abstract: Monday: A city mourns, rain coming later, and the accused Columbia University rapist speaks out.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday morning to you. Rain is coming.

headline: Targeted Attack on New York Police Officers Reopens Wounds From the Militant 1970s
abstract: The shooting of two officers by a man who left messages of antipolice hatred recalled a grim period in the city’s history.
lead_paragraph: For some members of the New York Police Department, the ambush killing of two officers over the weekend roused memories of a far darker chapter in the department’s past, the 1970s, when violence on the streets and anger at the police erupted into the deliberate murder of some officers.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Year in Political Pictures
abstract: Here are some of our favorite political images of the year by the staff photographers Doug Mills and Stephen Crowley, and the interns Gabriella Demczuk and Jabin Botsford.
lead_paragraph: First Draft hasn’t been around all year, but our staff photographers in Washington have been around a lot longer. Like flies on a wall, they’ve expertly watched President Obama, the goings-on in Congress and all things Washington. Here are some of our favorite images of the year by Doug Mills and Stephen Crowley, and the interns Gabriella Demczuk and Jabin Botsford.

headline: Advertising on Smartphones Embraced in China
abstract: Companies are expected to spend more money on digital advertising next year than on TV commercials in China, which has 527 million smartphone users.
lead_paragraph: Liu Xuelong, a television and documentary producer in Beijing, hasn’t used his television in years. He gets all of his entertainment on his iPhone 6 Plus, where he also taps a plethora of apps to buy plane tickets, pay bills and talk with clients.

headline: Top Finance Employees in London Expect Bonuses to Be 21% Bigger
abstract: More than 80 percent of managing directors and partners at financial firms in London expect their annual bonuses to increase this year, to an average of about $194,749, according to a survey by the recruitment firm Astbury Marsden.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Despite recent curbs on bonus payments in Europe, senior employees of financial companies in London expect their bonuses for 2014 to be 21 percent higher than last year, according to the results of a survey by a recruiting firm released on Monday.

headline: Painkiller Abuse, a Cyclical Challenge
abstract: The current wave of problems caused by opioid drugs like OxyContin is the third in United States history. Balancing their risks and benefits has been a delicate task.
lead_paragraph: Even as the Food and Drug Administration approves new, powerful opioid-based painkillers, the United States is in the midst of an epidemic of opioid overuse. This is not the first time.

headline: Is This Any Way to Pick a Company Health Insurance Plan?
abstract: I used our 24-inch printer to print very large blow-ups of these grids, and then spread them out on my conference table. The printouts entirely covered a table 15 feet by 5 feet — a huge mess, but at least I could walk around the table and see all of the details in one place.
lead_paragraph: Having chosen to continue with my current insurance provider, Independence Blue Cross, and also to continue offering multiple plans for my employees, my next step was to choose which of the company’s 38 plans to offer. Independence’s multiplan option, called “Blue Solutions” allows me to choose any five from a subset of 26 of the company’s 38 plans. Because I had a bad experience with the plan that most of my employees chose last year, a high-deductible bronze plan with low premiums, I wanted to take a look at all 26 plans again and compare their features.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Dec. 22, 2014
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. A live discussion is offered from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Dec. 23, 2014

headline: Dutch Insurer Fined $27.9 Million and Ordered to Dismiss C.F.O.
abstract: Delta Lloyd said it planned to challenge the decision by the central bank, De Nederlandsche Bank, in court and that the remedial measures were “disproportionate” and “based on incorrect assumptions.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Dutch insurer Delta Lloyd said on Monday that the central bank of the Netherlands had fined it 22.8 million euros, or about $27.9 million, and ordered it to dismiss its chief financial officer by 2016 because of improper gains from interest-rate hedging.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: Jeh Johnson, the Homeland Security secretary, placed flowers at a memorial to the officers; President Obama is under pressure to address growing racial tensions after the fatal shootings of two New York City police officers.

headline: 1939: Pont St. Louis Falls Into Seine
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A bridge crashed into the Seine in 1939.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The 200-foot Pont St. Louis, the only connecting link between the Île de la Cité and the Île St. Louis, was knocked down yesterday at 2:05 p.m. by the thump of a 600-ton barge, the Tunisie, while twenty or thirty persons and an automobile were on it. Late last night police set the toll at three dead and seven injured. The bodies of the three persons were recovered early in the evening. Three persons were trapped in the automobile that went to the bottom of the river. In the history of Paris’s many bridges, the Pont St. Louis is believed to have been the most luckless. It had met destruction twice since the original span was built by the order of Marie de Medici in 1614. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Dec. 23, 1939

headline: Morning Agenda: Fresh Doubt Over A.I.G.’s Bailout
abstract: New documents raise troubling issues about the government’s actions in the 2008 bailout of A.I.G. | The chairman of Ocwen Financial will step down as part of a legal settlement, according to a report. | Wall Street scored its latest victory against financial regulation. | Why we need an insider trading statute.
lead_paragraph: FRESH DOUBT OVER A.I.G.’S BAILOUT | Documents produced after a trial over the 2008 bailout of the American International Group raise troubling new issues about the government’s actions in the rescue of the insurance giant, Gretchen Morgenson writes in the Fair Game column in The New York Times. The trove of material stems from a lawsuit brought by Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of A.I.G., who contends the bailout amounted to an improper seizure of private property under the Fifth Amendment. While Mr. Greenberg is not the most sympathetic figure, his fight has unearthed significant information, Ms. Morgenson writes.

headline: A Postcard from the Western Amazon, on Peril and Hope
abstract: A longtime resident of Brazil’s westernmost Amazon state reflects on forests, martyrs and the future.
lead_paragraph: Lou Gold, a fairly frequent guest here, recently sent some fresh reflections about his life in the western Amazon city of Rio Branco, Brazil. Gold is a self-described retired ancient-forest defender. He suggested I post his piece around the December anniversaries of the birth (the 15th) and assassination (the 22nd) of Chico Mendes, Brazil’s most famous rain forest defender, because, as Gold told me, “Even though it’s tough times for the forest, hope for the dream is still alive.”

headline: British Regulator to Oversee 7 Additional Financial Benchmarks
abstract: The move to oversee a benchmark rates for currencies as well as other rates follows the taking over last year of regulation of the London interbank offered rate, or Libor.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Financial Conduct Authority of Britain said on Monday that it would regulate seven additional financial benchmark rates in Britain beginning in April, including an important rate for foreign currency trading, as part of its new power to oversee previously unregulated rates.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Corporate Governance Watchdog to Examine Barclays’ Auditor
abstract: The Financial Reporting Council said that it would review PricewaterhouseCoopers’ role in reporting to British regulators on the bank’s compliance with client asset rules after Barclays was fined $58.9 million in September for failing to properly segregate client assets.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – A British corporate governance watchdog said on Monday that it had begun an investigation into the accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers’ auditing of Barclays after the British bank was fined this year for failing to properly segregate billions of pounds in client assets.

headline: Robert Mugabe Dismisses More Government Officials in Zimbabwe
abstract: Amid fears of political turmoil gripping southern Africa, a separate political feud in neighboring Zambia was reported to have been resolved.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a long-range purge, President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, traveling in Asia, ordered further dismissals of government ministers back home, pursuing a sweeping crackdown on perceived disloyalty, according to state news media on Monday.

headline: Credit Rating Agency DBRS to Be Sold to 2 Private Equity Firms
abstract: Walter Schroeder, the founder and controlling shareholder of DBRS, will retain a stake in the Toronto-based company.
lead_paragraph: DBRS, the largest credit rating company in Canada, will be sold to a group of investors led by the private equity firms Carlyle Group and Warburg Pincus.

headline: Ex-Cabinet Minister Wins Tunisian Presidential Runoff
abstract: Beji Caid Essebsi won 55.68 percent of the vote in the country’s first free and democratic balloting for the post, Tunisia’s election commission said.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Beji Caid Essebsi, an 88-year-old former cabinet minister, won Tunisia’s first free and democratic presidential election in a runoff, the country’s election commission announced Monday.

headline: The Daily Gift: A Canoe You Can See Through
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: Facebook Says Experiments Prove Ads on Its Site Can Spur Donations
abstract: But some of the processes the company used were opaque, so a number of questions remain unanswered.
lead_paragraph: Facebook conducted two experiments with Democratic Senate campaigns this year to see if advertisements on its site encouraged people to make political contributions.

headline: Sale of Morgan Stanley Oil Trading Business to Rosneft Is Aborted
abstract: The collapse of the sale of the trading unit is the latest energy-related deal to encounter difficulties after tensions arose between the West and Russia over Ukraine
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley and Rosneft said Monday that they were terminating the agreed sale of a large portion of Morgan Stanley’s oil trading business to the state-controlled Russian oil company.

headline: Woman Killed While Protesting Chinese Copper Mine in Myanmar
abstract: Villagers said the 56-year-old was shot by security forces as the police and Chinese employees of the mine erected a fence after land had been seized to expand the project.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A villager protesting the expansion of a Chinese copper mine in Myanmar was shot and killed on Monday, witnesses said, in the latest bout of violence to mar the project.

headline: American Apparel Confirms Buyout Offer
abstract: Shares of the company surge after it said it had received an overture to buy the company for $1.30 to $1.40 a share.
lead_paragraph: Shares of American Apparel surged in early trading on Monday after the company said it had received an overture to buy the company for $1.30 to $1.40 a share.

headline: Read This Before You Buy Another Holiday Gift (or Goat)
abstract: We cannot use seasonal charitable giving to put a fig leaf over the ways our passion for cheap clothes and toys contributes to the problems we try to help solve with our donations.
lead_paragraph: Part of me loves witnessing family conversations this time of year about giving goats to African farmers via organizations like Heifer International and Oxfam instead of flatscreen televisions to ourselves. Our love of stuff is cluttering our homes and minds and destroying our planet, and the world could always use a little redistribution of wealth.

headline: Supreme Court Justices Admit Inconsistency, and Embrace It
abstract: Justices Antonin Scalia and Ruth Bader Ginsburg have both acknowledged shifting positions in recent cases, and found an ally from the past.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There is an art to admitting mistakes on the Supreme Court. Justice Antonin Scalia demonstrated the proper technique in a dissent last week.

headline: T’s Top 10 Music Stories in 2014
abstract: These 10 stories showcase musicians and their style, both on stage and off.
lead_paragraph: These 10 stories showcase musicians and their style, both on stage and off. More…

headline: Before Setting New Goals, Evaluate the Previous Ones
abstract: Revisit the goals for 2014 to see what was effective and to avoid repeating mistakes.
lead_paragraph: Over the next few weeks, you’ll hear a lot about setting financial and other goals. I doubt I’ll be the first (or the last) to ask what goals you have in mind for 2015. Obviously, setting goals and wanting to improve our lives are good things. But by focusing our attention in only one direction — the future — we’re missing an opportunity.

headline: From The Upshot: The Social Campaign
abstract: Some of the processes the company used were opaque, so a number of questions remain unanswered.
lead_paragraph: Facebook Says Experiments Prove Ads on Its Site Can Spur Donations

headline: Ocwen Chairman to Step Down in Settlement With New York Regulator
abstract: After an investigation into conflicts of interest, William C. Erbey has agreed to step down from his position as chairman of Ocwen and four other related companies.
lead_paragraph: The mortgage industry had high hopes for Ocwen Financial. The company’s chairman, William C. Erbey, had years of experience servicing subprime loans and helping financially troubled borrowers.

headline: Former Milwaukee Police Officer Won’t Be Charged in Death of Black Man in Park
abstract: The Milwaukee district attorney found that the white officer, since fired, had acted in self-defense in the fatal April shooting.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — In a case that echoed growing tension over race and policing in other cities, a former Milwaukee police officer who fatally shot an African-American man this year will not face criminal charges, a prosecutor announced on Monday.

headline: Caesars Entertainment in Deal to Shore Up Finances
abstract: The all-stock deal to acquire a publicly traded affiliate will leave Caesars Entertainment with $1.7 billion in cash.
lead_paragraph: As parts of the Caesars gaming empire lumber toward bankruptcy, the parent company is shoring up its finances in a bid to avoid taking on even more debt.

headline: Why Cafeteria Food Is the Best
abstract: Many parents undoubtedly think they are doing the best for their children by having them bring lunch from home instead of eating the lunches served in school. But recent studies clearly prove them wrong.
lead_paragraph: Many parents undoubtedly think they are doing the best for their children by having them bring lunch from home instead of eating the lunches served in school. But recent studies clearly prove them wrong.

headline: Detoxing the Martha Stewart Way
abstract: The original lifestyle mogul introduces a book full of clean recipes, like this Japanese soup, just in time for the new year.
lead_paragraph: Long before the rise of Gwyneth Paltrow and the Hemsley sisters, the original lifestyle mogul, Martha Stewart, was peddling recipes and sharing tips for crafting a happy home. Now, Stewart and the editors of her multimedia empire are turning their attention to the healthy eating trend with a new cookbook and detox guide called “Clean Slate” ($26, Clarkson Potter). The bulk of the self-help-like section is old news — eat fiber, exercise, skip processed foods — but the recipes feel original and fresh, and arrive just in time for better eating habits in 2015.

headline: Rethinking the Relationship Between Bosses and Employees
abstract: I now have 110 employees, many of whom have been with me for more than 15 years — with an average tenure of nine years. But are they my friends?
lead_paragraph: Can bosses be friends with their employees? When I started my business at 22, I didn’t think about it. Since then, my opinion has been shaped and battered through 36 years of torture, disappointment, disbelief, inspiration, support and appreciation.

headline: When Should Your Workday Start?
abstract: A new study suggests work is cutting into our sleep. So should we start coming in later?
lead_paragraph: Are you tired? If so, help — or, at least, a proposal for help — may be on the way. A new study suggests our jobs are cutting into our sleep, and it’s prompting some to recommend that the American workday start a little later.

headline: A Culinary Tour of Cuba
abstract: A home for artisanal cheeses, Cassoulet Week, bacon bread and more food news.
lead_paragraph: To Learn: A Cook’s Tour of Cuba and Culture

headline: What 2,000 Calories Looks Like
abstract: Even as restaurants talk about smaller portions, they continue to serve a full day's worth of calories in a single meal — or even a single dish.
lead_paragraph: Even as restaurants talk about smaller portions, they continue to serve a full day's worth of calories in a single meal — or even a single dish.

headline: Aunt of Slain Brooklyn Officer Speaks
abstract: Lucy Ramos, the aunt of the slain New York City police officer Rafael Ramos, spoke during a news conference Sunday in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Lucy Ramos, the aunt of the slain New York City police officer Rafael Ramos, spoke during a news conference Sunday in Brooklyn.

headline: Pope Criticizes Vatican Bureaucracy
abstract: Pope Francis issued a harsh critique of the Vatican bureaucracy that served him during his Christmas greeting on Monday to cardinals, bishops and priests.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis issued a harsh critique of the Vatican bureaucracy that served him during his Christmas greeting on Monday to cardinals, bishops and priests.

headline: Cuban Athletes Cheer as Nations Drop Fists
abstract: As barriers with the United States are set to be lifted, boxers, baseball players and others see the potential for Cuba to embrace professional sports further.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Cuba — Fidel Castro and Hugo Chávez faced each other on giant posters above the boxing rings at Amistad Arena, suggesting a friendly round of socialist sparring between eternal comrades.

headline: Ed Fredkin and the Doctor’s Dilemma
abstract: Can you solve this pair of puzzles by the inventor and entrepreneur Ed Fredkin?
lead_paragraph: Happy Holidays to everyone! We have a couple of puzzles to celebrate the season — both from a recent afternoon with the inventor and entrepreneur Ed Fredkin. We’ll warm up with an energy puzzle featuring a classic Christmas gift, and then meet an individual blessed with the power to heal through touch. Let’s first jump aboard —

headline: 1889: The Frankfurter, in an Oblate Spheroid
abstract: An 1889 Times article suggested that Italian street vendors helped popularize the food (later the hot dog) after a municipal crackdown on hand organs forced the musicians to find new work.
lead_paragraph: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: A Dispute Over Portion Size at Olive Garden
abstract: A hedge fund that owns a stake in the parent company of the restaurant chain wants a shift toward smaller portions of better food.
lead_paragraph: When we set out to make the “What 2,000 Calories Looks Like” feature, we had some help in understanding Olive Garden: a detailed September PowerPoint presentation from a hedge fund that said the chain was mismanaged, and in particular has prioritized food quantity over quality.

headline: Foreign Bribery Cases That Can Drag On and On
abstract: An overseas bribery inquiry involving Avon shows how long winding such cases can be, and how the costs of dealing with potential corrupt payments can exceed the punishment, Peter J. Henning writes in White Collar Watch.
lead_paragraph: It is fitting to recall a quote attributed to the famous Chinese General Sun Tzu that the “wheels of justice grind slow but grind fine” as Avon finally resolved an investigation into payments and gifts provided to government officials in China – some six years after it began.

headline: In Struggle for National Identity, Iraqis Rally Around Many Flags
abstract: For the new government in Baghdad, promoting a new sense of national unity is a challenge as great as battling the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — At checkpoints across Baghdad, soldiers have defied a recent order from the prime minister to remove Shiite religious flags and replace them with Iraqi ones. At schools in the northern city of Kirkuk, students have raised Kurdish flags. And in the southern port city of Basra angry citizens have designed their own flag, anchored by the image of a single drop of oil.

headline: One-Legged Cycling
abstract: Can exercise change our DNA?
lead_paragraph: Can exercise change our DNA?

headline: Climate-Friendly Nuclear Energy
abstract: Nuclear energy could help stem climate change, but economic conditions aren’t favorable for many existing nuclear power plants.
lead_paragraph: Nuclear energy could help stem climate change, but economic conditions aren’t favorable for many existing nuclear power plants.

headline: Is Natural Gas Better?
abstract: Natural gas seems to be better for the environment than coal because of its reduced carbon emissions, but environmentalists say it may not be better after all.
lead_paragraph: Natural gas seems to be better for the environment than coal because of its reduced carbon emissions, but environmentalists say it may not be better after all.

headline: Farewell
abstract: A final word, in alphabetical order, to bid farewell to the Science Times podcast.
lead_paragraph: A final word, in alphabetical order, to bid farewell to the Science Times podcast.

headline: David Orr’s 10 Favorite Poetry Books of 2014
abstract: Books by Louise Glück, Fanny Howe, Christian Wiman and others.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to annual best-books lists, poetry is the cat that wandered into the dog show. No matter how much one tries, as The Times does, to include poets among the various biographers, essayists, novelists and so forth, it’s hard not to feel that poetry is fundamentally different from prose of any stripe. (Prose, said Coleridge, is “words in their best order,” whereas poetry is “the best words in their best order” — but then, Coleridge was a poet.) So here are 10 American poetry collections published in 2014 that I would recommend not only to poetry veterans, but to readers coming to the form with limited experience. In keeping with Times policy, this list includes no friends, lovers, babysitters or college roommates. (If I were allowed to include friends, my list would certainly include Maureen McLane’s “This Blue,” which was a finalist for the National Book Award.) In the interests of spreading the wealth, I’ve also generally favored work by poets I haven’t written about already.

headline: New York Theater Plans Live Reading of ‘The Interview’ Script
abstract: The Treehouse Theater said the live reading, with comedians from the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater, is “an opportunity for people to come together in the name of free speech.”
lead_paragraph: While Sony is deciding whether you’ll be able to see “The Interview” on movie screens, through video-on-demand services or perhaps not at all, an independent New York theater says that it will present a live reading of the script for that controversial Seth Rogen-James Franco comedy this weekend.

headline: The Flavor of Christmas in a Glass
abstract: Toasting holidays past and present with a cocktail of amaretto, Curaçao, bourbon and clementines.
lead_paragraph: Chestnuts roasting on an open fire are all fine and well, but to me, the most satisfying smells of Christmas are those of clementine peels and brown sugar, cinnamon and clove — along with the sharp sting of strong whiskey and a sweet waft of amaretto liqueur. (I love the fatty fragrance of a slowly cooking goose, too, but that’s hard to work into a drink, even though I imagine an inventive bartender in, say, Seattle, would happily give it a shot.)

headline: On the Night Before, a Prelude to Fun
abstract: Conjuring the anticipation of Christmas Eve with applejack, Scotch and a burst of effervescence on the tongue.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes I wonder whether holiday drinking traditions endure because the beverage in question has proved popular generation after generation, or because long ago people figured out that coming up with something new that’s as good is just too difficult.

headline: Francis Uses Christmas Speech to Criticize Vatican Bureaucracy
abstract: Francis criticized the administration that runs the Holy See for “ailments and temptations” like a narcissistic “pathology of power.”
