lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis excoriated the Vatican bureaucracy in his traditional Christmas address on Monday, saying that some of the cardinals, bishops and priests who run the Roman Catholic Church suffer from a “spiritual Alzheimer’s.”

headline: Alstom to Plead Guilty and Pay U.S. a $772 Million Fine in a Bribery Scheme
abstract: The French industrial company doled out more than $75 million in bribes to get $4 billion in contracts around the world, United States authorities said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The French industrial giant Alstom has agreed to plead guilty and pay a $772 million penalty to the United States in a bribery investigation by the Justice Department.

headline: De Blasio, With Bratton by Side, Seeks Balance After 2 Killings
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio visited the families of two New York City police officers who were killed and called for a break in protests as he sought to show leadership over a divided city.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, publicly silent and largely out of view the day after two police officers were killed in Brooklyn, re-emerged on Monday, straining to demonstrate leadership over a fractured city.

headline: The Best of 2014
abstract: Highlights from the year, as chosen by the editors of The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Highlights from the year, as chosen by the editors of The New York Times.

headline: The Secret History of Filing Cabinets
abstract: It’s about non-digital IT.
lead_paragraph: Vox has a nice article about the origins of the business cubicle, which includes a discussion of filing cabinets – which is fine as far as it goes. But there is actually quite a lot more to say, as you’d know if you’d read a wonderful book (with a rather drab title), Control Through Communication, written by my friend JoAnne Yates of MIT’s Sloan School.

headline: Investment Firm F-Squared to Pay $35 Million in Penalties Over Inaccurate Data
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission says the returns used in the firm’s marketing effort of a new strategy were hypothetical and inflated, in some cases by 350 percent.
lead_paragraph: F-Squared Investments, a fast-growing investment company, reached an agreement on Monday to pay $35 million in penalties to the Securities and Exchange Commission over allegations that it defrauded investors by providing inaccurate performance data.

headline: North Korea Loses Its Link to the Internet
abstract: While perhaps a coincidence, the failure, which lasted about 10 hours, began after President Obama said the U.S. would respond to an act of “cybervandalism” against Sony Pictures.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A strange thing happened to North Korea’s already tenuous link to the Internet on Monday: It failed.

headline: For Stanford Class of ’94, a Gender Gap More Powerful Than the Internet
abstract: How an industry devoted to overturning barriers let a gender gap stand unchallenged.
lead_paragraph: How an industry devoted to overturning barriers let a gender gap stand unchallenged.

headline: Dare to Dream of Falling Short
abstract: So much for the relentless “you can do it” attitude that pervades our culture. Apparently, being mindful of the real barriers that are placed in the way of your dreams is a far more effective way of achieving your goals.
lead_paragraph: Ever hear the joke about the guy who dreams of winning the lottery? After years of desperate fantasizing, he cries out for God’s help. Down from heaven comes God’s advice: “Would you buy a ticket already?!”

headline: Facebook Page Goes Dark, Angering Russia Dissidents
abstract: Members of the Russian political opposition said Facebook had capitulated to government pressure without consulting them.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A decision by Facebook to block a page used to rally Russian opponents of President Vladimir V. Putin has engulfed the world’s largest social networking site in political controversy and raised accusations that it censors content on behalf of the authorities here.

headline: Epiphany on a Kosovo Rooftop
abstract: Fred R. Conrad may be best known for his exquisite portraits, but an assignment in Kosovo taught him the value of watching and waiting for the story to come to him.
lead_paragraph: Kathy Ryan, the director of photography for The New York Times Magazine, sent me to Kosovo in June of 1999 to take a panoramic picture of a burned-out street that would be published over four pages. There was one proviso: Whatever ruins I decided to photograph had to reveal the horrors that had been inflicted upon its occupants.

headline: Restoring a Master’s Voice
abstract: We reflexively think of Ivan Pavlov as the man with the drooling dogs and clanging bell. But a century ago, he was pursuing a more ambitious agenda.
lead_paragraph: Training a dog to salivate at the sound of a bell would have seemed pretty stupid to Ivan Pavlov. He was after much bigger things.

headline: Last-Minute Gifts: Monthly Box Subscriptions for Children and Teenagers
abstract: Maybe the perfect gift is one that arrives later, in the form of a monthly delivery of books, geek toys, craft supplies or more.
lead_paragraph: A subscription is the gift that keeps on giving, and children (and teenagers and adults, too) still love getting their own mail (or UPS or FedEx delivery, as the case may be). Tempted as I am by these extra possibilities, I’m not buying one more nonnecessity until February. But if I were still shopping, these fun boxes suited to various ages and interests would be where I would turn.

headline: Russia’s Central Bank Acts to Save Trust Bank, a Failing Lender, With More Rescues Expected
abstract: The Russian government said it would inject $530 million into Trust Bank, a retail lender, and analysts predict more bailouts could follow.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia moved to prop up a failing lender on Monday in the country’s first retail bank bailout after the recent precipitous decline in the ruble.

headline: As Caesars Deals, a Showdown in Las Vegas Awaits
abstract: Bondholders in the casino company’s biggest unit back a bankruptcy that its parent’s merger with an affiliate could fund, says Quentin Webb of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: The ill-fated 2008 buyout of Caesars has pitted plenty of high finance’s high rollers against one another. Despite a couple of breakthroughs, Wall Street’s poker game over the casino company isn’t quite over.

headline: Joe Cocker Is Dead at 70; Raspy-Voiced Rock Star With Distinctive Moves
abstract: Mr. Cocker was known for his passionate, idiosyncratic takes on songs like the Beatles’ “With a Little Help From My Friends.”
lead_paragraph: Joe Cocker, the gravelly British singer who became one of pop’s most recognizable interpreters in the late 1960s and ’70s with passionate, idiosyncratic takes on songs like the Beatles’ “With a Little Help From My Friends,” died on Monday at his home in Crawford, Colo. He was 70.

headline: Anish Kapoor Chosen for Solo Show at Versailles
abstract: Mr. Kapoor, who was born in India and has lived in London for decades, is probably best known recently for his “ArcelorMittal Orbit” in Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park in London.
lead_paragraph: PARIS –The sculptor Anish Kapoor will be the next contemporary artist to be given a one-man show at the Château de Versailles. Mr. Kapoor’s show will run from June to October next year, the palace’s chief administrator, Catherine Pégard, said in an interview.

headline: Renée  Fleming to Star in ‘Living on Love’ on Broadway
abstract: Written by the Tony Award winner Joe DiPietro, “Living on Love” was first mounted at the Williamstown Theater Festival.
lead_paragraph: The Grammy Award-winning opera singer Renée Fleming will make her Broadway debut this spring in the new play “Living on Love,” a comedy about long-married artists that is based on Garson Kanin’s play “Peccadillo,” the producers announced on Monday.

headline: Turkey’s President Accuses Advocates of Birth Control of Being Traitors
abstract: The remarks by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan were the latest in a campaign to buttress what he sees as Turkey’s rightful place in the world.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — He has called women unequal to men. He has demanded that some high school students learn an Ottoman-era script scrapped nearly a century ago. Now, he has described birth control as treasonous.

headline: French Politics Served in a Pita
abstract: To the far right National Front, France’s most popular fast-food import from the East represents nothing less than a threat to the country’s identity.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — From the kitchen of the luxury Mandarin Oriental Hotel, the Michelin two-star chef Thierry Marx is waging a mini-campaign against culinary racism. He is making kebabs.

headline: Broncos-Bengals Preview: The N.F.L. Playoff Implications
abstract: The Bengals could miss the playoffs — or rise to be the A.F.C.'s second seed. The game also matters to the Ravens and the Patriots.
lead_paragraph: Tonight’s Bengals-Broncos game in Cincinnati will have a big influence on the A.F.C. playoff picture. We’ve been breaking down the playoff scenarios over the last couple of weeks — in words  and through our simulator — and we wanted to offer a quick overview of the implications of the game.

headline: Judge Orders Tax-Fraud Trial for Princess Cristina of Spain
abstract: The move was a blow to the monarchy and came in a case stemming mostly from the princess’s role in a company that she owned with her husband.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Princess Cristina of Spain was ordered on Monday to stand trial on tax fraud charges, a blow to the hopes of Spain’s royal household to limit the damage to the monarchy’s reputation from a continuing corruption case.

headline: Party Opens an Inquiry Into a Onetime Aide to China’s Ex-Leader
abstract: President Xi Jinping’s anticorruption campaign cast a wider net by focusing on a sitting official who was a trusted associate of the former President Hu Jintao.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Communist Party has begun an investigation of a top aide to former President Hu Jintao, demonstrating the lengths to which President Xi Jinping is willing to go in his campaign to root out official corruption in China.

headline: Do Aliens Know It’s Christmas?
abstract: As the possibilities for life elsewhere seem to expand with the universe, astronomers and theologians ponder how new discoveries may alter our notions of spirituality.
lead_paragraph: A star appeared in the East.

headline: Official Says Shooting Was Justified
abstract: The Milwaukee district attorney, John T. Chisholm, said that a former police officer, Christopher Manney, who fatally shot an unarmed black man, Dontre Hamilton, would not be charged in the episode.
lead_paragraph: The Milwaukee district attorney, John T. Chisholm, said that a former police officer, Christopher Manney, who fatally shot an unarmed black man, Dontre Hamilton, would not be charged in the episode.

headline: How E-books May Disrupt Your Sleep
abstract: Planning to read in bed tonight? It may be better to read from a printed book instead of an e-book reader.
lead_paragraph: Planning to read in bed tonight? It may be better to read an actual book instead of an e-book reader. A small study has found that reading light-emitting electronic devices before bedtime is a recipe for poor sleep.

headline: Poland Suspends Inquiry Into a Former Vatican Envoy
abstract: The investigation of Jozef Wesolowski, accused of abusing boys in the Dominican Republic, was halted because Dominican investigators had not responded to requests for evidence.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Poland has suspended an investigation into the Polish-born former Vatican ambassador, Archbishop Jozef Wesolowski, who has been accused of sexually abusing boys while serving in the Dominican Republic.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
abstract: Food news for the holidays.
lead_paragraph: It’s worth taking a look back at 2014 and the food politics that got the country talking (and voting): Mexico passed a tax on soda and in a historic vote Berkeley opted to follow suit; the midterm elections saw minimum wage hikes pass in five states and protests for fair pay for fast food workers in dozens more; GMO labeling initiatives made it onto multiple state ballots; and the USDA finally agreed to ban junk food in school cafeterias, to name just a few food issues that moved forward this year.

headline: Rep. Michael Grimm Is Said to Agree to Tax Fraud Guilty Plea
abstract: A guilty plea by Mr. Grimm, a Republican from Staten Island who has steadfastly maintained his innocence, would almost certainly put him under tremendous pressure to resign.
lead_paragraph: Representative Michael G. Grimm, a Republican from Staten Island who was easily re-elected to his third term in Congress last month despite a pending federal indictment, has agreed to plead guilty to a single felony charge of tax fraud, according to three people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: 1964: Neater Offices in White House
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: White House staff was promised new quarters in 1964.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Johnson intends to start off his new administration by remodeling and redecorating the west wing office area of the White House. Assistant White House press secretary Malcolm Kilduff said the facelifting will not include the president’s Oval Office. He reported that the rest of the west wing, which contains the press quarters and White House staff working area, will likely be remodeled and outfitted with new furniture. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Dec. 23, 1964

headline: Living With Cancer: Playing the C Card
abstract: After the diagnosis, cancer can serve many purposes — an excuse for ice cream, a motivation to go fly-fishing, a reason to not do just about anything.
lead_paragraph: If you are dealt a crummy hand, you might find yourself playing the cancer card — even if other people object. I’ve come to believe that in certain cases, I not only could but should play the C card.

headline: De Blasio on Slain Police Officers
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York spoke about the killing of two police officers on Saturday at the Police Athletic League’s December luncheon on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York spoke about the killing of two police officers on Saturday at the Police Athletic League’s December luncheon on Monday.

headline: How a Cuban Spy and His Wife Came to Be Expectant Parents
abstract: By practicing “sperm diplomacy,” a Senate staffer became a central facilitator of the Cuba shift.
lead_paragraph: It was no easy feat to get a vial of frozen sperm from Gerardo Hernández, a Cuban spy serving two life sentences in California, to Panama, where his wife, desperate to have a baby, was artificially inseminated.

headline: Freud Gets Marathon Reading Treatment
abstract: Writers, philosophers and veterans will gather to read from “Civilization and Its Discontents,” a work the organizers called “the definitive text on human destructiveness.”
lead_paragraph: Sigmund Freud’s “Civilization and Its Discontents” will become the latest work to get the marathon reading treatment, when writers, philosophers, psychoanalysts, Iraq war veterans and others gather at Judson Memorial Church in New York City on Jan. 3 to recite what the organizers described as “the definitive text on human destructiveness.”

headline: The Danger of Going Off Course
abstract: Why is it important to take the full course of antibiotics even if you start to feel better?
lead_paragraph: Q. WHY IS IT NECESSARY TO TAKE ALL

headline: For Bronx Building Workers, Even a Small Tip Can Be Substantial
abstract: Gratuities might be hard to come by at the holidays, but not gratitude.
lead_paragraph: With its gilded beamed ceilings, white stucco walls and Moorish tiled floors, the lobby of 975 Walton Avenue would fit right in on the streets of Andalusia or the Upper West Side. The heavy steel doors and flickering fluorescent lights give away that the building stands on a busy block in Highbridge, not far from Yankee Stadium in the Bronx.

headline: Robot Leads a Six-Legged Race for Knowledge
abstract: Researchers have modeled a robot on a stick insect and named it Hector.
lead_paragraph: With six legs, elastic joints and a long, articulated body, Hector is the first robot modeled on a stick insect. Hector has learned to walk, bringing his creators one step closer to understanding six-legged locomotion. The trick, researchers at Bielefeld University in Germany say, is getting all parts of Hector’s ultralight body to communicate with one another so the robot never has too many legs in the air at one time.

headline: Easter Eggs Without a Kit
abstract: Tinamous produce glossy, spectacular eggs in colors like sky blue, lime green and rich chocolate. How do they do it?
lead_paragraph: When it comes to shell color, most birds’ eggs conform to one of four motifs: colored with spots, colored without spots, white with spots or pure white.

headline: Sony Emails, Free Speech — and Trying a Little ‘F2F’
abstract: A look at some of the questions and the strong opinions that have emerged since the so-called Guardians of Peace made its massive cyberattack on Sony.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere in academia, an enterprising law professor is putting together a lecture on the hacked Sony emails, considering the legal and free-speech issues they raise.

headline: That Old PlayStation Can Aid Science
abstract: Gaurav Khanna built a supercomputer at the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth physics department using 200 PlayStation 3 consoles.
lead_paragraph: This spring, Gaurav Khanna noticed that the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth physics department was more crowded than usual. Why, he wondered, were so many students suddenly so interested in science?

headline: Goldman Sells Aluminum Subsidiary
abstract: Goldman Sachs has sold an aluminum warehouse subsidiary that drew criticism to a European private equity firm, Reuben Brothers.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs has sold an aluminum warehouse subsidiary that drew criticism to a European private equity firm, Reuben Brothers.

headline: A Big Week, and a Big Year, for ‘The Lion King’ on Broadway
abstract: The long-running Broadway hit cleared the $2 million mark at the box office last week, and is set to be the year’s top-selling show, ahead of “Wicked.”
lead_paragraph: The long-running Broadway hit “The Lion King” cleared the $2 million mark at the box office last week — the only show to do so out of 36 running — another big number for a musical that will stand as the top-grossing show of the year when 2014 concludes. According to box-office data released on Monday, “The Lion King” grossed $2,200,409, beating another durable blockbuster, “Wicked,” which took in $1,986,719.

headline: For Heroin Users, Less May Reduce Immune Cells
abstract: A study shows that in a year, those who used heroin only intermittently lost more CD4 blood cells than those who did not use it. Regular users had a slightly higher CD4 count.
lead_paragraph: Occasional heroin use may be worse for the immune system than continual heroin use, according to a new study.

headline: Looking Fabulous at 40, and Still Happy to Step on a Few Toes
abstract: The all-male troupe Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo continues to shine in the second program of its anniversary season in its home city.
lead_paragraph: At the Joyce Theater on Thursday, a Russian-accented voice announced the absence of Natalia Notgudinov, among other changes in the program, but also said that all the ballerinas were in “very, very good moods.”

headline: Group Sues Aetna, Claiming Discrimination Against H.I.V. Patients
abstract: Consumer Watchdog says a new policy requiring patients to obtain drugs by mail order violates the federal health care law.
lead_paragraph: A consumer group has sued the health insurer Aetna, claiming that it discriminated against patients with H.I.V. when it required them to obtain medications exclusively through its own mail-order pharmacy.

headline: The Great Carnivores of Europe
abstract: Big carnivores are making a comeback in Europe without the aid of wildlife preserves, suggesting the animals are better at adapting to life with humans than once suspected.
lead_paragraph: Big carnivores such as brown bears and wolves are making a comeback in Europe without the aid of wildlife preserves, suggesting the animals are better at adapting to life with humans than once suspected, a new study has found.

headline: Big Whiners. Now, Back to the Kids.
abstract: Reality television shows featuring children often end up being a showcase for difficult parents.
lead_paragraph: Proposed New Year’s resolution: Enough already with young children on reality television shows. Oops; too late. “Friday Night Tykes” has already sent out its Season 2 premiere for review.

headline: Crows’ Bad Reputation Is Put to the Test
abstract: Western culture has never been kind to corvids, from Poe’s raven to Rossini’s thieving magpie. But, a study has found, the birds are not as dangerous as their reputation suggests.
lead_paragraph: Western culture has never been kind to corvids, from Poe’s raven to Rossini’s thieving magpie. And lately, neither has South Africa, which has been using poison to eradicate crows that are considered a threat to other species.

headline: Losing Bits of Ourselves
abstract: A letter to the editor.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Flavors From the Past
abstract: A letter to the Editor.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Pakistan Fast Tracks Execution of Militants
abstract: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif issued an order amid clamor for a tough response to the Taliban attack on a school that left 148 people dead.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif directed his top legal officer on Monday to fast-track the execution of militants on Pakistan’s death row, amid a continuing public clamor for a tough response to last week’s Taliban attack on a school in Peshawar.

headline: Albums From Jesse Stacken and Norberto Lobo
abstract: The year’s final days are a good time for critics to run a dragnet for what they missed.
lead_paragraph: JESSE STACKEN

headline: Putin Critic’s Final Speech at Trial
abstract: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny gave a powerful closing speech at his trial.
lead_paragraph: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny gave a powerful closing speech at his trial.

headline: Most Effective Protest: Vote
abstract: Steve Sandell, a reader, writes that an increase in voter registration would provide “a change in the narrative.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: E-Cigarettes in China
abstract: Neil W. Schluger of the World Lung Foundation calls for strict regulation in the United States.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Performance | Danielle de Niese
abstract: The lyric soprano Danielle de Niese sings the Bach-Gounod “Ave Maria,” which she will perform on Christmas Eve at the midnight mass at St. Patrick’s Cathedral.
lead_paragraph: The lyric soprano Danielle de Niese sings the Bach-Gounod “Ave Maria,” which she will perform on Christmas Eve at the midnight mass at St. Patrick’s Cathedral.

headline: Pint-Size Activities With an Adult Twist
abstract: Child-friendly activities are getting a slightly grown-up spin at hotels from Chicago to Saint Lucia.
lead_paragraph: Child-friendly activities are getting a slightly grown-up spin at hotels from Chicago to Saint Lucia.

headline: Love, Whimsy and Intrigue in the Strings Section
abstract: “Mozart in the Jungle,” Amazon’s newest streaming series, is a backstage story about a sexy New York conductor and the classical musicians around him.
lead_paragraph: For Amazon, “Transparent” was a little like the 1968 New York Jets of the upstart American Football League, the surprise winners of Super Bowl III. After Netflix scored the first two big victories in the original-digital game with “House of Cards” and “Orange Is the New Black,” Amazon (in this metaphor, the A.F.L.) turned the tables with “Transparent,” one of the best-reviewed series of the year, when it appeared in September.

headline: As Royal Pal, a Highfalutin Tub of Guts
abstract: Antony Sher is Falstaff in the Royal Shakespeare production of the two parts of “Henry IV” now underway in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A lust for wine, women and mischief are the hallmarks of Falstaff, one of Shakespeare’s greatest characters. All these outsize appetites shine through Antony Sher’s marvelous performance of the role in the Royal Shakespeare Company production of the two parts of “Henry IV,” here at the Barbican Theater.

headline: Nuclear: Carbon Free, but Not Free of Unease
abstract: Advocates continue to argue that reactors make sense in a world fighting climate change, but the industry is sagging.
lead_paragraph: Next week, if all goes as planned, the 42-year-old nuclear reactor at the Vermont Yankee generating station will be shut down for the last time. The steam turbine at the plant, which at its peak could make enough electricity for about half a million homes with virtually no greenhouse gas emissions, will grind to a halt.

headline: Once Upon a Midnight Blurry
abstract: Nearly half a century ago, Leonard Freed photographed a Madison Avenue holiday party where ties were loosened, and so were inhibitions.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half a century ago, Leonard Freed photographed a Madison Avenue holiday party where ties were loosened, and so were inhibitions.

headline: Mystery in a Mormon Community
abstract: A woman finds her suspicions confirmed in “The Bishop’s Wife,” by Mette Ivie Harrison.
lead_paragraph: Linda Wallheim, the title character of “The Bishop’s Wife,” doesn’t hold an official position. Her husband, Kurt, has two. He is nominally an accountant, and one of the book’s kind gestures is to mention this only in passing. But he spends most of his time as the bishop of a Mormon ward in Draper, Utah. He officiates, delivers sermons and listens in confidence to the ward (or congregation) members’ most closely held secrets. Sometimes he even asks for Linda’s help.

headline: Directors’ Letter Protests Firing of Theater J’s Artistic Director
abstract: About 60 theater directors have signed a letter protesting the firing of Ari Roth as artistic director of Theater J in Washington.
lead_paragraph: The leaders of about 60 theaters have signed a letter protesting the firing of Ari Roth as artistic director of Theater J in Washington.

headline: Hacking Reality: When Art Imitates Technology
abstract: The filmmaker Michael Mann’s “Blackhat,” due out in January, has echoes of the Sony hacking incident that led to the cancellation of a movie, “The Interview.”
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif. — At a critical moment in Michael Mann’s cyberthriller, “Blackhat,” a naïve security guard slips a young woman’s thumb drive into his corporate computer.

headline: A Director Holds Up a Mirror to Turkey
abstract: “Winter Sleep” is the latest film from the Turkish director Nuri Bilge Ceylan, who makes movies that explore themes like morality and class.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — “Winter Sleep,” the deeply felt new film by the Turkish director Nuri Bilge Ceylan, took the top prize at this year’s Cannes Film Festival and has been hailed by critics, who say it cements his place as one of the most important auteurs working today.

headline: Natural Gas: Abundance of Supply and Debate
abstract: Depending on one’s point of view, natural gas is either an essential tool to meet the challenge of climate change, or another dirty fossil fuel.
lead_paragraph: MEAD, Colo. — Natural gas is the Rorschach test of energy policy. Depending on one’s point of view, it can be either an essential tool for meeting the challenge of climate change or another dirty fossil fuel that will speed the planet down the path to calamitous warming.

headline: On the Community College Beat: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: The reporter Ginia Bellafante provides a look at the story behind the stories that make up her three-part series on community colleges.
lead_paragraph: “Raising Ambitions: The Challenge in Teaching at Community Colleges,” the final article in Ginia Bellafante’s series about community colleges, ran in the paper this weekend.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
abstract: Pakistan and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Pakistan and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: In Interfaith Homes, Dealing With the ‘December Dilemma’
abstract: With Hanukkah in the homestretch and Christmas approaching, Jewish readers talk about their first Christmas trees and balancing traditions.
lead_paragraph: Two people meet. They fall in love. Big questions come up. Move in together? Do you want children? Big questions are answered. Life flows on.

headline: Pictures of the Day — Dec. 22, 2014
abstract: Photos from Pakistan, Israel, Spain and Cuba.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Pakistan, Israel, Spain and Cuba.

headline: Union Leaders Attacked at Bangladesh Garment Factories, Investigations Show
abstract: In response to the assaults, two major apparel companies are ending or suspending orders with the Azim Group, which owns the two factories where they occurred.
lead_paragraph: The garment factory’s closed-circuit camera captured some unusual activity: Out front a female union leader was swarmed by people, pushed to the ground and assaulted while a male union activist was chased away and punched.

headline: Fracking’s Big Backer
abstract: While natural gas prices are down, Southwestern Energy and its chief executive, Steve Mueller, are betting big on hydraulic fracturing. Virtually no one is following their lead.
lead_paragraph: While natural gas prices are down, Southwestern Energy and its chief executive, Steve Mueller, are betting big on hydraulic fracturing. Virtually no one is following their lead.

headline: Soaring: View From the Cockpit
abstract: The view from the cockpit as a seasoned pilot and a passenger experience soaring, also called gliding, at Sundance Aviation in Moriarty, N.M.​
lead_paragraph: The view from the cockpit as a seasoned pilot and a passenger experience soaring, also called gliding, at Sundance Aviation in Moriarty, N.M.​

headline: Finding Serenity in a Ride on the Wind
abstract: Dr. Michael Graves, the sole urologist covering an area of at least a half-dozen counties in Texas, counteracts the long hours spent in the operating room by soaring in a lightweight glider, thousands of feet above the landscape.
lead_paragraph: PLAINVIEW, Tex. — They call this part of the world the giant side of Texas, just under the panhandle, where the crunchy brown fields and watercolor skies seem endless, with the occasional cluster of pine trees standing as conspicuously as skyscrapers.

headline: 11 Women, Seven Seas and One Point to Make
abstract: SCA is the fifth all-female team to compete in the 40-year history of the around-the-world event, but it is notably not affiliated with a men’s team.
lead_paragraph: In June 2002, the British sailor Abby Seager stepped off a 60-foot sailboat she had just raced around the world in the Volvo Ocean Race, hoping to have paved the way for professional women’s ocean racing.

headline: Columbia Journalism School to Scrutinize Rolling Stone Rape Article
abstract: The magazine has asked the Columbia University School of Journalism to conduct an independent review of an article about an alleged gang rape at the University of Virginia.
lead_paragraph: Rolling Stone magazine said Monday that it had asked the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism to conduct a review of a widely disputed article about a gang rape at the University of Virginia.

headline: Sugar Season. It’s Everywhere, and Addictive.
abstract: The sweet craving that once offered a survival advantage now works against us.
lead_paragraph: YOUR co-worker brought in brownies, your daughter made cookies for a holiday party and candy is arriving from far-flung relatives. Sugar is everywhere. It is celebration, it is festivity, it is love.

headline: Udo Jürgens, Austrian Singer and Songwriter, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Jürgens, known as the Frank Sinatra of Europe, sold more than 100 million records over five decades.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Udo Jürgens, an Austrian-born singer and songwriter who became known as Europe’s Frank Sinatra as he helped define postwar popular music in the German-speaking world, died on Sunday in Gottlieben, Switzerland. He was 80.

headline: Natural Gas Glut Isn’t Deterring Southwestern Energy
abstract: Southwestern, the No. 4 domestic producer of natural gas, is developing over 400,000 acres of reserves in the shale fields of West Virginia and Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: WONDERVIEW, Ark. — Across the giant Fayetteville shale gas field here, country roads that were clogged by truck traffic just a few years ago are empty again. Once aglow at night from the bright lights twinkling on drilling rigs, the roads are now dark under the starry Arkansas sky.

headline: Moody’s Lowers the Metropolitan Opera’s Credit Rating
abstract: The Met’s decision to once again use its Chagall murals as collateral for loans was one factor cited in the ratings downgrade, the latest evidence of the group’s financial travails.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera’s decision to once again use its monumental Chagall murals as collateral for loans was one of the factors Moody’s Investors Service cited on Monday when it downgraded the company’s credit rating, noting the company’s “weakened financial profile.”

headline: C.D.C. Head Says Fight on Ebola Will Be Long
abstract: Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, back from a weeklong trip to West Africa, said he saw hopeful signs in Guinea and Liberia, but there was ample reason for continued concern.
lead_paragraph: There are reasons for both hope and continued worry about the Ebola epidemic in West Africa, Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said on Monday.

headline: Poll Finds Mixed Views on Obama’s Handling of Cuba
abstract: While most Americans approve of the decision to restore diplomatic and trade ties with Cuba, attitudes toward President Obama’s handling of relations with Cuba are mixed, according to the latest CBS News poll.
lead_paragraph: While most Americans approve of President Obama’s decision to restore diplomatic and trade ties with Cuba, attitudes toward his handling of relations with Cuba are mixed, according to the latest CBS News poll.

headline: Yellen’s First Year at Fed: A Remarkably Steady Course
abstract: Though Janet L. Yellen’s approach at the Federal Reserve has hewed closely to her predecessor’s, central bank officials and outside experts expect changes next year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In her first speech as chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, Janet L. Yellen told the stories of three people looking for work.

headline: The Real Threat to Hillary Clinton: Jim Webb
abstract: It’s Jim Webb, not Elizabeth Warren.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE conventional wisdom is that Hillary Rodham Clinton will be almost impossible to dislodge from the Democratic presidential nomination and that even if she does encounter some hiccups, they will come from her left flank on economic policy. But if Mrs. Clinton runs, she may face a serious and very different threat: her own foreign policy record. While she can pretty much split the difference with any primary opponents on economic policy, the divisions over foreign affairs could be a lot harder to paper over for Mrs. Clinton, who has been tacking to the right on Iran, Syria and Russia in anticipation of Republican assaults during the general election.

headline: Labor Ruling Could Allow More Faculty to Unionize
abstract: The National Labor Relations Board has issued a broad ruling that could potentially bolster organized labor on campuses at a time when unions are pushing to represent the growing number of adjunct professors.
lead_paragraph: The National Labor Relations Board has issued a broad ruling that could open the way for more faculty members to join unions at private colleges and universities, a decision that could potentially bolster organized labor on campuses at a time when unions are pushing to represent the growing number of adjunct professors.

headline: Taliban Push Into Afghan Districts That U.S. Had Secured
abstract: Just four years after the American troop surge, a sustained fighting effort by the Taliban has put parts of southern Afghanistan back under direct threat.
lead_paragraph: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan — In a large swath of the Taliban heartland in southern Afghanistan, government centers are facing a long-dormant concern this winter: Four years after the American troop surge helped make such places relatively secure, they are back under threat from the insurgents.

headline: BMW Joins in Expansion of Takata Airbag Recalls
abstract: BMW joined four other automakers in making nationwide recalls, saying it would replace airbags in 140,000 3 Series vehicles,
lead_paragraph: On Monday BMW became the latest automaker to cede to pressure from federal regulators to expand nationwide a recall of airbags made by the Takata Corporation that may be at risk of rupturing.

headline: Bowe Bergdahl’s Disciplinary Fate Placed in Hands of Army General
abstract: Gen. Mark Milley will decide if Sergeant Bergdahl should be court-martialed and what, if any, charges will be filed against him.
lead_paragraph: The fate of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl now rests with a four-star Army general at Fort Bragg, N.C., who will decide whether the soldier, who disappeared from his tiny Army outpost in rugged eastern Afghanistan in 2009, should be court-martialed and what, if any, charges will be filed against him.

headline: A Newspaper for Injured Civil War Vets
abstract: December 1864 saw the first issue of The Soldier’s Friend, which would exclusively serve disabled and wounded Union veterans.

headline: Argentine City Takes Beauty Off Its Pedestal
abstract: The City Council in Chivilcoy, Argentina, has banned beauty pageants after it decided that the nation’s unwavering expectations for female beauty were out of control.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Argentina’s obsession with certain standards of female beauty has contributed to some of the world’s highest rates of eating disorders among women. Attention to female beauty is so prevalent here that a former Miss Argentina trying to maintain her youthful appearance recently died of complications from plastic surgery intended to make her buttocks firmer.

headline: For Frequent Flier Mileage Runs, Time Is Running Out
abstract: As they focus on travelers who produce the most revenue, airlines are making it difficult for frequent fliers to accumulate miles cheaply at year-end.
lead_paragraph: IT’S the end of the year, and some posts on air-travel forums sound desperate. “Need 1,500 miles this weekend,” says one notice on FlyerTalk.com. “I need 1,820 miles to make Platinum next year,” proclaims another on Milepoint.com.

headline: No Guns for Christmas
abstract: Based on two police shootings in Ohio, this short documentary questions whether toy guns can really be innocent gifts.
lead_paragraph: Based on two police shootings in Ohio, this short documentary questions whether toy guns can really be innocent gifts.

headline: ‘No Guns for Christmas’
abstract: Based on two police shootings in Ohio, this short documentary questions whether toy guns can really be innocent gifts.
lead_paragraph: As Christmas approaches, children across the nation are asking Santa for toy guns. But after two recent shootings in our home state of Ohio, toy guns no longer seem so innocent.

headline: Tiny Airport Fights for Sliver of Atlanta Market
abstract: Paulding Northwest, which is about 50 miles from the giant Hartsfield-Jackson Airport, has applied for a commercial license to introduce two flights a week.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS, Ga. — Airports do not get much smaller than Silver Comet Field at Paulding Northwest Atlanta Airport, where an undeveloped two-lane road weaves to a church-quiet setting framed by small hills.

headline: On This Trip, It’s Seatbelts Off for Safety
abstract: An excursion to a stone quarry in Italy involves winding roads and a cliff, but riders had to be prepared to take a leap in case of an accident.
lead_paragraph: I FEEL fortunate that my business travel allows me the opportunity to see the world and find inspiration in new locales, but airports and I don’t get along. Yet considering how much I am required to travel for business, it’s a relationship to which I have resigned myself. As senior vice president for design and construction with Brookfield Office Properties most of my business travel involves assessing continuing and future projects, as well as materials.

headline: Why Should Toys Come in Pink and Blue?
abstract: Can more inclusive marketing of toys  break down gender roles and expand options of what's fun and acceptable for children?

headline: Liberia: Soccer Star Leads Senate Race
abstract: The former soccer star George Weah appeared to have won a landslide victory in a Senate race that pitted him against the president’s son, Robert Sirleaf.
lead_paragraph: The former soccer star George Weah appears to have won a landslide victory in a Senate race that pitted him against the president’s son, Robert Sirleaf. Mr. Weah won 79.7 percent of the vote in Montserrado County, which includes the capital, Monrovia, while Mr. Sirleaf received 11.2 percent, according to provisional results released Monday. Mr. Sirleaf said he would not challenge the official results. The elections on Saturday were the first in the region since the recent Ebola outbreak. Only 27.9 percent of all registered voters turned out to vote. More results will be released Wednesday, and the final results will be released in January.

headline: No Longer Anonymous: Gravedigger Gets His Due at a Psychiatric Hospital
abstract: Willard State Psychiatric Hospital in upstate New York will permit a memorial in the name of the man who dug more than 1,500 graves for his fellow patients.
lead_paragraph: Over several decades, an immigrant dug more than 1,500 graves for his fellow patients at Willard State Psychiatric Hospital in upstate New York. He took pride in his shovel’s precision. And when he died in 1968, he joined them in anonymity, his grave — like all the others — marked not with a surname on a headstone but by a numbered stake.

headline: Facing Cancer and Financial Burdens, an Immigrant Finds Aid
abstract: Beata Bien, who emigrated from Poland in 1993, was abandoned by her boyfriend after she learned she was pregnant. Then she learned that she had cancer and that there were people who could help.
lead_paragraph: Sunlight and the sound of traffic from Fort Hamilton Parkway streamed through the windows of Beata Bien’s second-floor studio apartment on a recent morning in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. The rays illuminated the tears in her green eyes and the pink Hello Kitty decorations adorning the small room.

headline: Qatar Suspends News Channel Critical of Egyptian Government
abstract: The shutdown of the channel, an Egyptian affiliate of the Qatari-owned Al Jazeera network, is also a blow to what remains of the Muslim Brotherhood.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Bowing to pressure from its neighbors, Qatar is suspending its broadcast of a satellite news channel sharply critical of Egypt’s military-led government.

headline: Joe Cocker Was the Master of the Beatles Cover
abstract: Joe Cocker was also the only performer who successfully covered and even improved on The Beatles.
lead_paragraph: There are so many reasons to mark the passing of the great Joe Cocker – as many songs as he wrote, recorded and performed in his remarkable concerts. For me, Cocker was also the only performer who successfully covered and even improved on The Beatles.

headline: Obama Administration to Investigate Insurers for Bias Against Costly Conditions
abstract: The administration said it had become aware of “discriminatory benefit designs” that discouraged people from enrolling because of age or medical condition.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Monday that it would investigate prescription drug coverage and other benefits offered by health insurance companies to see if they discriminated against people with AIDS, mental illness, diabetes or other costly chronic conditions.

headline: Chrysler Says Not All Jeeps in Recall Will Be Repaired
abstract: The automaker told federal regulators that vehicles too damaged for a planned safety fix, intended to prevent fires in the event of collisions, would go unrepaired.
lead_paragraph: Chrysler has told federal safety regulators that it would not help thousands of consumers whose recalled Jeeps were too rusty to be fixed for a fire hazard, even though regulators have said that the failure to do so would be a “great concern.”

headline: The Slaying of 2 Officers in Brooklyn
abstract: Readers discuss the accusations and reactions that followed the killings.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Neglected Server Provided Entry for JPMorgan Hackers
abstract: The weak spot at JPMorgan appears to have been a fairly simple two-step password system that was neglected.
lead_paragraph: The computer breach at JPMorgan Chase this summer — the largest intrusion of an American bank to date — might have been thwarted if the bank had installed a simple security fix to an overlooked server in its vast network, said people who have been briefed on internal and outside investigations into the attack.

headline: Financial Start-Ups Aim to Court the Anti-Finance Crowd
abstract: Financial start-ups re trying to reach younger and middle-class Americans by upending the customary fee structure.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Profit is usually a top priority on Wall Street, but some of the latest ventures into finance by start-ups seem to be inspired more by Karl Marx than John Pierpont Morgan.

headline: The Subtle Sensations of Faith
abstract: The experience of faith is properly understood as an ever-evolving longing rooted in an experience, large or small, of the transcendent.
lead_paragraph: With Hanukkah coming to an end, Christmas days away, and people taking time off work, we are in a season of quickened faith. When you watch people exercise that faith, whether lighting candles or attending Midnight Mass, the first thing you see is how surprising it is. You’d think faith would be a simple holding of belief, or a confidence in things unseen, but, in real life, faith is unpredictable and ever-changing.

headline: Mitch McConnell’s New Senate Goal: Turn Republican Dial to Yes
abstract: The incoming majority leader acknowledges it will be challenging to change the mind-set of a caucus whose opposition to the president he was instrumental in leading.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As he prepares to guide Republicans out of the wilderness of the Senate minority, Senator Mitch McConnell, the incoming majority leader, knows his real problem is not corralling mavericks in his party like Senator Ted Cruz. It is persuading other Senate Republicans conditioned to voting no that it is time to vote yes.

headline: A Window Onto Evolving Traditions in Paris
abstract: The Christmas window displays at Paris’s main department stores have bent obligingly with the years, reflecting a creeping — sometimes jarring — fusion of popular and consumer culture.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Crouched precariously amid cascades of fishing line, behind a drum kit dusted with iridescent artificial snow, Jean-Claude Dehix ministered patiently to a rebellious marionette, oblivious to the businessman on the other side of the plate glass window who was taking a last, lazy drag of his morning cigarette.

headline: Cliff Sloan, Guantánamo Envoy, Quits Amid Delays in Prisoner Releases
abstract: Mr. Sloan, the envoy who negotiates detainee transfers from the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, is resigning, dealing another blow to efforts to close the facility.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department envoy who negotiates detainee transfers from the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, is resigning, dealing another blow to President Obama’s efforts to close a facility that top administration officials say is a blight on the country’s international standing.

headline: Odell Beckham Jr.’s Meteoric Rise Offers Tom Coughlin Chance to Mentor
abstract: Through the good and the bad, the Giants’ coach was trying to teach his star wide receiver to “do things the right way.”
lead_paragraph: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin knows Odell Beckham Jr. is a special talent. But as a seasoned 68-year-old coach, he wants to be sure that his rookie 22-year-old wide receiver does not exhibit behavior that tarnishes his rising star.

headline: Christmas Holiday Closings in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut
abstract: Transit schedules, parking rules and various closings that will take effect on Christmas.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: I.R.S. to Auction Off Annuity From Darryl Strawberry’s Mets Days
abstract: To pay off tax debts, a minimum bid of $550,000 has been set for the right to receive the remaining payments of $1.28 million from a contract extension signed in 1985.
lead_paragraph: In 1985, when Darryl Strawberry’s career appeared to have no bounds, he signed a contract extension with the Mets. A portion of the estimated $7 million deal was deferred, paid out monthly over 30 years after the end of his career.

headline: Mr. de Blasio’s Call for Harmony
abstract: The murder of two policemen in Brooklyn has inflamed rifts between the police and Mayor Bill de Blasio and between the police and the public.
lead_paragraph: First, do no harm. That principle applies to those who command the public’s attention at this moment of heightened tension in New York City.

headline: After Botched Execution, Oklahoma Is to Resume Lethal Injections
abstract: A federal judge ruled that the use of the sedative midazolam did not amount to an experiment on human subjects.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Oklahoma City on Monday said that the state can resume executing prisoners this winter, rejecting the argument by some medical experts that using the same sedative involved in the bungled execution of Clayton D. Lockett in April amounted to an illegal experiment on human subjects.

headline: United Nations Security Council Examines North Korea’s Human Rights
abstract: North Korea chose not to speak at the Council briefing, which focused largely on a United Nations inquiry that had found widespread and systematic human rights abuses.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations Security Council for the first time turned its attention to human rights in North Korea on Monday, as Pyongyang and Washington traded accusations over a hacking attack against a Hollywood studio, and North Korea’s already limited connection to the Internet went down completely.

headline: FreshDirect Breaks Ground in the South Bronx, Prompting Protests
abstract: The online grocer plans to offer hundreds of new jobs, but opponents say the increased truck traffic will worsen the air quality in an area with high asthma rates.
lead_paragraph: In what has become a familiar scene across New York City, more than three dozen protesters chanted and waved cardboard cutouts of raised fists in the South Bronx on Monday.

headline: Pakistan’s Baffling Response to Extremism
abstract: Two days after a massacre at a school, a court granted bail to a militant accused of orchestrating the 2008 Mumbai terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: Despite the grief and rage that followed the massacre of 148 students and their teachers by Taliban militants at an army-run school in Peshawar last week, Pakistan persists in its duplicitous and self-defeating response to the extremism that is threatening the country. Immediately after the attack, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif promised that Pakistan would no longer distinguish between the “bad” Pakistani Taliban, which is seeking to bring down the Pakistani state, and other “good” Taliban groups that for years have been supported or exploited by Pakistan’s Army and intelligence service to attack India and wield influence in Afghanistan. What his words should mean is that Pakistan will no longer tolerate any extremists. But initial indications are not promising.

headline: Shale and the Falling Price of Oil
abstract: With global oil prices falling and falling some more, the Saudis don’t want a repeat of 2008.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago, the price of oil went on an incredible roller-coaster ride. In January 2008, oil hovered around $90 a barrel. By July, it had reached $147 a barrel. By the end of the year, it had plunged to under $35 a barrel.

headline: In New York, Miami Coach Jim Larranaga Returns to Roots
abstract: Larranaga, a former Providence star, coached against the Friars and lost on Monday at Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: After firing Coach Tim Welsh at the end of the 2008 season, Providence College offered the job to Jim Larranaga. It seemed like a perfect match. Larranaga was a former Providence star and a 1971 graduate who was two years removed from leading George Mason to an improbable berth in the Final Four.

headline: Helping New Team, but Giving Biggest Assists to Her Family
abstract: Daisha Simmons’s transfer from Alabama was welcome news for Seton Hall and especially for her mother, Christena, and her older brother Chaz.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J. — During the past few weeks, Christena Simmons’s jobs as a postal carrier and a Target employee have reached peak demand.

headline: Storied Locale
abstract: The return of Bruce Haight.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — As fairy tales go, “JACK and the BEANSTALK” was never one of my favorites, what with all the blood and the scary GIANT and, most of all, the height. I am terrified of heights, and the thought of anyone climbing higher than bar-stool height makes me dizzy.

headline: Gunman May Have Used Garner and Brown Cases to Justify Police Killings, Experts Say
abstract: Like most people who assault uniformed officers, experts said, Ismaaiyl Brinsley was most likely a social misfit with a longstanding grudge against authority in general, and the police in particular.
lead_paragraph: The portrait of Ismaaiyl Brinsley — the 28-year-old man who the authorities say fatally shot two New York police officers last weekend, before killing himself — is still being filled out. But the facts that have surfaced so far, experts say, suggest that he was neither a political activist nor a psychotic madman.

headline: At New York Police Department Funerals, Politics, Grief and Shifting Traditions
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio said he would attend the funerals of Officers Rafael Ramos and Wenjian Liu, whose backgrounds diverge from the New York Police Department’s Irish and Italian roots.
lead_paragraph: The rumble of motorcycles, the faraway sounds of bagpipers, a hearse carrying a coffin covered with a flag. Helicopters passing in a “missing man” formation, leaving a gap of open sky to symbolize a lost life.

headline: Billie Whitelaw, Longtime Beckett Muse, Dies at 82
abstract: Ms. Whitelaw, an English actress, first encountered Samuel Beckett’s work at the National Theater in London in 1964.
lead_paragraph: Billie Whitelaw, the English actress who became both acolyte and muse to the playwright Samuel Beckett and one of the foremost interpreters of his austere and deeply unsettling work, died on Sunday in London. She was 82.

headline: After Suing, Tenant Comes Home to the Brooklyn Apartment She Was Made to Leave
abstract: Tranquilina Alvillar returned to 193 Bedford Avenue in Williamsburg on Monday, after being ordered to vacate in 2011 and her subsequent lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: Tranquilina Alvillar stepped out of the truck and onto the curb at Bedford Avenue in Williamsburg just after 9 a.m. on Monday, carrying a Bible and wearing two scarves.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 22, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Worst Knicks Team Ever? That’s Saying a Lot
abstract: This year’s team, at 5-25, could surpass the club’s previous worst season mark of 21-59, set by the 1962-63 Knicks.
lead_paragraph: When you’re a bad team, you might as well be astonishingly bad. If the Knicks were, say, 13-17 at the moment, they would simply be meandering through the current N.B.A. season, going nowhere in particular. They would be neither terrible nor good, nor overly interesting.

headline: Larry Smith, Hip-Hop Producer, Dies at 63
abstract: Mr. Smith’s work with the pioneering group Run-DMC pushed hip-hop out of disco’s orbit with a signature recorded sound and helped move it closer to the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Larry Smith, a record producer who in the early and mid-1980s helped give hip-hop arena ambitions through his work with the pioneering group Run-DMC, died on Friday in Flushing, Queens. He was 63.

headline: Jets Seem to Prepare for a Potential Overhaul
abstract: The potential hiring of a consultant by the team owner Woody Johnson does not bode well for Coach Rex Ryan, and perhaps General Manager John Idzik as well.
lead_paragraph: The final week of the Jets’ season began with the clearest indication yet that it could also be the final week of Coach Rex Ryan’s tenure — and perhaps General Manager John Idzik’s as well.

headline: Conflict Coverage Proves Deadly Job for Journalists
abstract: In its annual report, the Committee to Protect Journalists said that Syria remained the world’s deadliest country for journalists for the third consecutive year.
lead_paragraph: Journalists who were killed in 2014 because of their work included an unusually high proportion of foreign correspondents who had been covering conflicts in the Middle East, Ukraine and Afghanistan, a leading news media advocacy group said in an annual report released Tuesday.

headline: Word of the Day | tarry
abstract: This word has appeared in 12 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: tarry •\ˈter-e, ˈta-re\• verb

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: NOON (AMC) THE NATIVITY STORY (2006) Keisha Castle-Hughes, who at 13 received a best actress Oscar nomination for “Whale Rider,” plays Mary, a Nazareth teenager turned wife and expectant mother. Oscar Isaac (“Inside Llewyn Davis”) is Joseph, her husband in an arranged marriage. Catherine Hardwicke (“Thirteen”) directed this biblical adaptation from a script by Mike Rich. “Rather than trying to reinterpret or modernize a well-known, cherished story, the filmmakers have rendered it with a quiet, unassuming professionalism,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Taxi Ride in Xinjiang Reveals Ethnic Strains
abstract: A ride with an ethnic Han Chinese woman in the city of Karamay was a reminder of the frictions that have accompanied the economic drive in the oil-rich region of Xinjiang.
lead_paragraph: In “On the Silk Road, Oil and Tensions,” The New York Times video journalist Jonah M. Kessel explores the ethnic tensions amid the energy abundance of Xinjiang. Below, he describes an encounter during his journey.

headline: China to Send Its First Infantry Troops to U.N. Mission in South Sudan
abstract: The move is widely seen as a sign of greater Chinese commitment to United Nations peacekeeping efforts and of Beijing’s wishes to step up protection of its commercial interests in the country.
lead_paragraph: China’s first infantry contribution to a United Nations peacekeeping force will depart for South Sudan in January, the state news media has reported.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 23, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “The identity issue — getting an identity that all Iraqis can agree on so the state stays together — is serious. This is a struggle for a new vision of Iraq.”

headline: Corrections: December 23, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, December 23, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Test Yourself | Cat Cafes
abstract: Here are the first seven paragraphs from a Dec. 15 article, “To Spur Adoptions, an Oakland Cafe Puts Cats Among the Patrons.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are the first seven paragraphs from a Dec. 15 article, “To Spur Adoptions, an Oakland Cafe Puts Cats Among the Patrons.”

headline: Cargill Abandons Pursuit of Dutch Animal Feed Supplier Nutreco
abstract: The decision by Cargill removes a rival to a $3.65 billion bid by SHV Holdings of the Netherlands for Nutreco, a Dutch supplier of feed for livestock and fish farms.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The American food and agriculture giant Cargill said on Monday that it was abandoning its pursuit of Nutreco, the Dutch supplier of feed for livestock and fish farms, removing a rival to SHV Holdings’ proposed acquisition of Nutreco.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Facebook Angers Russian Opposition by Blocking Protest Page
abstract: Does Facebook have a responsibility to protect First Amendment rights in other countries like Russia?
lead_paragraph: In “Facebook Angers Russian Opposition by Blocking Protest Page,” Andrew Roth reports on Russia’s attempts to censor social media content.

headline: Do You Look Forward to New Year’s Eve?
abstract: Do you feel society puts too much pressure on everyone to have an amazing night?
lead_paragraph: How do you view the end of one year and the beginning of another? Do you celebrate with friends or family? Do you go to parties, or play it low key at home? And how do you see the new year itself — as an opportunity for new beginnings and resolutions, or just a change in digits from 14 to 15?

headline: Once Upon a Midnight Blurry
abstract: Nearly half a century ago, Leonard Freed photographed a Madison Avenue holiday party where ties were loosened, and so were inhibitions.
lead_paragraph: Inside some retirement villa rec room, a few 80-something New York transplants are being serenaded for the umpteenth time with “Grandma Got Run Over by a Reindeer.” Maybe they’re wearing ugly sweaters, sipping alcohol-free eggnog and tapping their toes. And maybe they’re daydreaming about that one special Christmas in 1966 …

headline: Tibetan Woman Dies After Setting Herself on Fire in China
abstract: The death brought to 135 the number of Tibetans who have set themselves ablaze since 2009 to protest what many regard as government intrusion.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A Tibetan woman died on Monday after setting herself on fire, the latest in a string of self-immolations protesting Chinese rule, according to Tibetan exile and advocacy groups.

headline: My Christmas Visitors
abstract: The best present of all, of course, is the presence of other souls.
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE LAKES, Me. — Of all the unexpected visitors my family received over the holidays, there was probably no soul more unlikely than Vietnam Santa. Forty years ago, my parents and sister had gone out one night just before Christmas, leaving me alone. I was 16, and I’d managed to make some unfortunate decisions, winding up goofy on a cocktail I’d invented that contained equal measures of Virginia Gentleman bourbon and orange Hi-C. Also, I had invited over a girl I barely knew, who’d arrived intending to make out with me but who had instead passed out in a guest room on the third floor.

headline: The Hemiparasite Season
abstract: There are more than 1,300 species of mistletoe, some tropical.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Mistletoe. The word conjures winter holidays, office parties, stolen kisses, romance. But appreciation of the plant is no modern thing. Kissing under the mistletoe has been happening for at least 200 years. And some 2,000 years ago, the druids in what is now Britain venerated the plant when it grew on an oak. When they found it, they dressed in white, harvested it with a golden sickle, and sacrificed two white bulls. Or so says that great Roman, Pliny the Elder, in his “Natural History.” The druids — Pliny continues — believed that mistletoe could make barren animals fecund, and that it was an antidote to all poisons.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: Subway Etiquette Offenders
abstract: Tuesday: tell us your subway pet peeves, warm and rainy weather, and the mayor calls for calm.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this soggy Tuesday.

headline: 1889: Total Eclipse of the Sun
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Astronomers watched a solar eclipse in 1889.
lead_paragraph: LOANDA — Between eleven o’clock yesterday morning and half-past two in the afternoon [Dec. 22] the total eclipse of the sun was eagerly watched by the United States expedition of astronomers, which had arrived here on board the Pensacola for that purpose. The weather was clear during the first part of the eclipse, but the sky was obscured about the time of the totality. The atmospheric conditions varied very much during the eclipse phenomena, but the results were not disappointing. The direct view photoheliograph of 40-foot focus proved an entire success, and the equatorial mounting for it worked very satisfactorily. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Dec. 24, 1889

headline: Happy Holidays
abstract: The blog will be on vacation through Jan. 4, but we’ve left you with lots to do.
lead_paragraph: Merry Christmas, happy Hanukkah, joyous Kwanzaa and happy New Year.

headline: After Leak, Madonna Offers Show of Force
abstract: The singer shows she remains a force to be reckoned with by releasing six songs from her coming album in response to an online leak.
lead_paragraph: In some circles, the six saddest words in the English language may be: “Don’t you know who I am?” Often the answer is an ego-crushing “no.” So when Madonna names a song “Bitch I’m Madonna” — and books Nicki Minaj to add praise — well, no one knows better than she does that celebrity is Darwinian.

headline: Daily Report: Simple Flaw Allowed JPMorgan Computer Breach
abstract: The weak spot at JPMorgan appears to have been a fairly simple two-step password system that was neglected, leading to a major security breach this summer.
lead_paragraph: The computer breach at JPMorgan Chase this summer — the largest intrusion of an American bank to date — might have been thwarted if the bank had installed a simple security fix to an overlooked server in its vast network, said people who have been briefed on internal and outside investigations into the attack, Matthew Goldstein, Nicole Perlroth and Michael Corkery report.

headline: Ex-Official and Property Tycoon Are Sentenced in Hong Kong Graft Case
abstract: The former No. 2 official in the city government and a real estate mogul were given terms of seven and a half years and five years in prison.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The former second-highest ranking official in the Hong Kong government and a property tycoon were sentenced on Tuesday to seven and a half years and five years in prison after their convictions in a high-profile corruption case.

headline: So Long, From You’re the Boss
abstract: After five years, this is the final post on You’re the Boss. As a parting gift, we offer some highlights from another year spent in the trenches, where we all continued to make mistakes and learn lessons.
lead_paragraph: For the past five years, it’s been my pleasure to edit the You’re the Boss small-business blog, which has afforded me the opportunity to work with a talented array of journalists and business owners. The journalists covered their beats diligently, the owners shared their ups and downs generously, and we all benefited from the comments offered by an exceedingly smart group of readers.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio faces a political crisis over the fatal shooting of two police officers by an African-American man.

headline: How Losing a Job Can Be Bad for Your Health
abstract: Previous studies have found a link between high unemployment and improved health indicators, like weight loss. But that may be changing.
lead_paragraph: Being out of work can be advantageous for people’s physical health. Unemployed people have more time to exercise and cook at home, and less money to buy cigarettes or junk food. Studies in the United States and Europe over the years have found that when unemployment is high, people lose weight and become healthier and overall mortality rates drop.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Morning Agenda: How Hackers Got Into JPMorgan
abstract: The computer breach at JPMorgan Chase might have been prevented with a simple security fix. | Financial start-ups are trying to reach an anti-finance crowd. | After a settlement, Ocwen will remain on a tight regulatory leash. | F-Squared Investments was fined over accusations it defrauded investors.
lead_paragraph: HOW HACKERS GOT INTO JPMORGAN | The giant computer breach at JPMorgan Chase this summer might have been prevented if the bank had installed a simple security fix to an overlooked server in its network, Matthew Goldstein, Nicole Perlroth and Michael Corkery report in DealBook. While JPMorgan spends $250 million a year on computer security, the weak spot in this case was very basic, according to people who have been briefed on internal and outside investigations into the attack.

headline: In Performance: Danielle de Niese Sings ‘Ave Maria’
abstract: The soprano Danielle de Niese sings the Bach-Gounod setting of “Ave Maria,” which she will perform on Christmas Eve at St. Patrick’s Cathedral.
lead_paragraph: Danielle de Niese, a soprano who weds diva glamor to pop star chic, just finished a run as Susanna in Mozart’s “Le Nozze di Figaro” at the Metropolitan Opera and is preparing to sing at another New York institution: she is scheduled to appear Christmas Eve at midnight mass at St. Patrick’s Cathedral. Perhaps with that in mind, she chose to sing some sacred music here: the Bach-Gounod setting of “Ave Maria.” But Ms. de Niese, who has an operatic family — her husband, Gus Christie, is chairman of the Glyndebourne Festival in Britain — will be back on secular opera stages soon. The Met’s new production of Lehar’s “The Merry Widow” opens New Year’s Eve, and Ms. de Niese will join its cast in April singing the role of Valencienne.

headline: Tricky Little Things
abstract: Questions about where to put hyphens may seem trivial, even pedantic. But small errors can distract readers who should be focused on the substance of our reporting.
lead_paragraph: PLEASE NOTE: After Deadline will be on vacation for the next two weeks, returning on Tuesday, Jan. 13.

headline: Two Rounds Fail to Elect a President in Greece
abstract: The voting will either enable the coalition government of the prime minister to remain in power or lead to a snap general election and new political and financial upheaval.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The Greek Parliament failed on Tuesday to elect a new president in the second of three rounds of voting that will either enable the coalition government of Prime Minister Antonis Samaras to remain in power or lead to a general election and new political and financial upheaval.

headline: A Gender Gap More Powerful Than the Internet
abstract: Instead of narrowing gender gaps, the technology industry created vast new ones for Stanford University’s pioneering class of 1994.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — In the history of American higher education, it is hard to top the luck and timing of the Stanford class of 1994, whose members arrived on campus barely aware of what an email was, and yet grew up to help teach the rest of the planet to shop, send money, find love and navigate an ever-expanding online universe.

headline: TripAdvisor Fined $610,000 in Italy for Failing to Prevent Fake Reviews
abstract: The American company, which allows travelers to rate hotels and restaurants around the world, said it would appeal the decision by the Italian competition watchdog.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — TripAdvisor, the travel review website, has gotten a bad comment from the Italian competition authorities.

headline: France Puts More Troops on Streets After a String of Attacks
abstract: Security officials say they have not established any direct links between the assaults, which have reinforced concerns about Islamic militancy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — After a string of attacks across France that has heightened concerns about Islamic militancy, Prime Minister Manuel Valls said on Tuesday that hundreds of additional military personnel would be ordered onto the streets to reinforce a routine deployment of security forces.

headline: Facing Uphill Struggle for Sponsors, U.S. Skiers Lead a Crowdfunding Trend
abstract: The U.S. Ski and Snowboard Association and other national sports federations have teamed up with a crowdfunding site, but not everyone likes the idea.
lead_paragraph: Keri Herman is one of the best female freestyle skiers in the world. She is ranked No. 1 in slopestyle and fifth over all in the Association of Freeskiing Professionals. At 32, she believes that she is still in the prime of her career.

headline: The Daily Gift: Wine for the Year
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: Dear Santa, Bring Back the Old New York
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A Christmas wish for the old Schrafft’s, the Pan Am Building, opera without the subtitles and a quiet, uncrowded St. Patrick’s.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: What 5 Percent Means
abstract: About that Obama economy.
lead_paragraph: OK, that was a seriously impressive GDP report — 5 percent growth rate, and it’s all final demand rather than an inventory bounce. But what does it mean?

headline: Wall Street Blocks the Light
abstract: An overhaul of the Freedom of Information Act did not survive the legislative deal-making that produced the spending plan. William D. Cohan laments that loss in the Street Scene column.
lead_paragraph: Lost in all the recent hoopla about how Wall Street used its substantial political muscle this month to water down the laws and regulations intended to keep us safe from its bad behavior as part of the spending plan known as Cromnibus is the sad story of how the Street somehow was also able to kill another bill it did not like: the revised version of what was generally known as the FOIA Improvement Act of 2014.

headline: Dear Santa, Please Bring Daddy
abstract: This year, my husband will return from his predeployment work-ups to spend Christmas with us, and my daughter will get her wish. Next year, there will be nothing even Santa can do.
lead_paragraph: Standing on top of the 10-foot ladder, just higher than the “do not go above this step” label, I said a silent prayer that I wouldn’t fall and break my neck during nap time.

headline: Commies Like Me
abstract: What we’ve learned from macroeconomic debate.
lead_paragraph: I’ll leave this to Noah Smith. I’ll just say that the past five-plus years of macroeconomic debate have been a learning experience. But not so much about economics — I didn’t see the crisis coming, but post-crisis macroeconomics has actually worked pretty much the way I expected and predicted. (Yes, deflation is surprisingly hard to achieve, but I took that on board early.)

headline: T’s Top 10 Interiors Featured in 2014
abstract: These 10 interiors inspire envy, wanderlust and joy, from Virginia and Connecticut to Tuscany and Tangier.
lead_paragraph: These 10 interiors inspire envy, wanderlust and joy, from Virginia and Connecticut to Tuscany and Tangier. More…

headline: Economic Vital Signs in 3rd Quarter Were Strongest in a Decade
abstract: The Commerce Department revised its summer growth figures to 5 percent, bolstered by robust spending by businesses and consumers.
lead_paragraph: The American economy grew last quarter at its fastest rate in over a decade, providing the strongest evidence to date that the recovery is finally gaining sustained power more than five years after it began.

headline: Family Protests After Its Tradition of Installing Crèche at the Met Is Halted
abstract: For decades, Loretta Hines Howard and her descendants helped install the Nativity scene at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, but the museum has told them their services are no longer needed.
lead_paragraph: All is not calm in the little Baroque town of Bethlehem at the base of the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Christmas tree.

headline: R.B.S. to Hold Bonuses for 18 as Part of Currency Trading Review
abstract: The lender has been reviewing the conduct of more than 50 current and former traders.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Tuesday that it was holding payment of a unvested portion of bonuses to 18 current and former employees until it completes an internal review of its foreign currency trading operations.

headline: When Officers Die and Protests Get the Blame
abstract: Some officials have linked Ismaaiyl Brinsley’s killings of two N.Y.P.D. officers to protests against police violence. But others say this linkage misunderstands Mr. Brinsley and the protests.
lead_paragraph: In the days after Ismaaiyl Brinsley’s killings of two New York Police Department officers and the shooting of a Baltimore woman, some in positions of authority have linked the crimes to protests against police violence. But others believe this linkage misunderstands both Mr. Brinsley and the protests — and that such misunderstanding could have serious consequences.

headline: Nothing Non-Gold Can Stay
abstract: It’s hard to be FDR.
lead_paragraph: David Beckworth has a good post pointing out that the Fed has been signaling all along that the big expansion in the monetary base is a temporary measure, to be withdrawn when the economy improves. And he argues that this vitiates the effectiveness of quantitative easing, citing many others with the same view. My only small peeve is that you might not realize from his list that I made this point sixteen years ago, which I think lets me claim dibs. Yes, I’m turning into one of those crotchety old economists who says in response to anything, “It’s trivial, it’s wrong, and I said it decades ago.”

headline: In Israel, Antitrust Regulator Reviews Natural Gas Development
abstract: Officials expressed concerns that Noble Energy, a Houston-based company, and its partners have a monopoly on the sector.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Israel’s fledgling natural gas industry was rattled on Tuesday over a threat by the country’s antitrust regulator to break an American-Israeli group’s hold on the country’s gas resources.

headline: In Ocean Races, Some of the Biggest Perils Can’t Be Seen
