lead_paragraph: In the 1960s and 1970s, the Cuban government brutally repressed sexual minorities, but in the last seven years there has been an evolution of rights for people who identify as L.G.B.T. This transformation was led by Mariela Castro, a straight woman who is the daughter of the current president, Raúl Castro.

headline: 1914: Royal Navy Stages Joint Sea and Air Strike on Cuxhaven
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The British waged a raid on the German coast on Christmas eve, 1914.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The latest despatches which have come to hand concerning the British naval raid on the German fleet off Cuxhaven show that it was an eminently satisfactory exploit, carefully thought out and arranged weeks before, and brilliantly executed.

headline: The Obama Bounce
abstract: Not a boom, but some good stuff is happening.
lead_paragraph: Dean Baker is, of course, right: this is not a boom, and comparisons to the 1990s are insane. Still, growth has clearly picked up, and the public seems to be noticing. So what can we say about the Obama non-boom?

headline: Scores Are Stranded as Ferry Catches Fire Off Greek Coast
abstract: Rescuers battled rough seas to reach the stricken ferry that caught fire off the northwestern coast of Greece on its way to Italy.
lead_paragraph: VERBANIA, Italy — Italian, Greek and Albanian vessels battled gale-force winds and rough seas early Monday as they struggled to rescue hundreds of passengers stranded on a ferry that caught fire on Sunday off the northwestern coast of Greece en route to Italy.

headline: Moscow on the Brazos
abstract: Shale boom, shale slump.
lead_paragraph: OK, not really. But falling oil prices will have very different effects on different regions of the United States, with those states that have benefited most from the shale boom hurt a lot even as most Americans gain.

headline: ‘Unbroken’ Starts Strong, but Furry-Footed Hobbits Still Rule Box Office
abstract: Seven major new films opened in a varying number of theaters on Christmas Day, and by Sunday very different Hollywood camps were celebrating. “Unbroken” was an unexpected hit, while “Into the Woods” found a broad audience. But no newcomer could topple “The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies.”
lead_paragraph: Seven major films opened in a varying number of theaters on Christmas Day, and by Sunday very different Hollywood camps were celebrating. Angelina Jolie’s war drama “Unbroken” was an unexpected hit. Disney’s adaptation of the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical “Into the Woods” found a broad audience. And Clint Eastwood’s “American Sniper,” arriving in just four theaters, delivered eye-popping returns. But no newcomer could topple the furry-footed creatures from Middle-earth.

headline: Maybe This Will Make Mom Proud
abstract: In his solo show, the comedian Brad Zimmerman draws on his long climb to the stage.
lead_paragraph: Brad Zimmerman may well have brought many of us a salad or a mac and cheese once. Now, in “My Son the Waiter: A Jewish Tragedy,” he brings us the story of his failure, and it’s pretty delicious. As Mr. Zimmerman admits, a typical proud mom might brag about her son vacationing in the Caribbean or buying a big, new house; his mother has to tell her friends, “If all goes well, Brad is buying a bookcase.”

headline: ‘The Interview’ Brings In $15 Million on Web
abstract: Sony did not say how much of that total represented $6 digital rentals versus $15 sales.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “The Interview” generated roughly $15 million in online sales and rentals during its first four days of availability, Sony Pictures said on Sunday.

headline: Bratton’s Unsought Role: Peacemaker Between His Officers and His Boss
abstract: William J. Bratton, the New York City police commissioner, criticized the actions of scores of officers who turned their backs on Mayor Bill de Blasio at one point during a slain officer’s funeral.
lead_paragraph: When William J. Bratton returned to lead the New York Police Department for the second time in two decades, the once headline-grabbing commissioner seemed determined to adopt a lower profile.

headline: Two Flights Go Missing, but Their Stories Are Not the Same
abstract: AirAsia Flight 8501 disappeared in the same part of the world as Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 but differs in important ways.
lead_paragraph: Indonesia AirAsia Flight 8501, an Airbus A320 airliner carrying 162 people, disappeared from radar screens early Sunday, about 40 minutes after leaving the Indonesian city of Surabaya en route to Singapore. A full day of searching the relatively shallow waters off the coast of Borneo has so far yielded no sign of the aircraft, raising a familiar mix of uncertainty and grief just nine months after Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 disappeared shortly after takeoff from Kuala Lumpur. Though Flight 8501 disappeared in a similar part of the world, it involves a different airline and a different type of aircraft.

headline: In Haiti, Battling Disease With Open-Air Clinics
abstract: Two new clinics in Haiti for treating cholera and tuberculosis could be models for other struggling countries that lack resources for high-end Western-style hospitals.
lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — The pictures of medical dysfunction were devastating — broken hospitals in Africa struggling, and largely failing, to contain the Ebola epidemic. As deaths mounted, the problems seemed intractable: no money, no infrastructure, no hope.

headline: Jets Finish on Note That Raises Question: Where Has This Been?
abstract: Stellar performances by quarterback Geno Smith and wide receiver Eric Decker gave the Jets a convincing win in what could have been Coach Rex Ryan’s last game.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Picture a hypothetical general manager candidate, whoever it may be. He flips on the Jets’ game at some point on Sunday to evaluate the disparate crop of talent on a team that had won only three times before.

headline: After Giants Display Mistakes of Past, Focus Shifts to Coach Tom Coughlin’s Future
abstract: A spectacular touchdown by Odell Beckham Jr. was not enough to help the Giants, who finished the season at 6-10, overcome a surging Philadelphia offense.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Tom Coughlin’s 11th season as the Giants’ coach ended Sunday with the same unsavory 6-10 record that he had in his first year leading the team. It is also the Giants’ worst record since Coughlin’s inaugural 2004 season.

headline: Israel Wins World Mind Games’ Open Teams Final
abstract: At the fourth SportAccord World Mind Games in Beijing, the 48-board final of the open teams was between Israel and the United States.
lead_paragraph: At the fourth SportAccord World Mind Games in Beijing, the 48-board final of the open teams was between Israel (Alon Birman, Dror Padon, Lotan Fisher, Ron Schwartz and the brothers Ilan and Ophir Herbst) and the United States (Huub Bertens, Curtis Cheek, Vincent Demuy, John Kranyak, Justin Lall and Roger Lee).

headline: Whether Working or Job Seeking, the Algorithm Is Watching
abstract: Two forthcoming books explore how companies use employee-scoring systems to rate job applicants and employees alike.
lead_paragraph: Are you perusing LinkedIn at work more than usual?

headline: Saucy Newcomers, Graying Punk Rockers
abstract: Cabaret is alive, stirring up excitement and receiving transfusions — thanks to young newcomers and old rockers — but no one can honestly say it’s in great health.
lead_paragraph: Descending the staircase into 54 Below, the raffish, speakeasylike cabaret in the basement of the notorious disco Studio 54, you feel a stir of excitement. The audience, made up largely of Broadway professionals, music-theater fans and tourists, is typically so revved up that you might imagine that cabaret, the struggling stepchild of musical theater and first cousin of jazz, is enjoying a renaissance. Where else can Broadway babies shed their theatrical roles and strut their stuff as soloists singing whatever they choose?

headline: The Scent of an Actor, Lauded and Holding Court
abstract: The actor Jake Gyllenhaal promoted his new film, “Nightcrawler,” at an industry event in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: A colleague emerged from the Toronto International Film Festival in September highly annoyed that Jake Gyllenhaal’s creepy sang-froid performance in Dan Gilroy’s “Nightcrawler” was not generating lots of awards buzz.

headline: Final Warning
abstract: Kim Jong-un of North Korea has already taken the new year hostage.
lead_paragraph: Kim Jong-un of North Korea has already taken the new year hostage.

headline: United Arab Emirates Ban ‘Exodus’ Movie
abstract: The United Arab Emirates have become the third country to ban Ridley Scott’s $140 million film about the biblical story of Moses leading the Jews out of Egypt.
lead_paragraph: The United Arab Emirates have become the third country to ban “Exodus: Gods and Kings,” Ridley Scott’s $140 million film about the biblical story of Moses leading the Jews out of Egypt. The decision was made because of the film’s “many mistakes not only about Islam but other religions, too,” Juma Obeid Al Leem, director of media content tracking at the National Media Council, told the English-language newspaper The Gulf News. The announcement came on the heels of announcements that the film would not be shown in Morocco and Egypt because of its portrayal of Moses, as well as historical inaccuracies and giving “a Zionist view of history.” “Exodus,” produced by 20th Century Fox, was previously criticized for having white actors in the leading roles — including Christian Bale as Moses — despite being set in Egypt. It has had tepid results at the box office, taking in $52.5 million in domestic ticket sales since opening nationwide on Dec. 12, according to Box Office Mojo. It’s not the first time Arab countries have banned Hollywood films because of religion: Darren Aronofsky’s “Noah” was barred in several countries in the spring, and the animated movie “The Prince of Egypt” was forbidden in Egypt in 1998.

headline: The Set for ‘The Alamo’ Hopes to Live Again as a Theme Park
abstract: A businessman in Corpus Christi, Tex., hopes to bring tourists back to Alamo Village.
lead_paragraph: The Alamo has weathered cannon blasts, Santa Anna’s army and urban growth. But for a replica of that Texas landmark, above, neglect may be the biggest foe. Alamo Village, a 400-acre set built in the late 1950s for John Wayne’s movie  “The Alamo,” is slowly losing the battle against time and nature, The Associated Press reported. More than 100 additional productions, including movies and music videos, were filmed at the site, about 120 miles west of the actual Alamo in downtown San Antonio. The set contained more than 200,000 square feet of permanent buildings, including a church, blacksmith shop and a jail, according to the Texas State Historical Association. For several decades it was a popular tourist destination, drawing hundreds of daily visitors at its height for musical shows and staged gunfights. But attendance waned in the 1980s as traffic shifted north after the completion of Interstate 10, The A.P. reported. The set was put up for sale in 2004 by Virginia Shahan, who took over operations after the death in 1996 of James T. Shahan, her husband and founder of Alamo Village. It was eventually closed in 2010, about a year after Ms. Shahan died. The site is now mostly used for cattle grazing and hunting, and some buildings are beginning to succumb to the elements, The A.P. reported. David Jones, a businessman in Corpus Christi, Tex., hopes to bring tourists back to Alamo Village. He told The A.P. he is close to raising the $8 million he estimates is needed to buy the property and turn it into a Texas version of Old Tucson, a theme park in Arizona.

headline: A Feast and a Lions’ Den, Conveyed in Multiple Ways
abstract: A storyteller and music are used in “The Play of Daniel,” part of the Trinity Wall Street Twelfth Night Festival.
lead_paragraph: When attending any kind of music drama written in a language other than English, American audiences have come to expect that the text will be performed in an English translation or some system of projected supertitles will be employed.

headline: On the Civil Rights Map, a Crooner and His Driver
abstract: Ravi Howard uses Nat King Cole as a device for exploring the civil rights movement.
lead_paragraph: In “Driving the King,” Ravi Howard tells a thoroughly convincing story about the singing star Nat King Cole’s best friend. Both are black men named Nat and were boyhood pals in Montgomery, Ala., but Nat King Cole owes Nat Weary an extraordinary debt of gratitude. Weary, a soldier newly home after the end of World War II, was present at the Alabama concert where Cole was attacked onstage in the middle of a performance. He bludgeoned the white assailant with a microphone, saved the singer and served 10 grueling years in prison for his trouble.

headline: Cosby Team’s Strategy: Hush Accusers, Insult Them, Blame the Media
abstract: Bill Cosby’s team has used an aggressive legal and media strategy to keep accusations of sexual misconduct quiet for years.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, when Tamara Green told the “Today” show and The Philadelphia Inquirer that Bill Cosby drugged and sexually assaulted her in the early 1970s, one of Mr. Cosby’s lawyers publicly branded the allegations “absolutely false,” while his aides approached another newspaper with “damaging information” about her, according to court documents.

headline: To the Letter
abstract: Look for the hidden message from Peter A. Collins.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE— Happy Monday, everyone! We’ve got an entertaining and breezy solve for you today, courtesy of Peter A. Collins. He has a clever theme running throughout the puzzle, which we’ll hear about in a bit.

headline: Before the Chinese Year of the Sheep, a Bulge in Births
abstract: Parts of China have seen full maternity wards, as parents try to take advantage of the auspicious Year of the Horse and avoid giving birth in the less fortuitous Year of the Sheep.
lead_paragraph: The fast-approaching arrival of the Year of the Sheep has sent many young couples into a frenzy to ensure that their babies are delivered before Lunar New Year’s Day on Feb. 19 for fear that their child will end up, as the old saying has it, among the “nine out of 10 sheep who will lead an unhappy life.”

headline: Wittiness, Pluck and Range
abstract: Brian Seibert offers six dance highlights of 2014, mainly consisting of established artists delivering more of what they are were known for.
lead_paragraph: The lingering flavor of dance in 2014 is bittersweet. It wasn’t much of a year for budding voices or surprising developments. What stays brightest in my memory are mainly instances of established artists delivering more of what they were already known for, several of them for the last time. Here are six highlights.

headline: 2014 Proves a Grim Year in Malaysian Aviation
abstract: Should no survivors be found aboard the missing AirAsia flight, Malaysian carriers, or their subsidiaries, will have been involved in the world’s three deadliest aviation disasters this year.
lead_paragraph: For Malaysian aviation, 2014 has been an unimaginably horrible year.

headline: Ebola’s Patient Zero
abstract: In rural Guinea, a 1-year-old boy named Emile contracted a mysterious illness that spread terror and confusion. An exclusive video by the PBS series “Frontline” in association with The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: In rural Guinea, a 1-year-old boy named Emile contracted a mysterious illness that spread terror and confusion. An exclusive video by the PBS series “Frontline” in association with The New York Times.

headline: In Ebola Outbreak, Fear and Evasion
abstract: As Ebola ravaged Guinea in March 2014, fearful communities hid the sick from health authorities. An exclusive video produced by the PBS series “Frontline” in association with The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: As Ebola ravaged Guinea in March 2014, fearful communities hid the sick from health authorities. An exclusive video produced by the PBS series “Frontline” in association with The New York Times.

headline: The Path of the Ebola Outbreak
abstract: A look at how the disease spread far beyond Meliandou, Guinea in just a few months.
lead_paragraph: A look at how the disease spread far beyond Meliandou, Guinea in just a few months.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Dec. 29
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Pinterest Pushing Deeper Into Ads
abstract: On New Year’s Day, the digital scrapbook Pinterest will start selling ads to marketers, competing with Google, Twitter and Facebook for ad revenue from the biggest consumer brands.
lead_paragraph: A quick glance at the digital scrapbook Pinterest makes it seem like the anti-Facebook. It has no stream filled with friends’ faces and baby pictures, but rather a sprawling, colorful grid of recipes, photographs of clothes and a shopping list of presents to buy for loved ones.

headline: As Hair Grows, So Does Fondness for a Barber
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: After a local barbershop shutters, a yearslong search for a new barber ends with a cut and a surprise.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: A Ban on Child Labor in Tobacco Fields
abstract: The Obama administration should act on its own to restrict children from working on tobacco farms.
lead_paragraph: Responding to a damning report this year by Human Rights Watch, some cigarette companies and growers have said they will voluntarily restrict child labor in tobacco fields. Though welcome, these steps should be reinforced by new federal rules.

headline: Foreign Aid and Abortion Rights
abstract: It’s time to end a blanket ban that stems from a misinterpretation of the Helms amendment.
lead_paragraph: A small provision tucked in the new federal spending bill ends a longstanding injustice by easing a 1979 rule that prohibited the Peace Corps from providing any abortion coverage for female volunteers, who now make up nearly two-thirds of those who serve.

headline: Sexual Assault Claim at Columbia
abstract: Readers react to an article about the accuser and accused in the case.

headline: Recertifying Doctors: Weighing the Benefits
abstract: The president of the American Board of Internal Medicine says the exams are valuable; two doctors disagree.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Movie Box Office Blues
abstract: One reader thinks there are ways to attract more business.

abstract: Carol Rothouse, a reader, asks what role will be left for “the human element.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Family Court Judges
abstract: A reader says that too many of their rulings are arbitrary and not in the best interests of the child.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Where Afghan War Was Transferred Long Ago
abstract: The official conclusion of the international combat mission in Afghanistan arrived Sunday, but for the Afghans fighting in this remote border district, the symbolic end to America’s 13-year war brought little change.
lead_paragraph: DANGAM, Afghanistan — The official conclusion of the international combat mission in Afghanistan arrived Sunday, but for the Afghans fighting in this remote border district the symbolic end to America’s 13-year war brought little change.

headline: Ferguson Officer on Leave After Calling Michael Brown Site ‘Trash’
abstract: A spokesman for the Ferguson, Mo., police department has been placed on unpaid leave after he admitted that he referred to a memorial for Michael Brown as “a pile of trash in the middle of the street.”
lead_paragraph: A spokesman for the Ferguson, Mo., police department has been placed on unpaid leave after he admitted that he referred to a memorial for the black teenager fatally shot by a white officer as “a pile of trash in the middle of the street,” and then falsely claimed that he had been misquoted by The Washington Post, city officials said.

headline: Walgreen to Vote on Alliance Boots Acquisition and Lithuania to Join Eurozone
abstract: Investors in the Walgreen drugstore chain will vote on Monday. And on Thursday, Lithuania officially becomes the newest eurozone member.
lead_paragraph: WALGREEN VOTE EXPECTED ON ALLIANCE BOOTS DEAL

headline: President’s Test: Family Vacation With Teenage Girls
abstract: As president, Barack Obama must contend with challenges of global importance. As a father, he potentially faces a home test: A two-week family vacation with teenage daughters.
lead_paragraph: KAILUA, Hawaii — As president, Barack Obama must contend with challenges of global importance, even while on vacation. But as a father, he potentially faces a test on the home front: A two-week family vacation with teenage daughters.

headline: Around an Invisible Leader, Taliban Power Shifts
abstract: The reclusiveness of Mullah Muhammad Omar raises questions about the group’s leadership and its influence in the jihadist world next to the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If the Taliban’s reclusive leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, were ever to assert himself more publicly, this would have been the year to do it.

headline: In a New Approach to Fighting Disease, Helpful Genetic Mutations Are Sought
abstract: After years of looking for genetic mutations that cause diseases, investigators are now searching for those that prevent them.
lead_paragraph: Doug Whitney should have died years ago. The 65-year-old resident of Port Orchard, Wash., has a devastating gene mutation that — according to the medical literature — causes early onset Alzheimer’s disease in everyone who inherits it.

headline: Notable Opinion Art of 2014
abstract: The best illustrations that accompanied opinion pieces in The New York Times this year, as selected by the section’s art directors.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Opinion section has been a venue for provocative illustration since the inception of the newspaper’s Op-Ed page in 1970. In this collection of notable illustrations of 2014, you’ll find that tradition intact.

headline: ‘Monster Strike’ Gives Former Social Media Giant Mixi a Second Act
abstract: Mixi was a once-dominant social network that Facebook had driven to the edge of collapse — and then it created the mobile game Monster Strike.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — It was a familiar trajectory for a social network like Facebook that did not happen to be Facebook: One moment there were tens of millions of users and a multibillion-dollar stock market valuation. The next, a plunge toward whatever-happened-to-it oblivion.

headline: Building a Park to Span a Divide in Washington
abstract: Turning a disused bridge into a public park could link some of the district’s tourist-oriented neighborhoods with Anacostia, one of its final frontiers in the march toward gentrification.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the edge of the historic Anacostia neighborhood here there is a very ugly bridge.

headline: 2014: The Year in Questions
abstract: Behold, the ninth annual Op-Ed quiz.
lead_paragraph: Behold, the ninth annual Op-Ed quiz.

headline: The Obama Recovery
abstract: So much for that story line about the president being a job-killer.
lead_paragraph: Suppose that for some reason you decided to start hitting yourself in the head, repeatedly, with a baseball bat. You’d feel pretty bad. Correspondingly, you’d probably feel a lot better if and when you finally stopped. What would that improvement in your condition tell you?

headline: Radio Station Backed by U.S. Is Raided in Azerbaijan
abstract: A dozen employees of Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, including an anchor and the cleaning woman, were arrested and detained for up to 12 hours over the weekend, as prosecutors intensified a crackdown on journalists.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A dozen employees of Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty in Azerbaijan were arrested and detained for up to 12 hours of questioning over the weekend, as state prosecutors intensified a crackdown on journalists and nongovernmental organizations that has drawn sharp criticism in the West.

headline: Amid Student Debt, Overcoming a Roadblock to His Career Dreams
abstract: Abdu Rodney, saddled with student loan debt, got help obtaining his driver’s license, which he needs as he pursues environmental work.
lead_paragraph: In his years of skateboarding, Abdu Rodney has had the run of Brooklyn. He has jumped the stone steps at Cadman Plaza, between the federal district courthouse and the Brooklyn Bridge, and suffered sprained joints and lacerated skin, attending much of high school covered in a shifting cartography of scrapes and bruises.

headline: Hamas Turns Back 37 Gaza War Orphans From a Bridge-Building Trip to Israel
abstract: Israeli and Palestinian officials had organized the visit for 37 children from Gaza as a way to promote peace and reconciliation, but the Hamas authorities turned them back at a border crossing.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Thirty-seven young war orphans from Gaza set out on Sunday for a rare visit to Israel. They got as far as the Erez border crossing at the northern end of the Palestinian coastal enclave. There the Hamas authorities turned them back, barring the visit at the last minute.

headline: Behind the Scenes of ‘Today,’ ‘This Morning’ and ‘Good Morning America’
abstract: In the dark hours of the morning, some of television’s biggest celebrities are already rolling out into the streets of the city that never sleeps.
lead_paragraph: In the dark hours of the morning, some of television’s biggest celebrities are already rolling out into the streets of the city that never sleeps.

headline: Have Human Rights Treaties Failed?
abstract: Do international human rights treaties work to protect vulnerable populations, or should they be abandoned in favor of other measures?

headline: Door Hogs, Music Blasters, Litterbugs: Readers Sound Off About Subway Rudeness
abstract: With a new subway etiquette campaign about to start, riders listed what behaviors irritated them the most, including backpacks that whack, garlic breath and personal grooming.
lead_paragraph: The thump of loud music coming from headphones. A whack by an overstuffed backpack. The messy, pungent burrito.

headline: Alarming Gaps in Presidential Protection
abstract: Congress must not stint on budget support to make sure the Secret Service can do its job.
lead_paragraph: For all the attraction of the White House as a photogenic backdrop, the sad truth is its 7-foot-6-inch fence needs to be at least four to five feet higher, with outwardly thrust picket tops, if the president of the United States is to be adequately protected.

headline: Despite Veto, Sponsors of Port Authority Bill Continue Push for Reform
abstract: As lawmakers in New York and New Jersey conceded there was little chance to override their governors’ rejection of the measure, they mulled other options, including possible federal legislation.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — A day after the governors of New York and New Jersey rejected legislation aimed at upending a culture of political interference at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the bill’s bistate sponsors said they were determined to move ahead with reforms, albeit at a pace they deemed too slow for the controversy-prone agency.

headline: Pot Pie, Redefined? Chefs Start to Experiment With Cannabis
abstract: As states legalize marijuana, cooking with cannabis is emerging as a legitimate and very lucrative culinary pursuit.
lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — Recreational marijuana is both illegal and controversial in most of the country, and its relationship to food does not rise much above a joke about brownies or a stoner chef’s late-night pork belly poutine.

headline: In Battle to Defang ISIS, U.S. Targets Its Psychology
abstract: Officials acknowledge they have barely made a dent in the larger, longer-term campaign to kill the ideology that animates the terrorist movement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Maj. Gen. Michael K. Nagata, commander of American Special Operations forces in the Middle East, sought help this summer in solving an urgent problem for the American military: What makes the Islamic State so dangerous?

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 28, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Looking to Claim a Title and End a Streak, the Lions Find Only a Loss in Green Bay
abstract: In a game that decided the N.F.C. North champion, the Lions fell to the Packers in Wisconsin for the 23rd consecutive season.
lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — The last time the Detroit Lions won a game in Wisconsin, George Herbert Walker Bush was president, Michael Jordan had only one championship ring and “The Silence of the Lambs” was a hit movie.

headline: Kids and Jails, a Bad Combination
abstract: Despite reforms, there are still too many juveniles behind bars, sometimes for offenses like skipping school or violating curfew.
lead_paragraph: There are few bright spots in America’s four-decade-long incarceration boom, but one enduring success — amid all the wasted money and ruined lives — has been the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act, the landmark law passed by Congress in 1974.

headline: Colleges Often Entice Top Prospects by Recruiting Their Mentors, Too
abstract: Despite raising some eyebrows, N.C.A.A. rules allow basketball coaches to hire a recruit’s relative or former coach, which can help lock up a player’s services.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J. — Isaiah Whitehead leaned against a table on the sideline at practice Friday and watched his mentor go to work. About 10 feet in front of him, the mentor, the Seton Hall assistant coach Dwayne Morton, known as Tiny, was preparing the team for a defensive drill.

headline: Media Companies (and Executives) on the Hot Seat in 2015
abstract: Taking stock of the businesses that face challenges in the coming year.
lead_paragraph: While it’s great news that the economy is (slowly) coming back, it’s important to remember that a rising tide does not necessarily lift all boats. That is especially true in the media industry, where a bad stretch of advertising and extensive challenges to existing business models have clobbered many legacy outfits.

headline: In Shadow of New Search, a Long Aviation Mystery Remains Unsolved
abstract: The Australian and Malaysian governments still have ships scouring the Indian Ocean for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which disappeared on March 8.
lead_paragraph: KATOOMBA, Australia — The sudden disappearance of AirAsia Flight 8501 and the search in the waters of Southeast Asia have brought to mind one of the greatest aviation mysteries of modern times: the vanishing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 on March 8 with 239 passengers and crew aboard.

headline: Claude Frank, Pianist Admired for Performing Beethoven, Dies at 89
abstract: In addition to his concert and recording career, Mr. Frank was also an influential teacher of generations of pianists.
lead_paragraph: The American pianist Claude Frank, widely admired for his insightful, sensitive performances of the solo and chamber works of the Germanic masters, and an influential teacher to generations of pianists, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan, three days after turning 89.

headline: Postwar Sri Lanka’s Awkward Peace
abstract: The Sinhalese of the victorious south happily tour the war-ravaged north, where some of the defeated northern people receive them warily.
lead_paragraph: KILINOCHCHI, Sri Lanka — Two men were riding the train known as the Queen of Jaffna as it rattled through the haunted battlegrounds of Sri Lanka’s civil war.

headline: Under .500 and Overjoyed, Panthers Head to Playoffs
abstract: Carolina earned the N.F.L.'s 12th and final playoff spot with a win over Atlanta, finishing the regular season at 7-8-1.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The N.F.L.’s 12th and final playoff berth was claimed Sunday evening, even though purists might have preferred an odd number of tournament teams over a field tainted by a division champion with a losing record.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: Studios played to fans with popular stories this year — six of the top 10 films were sequels.
lead_paragraph: Studios played to fans with popular stories this year — six of the top 10 films were sequels.

headline: Rex Ryan Says He’s ‘Not Afraid of Anything’
abstract: Until he is told otherwise, Ryan is still the Jets’ coach. That was how he approached Sunday’s game against the Dolphins.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Rex Ryan wore a white long-sleeve shirt, as he always does on game days, and a black sweater vest, as he always does, and khaki pants, as he always does.

headline: New York Casinos’ Remote Homes Could Dampen Success
abstract: A state board’s recommendation that licenses for three upstate casino resorts be approved is getting mixed reviews from gambling analysts, urban planners, politicians and rival developers.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo won widespread praise for moving like an express train with his plan to expand casino gambling in New York, passing legislation, settling disputes with tribal casinos and sticking to a fast-paced schedule for reviewing what ended up being 16 proposals.

headline: As Packers Expand, the Neighborhood Changes. Party On.
abstract: As the Packers’ popularity has soared, the neighborhood around Lambeau Field has evolved into something less quaint.
lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — To crazed Packers fans, Tyler Jozwiak is living the dream. He rents half a house for $650 a month on Stadium Drive, a block from Lambeau Field. From on top of the garage, he can peek into the team’s training facility. On game days, he wakes up at 6 a.m., fires up the grill, mixes a Bloody Mary, tailgates with dozens of Cheeseheads, then crosses the street and is in his seat by kickoff.

headline: On Tribal Lands, Oil and Trouble
abstract: Murder charges spark an investigation into a tribal chairman’s business dealings on the oil-rich Fort Berthold Reservation in North Dakota.
lead_paragraph: Murder charges spark an investigation into a tribal chairman’s business dealings on the oil-rich Fort Berthold Reservation in North Dakota.

headline: In North Dakota, a Tale of Oil, Corruption and Death
abstract: Tex G. Hall, a tribal chief connected to the oil industry, has pushed profits on the Fort Berthold Reservation. But accusations of corruption and murder for hire have upended business as usual.
lead_paragraph: FORT BERTHOLD INDIAN RESERVATION, N.D. — Tex G. Hall, the three-term tribal chairman on this remote, once impoverished reservation, was the very picture of confidence as he strode to the lectern at his third Annual Bakken Oil and Gas Expo and gazed out over a stuffed, backlit mountain lion.

headline: 31-Year-Old Man Is Shot to Death in Manhattan
abstract: The man, identified as Rashaun Nicholson, was pronounced dead at the scene on Catherine Street, outside a homeless shelter.
lead_paragraph: A 31-year-old man was shot to death outside a homeless shelter in Lower Manhattan on Sunday night, the police said.

headline: Play-by-Play, but First Up: Charting Stats, Hour by Hour
abstract: Pete Pranica goes through unique rituals to prepare for the high-wire act of conveying the play-by-play action of Memphis Grizzlies games for live broadcasts.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Six hours before the fickle madness of another N.B.A. game, Pete Pranica sat at a desk in his hotel room here with some of the tools of his trade: several sheets of legal-size paper, a portable printer, eight felt-tip pens, a stick of glue and a small pair of scissors.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 12:30 P.M. (TCM) WHAT EVER HAPPENED TO BABY JANE? (1962) This film, based on Henry Farrell’s lesser-known 1960 novel of the same name, briefly resurrected the careers of its stars, Joan Crawford and Bette Davis. Ms. Davis, above, plays Baby Jane Hudson, a former childhood vaudeville sensation whose career was long ago overshadowed by that of her movie-star sibling, Blanche (Ms. Crawford). Blanche’s own career ended years ago, after she was crippled in an “accident.” Now the two live together, forgotten, haunting a crumbling Hollywood manse while Jane slowly tortures her disabled sister to death. The critic Bosley Crowther, who didn’t care for the film, wrote in The New York Times about Ms. Davis’s performance: “She shrieks and shrills in brazen fashion, bats her huge mascaraed eyes with evil glee, snarls at the charitable neighbors and acts like a maniac.”

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Cavaliers at Hawks
abstract: The Hawks have adopted a team-oriented offense that may prove effective against a Cavaliers defense that has been lacking at times.
lead_paragraph: The Atlanta Hawks, who host the Cleveland Cavaliers at 7:30 Eastern on Tuesday (NBA TV), have won 15 of their last 17 games and have risen to second place in the Eastern Conference. While their schedule was fairly easy for the first six weeks, they recently took a brief trip to the middle of the country and were able to beat the Rockets and the Mavericks before returning home and stealing one away from the Clippers in the fourth quarter. Those are all good teams. Are the Hawks a good team, too?

headline: Giants Replay: Week 17
abstract: Despite an offensive outburst that helped the Giants collect 505 total yards, they lost to the Eagles, 34-26, in their final game of the 2014 N.F.L. season.
lead_paragraph: Despite an offensive outburst that helped the Giants collect 505 total yards, they lost to the Eagles, 34-26, in their final game of the 2014 N.F.L. season.

headline: Corrections: December 29, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Monday, December 29, 2014.
lead_paragraph: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 29, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “The weed is pretty faint, but it’s not an un-delicious weed type flavor. It’s almost like when you do a savory cookie and you might find sage or rosemary or verbena in it.”

headline: China Adds New Barrier to Gmail
abstract: The government appears to have blocked the ability of people in China to access their Gmail accounts through third-party email clients.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese government appears to have blocked the ability of people in China to gain access to Google’s email service through third-party email services like Apple Mail or Microsoft Outlook, which many Chinese and foreigners had been relying on to use their Gmail accounts after an earlier blocking effort by officials, according to Internet analysts and users in China.

headline: Philadelphia, City of Father Divine
abstract: A photographer searching for remnants of fringe faiths gets a glimpse of the enduring devotion of adherents to Father Divine, the preacher who rose to prominence in Depression-era Harlem.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Kristin Bedford trekked through the sweltering summer streets of Philadelphia in 2013, looking for remnants of forgotten religions. In college, as a religious studies major, she’d been influenced by Arthur Fauset’s 1944 book “Black Gods of the Metropolis: Negro Cults of the Urban North,” in which he’d chronicled five spinoff religions in African-American communities.

headline: The Future, Revisited
abstract: Circumstances had changed, and all these documents needed to change, too.
lead_paragraph: When last I wrote my will, I didn’t have a dog, a point that had begun to nag at me.

headline: Shares Drop for AirAsia After Plane Disappears
abstract: Investor sell-off was behind an 8.5 percent decline following news of the airline's first major crisis.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Shares in AirAsia fell 8.5 percent in Kuala Lumpur on Monday, a day after the Malaysian airline said one of its planes went missing with 162 people on board.

headline: Europe Braces for Economic Fallout as Greece Heads to Early Elections
abstract: The Greek Parliament on Monday failed to avert an early general election, reviving the toxic debate over austerity as the way to cure the continent’s economic woes.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Governments and investors across Europe braced for renewed economic upheaval on Monday after the Parliament in Greece failed to avert an early general election, reviving the toxic debate over austerity as the way to cure the Continent’s economic woes.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Obama Says Health Law Is Helping White Americans, Despite Perceptions
abstract: In an interview scheduled to air Monday on NPR, President Obama said that despite the perception the Affordable Care Act is for blacks and Latinos, it is helping many whites.
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — President Obama said that despite the perception that the Affordable Care Act is for blacks and Latinos, it is helping many whites.

headline: New York Today: The Year in Sports
abstract: Monday: A tough year for most fans, fair weather, and the confetti is ready for New Year’s Eve.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this brisk Monday.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: Mr. Obama is halfway through his year-end trip to Hawaii. While he has kept a low profile, he’s been fairly busy.
lead_paragraph: Playing the Numbers Game With the Obamas’ Christmas Vacation

headline: Search for AirAsia Jet Widens and Receives Assistance From U.S. Warship
abstract: The destroyer Sampson was dispatched to help look for Flight 8501 as the search area was expanded to 60,000 square miles.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — A United States warship was dispatched to join the search for a missing AirAsia jet on Tuesday, as the Indonesian authorities announced an expanded search area.

headline: Daily Report: Pinterest Opening Its Boards to Ads on Wide Scale for First Time
abstract: On New Year’s Day, the digital scrapbook Pinterest will start selling advertising, competing with Google, Twitter and Facebook for marketing revenue from the biggest consumer brands.
lead_paragraph: A quick glance at the digital scrapbook Pinterest makes it seem like the anti-Facebook. It has no stream filled with friends’ faces and baby pictures, but rather a sprawling, colorful grid of recipes, photographs of clothes and a shopping list of presents to buy for loved ones.

headline: Signs of a Tightening Labor Market, but Still Room for Improvement
abstract: Improvement in labor force participation is a particularly important and encouraging development.
lead_paragraph: Though it still has a long way to go, the American job market improved a lot more in 2014 than in 2013.

headline: Health Law Helped Adults. Now, What About Children?
abstract: A successful program for children’s health insurance is up for renewal next year. It covers important things that the Affordable Care Act sometimes does not.
lead_paragraph: With the Affordable Care Act seemingly off to a good start in its first year, increasing access to insurance coverage for adults, attention is likely to turn to an older program for children that will come to an end in 2015 if it is not reauthorized: the Children’s Health Insurance Program, or CHIP.

headline: Croatian Presidential Election Heads for January Runoff
abstract: After a close first round, the center-left incumbent, Ivo Josipovic, will face his conservative opponent, Kolinda Grabar-Kitarovic, on Jan. 11.
lead_paragraph: After a close first round in the Croatian presidential election, the center-left incumbent, Ivo Josipovic, will face his conservative opponent, Kolinda Grabar-Kitarovic, in a runoff election on Jan. 11, the electoral commission said on Monday.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Rex Ryan and John Idzik Pay for the Jets’ Ineptitude With Their Jobs
abstract: Dissatisfied with the team’s performance and direction, the owner Woody Johnson fired Ryan after six season as his coach and Idzik after less than two as his general manager.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Soon after he was fired, Rex Ryan addressed his players one final time Monday. For weeks, he had been telling them that he loved them, cared about them, appreciated them, and so when the reckoning finally came, Ryan did not say much.

headline: Responses to Ferry Fire Off Coast of Greece Are Criticized
abstract: The Italian Navy on Sunday rescued 427 people from a burning ship, and questions quickly arose about the response of the stricken ship’s crew.
lead_paragraph: VERBANIA, Italy — As black smoke gushed from the lower decks of the stricken ferry, Italian and Greek fireboats bobbed alongside, blasting water at the flames, while overhead helicopters churned through heavy Adriatic winds and mist to rescue the increasingly desperate passengers.

headline: Icahn Calls for Manitowoc to Split in Two
abstract: After taking a 7.7 percent sake, Carl Icahn becomes the second activist investor this year to urge a breakup.
lead_paragraph: The activist investor Carl C. Icahn disclosed on Monday that he had taken a large stake in the Manitowoc Company of Wisconsin and was adding his voice to a call for the company to break up.

headline: Moviegoers Voted With Their Wallets; Now It’s the Academy’s Turn
abstract: Hollywood can start marking their ballots today to decide the Oscar nominations.
lead_paragraph: Everyone enjoy their holiday break? Great, because now it’s back to business, more or less. Things really crank back into high gear next week. But today the Oscar nomination ballots are being mailed out and also being made available online; they’re due back Jan. 8.

headline: Japan and South Korea Vow to Share Intelligence About North via the U.S.
abstract: Under the pact, the sharing of classified information will be limited to North Korea’s missile and nuclear weapons programs.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Japan and South Korea on Monday pledged for the first time to share military intelligence about North Korean weapons programs, in a three-way pact with the United States that Washington hopes will improve cooperation between its mutually estranged Asian allies.

headline: T’s Top 10 Food Stories of 2014
abstract: These 10 stories savor the art of crafting the perfect plate and relish the people behind them.
lead_paragraph: These 10 stories savor the art of crafting the perfect plate and relish the people behind them. More…

headline: 1889: New Names of Paris Streets
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1889: A good proportion of Paris streets have had their names changed.
lead_paragraph: With the last twelve months a goodly proportion of the streets of Paris have had their names changed. A special committee of the Municipal Council has been working with a will to weed out any and every name that might recall the facts that Paris had ever been a Royalist or Imperialist city, and that the Church had once been an important factor in municipal life. In some cases the changes made have been for the better; in some other cases Parisians almost unanimously agree the changes have been much for the worse and not worth the inconvenience they have caused.— The New York Herald, European Edition, Dec. 30, 1889

headline: Could a Personality Test Improve Your Health?
abstract: A growing body of research suggests that personality can affect your health, and that changing it could help you get better.
lead_paragraph: Are you open to new experiences? Are you a risk taker? Do you like parties?

headline: Xiaomi, Chinese Phone Maker Favored by Young, Valued at $45 Billion
abstract: A new round of financing raised $1.1 billion for the company, which has become one of the world’s biggest smartphone makers by offering cheap, high-quality phones through clever online marketing campaigns.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Xiaomi, the fast-rising Chinese smartphone maker, has mustered a new $1.1 billion war chest in its latest round of fund-raising, the company’s founder and chief executive said on Monday.

headline: Four Teams That Failed to Make Playoffs Move On Quickly
abstract: The Jets and the Bears cut ties with their general manager and coach, while the Falcons and the 49ers parted ways with only their coach.
lead_paragraph: If Black Monday, as the day after the end of the N.F.L. regular season is known, had a soundtrack, it might be the album “Let It Bleed” by the Rolling Stones.

headline: At 90, Still a Haven for Broadway Performers
abstract: The former residential hotel the Whitby, which was developed especially for theater workers, was converted to co-ops and still attracts creative types.
lead_paragraph: On a ceaselessly rainy day this month, the residents of the Whitby gathered inside the lobby of the grand old building in Manhattan for its annual Christmas party. Children crawled and darted around the legs of clustered parents. Plastic folding tables were laden with nuts, cold cuts and pizza. Soda and wine sloshed in disposable cups while the lights and ornaments twinkled on a small artificial Christmas tree.

headline: Commuting Across the Waves
abstract: Those who ride the Staten Island Ferry and other water-commuting services get in touch with the elements on their trip.
lead_paragraph: Those who ride the Staten Island Ferry and other water-commuting services get in touch with the elements on their trip.

headline: Court Moves Up Verdict Announcement for Putin Critic
abstract: The abrupt date change raised the possibility that Aleksei A. Navalny, who rose to prominence as an anticorruption activist, would be handed a lengthy prison term just before New Year’s Eve.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A court on Monday unexpectedly moved up the announcement of a verdict in a criminal case against one of Russia’s most prominent political opposition leaders, Aleksei A. Navalny, saying the decision would be given on Tuesday morning rather than on Jan. 15.

headline: Ndamukong Suh Is Barred One Game for Stepping on Rodgers
abstract: Suh will appeal his one-game suspension in the hope that he can play in Sunday’s playoff game against the Cowboys.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. announced Monday that Detroit Lions defensive tackle Ndamukong Suh was suspended without pay for one game for stepping on Green Bay quarterback Aaron Rodgers during Sunday’s 30-20 loss to the Packers.

headline: Indonesian Officials on AirAsia Search
abstract: Indonesian authorities on Monday discussed the search for a missing AirAsia jet carrying 162 people.
lead_paragraph: Indonesian authorities on Monday discussed the search for a missing AirAsia jet carrying 162 people.

headline: AnonyWatch: Department of Ridiculous Reasons
abstract: Every time I write about anonymous sourcing, I emphasize that it is sometimes both necessary and important. These examples don’t measure up.
lead_paragraph: For many months now, I’ve been keeping track of the overuse of anonymous sources in The Times as a way of discouraging a practice that readers rightly object to.   The practice continues apace — as do ever-more-inventive reasons for granting anonymity.

headline: It’s Almost Time to Fill Out College Financial Aid Form for Fall 2015
abstract: The Free Application for Federal Student Aid, which is used by most states and colleges, will be available online on Jan. 1.
lead_paragraph: Students who plan to attend or continue college next fall should get ready to start the application for financial aid.

headline: An Animated History of New York’s Love-Hate Relationship With Commuting
abstract: Commuting is critical to New York City, and the metropolitan life it pioneered. The city has led the world in generating a miraculous daily movement that has now been mostly in place for a century.
lead_paragraph: Commuting is critical to New York City, and the metropolitan life it pioneered. The city has led the world in generating a miraculous daily movement that has now been mostly in place for a century.

headline: How a Ferry Ride Helped Make Brooklyn the Original Suburb
abstract: On May 10, 1814, a twin-hulled boat called the Nassau carried 549 passengers across the East River to Manhattan. Thus was the concept of commuting born.
lead_paragraph: This much is known about the maiden voyage of the Nassau: The twin-hulled boat carried 549 passengers, one wagon and three horses. It was captained by Peter Coffee, who would remain with the company that operated the vessel for 50 years.

headline: Speaking at Police Academy Graduation, de Blasio Is Greeted With Scattered Jeers
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio addressed hundreds of new police officers, noting their “heroic choice” of profession, but got a chilly reception.
lead_paragraph: Two days after scores of police officers turned their backs on Mayor Bill de Blasio while he spoke at a murdered officer’s funeral, a scattering of boos and jeers greeted the mayor on Monday as he addressed another Police Department event: the graduation ceremony for the fall class of 884 new officers.

headline: Malaysians Are Shaken by Loss of 3rd Jet in Year
abstract: At AirAsia’s hub in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, passengers and relatives of people about to board flights expressed skepticism over official bulletins about Flight 8501.
lead_paragraph: SEPANG, Malaysia — Mohammad Mallaeibasir said his goodbyes to his childhood friend from Iran at the sprawling international airport here last March 7. Parting was easy then. Both he and his friend were teenagers with their whole lives, and presumably many reunions, ahead of them.

headline: Kate Jones and the Star-9 Challenge
abstract: Try this nine-pointed challenge by puzzle creator Kate Jones.
lead_paragraph: This week we celebrate 2014 with an original star puzzle from Kate Jones, a puzzle designer, philosopher and former ballroom dance teacher.

headline: Numberplay 2014: A Year in Review
abstract: A reflection on the past year of weekly Numberplay puzzles, including links to the 51 puzzles of 2014.
lead_paragraph: Playing around with puzzles is all about the joy of solving and creating with friends, and we saw plenty of that here in Numberplay this last year. Thank you to everyone who participated in 2014, whether by submitting a puzzle, joining the online discussion, or by bringing the action into the classroom or lunchroom.

headline: First Draft Focus: Reflecting on 2014
abstract: A view of Washington.

headline: 1914: Tipperary Song Is a Hit
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1914: A Long Way to Tipperary Song Is a Hit
lead_paragraph: LONDON — ‘It’s a Long Way, etc.,’’ must look to its laurels, for the British ‘‘Tommy’’ is now wrestling with the refrain of a new ditty, singing it, whistling it, humming it, and murdering it.

headline: Airports Modernize Dining Options With Farm-to-Terminal Fare
abstract: The interest in locally sourced food has reached the once-grim world of airport cuisine, and restaurateurs and producers are working to adapt to airports’ challenges.
lead_paragraph: Outside of the hotel minibar, few places for business travelers have had more unhealthy fare than airports, home of the stale, prewrapped sandwich and fast food burger. But that is starting to change.

headline: Jim Harbaugh Is Said to Be the Next Coach at Michigan, His Alma Mater
abstract: The university is expected to announce the hiring of Harbaugh, who finished his fourth season as coach of the San Francisco 49ers on Sunday, at noon on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Jim Harbaugh will be announced as the University of Michigan’s next football coach in a news conference at noon Tuesday, according to a person with knowledge of the situation. Harbaugh, who arrived in Michigan late Monday afternoon, completed his fourth season as coach of the San Francisco 49ers on Sunday afternoon. He will also be introduced at the Michigan-Illinois men’s basketball game, which starts at 3 p.m. Tuesday.

headline: Israeli Military Kills Palestinian Teenager in West Bank
abstract: The military said its forces opened fire after a group hurling rocks on a main road failed to heed a call to stop and disregarded warning shots.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military on Monday said its forces fatally shot a Palestinian teenager in the West Bank.

headline: Laura Dern Won’t Let Her Kids  See ‘Wild at Heart’
abstract: It’s not her part that might alarm the children; it was the role played by her mother.
lead_paragraph: The Bagger was especially amped to sit down and chat with Laura Dern – in schmancy Santa Monica, no less – because a) the Bagger has a minor obsession with David Lynch, who cast Ms. Dern in three of his films, and b) at 5-foot-10 or thereabouts, Ms. Dern is tall like the Bagger, who often looms over Hollywoodians, who tend to be quite small. Ms. Dern, meanwhile, is in “the conversation” for a best supporting actress nod, playing the mother to Ms. Witherspoon’s character in the film version of Cheryl Strayed’s “Wild.”

headline: Deal Talk Starts to Become Part of the Boom
abstract: Financial communications firms, accustomed to advising others about mergers and acquisitions, could be targets in their own right but should tread cautiously, Quentin Webb writes for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Spin doctors for mergers and acquisitions may get swept up in the deal action. If anyone knows how to assess the climate for takeovers, it should be financial public relations advisers.

headline: The Year in White-Collar Crime
abstract: The new year will bring cases from the subprime mortgage crisis, a Justice Department decision on an appeal of an insider trading ruling and, perhaps, new accounting frauds, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: White-collar crime cases can take years to develop, so today’s headlines often reflect what happened well in the past. And as we approach the end of 2014, there is a sense, to steal a line from Yogi Berra, that it’s like déjà vu all over again.

headline: Learning Mexican Cooking From Diana Kennedy
abstract: Recommendations for the new year, including a vow to drink rosé in winter, seafood delivered to your door and more.
lead_paragraph: Clean out the spice shelf and drink rosé in winter: These are my culinary resolutions for 2015. Here are a few other suggestions for the new year.

headline: Survivors Airlifted From Burning Ferry
abstract: Video from the Italian Coast Guard shows a ferry in flames off the coast of Greece. The vessel, carrying 422 passengers and 56 crew members, was on its way to Italy.
lead_paragraph: Video from the Italian Coast Guard shows a ferry in flames off the coast of Greece. The vessel, carrying 422 passengers and 56 crew members, was on its way to Italy.

headline: Shake Shack Files to Go Public
abstract: The chain plans to use the I.P.O. proceeds to open new Shake Shacks and renovate old ones, as well as pay down some debt.
lead_paragraph: A onetime hot dog cart is on its way to becoming a global company listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Add This to Your Busy Schedule: Time With Family and Friends
abstract: In our professional lives, metrics for efficiency and effectiveness make a lot of sense, but don’t structure your leisure time in the same way. Let go of the numbers and make people the focus.
lead_paragraph: If I ask, “How are you today?” I already have a good idea what you’ll say.

headline: Charities That Inspire Kids: Mobile Loaves and Fishes
abstract: Mobile Loaves and Fishes inspires Claudia Barlow and her daughter, Bailey, to work with a community of homeless and formerly homeless people in Austin, Tex.
lead_paragraph: This week, we’re sharing stories from children, teenagers and families about the charities that inspire them to give time, money and passion. Mobile Loaves and Fishes in Austin, Tex., inspired Claudia Barlow to write.My 13-year-old daughter, Bailey, and I have been volunteering with Mobile Loaves and Fishes, an Austin-based organization that serves the homeless, for the last year and a half.

headline: Jets Owner Discusses Firings
abstract: Woody Johnson, the owner of the Jets, discussed why he fired Rex Ryan as coach and John Idzik as general manager, saying, “I thought it was in the best interest of the team to do it.”
lead_paragraph: Woody Johnson, the owner of the Jets, discussed why he fired Rex Ryan as coach and John Idzik as general manager, saying, “I thought it was in the best interest of the team to do it.”

headline: Most Gay Men Still Excluded From Giving Blood
abstract: Under the F.D.A.’s new policy, any man who has had sex with another man in the last year may not donate.
lead_paragraph: Last week the Food and Drug Administration scrapped its decades-old de facto ban on blood donation by gay and bisexual men—and replaced it with another de facto ban on blood donation by gay and bisexual men.

headline: 2014: The Year in Interactive Storytelling, Graphics and Multimedia
abstract: Selected Times graphics, visualizations and multimedia stories from 2014.
lead_paragraph: Selected Times graphics, visualizations and multimedia stories from 2014.

headline: Where Have All the Counselors Gone?
abstract: Education tends to be a very politicized subject, and nobody wants to be seen as part of a system that comes up short for students.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Elizabeth Harris reported on the shortage of counselors in the public school system. Nationally, the ratio is nearly 500 students to one counselor. Ms. Harris explains how she assembled her piece.

headline: Fire Damages Another Islamic Site in Sweden
abstract: A room in southern Sweden used as a worship center was destroyed by fire, the second instance of suspected arson against Muslims in less than a week.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A basement room used as a place of worship by Muslims in a southern Swedish town was destroyed by a fire on Monday, officials and the imam for the town said. It was the second time in the past week that an Islamic worship center was damaged by a fire in Sweden, where a far-right party with an anti-immigration stance has been gaining support and influence.

headline: Imam Discusses Swedish Mosque Fire
abstract: Samir Muric, an imam in Eslov, spoke after a fire ripped through a Swedish mosque on Monday, causing concerns among Muslims.
lead_paragraph: Samir Muric, an imam in Eslov, spoke after a fire ripped through a Swedish mosque on Monday, causing concerns among Muslims.

headline: A Greek Revival of Anxiety, Some Say Without Foundation
abstract: Analysts remained divided as to whether the election of a new government in Greece will signal a return to the dark days of the European debt crisis.
lead_paragraph: Greek agita is back. Or is it?

headline: Why Greece’s New Crisis Isn’t Spreading to the Rest of Europe
abstract: This time around, financial markets seem to view Greece’s problems as limited to Greece. That’s great, unless the markets are wrong.
lead_paragraph: Remember “Grexit”? That would be the term, coined by Citigroup analysts in 2012, for Greece exiting the euro currency area, an event that at the time seemed to threaten the very idea of a united Europe and sent tremors through the global economy.

headline: Mayor Congratulates New Police Officers
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio received a mixed reaction on Monday at the New York Police Department graduation ceremony.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio received a mixed reaction on Monday at the New York Police Department graduation ceremony.

headline: Allianz Is to Share in Payouts Over 3 Malaysia-Linked Air Disasters
abstract: The German insurance giant faces responsibility as the lead reinsurer for AirAsia and Malaysia Airlines.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The German insurance giant Allianz will be partly responsible for an estimated hundreds of millions of dollars in payouts on three major passenger jet disasters this year, including that of AirAsia Flight 8501, which is thought to have crashed into the sea on Sunday.

headline: Navalny on Putin, Being Bugged and Revolution
abstract: Aleksei A. Navalny rose to prominence as an anticorruption blogger with a special knack for turning a memorable phrase.
lead_paragraph: Aleksei A. Navalny rose to prominence as an anticorruption blogger with a special knack for turning a memorable phrase.

headline: New Life for a Fanciful Tale of Mortals and Sprites
abstract: A new version of the 1866 ballet “La Source” is running at Palais Garnier.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A beautiful water sprite falls in love with a mortal man, but that love leads to her death. Spirits watch humans make a mess of things, occasionally intervening to beneficent effect. A magical flower causes people to fall in love. Two women, one earthly and one spiritual, are potential mates for the mortal hero.

headline: Pakistani Judge Upholds Bail for Suspect in Mumbai Attacks
abstract: The Islamabad High Court said that Zaki-ur-Rehman Lakhvi, who is accused of masterminding the 2008 Mumbai attacks, should be able to win his release.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Islamabad High Court said on Monday that the militant commander accused of masterminding the 2008 Mumbai terrorist attacks should be allowed to post bail and win his release, despite government efforts to continue holding him.

headline: A History of Ebola in 24 Outbreaks
abstract: A review of the two dozen recorded Ebola outbreaks suggests some common themes.
lead_paragraph: A review of the two dozen recorded Ebola outbreaks suggests some common themes.

headline: Documents Reveal Details of F.B.I. Inquiry Into Nevada Senator
abstract: The documents disclose for the first time how much John. E. Ensign strong-armed political donors to find lobbying work for the husband of a woman he had an affair with.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was one of Capitol Hill’s most salacious scandals, featuring a senator’s affair with a campaign aide, an outraged husband, tens of thousands of dollars in hush money, illicit lobbying deals with Las Vegas power brokers and a dramatic intervention by a leading Christian ministry.

headline: A Kansas Town Rallies for a Modest Lifeline: A Local Grocery Store
abstract: Plains has struggled in ways familiar to many towns in the Midwest. A grocery store, some residents believe, would afford them more than just fresh food.
lead_paragraph: PLAINS, Kan. — Here in southwest Kansas, where small communities have struggled since the Dust Bowl to retain businesses and residents, a town’s viability is measured by what has not yet closed. Losing a post office is considered the kiss of death. Losing a school can be a terminal diagnosis.

headline: Giants Are Said to Hold Steady With Coughlin
abstract: Seeing improvement in the latter stages of a second straight losing season, team management granted Coach Tom Coughlin a reprieve.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants may have lost 19 of their past 32 games and failed to make the playoffs in five of the past six seasons, but there will be no major changes in leadership next season. The brain trust treasures continuity, has faith in Coach Tom Coughlin and wants to avoid putting Eli Manning through a second revamping of the offensive system in two years.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ a Hit With Pirates, Too
abstract: The HBO fantasy series “Game of Thrones” was the most pirated TV show in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Like the general television viewing audience, viewers of pirated programming spent 2014 enjoying intrigue, bloodshed, superheroes, dragons, zombies and a bit of gratuitous nudity – they just didn’t feel like paying for it.

headline: How Ebola Roared Back
abstract: For a fleeting moment last spring, the epidemic sweeping West Africa might have been stopped. But the opportunity to control the virus, which has now caused more than 7,800 deaths, was lost.
lead_paragraph: On the flight back to Atlanta, Dr. Pierre Rollin snoozed in Seat 26C in his usual imperturbable way, arms folded, head bobbing, oblivious to loudspeaker announcements and the periodic passing of the galley cart.

headline: At Broadway Box Offices, a Happy Holiday Season
abstract: Several Broadway shows are hitting theatrical high notes as 2014 comes to a close.
lead_paragraph: Several Broadway shows are hitting theatrical high notes as the curtain comes down on 2014, according to box office data released on Monday.

headline: The Goal: To Widen the Appeal of a Sport
abstract: “Road to the NHL Winter Classic,” on Epix, is a four-part special leading up to the National Hockey League’s annual outdoor game.
lead_paragraph: The National Hockey League really hit on something when, on New Year’s Day 2008, it staged the first Winter Classic, an ordinary regular-season hockey game made extraordinary by the setting: outdoors, in a big stadium.

headline: Guggenheim’s Works & Process Series to Offer Dancing, Singing and More
abstract: The spring season of the Guggenheim Museum’s Works & Process series offers a varied lineup, from ballet to a discussion with a professor of psychiatry.
lead_paragraph: A world premiere, a Tony Award winner and a Japanese puppet are scheduled for the Guggenheim Museum’s Works & Process series, organizers announced Monday. The series, which offers audiences insight into creators and performers of coming works, begins its spring season with a preview of “Heatscape,” Justin Peck’s new work for Miami City Ballet, on Jan. 18 and 19 — two months before its scheduled debut.

headline: In Performance | James Earl Jones
abstract: Mr. Jones performs a monologue from the Broadway revival of Moss Hart and George S. Kaufman’s 1936 comedy “You Can’t Take It With You,” at the Longacre Theater.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Jones performs a monologue from the Broadway revival of Moss Hart and George S. Kaufman’s 1936 comedy “You Can’t Take It With You,” at the Longacre Theater.

headline: For Symphonic Treasures, the Freshness of Youth
abstract: The New York String Orchestra performed Tchaikovsky’s Serenade for Strings (Op. 48) at Carnegie Hall on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: On the second page of the score to his Serenade for Strings (Op. 48), Tchaikovsky wrote an inscription that indicates the sound he had in mind for the piece. “The larger the number of players in the string orchestra,” the note reads, “the more this shall be in accordance with the author’s wishes.”

headline: The Appeal of the Parent-Child Rom-Com
abstract: In movies where adults fall for children, parents, nonparents and children alike see an idealized version of what they want in their own family relationships.
lead_paragraph: I’ve recently discovered a hidden movie genre: the parent-child romantic comedy. They’re not advertised as such, but the theme is unmistakable: a parent-child rom-com is a story in which an adult falls in love with a child, usually culminating in adoption (or step-parenthood).

headline: Contemporary Art Sizzles in Shanghai
abstract: The Power Station of Art blew onto the contemporary art scene in Shanghai in 2012 and is finding its footing.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Few knew what to expect of the Power Station of Art when it blew onto the contemporary art scene here in 2012. Just one year earlier, the Power Station — the first state-owned contemporary art museum in China — had been but a half-baked idea in the minds of local government officials intent on transforming Shanghai into an international cultural capital.

headline: The Sum Of All My Fears
abstract: I talk about plagues, AI, and economics.
lead_paragraph: Ezra Klein asks, What Is Paul Krugman Afraid Of? Um, interviews that are fine, as far as they go, but use an old photo? Actually, no problem. Did I say anything interesting? I have no idea.

headline: Walkabout:  Tragedies on the Water, in the Air
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Rescue Effort Helicopter crews on Monday evacuated the last of hundreds of people trapped aboard a Greek ferry that caught fire off Albania. The death toll climbed to eight, as survivors told of a frantic rush to escape the flames and pelting rain. (Associated Press via The New York Times)

headline: Capitalism, as Woven Through Cotton
abstract: “Empire of Cotton: A Global History” shows how much has been missed in studies focused on the vulnerable without incorporating the structural advantages of the powerful.
lead_paragraph: After a quarter-century of tightly focused studies, historians are addressing extended periods of time and the global dimensions of history. As Thomas Piketty did in “Capital in the 21st Century,” his excellent recent study of wealth and inequality, Sven Beckert takes the long view in “Empire of Cotton: A Global History.” Mr. Beckert’s book is more broadly framed and more readable, but at its heart, as in Mr. Piketty’s book, is inequality.

headline: Freeze Frames of Canada’s Ice Huts
abstract: A photographer has traveled through Canada’s frozen climes in search of ice huts, primitive, portable shelters built by fishermen.
lead_paragraph: A photographer has traveled through Canada’s frozen climes in search of ice huts, primitive, portable shelters built by fishermen.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Indonesia and Elsewhere
abstract: Indonesia and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Indonesia and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day

headline: British Group Toughens Its Code for Art Sales
abstract: Publicly funded museums that seek to sell important work will face tougher sanctions from the Museums Association in Britain.
lead_paragraph: Publicly funded museums that seek to sell important work will face tougher sanctions from the Museums Association in Britain, The Independent reported. The move comes after the Northampton Borough Council decided to sell an ancient Egyptian statue owned by the Northampton Museum and Art Gallery. After that sale, through Christie’s in July, the association barred the Northampton council from its membership, and Arts Council England revoked the accreditations of the Northampton museum as well as the Abington Park Museum, also run by the borough council, for five years. The Museums Association is further tightening its ethics code to help stem sell-offs of valuable antiquities from collections run by financially struggling institutions, and it is in talks with Arts Council England, the Heritage Lottery Fund and the Art Fund to establish a joint response to such sales. The Museums Association’s director, Sharon Heal, said the association was not opposed to sales “if museums act in an ethical way in respect to the public, the collection and the museum.”

headline: Respect and Awards, but Still No Oscar
abstract: Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne explain the genesis of “Two Days, One Night,” which did not make the Academy’s shortlist of foreign films.
lead_paragraph: Another Oscar season, another snub for the Dardenne brothers. Their “Two Days, One Night,” Belgium’s submission for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film, won various festival and critics’ awards, as well as a European Film Award this month for Marion Cotillard’s taut performance as a factory worker whose job is in jeopardy. But the drama did not make the cut for the Oscar shortlist — the fourth time that the Dardennes, two of the most acclaimed European filmmakers, have been passed over by Hollywood.

headline: It’s a Tragedy, Even With the Clowns
abstract: “Burning Bluebeard,” a play set around a 1903 theater fire, has become a tradition in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — As holiday traditions go, the play “Burning Bluebeard” doesn’t exactly seem like a natural: no Cratchits, no elves, no Grinches, no sugarplum fairies. Its place in the season is all about timing. It’s based on the real-life story of a fatal fire that happened in the week between Christmas and New Year’s Day — and it’s told by clowns.

headline: Gun Smuggling on Plane Reveals Security Oversight
abstract: On Dec. 10, a man carrying a backpack containing 16 firearms with ammunition flew aboard a Delta Air Lines passenger jet to Kennedy International Airport in New York from Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport.
lead_paragraph: CRITICS who have long complained that airport security measures are mostly “security theater” have given a recent aviation gun-smuggling drama poor reviews.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Cuba’s Art Scene Awaits a Travel Boom
abstract: In Cuba, artists are cut off from supplies and the Internet yet celebrated by a coterie of international buyers, a pipeline that is likely to grow.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — Kadir López was working in his studio at his elegant home here when the doorbell rang. It was Will Smith and his wife, Jada Pinkett Smith.

headline: Sounds That Lingered: Critics’ Top 10 Concerts
abstract: Pop and jazz critics of The New York Times recall some of this year’s standout performances.
lead_paragraph: A critic’s year leaves memories, some fonder than others. Here, in order of preference, are pop and jazz standouts.

headline: Turkey Strengthens Rights of Syrian Refugees
abstract: New ID cards will grant access to basic health care and education, while a separate proposal would allow conditional work permits.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey has issued new regulations that grant Syrian refugees secure legal status in the country for the first time, clarifying and expanding rights for more than a million people who are rapidly assimilating into Turkish society.

headline: 2014: The Year in Questions – Quiz Answers
abstract: The answers for our ninth annual Op-Ed quiz.
lead_paragraph: 1. B – Uber

headline: Seeking to Ride on China’s Stock Market Highs
abstract: Risks abound for ordinary citizens who are piling into the stock markets at a pace not seen since 2007.
lead_paragraph: Kuang Qingming, a banker in Beijing, made a snap investment decision this fall.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Indonesia and Elsewhere
abstract: Indonesia and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Indonesia and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day

headline: Are We Really Eating Too Much Sugar?
abstract: Readers, including nutritionists and the Sugar Association, respond to an Op-Ed essay calling sugar addictive.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Police Funeral: Moving Words, and a Call for Respect
abstract: Readers react to coverage of the funeral of Officer Rafael Ramos, one of two officers killed by a gunman.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: More Help for Tunisia, a Mideast Success Story
abstract: A former Foreign Service officer appeals for more American support for Tunisia’s fledgling democracy.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Benefits of the Arts
abstract: Louise Slaughter, co-chairwoman of the Congressional Arts Caucus, writes about the benefits of the arts on the brain development of children.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
