headline: Quit Whining About Your Sick Colleague
abstract: Your irritation says more about the rat race than it does about the risk of disease.
lead_paragraph: WE all know the type: the colleague who comes in to work, red-eyed and drippy, and puts his germy fingers on the handle of the coffeepot or the button of the microwave door. He could have called in sick, but that would take a modicum of decency. No, this guy is a “team player.” He’s a cubicle Cal Ripken Jr., the office iron man with Sudafed.

headline: 3 Men Accused of Throwing Bleach at Anti-Fur Protesters in Manhattan
abstract: A mixture of bleach and ammonia missed the demonstrators, splashing onto bystanders and two strollers, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Three Manhattan fur vendors have been charged with throwing bleach and ammonia from a roof at a group of anti-fur protesters in SoHo, though the mixture missed its targets, splashing onto the clothes of some bystanders and onto two baby carriages, according to the police.

headline: In Los Angeles, Warm Receptions
abstract: Mike Woodson and Lawrence Frank, fired by New York teams, are now Doc Rivers’s assistants with the Los Angeles Clippers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After Toronto Raptors guard Greivis Vasquez sank yet another open jumper on Saturday, Los Angeles Clippers Coach Doc Rivers turned toward the bench and took a seat. His look of resignation, with the Clippers on their way to a convincing defeat on their home court, was certainly a familiar one to the two men who sat on either side of Rivers.

headline: The Soup and Soul Kitchen
abstract: This soup kitchen has a grand piano. And sometimes Broadway performers stop by to sing and play. Only at the Church of the Holy Apostles. Only in New York.
lead_paragraph: This soup kitchen has a grand piano. And sometimes Broadway performers stop by to sing and play. Only at the Church of the Holy Apostles. Only in New York.

headline: European Start-Ups Struggle to Keep Pace With Venture Financing
abstract: Europe’s tech companies are always eager to prove that they can compete with their U.S. counterparts, but still find it tough to raise money from venture capital firms.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Working from converted warehouses in East London and start-up lofts in trendy Berlin, Europe’s tech companies are always eager to prove that they can compete with their American counterparts.

headline: Pictures of the Day — Dec. 29, 2014
abstract: Photos from Indonesia, the West Bank, Italy and Iran.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Indonesia, the West Bank, Italy and Iran.

headline: At a Manhattan Soup Kitchen, Food on the Table and Chops on the Piano
abstract: At the Church of the Holy Apostles in Chelsea, hungry guests hear the clean, clear notes of a concert grand piano played by volunteers.
lead_paragraph: The line of men — they are almost all men — backs up around the corner on West 28th Street in Manhattan, turns and follows the iron fence line along Ninth Avenue and through the gates of the Church of the Holy Apostles. A worker at the door hands each a ticket, and from that point on, they are referred to as guests.

headline: Representative Steve Scalise of Louisiana Acknowledges Addressing Racist Group in 2002
abstract: Mr. Scalise, the No. 3 House Republican, spoke to the European-American Unity and Rights Organization, which was founded by the former Klan leader David Duke.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Steve Scalise of Louisiana, the No. 3 Republican in the House, addressed a group of white supremacists and neo-Nazis in 2002, a Scalise spokeswoman confirmed Monday as his party prepared to take control of both chambers of Congress.

headline: In a Position Beyond His Control
abstract: A flight attendant’s mishap foils the usual early-morning flight plan for the chief operating officer of the Breeders’ Cup.
lead_paragraph: A LOT of my career was spent in the banking industry. I didn’t travel much for work, and if I did it was all short-haul regional trips. Every now and then I would get to go to some big group meeting that involved a longer flight and I would get kind of excited. Though business travel was limited, my wife and I always enjoyed traveling for leisure and exploring the world. Neither of us had that opportunity when we were growing up, and now that we have children we want to show them what the world offers, both here and overseas.

headline: The Sidney Awards, Part 2
abstract: Here are the rest of the Sidney Awards for the outstanding essays of 2014.
lead_paragraph: The most powerful woman in the world may also be the most effective leader in the world. We kick off the second volley of the year’s best magazine essays by giving a Sidney Award to George Packer’s “The Quiet German,” a superb profile of Angela Merkel, which appeared in The New Yorker. (For Part 1 of the Sidney Awards, click here.)

headline: Jackson Asks Knicks Fans to Take a Sky-High Leap of Faith
abstract: Phil Jackson, the Knicks’ president, has asked fans to be patient, but the Knicks lack the kind of breakout players Jackson worked with in winning championships as a coach.
lead_paragraph: Once again, Knicks fans are being asked to take a leap of faith.

headline: For Solution to Income Stagnation, Republicans and Democrats Revise Their Playbooks
abstract: The economy has finally emerged from the financial crisis and the recession of 2007-9, but the long stagnation of middle-class incomes continues.
lead_paragraph: For average American families, the United States economy is like a football team that cannot move the ball, and has not been able to for 30 years.

headline: M.T.A. Officer, Hit by Car in 2013, Dies
abstract: Officer Thomas Choi, who was struck by a car on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, was the first officer of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s bridges and tunnels division to die in its 81-year history.
lead_paragraph: An officer for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority who was struck by a car on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge last year died from his injuries on Monday, officials said.

headline: Four Questions for 2015
abstract: Looking at some topics explored this year and making some predictions.
lead_paragraph: Will President Obama approve the Keystone XL oil pipeline? Up until recently, I always assumed that Obama would, sooner or later, despite the protests of the environmental community. In March 2012, for instance, he spoke positively about the proposed pipeline, which would bring oil mined from the tar sands of Alberta to refineries along the Gulf of Mexico. In addition, approval of the pipeline is important to the government of Canada, our neighbor and ally.

headline: An Economic Boom Recedes, but South America Might Avert the Bust
abstract: Governments of Brazil, Peru and Venezuela are seen as less likely than before to load up on debt and ignore danger signs.
lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru — The president of Venezuela calls for budget cuts as plummeting oil prices slash the country’s export income. Peru relaxes environmental regulations to clear the way for major mining projects, hoping to lift production in the face of falling prices of copper, gold and other metals. In Brazil, hurt by slumping prices for iron and soybean exports, a new, business-friendly cabinet is expected to cut spending and eliminate tax breaks to shore up government finances.

headline: Respect for NYPD Squandered in Attacks on Bill de Blasio
abstract: Acts of passive-aggressive contempt aimed at Mayor Bill de Blasio by New York police officers are disgraceful, and they are damaging the department’s credibility.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio has spent weeks expressing his respect and admiration for the New York Police Department, while calling for unity in these difficult days, but the message doesn’t seem to be sinking in.

headline: Assessing Punitive Damages in Possible G.M. Suit
abstract: Excerpts from a report prepared by Anton R. Valukas, who has been hired by General Motors to investigate its handling of an ignition switch defect, signal the possibility of the carmaker being liable for punitive damages.
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from a report prepared by Anton R. Valukas, who has been hired by General Motors to investigate its handling of an ignition switch defect, signal the possibility of the carmaker being liable for punitive damages.

headline: Lawyer Declines to Take On G.M. Suit
abstract: Noting the maximum amount that can be recovered, a partner at a Wisconsin law firm said it would be unwilling to pursue litigation against General Motors.
lead_paragraph: Noting the maximum amount that can be recovered, a partner at a Wisconsin law firm said it would be unwilling to pursue litigation against General Motors.

headline: Britain: Ebola Case Reported in Glasgow
abstract: A woman who had been working in Sierra Leone was being treated Monday for Ebola in a Glasgow hospital.
lead_paragraph: A woman who had been working in Sierra Leone was being treated Monday for Ebola in a Glasgow hospital. The woman, identified only as a health care worker for Britain’s National Health Service, arrived in Glasgow on Sunday night via Casablanca, Morocco, and Heathrow Airport in London, the Scottish government said. The Scottish first minister, Nicola Sturgeon, said the woman was believed to have had contact with only one person in Glasgow. Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt said the woman would be transferred soon to a specialist unit in London. Britain’s only previous case in the current outbreak was William Pooley, a nurse who also contracted the disease in Sierra Leone. He survived.

headline: Cuomo and Christie Stop Real Reform
abstract: The governors of New York and New Jersey chose to ignore the will of their state legislatures and try to maintain their iron grip over the Port Authority.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey have fumbled a great opportunity to reshape the notoriously secretive, patronage-ridden Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Rather than approve fundamental reforms passed by near-unanimous votes in both state legislatures, the two governors are proposing a weaker set of changes that would leave largely undisturbed their iron grip over the authority. For good measure, they have demanded the resignations of all present commissioners, which would give them even greater control going forward.

headline: Guards Retreat in London, but Just a Bit
abstract: At some residences for the queen’s family, the guards have moved behind gates, and farther from tourists, because of concerns about terrorism.
lead_paragraph: With their scarlet tunics, black bearskin caps and impassive faces, the guards standing watch outside Britain’s royal palaces are as much a tourist attraction as Big Ben and the Tower of London. But it is getting harder to see them.

headline: 3 Shots From Police Killed Los Angeles Man, Autopsy Finds
abstract: Ezell Ford’s autopsy report, which was released on Monday, had originally been withheld in the days after the shooting of Michael Brown by a Ferguson, Mo., police officer.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — An unarmed black man killed in August by Los Angeles police died of gunshot wounds to his back and side, according to an autopsy report released Monday.

headline: Court Filing Illuminates Morgan Stanley Role in Lending
abstract: Emails and documents filed in court provide a look at the extent to which Morgan Stanley influenced New Century’s push into riskier mortgages in the run-up to the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Since the financial crisis, Wall Street firms have argued that they were victims, just like everybody else, of the bad mortgages that were churned out by subprime lenders like Countrywide and New Century.

headline: Silver Spoons, Few Trophies
abstract: New York sports fans have come to expect men who have successfully built on family fortunes to meddle infuriatingly and fail miserably as team owners.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Woody Johnson does not quite take command of a room as much as he blends in. His manner is amiable but guarded. His sartorial message — a ubiquitous Jets cap that shouts jock informality offset by the seriousness of a dark business suit — is curiously mixed. His voice is shallow enough to be almost drowned out by photographers at work.

headline: U.S. Said to Investigate Sheldon Silver, New York Assembly Speaker, Over Payments
abstract: Mr. Silver is being investigated for payments he received from a firm specializing in an area of law far removed from his personal injury law background.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities are investigating substantial payments made to the State Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, by a small law firm that seeks real estate tax reductions for commercial and residential properties in New York City, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Deterring Cyberattacks From North Korea
abstract: The recent hacking on Sony Pictures should cause corporations and governments to redouble efforts to protect their networks.
lead_paragraph: The recent cyberattack on Sony Pictures, which the Obama administration said was committed by North Korea, shows how far the United States still has to go to deter such intrusions, despite warnings by officials and experts about cybersecurity dangers. Countless assaults on America’s computer networks by China and other foreign governments, hackers and criminals have demonstrated the urgent need for safeguards.

headline: Accepting Health Care
abstract: A sharp drop in Kentucky’s uninsured rate has made it a symbol of the Affordable Care Act’s potential, but some residents still delay signing up.
lead_paragraph: A sharp drop in Kentucky’s uninsured rate has made it a symbol of the Affordable Care Act’s potential, but some residents still delay signing up.

headline: Success of Kentucky’s Health Plan Comes With New Obstacles
abstract: A poor state with a starkly unhealthy populace, Kentucky is becoming a symbol of the Affordable Health Care Act’s potential, and its obstacles.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — In many ways, Kentucky, a poor state with a starkly unhealthy populace, has become a symbol of the Affordable Care Act’s potential.

headline: Austerity, From Street Level in Greece
abstract: The vast majority of Greeks are still experiencing the hardships of reform, with little evidence that the measures are working.
lead_paragraph: The vast majority of Greeks are still experiencing the hardships of reform, with little evidence that the measures are working.

headline: Greek Patience With Austerity Nears Its Limit
abstract: The vast majority of Greeks are still experiencing the hardships of reform, with little evidence that the measures are working.
lead_paragraph: NEA IONIA, Greece — Alexandra Nikolovieni, 55, lost her job escorting young children on a school bus four years ago and has not been able to find another one since. To help financially, her daughter and her son-in-law, who have two children, moved into her house. But now they have lost their jobs, too.

headline: Hurdle in Hunt for Missing Jet: Tracking System
abstract: As the search for AirAsia’s Flight 8501 continued, aviation experts said the difficulty in locating it underscored the limitations in how planes are tracked.
lead_paragraph: Just nine months after a Malaysia Airlines flight vanished, the puzzling loss of another passenger plane once again has highlighted an urgent question: How can modern jetliners simply disappear in today’s hyper-connected world?

headline: Timothy Dowd, Detective Who Led Son of Sam Manhunt, Dies at 99
abstract: Under Inspector Dowd’s direction, over 300 police officers scoured New York City for the serial killer, David Berkowitz, in a search described as a needle-in-a-haystack endeavor.
lead_paragraph: Timothy J. Dowd, the New York City police detective who led the manhunt that finally ensnared David Berkowitz, the serial killer who called himself the Son of Sam and whose yearlong shooting spree and evasion of the police spread fear across the five boroughs, died on Friday in Millbrook, N.Y. He was 99.

headline: Victims of G.M. Deadly Defect Fall Through Legal Cracks
abstract: The experience of some accident victims and their families shows that opportunities to raise public alarm bells about defective ignition switches were sometimes lost.
lead_paragraph: The law firm was unequivocal. It refused to take the case against General Motors involving a car crash that killed 18-year-old Natasha Weigel, saying that the value of her life in a lawsuit was too small to justify the expense and risk of litigation.

headline: Gathering Bedfellows, Odd and Otherwise, for Auld Lang Syne
abstract: Toasting and roasting the guests we’d like to invite for our annual DealBook “Closing Dinner.”
lead_paragraph: Dinner is about to begin. Please, take your seats.

headline: Ricardo Porro, Exiled Cuban Architect, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Porro’s architecture gave lyrical expression to a hopeful young Cuban revolution in the early 1960s before he himself fell victim to its ideological hardening.
lead_paragraph: Ricardo Porro, an architect who gave lyrical expression to a hopeful young Cuban revolution in the early 1960s before he himself fell victim to its ideological hardening, died on Thursday in Paris, where he had spent nearly half a century in exile. He was 89.

headline: Raising Grandchildren to Honor Her Daughter’s Dying Wish
abstract: Glenda Gomez adopted the two young children of her daughter Suhany Vasquez, who died of breast cancer in 2012. Providing for the family, which totals seven members, is a challenge.
lead_paragraph: To honor her child’s dying wish, Glenda Gomez became a mother again at age 54.

headline: Yankees Send Shawn Kelley to Padres for Johnny Barbato
abstract: In a transaction that added youth and saved money, the Yankees traded Kelley, a pitcher who missed much of last year with an elbow injury.
lead_paragraph: In another transaction that adds youth to the team and saves a few dollars, the Yankees traded the veteran right-handed relief pitcher Shawn Kelley to the San Diego Padres for a 22-year-old minor league right-hander, Johnny Barbato, a promising pitcher who missed much of last year with an elbow injury.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 29, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Smaller Footprints on the World's Welcome Mats
abstract: How can tourism flourish while causing as little harm as possible?

headline: Brooklyn Woman, at Ski Resort, Dies After Fall From a Chair Lift
abstract: Olga Filkin was riding up the slope alone at the Hunter Mountain Ski Resort when the accident occurred, the New York State Police said.
lead_paragraph: A 44-year-old Brooklyn woman fell more than 20 feet from a ski lift at Hunter Mountain Ski Resort over the weekend and died, the New York State Police said on Monday.

headline: Not a Pool
abstract: Go for a spin with Jeffrey Wechsler.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Did you notice that today’s puzzle looks a little bit wider than usual? (Not that I’m being judgmental — at this point in December I’m also wider than usual.) Look carefully and you’ll see that the grid is 16 units across instead of the regular 15. That’s because Jeffrey Wechsler, today’s constructor, has come up with a creative theme that calls for some extra room on the grid. And that means more puzzle for us.

headline: New Year’s Day Holiday Closings in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut
abstract: Transit schedules, parking rules and various closings that will take effect on New Year’s Day.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: Lost Dreams of Home Ownership in Hangzhou
abstract: Investors in a never-completed housing complex are trapped in a state of residential and economic limbo.
lead_paragraph: In “The Casualties in China’s Economy,” also available in Chinese, The New York Times video journalist Jonah M. Kessel reports on the social pressure that young people face to buy an apartment of their own, and what happens when those investments go wrong. Below, he describes the plight of those whose dreams of home ownership have gone awry.

headline: Rex Ryan Might Find Studio a Good Fit
abstract: If Ryan does not land another coaching job, he may be a natural in the TV studio.
lead_paragraph: Rex Ryan’s dismissal as coach of the Jets means that he can fulfill his destiny and become a studio analyst.

headline: Gleb Yakunin, Russian Priest and Dissident, Is Dead at 80
abstract: Father Yakunin challenged the Soviet government for its restrictions on religious liberty and accused the hierarchy of his own church of collaborating with the K.G.B.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Gleb Yakunin, a priest who fought the Soviet government for restricting religious rights, attacked the leaders of his Russian Orthodox Church for failing to defend those rights, and spent much of the 1980s in a prison camp and exile, died on Thursday in Moscow. He was 80.

headline: ‘Brazen,’ but Not Actionable
abstract: Some of the documents from the F.B.I.’s investigation of former Senator John Ensign of Nevada reveal that Mr. Ensign used “extremely brazen tactics” to find lobbying work for his mistress’s husband.
lead_paragraph: Some of the documents from the F.B.I.’s investigation of former Senator John Ensign of Nevada reveal that Mr. Ensign used “extremely brazen tactics” to find lobbying work for his mistress’s husband.

headline: Woody Johnson Wants Darrelle Revis to Return. Oops, Sorry.
abstract: Johnson may or may not have violated the N.F.L.'s tampering rules in explaining why the Jets did not pursue the Patriots’ Revis in March, when he was a free agent.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Woody Johnson would love cornerback Darrelle Revis to play for the Jets again. One problem: Revis is still under contract with the Patriots.

headline: Cuomo Vetoes Bill That Would Protect Teachers From Low Ratings
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, whose own administration drafted the legislation, has indicated in recent days that he wants to make the evaluation system in New York State tougher.
lead_paragraph: In a sharp reversal, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Monday night vetoed a bill that would have protected teachers and principals from receiving a low rating because of their students’ performance on state tests.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 3 P.M. (FXM) SUPER 8 (2011) Steven Spielberg co-produced this film, but that’s not the only service he rendered. He also seems to be its inspiration: Since its release, “Super 8” has drawn usually unfavorable comparisons to “Close Encounters of the Third Kind,” and especially to “E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial.” “Still,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, " ‘not as good as E.T.’ is not so bad.” The film, directed by the Spielberg admirer J. J. Abrams, is about a group of young teenagers (including Gabriel Basso, Ryan Lee, Joel Courtney and Riley Griffiths) in 1979 who are filming a low-budget zombie movie when they witness a violent train derailment. They can’t see much in the chaos of the crash, but it’s possible that their camera saw more. While they wait for the film to be developed, strange things begin happening in their town. Dogs and people disappear, electronics go missing, and the streets fill with soldiers. Mr. Abrams, Mr. Scott wrote, captures his protagonists and their era “with a sense of period detail that sits right on the line between uncanny and neurotic.” He added: “His 1979 is more like 1979 than the real 1979, which hardly seemed like a time of innocence and eager wonder. But no time ever does, except in retrospect.”

headline: Evidence That the Jim Crow Era Endures for Older Black Voters in the South
abstract: In states like North Carolina and Georgia, the black share of registered voters remains low among those who reached voting age before 1965.
lead_paragraph: Democrats have lamented low black turnout for decades, but black turnout today rivals that of white voters. That’s probably in part because of President Obama, but also because of generational replacement.

headline: Michael Grimm, in a Reversal, Will Resign From Congress
abstract: Mr. Grimm, a Republican from Staten Island, announced late Monday night that he would resign, two weeks after he pleaded guilty to felony tax evasion.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Michael G. Grimm, the Republican Party’s lone congressional representative in New York City, announced late on Monday that he would resign effective Jan. 5, two weeks after he pleaded guilty to felony tax evasion.

headline: Man, 84, Dies After Being Found Unresponsive at Queens Spa
abstract: The police were investigating the death of Hock Ma, of Forest Hills, who was found in a hot tub at Spa Castle and pronounced dead at a hospital.
lead_paragraph: An 84-year-old man died on Sunday after he was found unresponsive in a hot tub at a popular spa in Queens, the police said.

headline: Updates on Navalny Verdict
abstract: Times reporters David M. Herszenhorn and Andrew Roth attended a Moscow courtroom for the verdict and sentencing of Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition activist, and provided updates via Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Times reporters David M. Herszenhorn and Andrew Roth attended a Moscow courtroom for the verdict and sentencing of Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition activist, and provided updates via Twitter.

headline: Aleksei Navalny, Putin Critic, Is Spared Prison in a Fraud Case, but His Brother Is Jailed
abstract: Mr. Navalny was not jailed despite violating house arrest by trying to join an antigovernment rally. But in what was widely seen as the Kremlin punishing him, his brother Oleg was sentenced to three and a half years in prison in the fraud case.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Hours after being spared prison on Tuesday in a criminal fraud trial widely viewed as political revenge, the Kremlin’s chief antagonist, Aleksei A. Navalny, broke out of house arrest and tried to join an unsanctioned antigovernment rally, daring the authorities to throw him in jail.

headline: Corrections: December 30, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, December 30, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 30, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “It’s like if a plane crashes in the Hudson in the morning, and there’s a snowstorm in the afternoon and floods in the subways in the evening. And then you have two planes hit the World Trade Center in the middle of the night.”

headline: Searchers Pull AirAsia Plane Debris and Bodies From Java Sea
abstract: Rescue teams off the coast of Borneo found bodies and debris from the AirAsia plane that disappeared Sunday, but it remained unknown why the plane went down.
lead_paragraph: SURABAYA, Indonesia — The mystery of Indonesia’s missing airliner was partly solved on Tuesday, when rescue teams retrieved and tallied a grim inventory of bodies and debris from the plane off the coast of southwestern Borneo.

headline: Freeze Frames of Canada’s Ice Huts
abstract: A photographer has traveled through Canada’s frozen climes in search of ice huts, primitive, portable shelters built by fishermen.
lead_paragraph: Richard Johnson likes ice fishermen just fine. He has shared drinks with them. He has learned a bit about their lives while crammed into the huts where they carve out small patches of warmth from the bitter expanse of cold outside.

headline: Ebola Patient Is Moved to London, and 2 Others Are Tested in Britain
abstract: The patient in the confirmed case in Scotland had worked with a charity in Sierra Leone. Officials were testing two others, in Scotland and England, for the disease.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A health worker who returned from West Africa and was found to have Ebola when she arrived home in Scotland was transferred on Tuesday to Britain’s designated treatment center for the disease in London.

headline: Debris Found in Search for Missing AirAsia Jet
abstract: Rescue teams retrieved life vests, aircraft parts and what appeared to be a small blue suitcase off the coast of Borneo.
lead_paragraph: Rescue teams retrieved life vests, aircraft parts and what appeared to be a small blue suitcase off the coast of Borneo.

headline: Taiwan Considers Medical Parole for Jailed Former President
abstract: Chen Shui-bian, who is serving a 20-year prison sentence, is said to have health problems that include mild brain atrophy, severe depression and Parkinsonism.
lead_paragraph: A team of medical experts has reviewed the case of Taiwan’s imprisoned former president, Chen Shui-bian, fueling expectations that he could soon be released because of health concerns.

headline: Allies of Christie and Cuomo Defend Veto of Changes in Port Authority
abstract: Officials close to the governors of New York and New Jersey said the recommendations of their panel on the bistate agency were better than the reform bills they rejected over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: When the governors of New York and New Jersey rejected legislation over the weekend intended to overhaul operations at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, their opponents lamented what they characterized as the survival of the status quo.

headline: New York Today: Grading the Weatherman
abstract: Tuesday: A look back at the forecasts of 2014, chilly weather, and the mayor meets with police unions.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this cold Tuesday.

headline: Suspect in 2008 Mumbai Attacks Is Held in Pakistan on New Charge
abstract: A senior commander with the militant group Lashkar-e-Taiba was detained just a day after a high court said he could post bail in the Mumbai case.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Islamabad police on Tuesday rearrested a militant commander accused of masterminding the 2008 Mumbai terrorist attacks, just a day after a high court said he could post bail in that case.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: U.S. Embassy Describes Coup Attempt in Gambia
abstract: The Gambian government insisted that “peace and calm” prevailed after gunfire erupted overnight in the capital, Banjul.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Gunfire erupted overnight in Banjul, the capital of the West African nation of Gambia, and residents awoke Tuesday to find government buildings and the main bridge into town sealed off by fidgety soldiers.

headline: Daily Report: Latest Financing for Xiaomi, Chinese Smartphone Maker, Raises Value to $45 Billion
abstract: A new round of financing raised $1.1 billion for the company, which has become one of the world’s biggest smartphone makers by offering cheap, high-quality phones through clever online marketing campaigns.
lead_paragraph: Xiaomi, the fast-rising Chinese smartphone maker, has mustered a new $1.1 billion war chest in its latest round of fund-raising, the company’s founder and chief executive said on Monday, Neil Gough reports.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: Representative Michael G. Grimm of New York insisted last week that he would not resign from his seat, even after pleading guilty to federal tax evasion charges. On Monday night, he changed his mind.
lead_paragraph: After Boehner Meeting, an About-Face as Grimm Says He’ll Resign

headline: Prison Sentence for Maker of Documentary on Chinese Constitutional Rule
abstract: The filmmaker, Shen Yongping, was detained in April and formally arrested on June 4, the 25th anniversary of the military crackdown on student-led protesters in 1989.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese filmmaker who made a documentary on the Chinese Constitution and efforts to get the ruling Communist Party and the government to abide by constitutional law was sentenced on Tuesday by a Beijing district court to one year in prison for running an “illegal business,” his lawyer said.

headline: In Performance: James Earl Jones of ‘You Can’t Take It With You’
abstract: Mr. Jones performs a scene from the Broadway revival of the 1936 comedy.
lead_paragraph: The In Performance series ends 2014 with a prayer from James Earl Jones. In the Broadway revival of Moss Hart and George S. Kaufman’s 1936 comedy “You Can’t Take It With You,” Mr. Jones plays the head of an unconventional family living under the same roof during the Great Depression. In this scene he offers thanks for heavenly guidance through tough but funny times. The show, directed by Scott Ellis, is at the Longacre Theater.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: 1939: Hitler Appeals to God
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: 1939: Hitler appeals to God for protection in the New Year.
lead_paragraph: GERMAN FRONTIER — In a New Year’s order of the day today, Führer Adolf Hitler chose the ‘‘Gott mit uns’’ theme of the last war even though the ideology symbolized by the swastika looks to a Nazi-made Valhalla.

headline: New Yorkers Get Lost, Too
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Fearful of being late, a young woman switched from bus to cab to subway, and then worried she was on the wrong train.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The Art World’s Patron Satan
abstract: Stefan Simchowitz has supported dozens of emerging young artists. Why do so many people hate him?
lead_paragraph: At 3 a.m. on Oct. 9, 2013,the 24-year-old conceptual artist Amalia Ulman woke up in a hospital in rural Pennsylvania with a bone sticking out of her leg. She had been in an accident: The Greyhound bus that was taking her from New York to Chicago to curate a show had smashed into a garbage rig, killing one passenger and wounding dozens of others. She needed surgery. She also needed a lawyer. Ulman knew that her parents, who lived in northern Spain, would be of no help. “Who do I know in the States who’s not a kid on heroin?” she asked herself. After a moment’s thought, Ulman instructed her nurses to contact a man she had met only once: Stefan Simchowitz, the controversial 44-year-old movie producer, Internet entrepreneur and industrial scion who over the last seven years has pursued a manic quest to assemble the world’s most lucrative collection of emerging contemporary art.

headline: The Wreck of the Kulluk
abstract: Three years ago, Shell spent millions to send a colossal oil rig to drill in the remote seas of the Arctic. But the Arctic had other plans.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, Royal Dutch Shell, then the fourth-largest company on Earth, bought a drill rig that was both tall, rising almost 250 feet above the waterline, and unusually round. The hull of the Kulluk, as the rig was called, was made of 1.5-inch-thick steel and rounded to better prevent its being crushed. A 12-point anchor system could keep it locked in place above an oil well for a full day in 18-foot seas or in moving sea ice that was four feet thick. Its drill bit, dropped from a 160-foot derrick, could plunge 600 feet into the sea, then bore another 20,000 feet into the seabed, where it could verify the existence of oil deposits that were otherwise a geologist’s best guess. It had a sauna. It could go (in theory) where few other rigs could go, helping Shell find oil that (in theory) few other oil companies could find.

headline: Pollution Around the World: A Matter of Choices
abstract: Europe’s level of pollution may surprise some people, but it all comes down to a society’s priorities.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I wrote about China and India’s challenges with high particulate matter pollution — widely believed to be the most harmful form of air pollution. A chart comparing air pollution levels caught many eyes because it showed the severity of the problem in China, and even more in India.

headline: T’s Top 10 Design Stories of 2014
abstract: These 10 pieces reveal the new landscape of design, from unusual places to live to a crop of young ceramicists redefining their field.
lead_paragraph: These 10 pieces reveal the new landscape of design, from unusual places to live to a crop of young ceramicists redefining their field. More…

headline: American Workers Say Internet Makes Them More Productive
abstract: A new survey by the Pew Research Center finds that e-mail is very important to three-fifths of American workers, while social media is a blip on the charts.
lead_paragraph: While so many of us at the office this holiday week fritter away our days surfing the Internet, consider this: We claim the Internet has actually made us more productive at work.

headline: Can Writers Still ‘Make It New’?
abstract: Pankaj Mishra and Benjamin Moser debate whether there is any true novelty left for writers to explore.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. Ezra Pound told his fellow writers to “Make it new.” This week, Pankaj Mishra and Benjamin Moser debate whether there is any true novelty left for writers to explore.

headline: The Challenging Patients
abstract: Life expectancy for people with intellectual disability has tripled, but medical practices have failed to keep pace. A team of doctors at a Kentucky clinic offers a comprehensive approach to care.
lead_paragraph: Life expectancy for people with intellectual disability has tripled, but medical practices have failed to keep pace. A team of doctors at a Kentucky clinic offers a comprehensive approach to care.

headline: An Oasis of Care for People With Intellectual Disabilities
abstract: Parents have long struggled to find compassionate health care for adult children with profound disabilities. Those in Kentucky now have a place to go.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — A mother needs to get her son out the door. Thick white socks cover his contorted feet, a coat drapes his twisted shoulders, a water bottle with a straw nestles in the concave of his chest, and black straps on his wheelchair secure his wrists. He is 33 years old, and she has to get him to an appointment.

headline: With Deployment Looming, How Do You Measure a Year?
abstract: I remember us, the day our daughter was born after my husband’s return from Iraq, telling our families that he wouldn’t deploy again “until 2015.”
lead_paragraph: A favorite line, from a favorite song, in my favorite Broadway musical, “Rent.”

headline: Boehner Calls Grimm Resignation ‘Honorable’
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner gave his seal of approval to Representative Michael Grimm’s resignation.
lead_paragraph: Speaker John A. Boehner on Tuesday gave his seal of approval to Representative Michael G. Grimm’s resignation.

headline: Prova to Dish Out Pizza in Chelsea
abstract: Donatella Arpaia has taken back the lease on space that housed her namesake restaurant, which closed about a year ago.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: ‘Fury’s’ Dark Family Tale
abstract: The writer-director David Ayer explains how his World War II film “Fury” is really about a family — one that lives in a tank and goes to battle.
lead_paragraph: “Fury,” the harrowing World War II drama starring Brad Pitt, opened in October to lots of Oscar buzz, but for various reasons – perhaps its dearth of snob appeal, as one awards prognosticator suggested — it is considered a longshot, or even nonshot, in the major awards categories. Still the film managed to lure audiences (it sold lots of tickets) to its telling of the age-old “war is hell” story by focusing on the anarchic last days of war, when the end is foretold but the losing side will not go down without a vicious fight.

headline: No-Shampoo Regimens Replace the Suds
abstract: Co-washing products gain traction in the beauty industry.
lead_paragraph: Michael Gordon, the founder and former president of Bumble and bumble, will tell you that for many people, freshly washed hair is, in simple terms, “not cool.”

headline: Luise Rainer Dies at 104; Won Best Actress Oscars for Two Years Running
abstract: Ms. Rainer, who was born in Germany, left the pressures of Hollywood after winning Oscars in consecutive years in the 1930s.
lead_paragraph: Luise Rainer, who left Nazi Germany for Hollywood and soared to fame in the 1930s as the first star to win back-to-back Oscars, then quit films at the peak of her career for occasional stage work and roles as a wife, mother and mountain climber, died on Tuesday at her home in London. She was 104.

headline: Charities That Inspire Kids: Gift of Life Bone Marrow Foundation
abstract: Their family needed Gift of Life Bone Marrow Foundation’s help, but found that their work to find a donor for their son helped others as well, and inspires them still.
lead_paragraph: This week, we’re sharing stories from children, teenagers and families about the charities that inspire them to give time, money and passion. Robin Fineman wrote about Gift of Life Bone Marrow Foundation, which her family found through unfortunate circumstance, but which inspires them still.

headline: Democrats Pounce After Scalise Revelation
abstract: While the Republican leadership weighs its response to news that Representative Steve Scalise gave a speech to a white supremacist group in 2002, Democrats were quick to pounce on the controversy.
lead_paragraph: While the Republican leadership weighs its response to news that Representative Steve Scalise gave a speech to a white supremacist group in 2002, Democrats were quick to pounce on the controversy.

headline: Officials on AirAsia Flight 8501 Debris
abstract: The Indonesian president, the chief executive of AirAsia and the country’s rescue chief offered condolences to those who lost loved ones in the AirAsia plane crash and discussed the recovery efforts.
lead_paragraph: The Indonesian president, the chief executive of AirAsia and the country’s rescue chief offered condolences to those who lost loved ones in the AirAsia plane crash and discussed the recovery efforts.

headline: 1964: London Portobello Bargains
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: 1964: London’s Portobello Road where scores of colorful characters hold forth.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An Antique dealer who calls himself ‘‘Chip and Dale’’ one might find elsewhere. But ‘‘Cheap and Nasty’’ you’ll find only in London’s Portobello Road.

headline: Beijing’s Art Scene Raises Its Profile
abstract: Fairs and galleries seek to attract buyers with the work of emerging artists.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Sunday afternoon in the sunken terrace of Beijing’s sleek Opposite House Hotel, an art event was in full swing. The wine was chilling, the dumplings steaming and a few dozen locals and foreigners were looking on with curiosity as the artists Yan Wei and Yinmai O’Connor ran their black paintbrushes over the walls, furniture and even the human occupants of a whitewashed room.

headline: Restaurant Report: Marcus in London
abstract: Marcus Wareing at the Berkeley has returned as just plain Marcus, with an airier look, a more flexible menu and a mission to be more casual.
lead_paragraph: Word was that the London chef Marcus Wareing — once a made man in the Gordon Ramsay syndicate but more recently consolidating his own turf — wanted to eliminate some of the formality of his five-year-old restaurant in Knightsbridge. In the news media, there was talk of the end of fine dining. And in March, after a renovation intended to whack the starch out of the décor, Marcus Wareing at the Berkeley returned as just plain Marcus, with a more-airy look, some whimsical art on the walls, a more flexible menu and a mission to be more casual.

headline: Inside North Korea, a Reporter’s Journey
abstract: David E. Sanger, chief Washington correspondent for The Times, recalled a visit to the country 25 years ago.
lead_paragraph: David E. Sanger is the national security correspondent for The Times.

headline: Hotel Review: Hotel am Steinplatz in Berlin
abstract: A luxurious and comfortable experience that has both Old World aristocratic touches as well as a stylish modern feel.
lead_paragraph: ­From 195 euros, about $234 at $1.20 to the euro.

headline: Navalny Reacts to Judge’s Sentencing
abstract: Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader, spoke after a judge suspended Mr. Navalny’s jail sentence, but ordered his younger brother to serve a prison term of three and a half years.
lead_paragraph: Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader, spoke after a judge suspended Mr. Navalny’s jail sentence, but ordered his younger brother to serve a prison term of three and a half years.

headline: Art Basel, Eyes to the East, Names New Director for Asia
abstract: The Malaysian curator and art adviser Adeline Ooi has been named Asia director for Art Basel.
lead_paragraph: The Malaysian curator and art adviser Adeline Ooi has been appointed Art Basel’s director in Asia starting next month, the art fair announced Tuesday. Ms. Ooi will replace Magnus Renfrew, who left in July for Bonhams auction house, where he is now deputy chairman Asia and director of fine arts.

headline: Republicans Try to Fix Damage Scalise’s 2002 Speech Could Do in 2016
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner issued a statement supporting Steve Scalise of Louisiana, the No. 3 Republican in the House, who confirmed that in 2002 he addressed a group of white supremacists.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republican leaders, poised for a celebratory takeover of Congress next week, instead found themselves scrambling Tuesday to defuse a racially charged controversy over one lawmaker’s speech a decade ago to a white supremacist group.

headline: Managing Mail on the Mac
abstract: Also, guides for Android users and news from Facebook, including a reminder that a new privacy policy goes into effect Jan. 30.
lead_paragraph: Managing Mail

headline: Elder George Bush Is Released From Hospital
abstract: Former President George H. W. Bush was released from a Houston hospital where he has been staying since last week after experiencing shortness of breath.
lead_paragraph: Former President George Bush has been released from a Houston hospital where he had been staying since last week after experiencing shortness of breath.

headline: Charities That Inspire Kids: Water for South Sudan
abstract: When middle schooler Grady Beauregard heard a boy around his age describe his life in Sudan, it inspired Grady to reach out to others and find out what he could do to help.
lead_paragraph: This week, we’re sharing stories from children, teenagers and families about the charities that inspire them to give time, money and passion. Rob Beauregard wrote in about the work his son, Grady, did to raise money for Water for South Sudan.

headline: From a Writer and From Readers, Strong Opinions on Campus Rape Accusations
abstract: A passionate column that looked like news drew criticism.
lead_paragraph: In the history of The New York Times, the words “Sports of The Times” have a storied and well understood meaning. They accompany an opinion column, written by a staff member, including such prizewinning luminaries as Red Smith and Dave Anderson.

headline: Fear of Stowaways as Ferry Death Toll Off Coast of Greece Rises to 13
abstract: The ship that caught fire on Sunday was being towed to Italy, where authorities were trying to determine how many people had boarded and how many had been rescued.
lead_paragraph: VERBANIA, Italy — The death toll in a ferry fire off the Greek coast rose to 13 on Tuesday, including two Albanian workers who died while trying to connect a cable to the stricken ship. But prosecutors said that the number could rise because of fear that passengers who boarded illegally might have been trapped in the hold, where the fire raged.

headline: In Telluride, Fire as Art
abstract: A new festival in Telluride, Colo., features fire barrels and sculptures.
lead_paragraph: The mountain town of Telluride, Colo., is as famous for its summer festivals – there are 25 held from May to October – as its winter skiing. But this ski season it will be the home of the new Telluride Fire Festival, featuring “fire artistry,” or flaming objects like fire barrels and sculptures, that will line Main Street after dark.

headline: More Than 60 Years Later, a New Edition of Cartier-Bresson Classic
abstract: “The Decisive Moment,” a book of photographs by Henri Cartier-Bresson, has been republished in a new edition.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Henri Cartier-Bresson’s iconic photography book, “The Decisive Moment,” has been republished, 62 years after the highly influential collection of his early work was first released.

headline: Shake Shack I.P.O. Offers Healthy Profits and Curious Metrics
abstract: The global fast-food chain has filed to go public with some of the tortured trappings served up with new technology stocks., notes Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Shake Shack is turning the basic burger into complex financial cuisine.

headline: Heating Oil Mixed With Trouble
abstract: A family, its heating-oil business and New York are at the center of J. C. Chandor’s “A Most Violent Year.”
lead_paragraph: More brooding than brutal, “A Most Violent Year” finds Abel Morales (Oscar Isaac), the upwardly mobile owner of a heating-oil business, in a time of difficulty. Some of the trouble is atmospheric. It’s 1981, and New York City is in a state of decay that looks, in the burnished tints of movie hindsight, almost picturesque. Subway cars blossom with graffiti; the radio news wearily tallies each day’s shootings and stabbings; crime and corruption hang in the winter air like smog.

headline: U.S. Swap for Bergdahl Shook Up Secret Talks With Cuba
abstract: After the swap of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl for Taliban fighters provoked criticism, White House officials told Cuba that a deal for the release of Alan P. Gross must be more than a quid pro quo.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Of all the tense moments in the year and a half of secret negotiations to free Alan P. Gross from Cuba, none may have matched a meeting in Ottawa early in June between a two-person White House delegation and their Cuban counterparts.

headline: Police Unions’ Leaders Air Grievances in 2-Hour Meeting With de Blasio
abstract: The private meeting was an attempt to defuse tensions between Mayor Bill de Blasio and the leaders of police unions, who have snubbed and denounced him since two officers were fatally shot.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, moving to negotiate the gravest challenge of his one-year tenure, met on Tuesday with police union leaders who have been sharply critical of him since the shooting deaths of two New York City officers more than a week ago.

headline: Michigan Makes It Official: Jim Harbaugh Is the Football Coach
abstract: Harbaugh, who left the San Francisco 49ers to return to college coaching, was expected to provide a jolt of energy to the Wolverines’ beleaguered football program.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — It all seemed so familiar as Jim Harbaugh stood on a podium Tuesday and discussed becoming Michigan’s football coach.

headline: ‘Selma’ and Real-World Voter Intimidation
abstract: Registrars once administered easy poll tests to white applicants and impossible ones to black applicants.
lead_paragraph: Northerners who went south at the start of the civil rights movement were stunned to find localities where African-Americans represented an overwhelming majority of the population – but not a single black person could be found on the county voting rolls or in the jury pool. The new movie “Selma,” which focuses on the civil rights campaign in Selma, Alabama that led to the passage of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, vividly illustrates the system of intimidation and misdirection that made this possible.

headline: Harbaugh on New Role as Michigan Coach
abstract: The former San Francisco 49ers coach Jim Harbaugh spoke after he signed a deal to return to the University of Michigan to become the next football coach of the Wolverines.
lead_paragraph: The former San Francisco 49ers coach Jim Harbaugh spoke after he signed a deal to return to the University of Michigan to become the next football coach of the Wolverines.

headline: Whistle-Blower Awards Lure Wrongdoers Looking to Score
abstract: Compensation for whistle-blowers may not only be too much, it may also create perverse incentives and reward wrongdoing, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: There is the lottery and then there is being a corporate whistle-blower. It seems both pay out a jackpot, but the latter is a quicker path to riches, even when the recipient turns out to be a wrongdoer as well.

headline: Verbatim: Boehner Backs Scalise Amid Controversy
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner expressed his support for Representative Steve Scalise, who spoke at a conference for white supremacists in 2002.
lead_paragraph: — Speaker John A. Boehner, expressing his support for Representative Steve Scalise, who spoke at a conference for white supremacists in 2002.

headline: Shifting Fortunes, and Reputations, in Rose Bowl Game
abstract: Before Florida State returned to prominence, Oregon was regularly derided as a symbol of college football’s ruinous excesses. The two teams will meet on Thursday in a national semifinal.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Florida State’s resurrection as a college football power, culminating in a national championship last season and one of four berths in the inaugural playoff system this season, has been tainted by a string of arrests and investigations surrounding more than a dozen of its players.

headline: Personal Views of the City
abstract: "The City Out My Window: 63 Views on New York," a book by Matteo Pericoli, asks well-known New Yorkers to describe what they see from their windows.
lead_paragraph: "The City Out My Window: 63 Views on New York," a book by Matteo Pericoli, asks well-known New Yorkers to describe what they see from their windows.

headline: The Intercept Website Gets a ‘Serial’ Scoop
abstract: The story of “Serial” got an unexpected twist this week when the website The Intercept published an interview with Jay Wilds, a central figure in the case who had declined to be interviewed on the record by Sarah Koenig, the creator of “Serial.”
lead_paragraph: “Serial,” the blockbuster investigative podcast, ended its first season two weeks ago after gripping millions of listeners this fall with a 15-year-old murder mystery in Maryland.

headline: A Record Year for Auto Recalls
abstract: More vehicles, including old models, have been recalled in the United States in 2014 than ever before. Explore the size and scope of the recalls, and find out if your car has been affected.
lead_paragraph: More vehicles, including old models, have been recalled in the United States in 2014 than ever before. Explore the size and scope of the recalls, and find out if your car has been affected.

headline: Families of AirAsia Flight 8501 React
abstract: Family members of passengers and crew on AirAsia Flight 8501 grieved after Indonesian officials confirmed that the debris and bodies spotted in the Java Sea were from the missing plane.
lead_paragraph: Family members of passengers and crew on AirAsia Flight 8501 grieved after Indonesian officials confirmed that the debris and bodies spotted in the Java Sea were from the missing plane.

headline: Auto Industry Galvanized After Record Recall Year
abstract: Spurred by an ignition switch defect in millions of General Motors vehicles, the auto industry has issued more recalls involving old models than ever before, an analysis shows.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Spurred by a decade-old ignition-switch defect in millions of General Motors vehicles, the auto industry this year has issued more recalls involving old models — those made five or more years ago — than ever before, an analysis of federal recall records by The New York Times shows.

headline: Questioning the Historical Accuracy of ‘Selma’
abstract: A Johnson aide says the film wrongly paints the president as an opponent of the historic civil rights march.
lead_paragraph: Every Oscar season brings with it new charges of historical inaccuracies aimed at contending films – be it with the “Hurt Locker” or “Lincoln” or this year’s “Imitation Game.”

headline: Pick Your Favorite New York Zoo Animal
abstract: Ten photos of adorable, fearsome or otherwise noteworthy creatures await your judgment.
lead_paragraph: Fortunately for the Wildlife Conservation Society, which runs most of the city’s zoos, the definition of animal abuse does not include using photographs of animals to draw clicks to websites.

headline: Maotanchang: Study City
abstract: Chinese students hope this no-nonsense town will transform them into test-taking machines.
lead_paragraph: Chinese students hope this no-nonsense town will transform them into test-taking machines.

headline: Keynesians and the Volcker Disinflation
abstract: Things worked just the way the textbooks predicted they would.
lead_paragraph: Right-wing economists like Stephen Moore and John Cochrane — it’s becoming ever harder to tell the difference — have some curious beliefs about history. One of those beliefs is that the experience of disinflation in the 1980s was a huge shock to Keynesians, refuting everything they believed. What makes this belief curious is that it’s the exact opposite of the truth. Keynesians came into the Volcker disinflation — yes, it was mainly the Fed’s doing, not Reagan’s — with a standard, indeed textbook, model of what should happen. And events matched their expectations almost precisely.

headline: Pastries to Ring In the New Year
abstract: Ring-shaped breads and pastries are a good luck food for the New Year.
lead_paragraph: I’ve covered a number of good luck foods for the New Year in the Recipes for Health column, including beans, black-eyed peas and lentils, and greens. This year I had a lot of fun playing around with recipes for another type of good luck food: ring-shaped breads and pastries.

headline: Looking Back: Those We Lost in 2014
abstract: This year produced many deaths that stunned the country if not the world, in the fields of news, arts, sciences, politics and athletics.
lead_paragraph: The deaths that tend to endure in the public memory are the ones that shock. We react to them as if they were wholly unwarranted assaults on the natural order of things. People will say: He was too young. She was in her prime. It isn’t fair.

headline: Posters: The Fine Art of Selling Theater
abstract: A look at six theater posters from 2014 that demonstrated a keen sense of both style and salesmanship.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, Caroline Cahoon’s strikingly chic poster of a mysterious young woman with angry, piercing eyes — and no mouth! — looks like a dazzling vintage illustration for Bergdorf Goodman, or maybe a tear sheet from a bold new Pucci campaign. But her mod artwork turns out to be for a small production of the musical “Carrie” in Grand Rapids, Mich.

headline: Four Teams, Good and Bad, That Threw the Oddsmakers for a Loss
abstract: Twenty of the 32 N.F.L. teams finished the 2014 season within two wins of what Las Vegas predicted, but Dallas, Arizona, Tennessee and Tampa Bay were outliers.
lead_paragraph: Every year, Las Vegas projects the number of wins for each N.F.L. team. In most years, the majority finish within a couple of games of that projection; this year, 20 of 32 teams finished within two wins of their projected total. But each year there are also a few outliers. Below is a review of 2014’s two biggest overachievers and underachievers.

headline: The Question Hanging Over Greek Debt
abstract: In 2015, Greece will face some 22.3 billion euros in debt payments — much of it to those who took some the biggest risks in loading up on Greek bonds during the debt crisis: the European Central Bank and distressed investors.
lead_paragraph: It is perhaps the thorniest question that will face Alexis Tsipras, Greece’s left leaning firebrand, if he is voted into power next month: Should he keep servicing Greece’s punishing debt load?

headline: Quiz: What Was Popular in 2014?
abstract: Do you know which people, practices and proposals were popular this year? And did they deserve their popularity?
lead_paragraph: Do you know what America likes? Now you can find out — the quiz below will test your knowledge of which people, practices and proposals were popular in 2014. Take it and find out if you’re in step with public opinion this year, or if you’re more of a contrarian.

headline: BBC Delays Documentary on Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowles
abstract: “Reinventing the Royals” focuses on the hiring of a public-relations professional to restore the reputation of Prince Charles after the 1997 death of Diana, Princess of Wales, then his wife.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Walter Bagehot, in his 1867 book, “The English Constitution,” famously described the key to a lasting monarchy as mystery and obfuscation. “Above all things our royalty is to be reverenced, and if you begin to poke about it you cannot reverence it,” he wrote. “Its mystery is its life. We must not let in daylight upon magic.”

headline: A Minimalist Five-Bedroom House in Montevideo
abstract: In the Carrasco neighborhood along the Rio de la Plata, it is on the market for $1.3 million.
lead_paragraph: In the Carrasco neighborhood along the Rio de la Plata, it is on the market for $1.3 million.

headline: Charities That Inspire Kids: BlinkNow
abstract: A student is inspired by Blink Now, and her social studies teacher, to work for change for women in Nepal.
lead_paragraph: This week, we’re sharing stories from children, teenagers and families about the charities that inspire them to give time, money and passion. Karyne Brown, a student, emailed about her work with BlinkNow.

headline: Dying Is Easy; Change Is Hard
abstract: Philosophy meets self-help in “How We Are,” the first book in the projected “How We Live” trilogy by Vincent Deary, a British health psychologist.
lead_paragraph: In the brackish waters where philosophy meets self-help, a certain kind of unreadable book comes to spawn. It’s one that dresses up common sense in big words and, increasingly, in only vaguely understood neurobiological research.

headline: An All-Year Season of Discontent in Jazz
abstract: Frustration with “Whiplash,” anger at The New Yorker, dueling takes on prominent recordings: The jazz world had an all-year season of discontent.
lead_paragraph: In the opening scene of “Whiplash,” the breakout second film by Damien Chazelle, the rat-a-tat of a snare drum echoes in darkness, each stroke landing quicker than the last. It’s a rudimentary warm-up made to feel sinister — “like gunfire,” the screenplay suggests — and it sets up a mounting tension that the movie strives to maintain.

headline: Pictures of the Day — Indonesia and Elsewhere
abstract: Indonesia and Elsewhere: Photos of the Day
lead_paragraph: Indonesia and Elsewhere: Photos of the Day

headline: As Lithuania Joins Eurozone, Relief and Hesitation
abstract: In the new year, the country becomes the 19th nation to adopt the euro, and the likelihood of economic and geopolitical security looms large for many.
lead_paragraph: VILNIUS, Lithuania — If anyone still has good reasons for joining the euro, it is the people bundled against the cold of this snow-dusted capital.

headline: At COS, No Need for a Passport
abstract: COS is part of an emerging band of midlevel mass-market fashion that aims to draw those who have graduated from certain fast-fashion offerings.
lead_paragraph: Into the melee that is SoHo shopping in December came a calm visitor from abroad. All around were frantic hordes a-hoarding. But even in the last shopping days pre-Christmas, COS, a Swedish import finally arrived on American shores, kept its cool.

headline: Syrian Refugees in Turkey Get More Rights
abstract: Changes entitle Syrians to identification cards and access to basic services like health care and education.
lead_paragraph: Forced from their homes by civil war, millions of Syrians have been displaced, either within Syria or to neighboring countries.

headline: When Singing Verdi, Perfection Is No Substitute for Passion
abstract: The Met’s recent performances of “La Traviata” and “Aida” showcased both the potential pitfalls and the triumphs that await young Americans singing Verdi.
lead_paragraph: Young American opera singers have long faced the same bum rap as some other American products. They’ve been thought to be well tooled but inauthentic, genial but ultimately impersonal. While they’re as well trained as any musicians in the world, their smooth versatility is said to come across as anonymous onstage.

headline: Woman at Walmart Is Accidentally Shot Dead by 2-Year-Old Son
abstract: The 29-year-old mother was shopping with her 2-year-old boy and young relatives in Hayden, Idaho, when the boy found a gun in her purse and it discharged once, officials said.
lead_paragraph: HAYDEN, Idaho — The details are shatteringly ordinary. A 2-year-old toddler, sitting in a shopping cart in a Walmart, his mother’s purse unattended and within reach as she shopped. Three girls, all under age 11 — relatives of the boy and his mother, the police said — tagging along. A frosty morning in the northern Idaho panhandle, the temperature in the teens. Holiday break. The clothing aisles near electronics, back of the store.

headline: Dressing for the New Year in Brazil
abstract: Guests at the Ponta dos Ganchos resort in Brazil will celebrate the arrival of 2015 by wearing white (there will be fireworks too).
lead_paragraph: Guests at Ponta dos Ganchos (“Tip of the Hooks” in Portuguese) in southern Brazil will celebrate the arrival of 2015 in traditional fashion at the resort by dressing in white.

headline: Pictures of the Day — Dec. 30, 2014
abstract: Photos from Indonesia, Russia, Scotland and South Korea.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Indonesia, Russia, Scotland and South Korea.

headline: What We’re Reading: Great Times Reads of 2014 From Our Top Editors
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Dean Baquet, Susan Chira and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: The Way They Do the Things They Did, but This Time Live on Broadway
abstract: Today’s lineups of the Temptations and the Four Tops share a seven-night stand on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: The same old songs were different as “The Temptations and the Four Tops on Broadway” opened its seven-night engagement at the Palace Theater. As straightforward as its name, the show is a natty presentation of the two vocal groups that were, back in the 1960s, rivals at Motown Records, striving to make the gutsiest hits and the most slickly choreographed stage acts. Now each group is anchored by one original member — both harmony singers, not leads — and making the most of songs that remain indelible for the baby-boom generation.

headline: A Shaker Village Finds Enterprise Is Not So Simple
abstract: The Hancock Shaker Village in Massachusetts, a window into a religious sect that embraced celibacy and social tenets of egalitarianism and pacifism, is struggling financially.
lead_paragraph: PITTSFIELD, Mass. — Hancock Shaker Village, a cluster of historic houses, barns and shops set here amid gardens and cow pastures, has long sought to preserve the culture and traditions of the Shakers, the small but influential religious sect that became as well known for its minimalist furniture as for its social tenets of egalitarianism and pacifism.

headline: Incident Report of 2004 Chemical Weapons Accident in Delaware
abstract: Daniel Mould, a former staff sergeant in an explosive ordnance disposal team, was wounded in a chemical weapons accident after the police found a rusted artillery projectile at a chicken farm in Delaware in the summer of 2004.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Mould, a former staff sergeant in an explosive ordnance disposal team, was wounded in a chemical weapons accident after the police found a rusted artillery projectile at a chicken farm in Delaware in the summer of 2004.

headline: A Veteran’s Chemical Burns Expanded Military Doctors’ Knowledge, but His Care Faltered
abstract: An Air Force staff sergeant’s injuries from a chemical round led the Army to urge lifelong monitoring of such cases, but he says he was not tracked after retiring.
lead_paragraph: LORDS VALLEY, Pa. — Daniel Mould’s sense of abandonment was profound.

headline: As Feared, It’s a Season of High Flu Intensity
abstract: This year’s strain is proving to be a problem, with an early start to the season and a mismatch with the vaccine.
lead_paragraph: This article and charts, first published with flu statistics through Dec. 20, were updated on Jan. 7 with newly released figures.

abstract: What happens when you combine Burning Man, Independence Day fireworks, the last day of school and a full-contact Black Friday sale-a-bration? New Year’s Eve in Times Square.
lead_paragraph: What happens when you combine Burning Man, Independence Day fireworks, the last day of school and a full-contact Black Friday sale-a-bration? New Year’s Eve in Times Square.

abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Suh Wins Appeal and Will Be Able to Face Cowboys
abstract: The N.F.L. reduced the one-game suspension of Detroit Lions defensive tackle Ndamukong Suh to a $70,000 fine, which will allow him to play on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Detroit Lions defensive tackle Ndamukong Suh had his one-game suspension reduced on appeal to a $70,000 fine Tuesday, which will allow him to play Sunday against the Dallas Cowboys in a wild-card playoff game.

lead_paragraph: The city on the Hudson offers more space for the money, Manhattan views and an easy commute.

headline: Number of Police Officers Killed on the Job Climbs
abstract: An annual survey found that 126 law enforcement officers were killed while on duty in 2014, compared with 102 in 2013.
lead_paragraph: The number of law enforcement officers killed in the line of duty increased by nearly a quarter in 2014, according to an annual report released Tuesday, with more officers killed in ambushes this year.

headline: Ebola’s Other Victim: West Africa’s Economy
abstract: In Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia, Ebola is not just affecting immune systems but also the bottom lines of businesses and governments.
lead_paragraph: In Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia, Ebola is not just affecting immune systems but also the bottom lines of businesses and governments.

headline: Resolution for Palestinian State Fails in United Nations Security Council
abstract: A draft resolution to set a deadline to establish a sovereign Palestinian state failed to receive the nine votes that were needed for adoption in the 15-member Council.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations Security Council draft resolution that set a deadline to establish a sovereign Palestinian state was defeated Tuesday night after it failed to receive the nine votes that are needed for adoption in the 15-member body.

headline: A Democrat to Watch in 2015
abstract: In some ways the anti-Warren, Rhode Island’s first female governor is a dynamo and dissident who forces tough conversations on her party.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — With the New Year comes a new slate of officeholders whose careers warrant close attention and whose fates could have broader political implications. Put Gina Raimondo near the top of that list.

headline: App Smart | Apps for Laughs
abstract: Three apps meant to deliver the laughs: Mouthoff, Boothstache and Cheezburger.
lead_paragraph: Three apps meant to deliver the laughs: Mouthoff, Boothstache and Cheezburger.

headline: Gaza Is Nowhere
abstract: In the enclave, another war is waiting to happen.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — You trudge into Gaza from a high-tech Israeli facility through a caged walkway that brings you, after about 15 minutes, to a ramshackle Palestinian border post; and then, formalities completed, on you go, through dust and the reek of sewage, past the crumpled buildings and the donkey carts, to arrive at last in the middle of nowhere.

headline: Sexual Violence and Social Class
abstract: Readers discuss an Op-Ed article about how less privileged women have higher rates of sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Can the Internet Defeat Putin?
abstract: Apathy is the greatest threat to the Russian opposition.
lead_paragraph: ON Tuesday, a court in Moscow convicted Russia’s top opposition blogger, Aleksei A. Navalny, of criminal fraud. Mr. Navalny, who has been under house arrest for nearly a year, was given a suspended sentence and spared jail time. His younger brother Oleg, however, was sentenced to serve three and a half years. Aleksei Navalny is an anti-corruption activist and outspoken critic of President Vladimir V. Putin, and the verdicts were seen as a cynical strategy to punish him without turning him into an imprisoned martyr.

headline: Inmate Improv
abstract: Can a prison theater workshop prepare men for a life of freedom?
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — ONE of the members of our improv workshop, a baby-faced man in his 30s, made up a rule: The last person to arrive has to do a cartwheel. A shaggy-haired man with creaky knees manages a groaning little hop, while another wheels like a shot of light. In this fluorescent-lit classroom at the Macomb Correctional Facility in Michigan, it’s the willingness to take a risk that counts.

headline: The Year in Charts
abstract: How economics and politics unfolded in 2014, as told in 10 graphics.
lead_paragraph: Although developments on the political front were certainly dispiriting, for the first time in years, the economic news was not all gloomy. But with the economy improving, there was less focus on the continuing need to address flagging incomes, rising inequality and unbalanced government spending. Below are 10 charts to illustrate the crosscurrents of the past year in economics and politics:

headline: School Cash Insufficient in Kansas, Court Finds
abstract: The judges did not say that lawmakers had to increase K-12 funding to a particular amount, but suggested that the spending per pupil should be increased.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — A state court panel in Kansas ruled on Tuesday that public schools were being unconstitutionally underfunded, though it stopped short of ordering a specific increase in education dollars.

headline: Source of Ebola Outbreak in West Africa Might Be Bats, Study Says
abstract: Scientists have traced the origins of the current epidemic to a toddler in Guinea who may have caught the virus from bats in a tree near his village.
lead_paragraph: The toddler in Guinea who is thought to have been the first case in the current outbreak of Ebola in West Africa may have caught the virus from bats in a hollow tree near his village, scientists said Tuesday.

headline: Kings Theater in Flatbush Set to Reopen, and Lift a Neighborhood
abstract: The 1920s movie theater, soon to reopen as a performing arts center, is already stimulating development in its neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: A jewel of the golden age of the New York City movie theater is being revived, with the reopening in February of the former Loews Kings Theater on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn.

headline: Text of Draft Palestinian Resolution
abstract: The draft, edited by diplomats from Arab countries and Palestinian diplomats, sets a one-year deadline for negotiations with Israel and sets down targets for Palestinian sovereignty, including “full and phased withdrawal of Israeli forces” from the West Bank by the end of 2017.
lead_paragraph: The draft, edited by diplomats from Arab countries and Palestinian diplomats, sets a one-year deadline for negotiations with Israel and sets down targets for Palestinian sovereignty, including “full and phased withdrawal of Israeli forces” from the West Bank by the end of 2017.

headline: Ebola Ravages Economies in West Africa
abstract: In Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia, Ebola is not just affecting immune systems but also the bottom lines of businesses and governments.
lead_paragraph: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — On a recent sultry night, as the breeze stirred the palms and the waves gently crumbled against the shore, three women — Susan, Zenab and Tina — sat together at a beachside bar nursing bottles of warm beer.

headline: Doctor Loses License Over Assisted Suicides
abstract: Maryland regulators said that Dr. Lawrence D. Egbert had acted as what the Final Exit Network calls an exit guide for six people in Maryland from May 2004 to November 2008, which is illegal under Maryland law.
lead_paragraph: Maryland regulators this month revoked the medical license of an anesthesiologist for helping six ill people, none of whom had terminal conditions, to commit suicide.

headline: The Season of Giving
abstract: Is it better to invest money in a socially responsible business or give to a charitable group?

headline: Canada: Man Kills Eight in Alberta and Then Commits Suicide, Police Say
abstract: A man killed eight people, including two young children, in a “senseless mass murder” in Alberta before committing suicide, the Edmonton police chief, Rod Knecht, said Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A man killed eight people, including two young children, in a “senseless mass murder” in Alberta before committing suicide, the Edmonton police chief, Rod Knecht, said Tuesday. The killings occurred in two homes in Edmonton, the province’s capital, and the suicide at an Asian restaurant in nearby Fort Saskatchewan, he said. The police had been called to one of the homes Monday night by relatives of the man, who said he seemed suicidal, but they did not find him there. Early Tuesday they returned to the home, in north Edmonton, and found seven bodies, including those of a boy and a girl, Chief Knecht said at a news conference. No identities were released, and the relationships were not clear, Chief Knecht said, though he called the deaths “tragic incidents of domestic violence.”

headline: Wednesday’s College Football Bowl Games to Watch
abstract: A preview of bowl games, including the Orange Bowl, with Mississippi State and Georgia Tech, and the Fiesta Bowl, with Arizona and Boise State.
lead_paragraph: PEACH BOWL

headline: Atlanta Hopes a Three-Mile Streetcar Route Will Help Foster a New Urban Image
abstract: Atlanta added its name to the expanding list of cities that, backed by millions of dollars from the federal government, recently have constructed streetcar networks.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Pushing aside years of funding problems and construction dilemmas, this city on Tuesday opened a small loop of a transportation option that last operated here more than six decades ago: streetcars.

headline: Norwegians Turn Ambivalent on Statoil, Their Economic Bedrock
abstract: Though oil and gas provide a quarter of Norway’s G.D.P., concern over climate change is fracturing the country’s bond with its flagship company.
